webTitle: Gillingham in probe over alleged illegal payments

fields.headline: Gillingham in probe over alleged illegal payments
fields.trailText: Gillingham's chairman Paul Scally yesterday vehemently denied allegations of financial irregularities after a private investigator produced documents containing allegations of illegal payments to players.
fields.body:
Gillingham's chairman Paul Scally yesterday vehemently denied allegations that the club had been guilty of financial irregularities.

A private investigator has compiled several files of documents which contain allegations of irregularities and illegal payments to players at the First Division club.

But Scally said in a statement: "I am unaware as to the nature or substance of any allegations of financial irregularity.

"I strongly refute that any financial irregularities have occurred that I am aware of and will defend any allegations against the football club in the high court in the appropriate manner and at the relevant time.

"I am consulting with lawyers today but note that these allegations have persisted since May 1999 and despite requests have never been clarified or substantiated to either me, the club's accountants, the Football Association or the Football League."

The files were taken to the public relations expert Max Clifford, who said that he had urged the investigator to go to the Football Association but that the man "has very little faith in the Football Association" to conduct an investigation. The FA was last night awaiting developments.

"If someone presents us with any allegations directly and can substantiate them in any way we will launch an investigation," said a spokesman, Nick Barron. "However, that is not the case in this issue. No one has presented us with any evidence to support any allegations and we don't have the power to seize a dossier."

If the allegations are substantiated and of sufficiently serious nature Gillingham, who won promotion last season, could be demoted.

Swindon were demoted two divisions after gaining a place in the old First Division in 1990. The club admitted to 36 breaches of league regulations but after an appeal were allowed to remain in the old Second Division.

Scally rescued Gillingham from extinction in June 1995, buying the club for a penny.

webTitle: Architects pay tribute to Denys Lasdun

fields.headline: Architects pay tribute to Denys Lasdun
fields.standfirst:
Colleagues praise 'grandfather of modernism', who has died at 85 after career noted for National Theatre and housing towerblocks

Obituary: Sir Denys Lasdun
fields.trailText: The man hailed as "the greatest English architect of the early heroic modern period", Sir Denys Lasdun, died yesterday aged 85. The tribute was paid to him last night by an eminent fellow architect, Lord Rogers, who said: "The best of his buildings were recognised across the world."
fields.body:
The man hailed as "the greatest English architect of the early heroic modern period", Sir Denys Lasdun, died yesterday aged 85. The tribute was paid to him last night by an eminent fellow architect, Lord Rogers, who said: "The best of his buildings were recognised across the world."

Another, Sir Norman Foster, said: "He was a pioneer, a world-class architect who had tremendous influence."

Sir Denys, who had been ill with pneumonia, was famous for a span of mammoth projects largely in concrete, including the Royal National Theatre, ziggurat-shaped student flats at the University of East Anglia in Norwich, and some of the earliest British towerblock flats.

Periodically reviled for the theatre and the towerblocks, he later turned against the use of concrete for mass housing. "Big housing blocks in parallel slabs are anti-life," he declared.

The architect who had once once been called the grandfather of modernism in building added: "I began to be disillusioned with formulaic modernism. It was getting repetitive."

But he lived to see one of his first cluster of towers - 1955's four-block, 15-storey Keeling House in Bethnal Green, east London, restored as yuppie flats and maisonettes in the 1990s, with penthouses marketed for £375,000.

One of his last public appearances was in London on December 6 at the opening of the new courtyard of the British Museum, of which he was a trustee.

At the celebratory dinner, he sat next to the trustees' chairman, Graham Greene. Yesterday Mr Greene said news of his death was "a great shock, even bearing in mind his age. He kept his enthusiasm and energy right up to the last day. He was one of the great architects of our time.

"I am a great admirer of the National Theatre and of the way he entered so enthusiastically into any debate about architecture. A lot of criticisms were made of the theatre, which I am absolutely convinced are wrong. It is a very beautiful building which works wonderfully well for the theatregoer. It is not just architecture, but architecture for the people.

"Serving with him as a trustee, I got to know the way his mind worked. He addressed the problems of new galleries designed in historic surroundings with what I regard as great good taste."

Lord Rogers, who first worked as an architect in the 1970s with Sir Denys, said: "He was the greatest English architect of the early modern period, which is often called the heroic period. There were very few architects in those early days who had his exceptional talent.

"Architects usually mature late in life. He started young. In his 20s, he was designing houses in London which were exceptionally mature.

"He was strongly influenced by Le Corbusier. Those early houses were white, with horizontal windows and simple concrete frames. They were cubist in form. His later buildings continued that approach but were much more articulated, richer in style."

Among Sir Denys's buildings, Lord Rogers singled out the East Anglia flats, the National Theatre and the Royal College of Physicians' headquarters near Regent's Park, London, which achieved "harmony through contrast" with its Nash terrace surroundings.

"He took a lot of totally unjustified stick over the National," Lord Rogers said. "It was one of the first buildings to make use of one of our greatest assets, the river."

Sir Norman said: "He was a pioneer and also an extraordinarily supportive individual, young in spirit.

"He had a passion for quality - whether in those early days he was seeking to pioneer new forms of high-density urban housing, or later. He was a powerful, positive influence".

Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate, said last night: "Denys Lasdun was a committed modernist with a human touch. His buildings are some of the finest public buildings of the post-war period and are increasingly admired and loved by their users. He had a passionate interest in the painting and sculpture of his time."

Michael Hopkins, a leading architect of a later generation, said: "He had a fundamental influence on us. He was a pure modernist architect. His kind of modernism became misunderstood for a period.

"But it was intelligent and thoughtful and set an example in that way."

A pioneer's legacy

Royal National Theatre
Completed in 1976. An imposing array of foyers and terraces surrounds three theatres housing state of the art technology and modern auditoriums. The concrete panels remain a landmark along the Thames.

University of East Anglia
Completed in 1968. Lasdun was asked in 1962 to produce "a physical design which would reflect and complement the academic structure". His plan was that no building on campus should be more than five minutes' walk away from any other. He designed the core buildings including the striking "ziggurats", the pyramidal students' accommodation named after a tower built in ancient Mesopotamia.

Keeling House, Bethnal Green
Built in 1956. This London site has become known as the most innovative example of Lasdun's "cluster blocks". All living rooms within the block are positioned facing outwards, gaining maximum sun exposure as it moves around the towers.

Royal College of Physicians
Completed in 1964. In contrast to its surroundings in Regent's Park this building has been widely recognised as one of the finest examples of 60s architecture. It was awarded the Trustees Medal of the Royal Institute of British Architects in 1992 and Grade 1 listing in 1998.

Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge
Completed in 1966. One of the more modern colleges within the University of Cambridge and at odds to its neighbouring regency house. Hidden away from the main colleges and surrounded by gardens, the cost of Lasdun's spectacular design was just £300,000.

webTitle: Sometimes just a tweak can break that losing streak

fields.headline: Sometimes just a tweak can break that losing streak
fields.trailText: A poor run does not equal a poor coach. Bad form is a curious beast and sometimes the smallest of changes can turn things around.
fields.body:
I shouldn't think there is a manager in the world who can't identify with what Sven-Goran Eriksson went through in his last few weeks at Lazio. The losing streak is one of football's less enjoyable experiences.

I never found that a bad patch had me thinking more because as a manager you are constantly wondering whether there is anything you can do to improve things. But it certainly has you thinking in a different way.

The most important thing is that you are honest with yourself and see why you are losing. At times that might mean doing something drastic to the side or the system or the training. At Coventry in 1996, Gordon Strachan and I made an important change after a poor start.

We felt the team looked a bit laboured rather than sharp, so I brought in Roger Spry, a fitness trainer who had been with me at Sheffield Wednesday and Aston Villa, and spent time in Portugal working with Bobby Robson among others.

Roger introduced a sharper type of training and that got a response from the players. Ironically, he also introduced me properly to Eriksson when we were on a break in Estoril and Eriksson was staying in the same hotel.

I had met Eriksson years earlier in the Anfield boot room when Benfica were playing there, but this time we had a bit more time together. Roger and I even took his car one night, which I don't think he knew about.

Eriksson said after Lazio had lost 2-1 to Napoli on Sunday that it was best for the club if he moved on. But there are times when your team are on a losing run and yet you know they are playing well enough. Then you just keep pegging away, make the odd adjustment and wait for it to turn round.

I remember at West Brom in 1978-79 when we finished third in the old First Divison, got to the quarter-finals of the Uefa Cup and the semis of the FA Cup. The following season people thought we would be in the frame but we lost half a side for one reason or another.

Len Cantello and Laurie Cunningham left, Derek Statham and Cyrille Regis were injured, and by Christmas we were rank bottom of the table. I thought we were about to turn the corner so I made very few changes and kept encouraging. There was no need for shock treatment.

We stuck a boy called Remi Moses into the side just after Christmas and I think we lost one of the last 19 and finished 10th.

I never had a chance to turn round the bad run we went through at the Villa in 1994. Myself and the players are still convinced we were about to get going again but Doug Ellis decided my time was up. We were still in the cups and the squad had not lost its self-belief. Despite the results I felt we were playing well. The season before we had won the cup and the season before that we finished second in the league, yet I felt we were performing better than ever.

What I regret is playing three European matches on a Thursday night, against Internazionale twice and Trabzonspor. Although it earned the club great revenue from the television, we lost in the late stages of our games on the weekends after.

The Thursday we played Inter we were still taking penalties at 11.30pm. We had to play Newcastle on the Saturday and Kevin Keegan, who had been doing the commentary, was laughing when he came into my office. I said: "Your boys were in bed when we were taking penalties."

We played well a couple of days later but ran out of legs and were beaten 2-0. I left about a month later.

The affect a bad run can have was summed up by Graham Taylor recently. He said he couldn't see his Watford side winning again, but they went to Barnsley, dug in and won 1-0. Things can change, just like that.

I certainly wouldn't worry about Eriksson's credentials just because he had a bad couple of months at Lazio. It will have been hard for him to concentrate on his job with real single-mindedness, particularly with the press constantly ramming the England stuff down his throat. And in those circumstances the players can lose focus. It might only be a tiny percentage but it can make the difference.

The thing that disappointed me when I saw Lazio play this season was their team ethic, which is normally guaranteed in Eriksson's sides. I thought they looked a collection of very good individuals rather than a team.

Then again, whether he really wanted players like Hernan Crespo, I don't know. In Italy the presidents hold real sway and, no matter how strong the coach is, they get their way.

Eriksson won't have to worry about interference with England. Let's hope that goes for losing streaks as well.

webTitle: Maradona is hit by £16.5m tax bill

fields.headline: Maradona is hit by £16.5m tax bill
fields.trailText: Diego Maradona was yesterday notified by Italian tax police that he owes 52bn lire (£16.5m) in evaded taxes and interest.
fields.body:
Diego Maradona was yesterday notified by Italian tax police that he owes 52bn lire (£16.5m) in evaded taxes and interest.

Maradona arrived at Rome's Leonardo Da Vinci airport only to be escorted by tax inspectors to their office and given papers to sign.

The former Argentina striker is in Italy to appear on television shows and unveil a limited-edition coin engraved with his image.

David Johnson will complete a £3m move to Nottingham Forest today, pending a medical, after Ipswich accepted a second offer from the City Ground.

Johnson scored 22 goals in helping Ipswich to promotion last season but has lost his place to Marcus Stewart. Forest recently failed with a £2.5m bid.

Kidderminster's manager Jan Molby has transfer listed seven players in the wake of Wednesday's 2-0 defeat at Bury in the LDV Vans Trophy.

The Dane, on the shortlist for the Barnsley job filled by Nigel Spackman this week, has told Barry Horne, Ian Bogie, Paul Webb, Tony Bird, Tim Clarke and Steve Pope that they can leave. Dean Bennett will be allowed to go for a fee.

Sheffield United have put the £1m-rated Curtis Woodhouse on the transfer list at his own request after the breakdown of contract talks. The midfielder is under contract until the end of next season.

Manchester City's Tony Grant, 26, is talking over a £400,000 move to Barnsley and his club-mate Ian Bishop is expected to join Sheffield Wednesday on a free transfer.

webTitle: Petrescu poised to join Saints

fields.headline: Petrescu poised to join Saints
fields.trailText: Dan Petrescu is set to become the first of the "Bradford City three" to leave Valley Parade after Southampton yesterday offered him the opportunity to stay in the Premiership.
fields.body:
Dan Petrescu is set to become the first of the "Bradford City three" to leave Valley Parade after Southampton yesterday offered him the opportunity to stay in the Premiership.

The Romanian defender had talks with Southampton's manager Glenn Hoddle over a £800,000 move last night after it was made clear this week that he, along with Stan Collymore and Benito Carbone, did not figure in the Bradford manager Jim Jefferies' plans.

"It is a situation which suits both clubs," said Jefferies. "He has got 3 years left on his contract, so we're making a saving on that side and obviously that will help the club."

Petrescu, who was pursued by his former Chelsea manager Hoddle last summer before going to Bradford, said: "It is clear the intention of the club is to eliminate players with high salaries. The problem is that most of us don't want to go. I want to stay and fight for a place in the team.

So does Dean Windass, a mainstay at Bradford who may also be on the way out. Although the forward is not officially for sale, he is "confused" and "disappointed" at speculation that he is unwanted by Jefferies and can leave in return for £1.5m.

"I'm totally surprised by this," said Windass, "because I was only recently in the chairman's office trying to sort out a new contract. The manager hasn't said anything and neither has the chairman since that meeting."

Collymore, meanwhile, has turned down a loan move to Sheffield United. "I thought it was worth a try," said the First Division club's manager Neil Warnock. "If Stan decides he wants to play football, I think we could give him a platform for four or five games. It will keep him fit and on the pitch."

A similar switch, to Sheffield Wednesday, for Bradford's out-of-favour goalkeeper Matt Clarke was rejected by Jefferies.

webTitle: Royle pointing the wrong way

fields.headline: Royle pointing the wrong way
fields.standfirst: Manchester City are in free fall. Is the manager up to pulling them out of it?
fields.trailText: Manchester City are in free fall. Daniel Taylor asks if manager Joe Royle is up to pulling them out of it?
fields.body:
"We are definitely looking towards Europe. Put it this way: I will be very disappointed if we're not in the reckoning for a top-six place. Why should I be thinking any different? This club is thinking only one way and that's forward. The confidence is great and we cannot wait to get started. The lads are optimistic, I'm optimistic and we're going to give it everything."

These were the words of Joe Royle in August. It was time for predictions and the Manchester City manager oozed optimism from every pore. "People say it would be a great season for us to finish one place above the relegation zone but that is not our mentality," he said. "Quite honestly we are not expecting to struggle."

Five months later Royle has had to change his tune. Only Bradford are below them in the Premiership and a run of eight defeats in 12 league games has seen one of football's oldest partnerships reunited: City and crisis. They go together like Clough and Taylor, Keegan and Toshack, Posh and Becks.

"Maybe I was not being as realistic as others," Royle says now. "At the start of the season I honestly thought Europe was a realistic proposition. I suppose we've been forced to reassess now. Fourth from bottom, well, that would do us. We just need a change of luck."

In the past five seasons the fourth-from-bottom club have finished with 38, 41, 40, 41 and, last season, 36 points. In the past two 37 and 34 would have sufficed. At present City have 20 from 22 games, level with Middlesbrough and a point behind Coventry, both of whom have picked up in the last few games as City have slumped.

Royle entered the season with the security of a new four-year contract, the promise of £15m spending money from his chairman David Bernstein and a squad of earthy professionals buoyed by back-to-back promotions.

Acclimatising to a better Premiership than the one they departed, however, is proving somewhat scabrous for a club whose local derby has gone from Macclesfield to Stockport to Manchester United in two years. Questions are being asked. Has Royle taken City as far as he can? Can he pull them out of their current free fall?

"No one can argue with what Joe has achieved," says Peter Barnes, Royle's team-mate when City won their last trophy, the 1976 League Cup. "I'm his biggest fan but there's no point hiding from reality and, the way things are going, keeping City up will be the biggest test of his managerial career.

"Getting the team from the Second Division to the Premiership in successive years was an incredible achievement but, in a funny way, City probably won promotion back too soon. The standard now is so much higher and they could have done with a couple of seasons building up their squad in the First Division."

Royle is puzzled by the club's sudden decline and, whatever happens, the summer inquest promises to be both tortuous and torturous. He was embarrassed by the George Weah business but other nagging questions surround his transfer dealings and, at a time when the Premiership is fast losing its long-ball image, some of City's football has been like ping-pong in the sky.

What City desperately need is a ball-playing midfielder but Royle has been trying to sign the craggy Steve Lomas from West Ham and yesterday sanctioned Ian Bishop's free transfer to Sheffield Wednesday. Royle's "dogs-of-war" tactics kept Everton in the Premiership a few years ago and he appears to be dusting off the old manual.

"I know people will be talking about a crisis, the lines to the phone-ins will be buzzing and there will be letters of complaint to the local papers, but I honestly believe we are not that bad," he says.

"I have been in this business a long time now and I have seen a lot worse ruts than this. Yes, there have been mistakes but let's not forget how far we have come in such a short space of time. We've come up two divisions and a few mistakes are inevitable. It's become a confidence thing now."

For the present at least City's supporters are not belching vitriol in his direction. "I would say 95% are still behind him," says Ian Barton of the fans' committee. Football is an increasingly impatient business but Royle's overall achievements at Maine Road dictate that he deserves time.

He has indicated this will be his final contract, taking him up to his planned retirement age of 55. He talks about having more time to watch his son Darren playing semi-professionally with Ashton United, more time to walk his dogs and be with his wife Janet.

In the meantime there is plenty to keep him occupied, starting tomorrow with the visit of Leeds United. "We just need a change of luck," he says (again). A change of luck, a change of complexion, a change of morale but not, in the short term, a change of manager.

webTitle: Adair blamed for bomb at SDLP office

fields.headline: Adair blamed for bomb at SDLP office
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An SDLP politician last night blamed loyalist paramilitaries linked to the jailed Ulster Freedom Fighter Johnny Adair for a bomb attack on the party's north Belfast offices.
fields.body:
An SDLP politician last night blamed loyalist paramilitaries linked to the jailed Ulster Freedom Fighter Johnny Adair for a bomb attack on the party's north Belfast offices.

No one was hurt in the blast, but four members of a Scout group which rents the premises were trapped inside the Antrim Road building while army experts examined the remains of a crude device which exploded in the doorway.

Alban Maginness, an SDLP assembly member who had strongly welcomed Tuesday's decision by the Northern Ireland sentence review commission to keep Adair behind bars, said: "I have no doubt that it is linked to Adair. It is a Ulster Defence Association response, or an element linked with the UDA.

"It is the price that democracy pays when we have a paramilitary leader who exercises such an evil influence over a section of our community."

Mr Maginness, who was not in the building at the time of the blast, vowed that he would not be intimidated from speaking out against evil.

North Belfast Ulster Unionist MP Cecil Walker condemned the bomb, as did Sinn Fein's Gerry Kelly and Democratic Unionist Nigel Dodds.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, had Adair, who was freed in 1999 under the Good Friday agreement early release scheme, re-arrested last August, blaming him for igniting a loyalist feud that left seven men dead.

The sentence review commission reversed its earlier decision to let him out again after hearing detailed intelligence information from the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, and top Special Branch officers linking him to guns, drugs and paramilitary activity. Adair has said he will mount a high court appeal.

Security sources had warned that members of the UDA and UFF, many of whom are be coming increasingly disenchanted with the peace process, could use the Adair case as an excuse to attack Roman Catholics.

The bomb came as UDA elements were accused of involvement in escalating loyalist violence against nationalists in other parts of the Northern Ireland.

Two Larne families narrowly escaped injury in two pipe bomb attacks within 24 hours of each other and 16-year-old boy had a lucky escape after carrying a device from his garden in Kilrea, Co Londonderry.

William McCambridge, who has four children, said after a pipe bomb was hurled through the window of his home: "This is happening week in, week out. Eventually someone is going to get killed."

He appealed to the loyalist Ulster Democratic party and Progressive Unionists to try to end the violence.

There have been more than 30 pipe bombings, an average of two a week, since October. A nationalist SDLP assemblyman, Danny O'Connor, who represents the Larne area, accused loyalists of trying to drive out all Catholics.

"A lot of people don't want to admit it, but there is a form of ethnic cleansing going on in Larne," he said. "If this goes on, sooner or later someone is going to die. Catholics just don't feel safe anywhere."

Mr O'Connor, whose brother escaped injury when a nail bomb went off in his flat a few months ago, has given a dossier on 160 incidents in the past two years to the British and Irish governments.

He called on the RUC to stage more covert operations to catch those responsible, and appealed to the Protestant community to help.

"Someone knows the bully boys who are doing this. I suspect UDA elements are involved," he said.

RUC sub-divisional commander Karen Kennedy said the attacks were "cowardly and reckless" and urged anyone with information to contact the police. Supt Kennedy said her officers had carried out more than 300 operations specifically to combat sectarianism in Larne in recent months.

webTitle: Week 6: Fiji to Auckland

fields.headline: Treasured islands
fields.trailText: Despite the presence of spiders the size of his hand and excessively evangelical priests, Sam finds Fiji's islands so enchanting that he decides a week. But after seven days of reading and sunbathing, he discovers that "there's only so much sitting on a beach you can do"...
fields.body:
My eyes shot open. There it was again. Something was moving outside my bure (Fijian for traditional thatched building full of bugs). As my eyes became accustomed to the dark, I saw a hand creep through the open window. It crawled down the wall searching for me and then grabbed me by the shoulder.

"I'm awake, I'm awake!" I shrilled and leapt out of bed, cracking my head on the bunk above me. As I rolled about on the floor, moaning softly, I heard a voice asking in a puzzled whisper, "Are you okay, Mr Sam?"

It was 4.30 in the morning. Not my favourite time of day, but I was going on a hike up Wayasera's mountain to see the sunrise. I had been on the island for four days now and thought it was time to do something active.

After checking to make sure I was definitely awake (no doubt about that), my guide Naputo moved on to wake the others. I got dressed by torchlight, being careful not to look too closely at the rustling walls. I had seen a spider the size of my hand the night before and had come to the conclusion that denial was the best approach. If I couldn't see the the spiders, they couldn't see me.

I walked out and found the others. There were four in our little group: barefoot Naputo, Milan and Helen, both American, and me. With three torches between us we set off up a trail behind the village.

After only a few steps I was pouring with sweat. The heat and humidity were intense, and the creaking cicadas all around us seemed to make it worse. We climbed steadily up through the undergrowth, slipping and tripping.

As we got higher I could see pale streaks shooting out of the eastern sky. We hurried on - sunrise was not far off. Then we were out of the jungle and climbing over rocks. It was light enough to see now and we left the torches on the path.

Naputo said we were almost there. There was just one more hurdle; a walk along a narrow edge with a sheer drop on both sides. We gingerly stepped (or in my case crawled) along it... and there we were, on top of the island.

We were just in time. The sun came up 10 minutes later and the sea sparkled. Below stretched the islands of the Yasawas marching off towards the horizon. I guess it was a view worth getting up for.

I spent a week relaxing on Wayasera. It's a lovely place; what makes it extra special is that it's run by the island's villagers. All the proceeds from the holiday makers go straight back into the community - to provide new books for the school, for example. And because they live there too, the villagers are always around - calling 'bula' (hello) to you and shaking your hand. There are activities (organised by the smiling Big Jerry) such as snorkelling, a trip to the local village or the hike I did. And I met lots of nice people including two new card playing companions, Zoe and 'pokerface' Cathy.

So it was all very pleasant. But after I'd read all my books and reorganised my bag (for the millionth time on this trip - I'm still trying to get it down to a weight that I can lift) I did begin to get a little bored. I know all you people sitting back home in the office won't want to hear this, but there's only so much sitting on the beach you can do. However, after having rushed round the US, I thought a little boredom and time on my hands might not hurt, so rather than going to the airport I went on to another island instead.

This one was called Waya and I stayed at the Octopus Resort. It had the most amazing curved, palm-fringed beach and a coral reef right up to the shore. The green hills rose up behind the simple but clean bure accomodation, which sat virtually on the beach. The atmosphere here was rather more like that of a resort with good food than the other island - there was a definite distinction between the management and the local Fijian staff.

Still at the end of the day, no matter how beautiful it was, it was still just another beach, and after the initial excitement of looking round a new place I began to feel boredom setting in again. In a desperate attempt to stave this off, I went to the village church (it was Sunday and there was nothing else to do).

It's been some time since I last went to church, but I have to say that I thought this was a pretty remarkable service. After the usual readings the priest took the pulpit. He obviously felt his flock had been rather wayward recently, as he launched into an extraordinary fit of rage. There was much shouting and pointing of fingers. It was all in Fijian, so I'm not too sure what we were being berated about. I did ask afterwards but was told it was 'just the Bible'. All the locals seemed to be ignoring him anyway. They (and I) were more interested in the small child who kept trying to steal the hymn books. The choir was very good, though.

I left Waya the following day and got a fast boat back to the mainland. With me were a very cheerful Australian couple, Ben and Amber, and a Swedish girl called Hannah. More card playing companions - although these three kept beating me so I didn't like them quite so much - only kidding. Ben and Amber should feature in my tales again since they very kindly - and foolishly - invited me over to see them when I get to Sydney.

We stayed a night in a cheap hostel in Nadi (no spiders this time - just cockroaches) and then decided to travel down the Coral Coast to a backpacker place called the Beachhouse which Ben had heard about.

I can't recommend this place highly enough. It was clean, freshly painted and they served coffee and cakes in the afternoon. This was my kind of place. The beach wasn't that exciting but I'd had enough of them anyway and the Beachhouse made up for it by having a beautiful garden with hammocks.

After a very good night's sleep on a proper mattress, we joined the owner and his family on a hike inland. The local Fijians had just cut a trail through the rainforest up to a long forgotten waterfall and everyone was excited about seeing it for the first time in many years. It took a couple of hot hours of wading through streams and slipping back down muddy slopes before we reached the waterfall. With the sun streaming in, it was stunning. There was noisy rainforest all around and a small bathing pool at the bottom. With the others I climbed up to sit halfway, water pouring on my head and surrounded by little rainbows. As much as I liked the beaches, this is how I will remember Fiji.

Now I'm in Auckland, New Zealand. It looks like England only tidier. I'm supposed to go floating down a cave on an inner tube tomorrow - so I'll let you know how that goes next week.

webTitle: Week 7: Pokhara to Singapore

fields.headline: Southern comfort
fields.trailText: Week 6, Singapore Regretfully, Sue says goodbye to the vibrancy and colour of Nepal and finds herself in Singapore, where the cleanliness and affluence come as an unexpected pleasure. However, after only a few days there, she is eager to be off to Malaysia in order to begin exploring again.
fields.body:
Today I am in another phase of my travels. Today is also my daughter's birthday - happy birthday Rachel. I can't believe my baby is 20! I will be phoning her soon when it's a decent hour back home.

During my last couple of days in Nepal, legs back in working order, I met up with a young French woman, Valerie. We decided to take the trolley bus out to Bhaktapur. It was like being in a rickety tube in the rush hour, but with the added dimensions of spitting on the floor and huge baskets of wares on people's heads. I was dismayed to find that since my last brief visit to the city less than two weeks before, the entrance fee had increased by 150%. Amazing where a little wandering down lanes and up alleys will lead you. This time I did buy a little pottery elephant as a memento. I do love the place.

A black spot at this time was when I discovered that I had somehow lost Rachel's tape. It wasn't just the music and the link, but she had put a photo of us having a cuddle in the case and also a little note that I hadn't yet read. I felt very upset - but she is making another one.

There are many images of Nepal that will stay with me: the spectacular landscape; the scene at every water tap of the women always washing either the clothes, the children or their long, thick black hair; the calf muscles of the sherpas; the slow steady plod of women walking up the hills carrying huge baskets tied across their heads full of the packs and camping gear of trekkers; waking up to the bustle of the Tamil area of Kathmandu, and the sound of endless hawking and spitting which they do with great gusto; the humour of the people. I will miss it all.

On Monday I flew back to Bombay. Having my Swiss army knife removed at the security check, I waited about an hour at the other end for it to be returned to me as promised and then gave up. My bag will be much lighter if I carry on like this.

It is amazing what a difference a few weeks makes. Bombay no longer seemed so scary and the hawkers and beggars seemed less interested, or I found it easier to brush them aside, I am not sure which. That evening I met Steve and Bobbie, a pair of wandering musicians from Devon, who had made contact through the website. They took me out to dinner at the Taj hotel, Bombay's poshest. It was a most enjoyable evening in unaccustomed splendour. My thanks to them, it was much appreciated.

And so, on late Tuesday evening, I was off to Singapore, where I arrived at 7.30 in the morning. The flight was made more difficult by the man next to me continuously fidgeting and picking at various bits of himself. I am surprised he had any hair or face left by the time we landed. My nephew, Daniel, met me at the airport, easily recognisable by the distinct family likeness, despite the years since we had met. He lives in a flat in a lovely combo, with its own swimming pool and gym (I haven't tried either). It is again a touch of luxury and very enjoyable for a few days.

As for Singapore, I could not believe the difference from the Indian subcontinent. It is so clean and green, all the people so affluent and well dressed, the traffic moves in an orderly fashion down the four lane, one-way systems, the taxis and buses ferry you around efficiently in air-conditioned comfort. I found it disconcerting, unreal and alien at first but I confess to being inordinately excited that you could flush the paper down the loo. In fact in some toilets if you take too long the loo flushes automatically. A bit startling at first when you are relaxing and enjoying not having to rush out so that you dare breath again.

webTitle: Deadlock over plan for tube

fields.headline: Deadlock over plan for tube
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The prospect of a legal confrontation between Ken Livingstone and ministers over plans to part-privatise the tube increased yesterday as both the London mayor and the transport commissioner said they had failed to reach any agreement with the government.
fields.body:
The prospect of a legal confrontation between Ken Livingstone and ministers over plans to part-privatise the tube increased yesterday as both the London mayor and the transport commissioner said they had failed to reach any agreement with the government.

Bob Kiley, the former New York subway boss who took over as transport commissioner for London this week, said there had been an "ominous silence" from government since two meetings with John Prescott in December.

There could be no compromise, Mr Kiley said, on the transport secretary's plans to split up control of track and trains. He added that it was "disturbing" that the government had continued negotiating contracts with private companies without involving those who would manage London's transport.

Lawyers think that a challenge to the plans may be successful because of the way laws devolving government to London were framed.

Government sources said last month that the prime minister had instructed Mr Prescott to find a compromise. Ideas include giving Mr Livingstone a seat on the boards of the private consortiums bidding to take over stations, track and signalling.

webTitle: BBC and ITV push for election debate

fields.headline: BBC and ITV in talks on election debate
fields.trailText: 10.45am: The BBC and ITV meet today for talks on plans for a televised election debate, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
News bosses at the BBC and ITV are meeting today to push forward talks on the plans for a televised election debate following reports that Tony Blair was cooling on the idea.

The meeting follows a failed attempt by the Conservatives for three separate debates between the leaders of the three parties.

"We have rejected plans by the Conservatives, because we would have to include Sky in the debate," said Steve Anderson, ITV's controller of news, current affairs, religion and arts.

Mr Anderson added that he thought three hours of election debates would have been "too much" for viewers.

BBC sources were more circumspect, but one said: "The feeling is that we wanted to keep it just to terrestrial broadcasters".

Plans put forward by the Conservative party were for three debates, each featuring two of the three party leaders.

The Conservatives were keen to bring Sky News on board.

But the terrestrial broadcasters were unwilling to air programming produced by Rupert Murdoch-owned Sky News.

Mr Anderson denied reports that the "intransigence" of broadcasters and the Conservative party had "put the kibosh" on the debates.

"The BBC and ITV have cleared an hour each and to unpick that would mean creating a division between BBC and ITV."

A BBC insider claimed that it was now only Labour that was stalling on the plans.

The three political parties have an end-of-January deadline to come back to broadcasters to accept or reject the proposals.

The current plan would be for two three-way debates between the party leaders, one, on the BBC, hosted by David Dimbleby, and the second, on ITV, by his brother Jonathan.

Sky News was not available for comment.

webTitle: Hague claims his 'sceptic realism' is best for Europe

fields.headline: Hague claims his 'sceptic realism' is best for Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday claimed that his own brand of Eurosceptic realism was better-placed to protect Britain's interests in Europe - and to revitalise the EU - than Tony Blair's "heart of Europe" strategy.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Berlin and  Michael White  in London
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday claimed that his own brand of Eurosceptic realism was better-placed to protect Britain's interests in Europe - and to revitalise the EU - than Tony Blair's "heart of Europe" strategy.

Addressing a conference of rightwing European party leaders in Berlin, the Tory leader rehearsed his election campaign plan to put reform of the EU's farm policy at the centre of the drive to achieve enlargement of the 15-nation union to the south and east by 2003 if possible.

In what Tory aides billed as a constructive and positive approach - which contrasted with Labour claims that Mr Hague was heading for total withdrawal from the EU - Mr Hague also warned fellow-members of the European Democrat Union that applicant states must not be forced into "a rigid straitjacket of legislation especially on social policy."

He also invoked what may prove a campaign slogan, the right of different EU states "to combine in different combinations for different purposes and to a different extent, what we call a network Europe" - in contrast to talk of "pioneer groups" and inner cores by some EU leaders.

But the key element in the Conservatives' new approach was an emphasis on overhauling the 45 year-old common agricultural policy. It was the EU's most anomalous and costly mechanism, still taking half the budget, and the most fiercely defended by key agri-states led by France.

At yesterday's EDU meeting, attended by leaders from inside and outside the EU, Mr Hague branded the CAP "indefensible socially, economically, ecologically, environmentally and morally". He added: "It needs change".

In a document strongly influenced by Tory thinking, the leaders of the parties making up the EDU committed themselves to making CAP reform a priority. The admission of less developed states like Poland, with huge farm industries, would render an unreformed CAP insupportably expensive.

However, their joint declaration also pointed to glaring differences between British and continental conservatives on other key issues, a point gleefully highlighted by Labour HQ in London.

The last EDU declaration endorsed such priorities for Europe as the promotion and protection of human rights; social responsibility; the protection of the environment; effective decisionmaking, a euphemism for majority voting; and strong support for European security and stability, a topic which alarms pro-Nato Tories.

Yesterday Mr Hague spoke glowingly of enlarging the EU. "It is simply unacceptable that we are meeting in Berlin today over a decade after the collapse of communism and the fall of the Berlin Wall while there is still no clear end in sight for the applicant states", he told the meeting.

This is scarcely what had been expected from the leader of a party which rejected the outcome of last month's Nice summit, held specifically to prepare for enlargement by improving decision-making.

Mr Blair has mocked the Conservatives for threatening to veto enlargement to as many as 27 EU members simply because the Nice package included more qualified majority voting in the Brussels council of ministers.

At Mr Hague's side yesterday Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said the Conservatives could sign up to a Nice treaty that was solely about enlargement.

 An ICM poll, commissioned by Business for Sterling, found that 56% of British voters (66% in the 18-24 age range) wanted to stay in the EU and keep the pound. Only 15% chose to leave the EU and only 21% wanted to join the euro.

webTitle: Labour plans call centre to woo back stay-at-home voters

fields.headline: Labour plans call centre to woo back stay-at-home voters
fields.trailText: Labour is preparing a fresh offensive to shore up fragile support in the party's traditional heartlands by launching a professionally-staffed call centre to woo disaffected voters and Tory "floaters" who opted for Tony Blair in 1997.
fields.body:
Labour is preparing a fresh offensive to shore up fragile support in the party's traditional heartlands by launching a professionally-staffed call centre to woo disaffected voters and Tory "floaters" who opted for Tony Blair in 1997.

The party's HQ in Millbank is alarmed by the decline of grassroots activism and a string of reversals in local byelections caused by stay-at-home voters. The North Tyneside centre will be modelled on financial services operations in the north east, now known as the call centre capital of Britain.

Senior party members in the north have received circulars from Labour asking if they are prepared to work in the centre, which will have a full and part-time staff of 60 - making it a medium-sized, professional operation, according to specialists in the field.

The move coincides with a growing flood of advice from Millbank to backbench MPs, providing them with model speeches to make in Commons debates, model press releases and model articles for their local newspapers, as well as on-message answers to any tricky questions they may face.

Written in terms which infuriate more experienced MPs, Millbank's model article begins: "Three and half years after Anytown helped give the Labour government the chance to bring about the improvements you want, I believe the country is moving in the right direction ..."

Such initiatives reflect Mill bank's concern to ensure that all MPs speak with a united voice as the expected May 3 election looms. But the price sometimes paid is disaffection among activists and a fall-off in willingness to go out and canvass voters.

"What's the point of having five law and order bills in the Queen's speech if they put off activists and I can't get five party members to attend my general committee," one northern Labour MP complained this week.

The call centre plan also underlines concern about a falling party membership, and a collapse of a network of ward branches in some traditional areas where MPs have long been warning the party hierarchy that bolder measures are needed to bring traditional supporters back on board.

webTitle: Week 6: Katoomba to Coogee

fields.headline: The girl's guide to hunting and fishing
fields.standfirst: Milly's highs and lows leave her exhilerated as she meets her first marsupials, tries cliff jumping, and eats her favourite food
fields.trailText: Katoomba to Coogee Milly's highs and lows leave her exhilerated as she meets her first marsupials, tries cliff jumping, and eats her favourite food
fields.body:
That next day in Wollangambe was undoubtedly my favourite of the trip so far. Shaun the hostel owner had left early for work, leaving the residents to their own devices. The night before, the knowledgeable American fellow hosteller Scott had described a sheer cliff which sits on an incredibly deep dam, and I'd been dying to get there. Armed with his scribbled map we set out through the bush, beating off the flies with a stick, and after about half an hour came across the place.

It had been my ambition to jump from the top into the dam - both Scott and Shaun's son had said it was fine. However after a short swim and a 25-foot climb it did look pretty high up there! It wasn't until a 15-year old local boy did the jump first that I had the courage to leap. . . and it was incredibly exhilarating! Josh was just seconds behind me and I think for him it must have been worse as he's scared of heights - still, those few seconds of hanging and falling will stick in my memory!

After a quick swim we headed back for the lodge just in time to escape the thunder storm that had been brewing. We were desperate for it to die down as I wanted to go kangaroo searching in the evening. I wasn't disappointed. Again using a map drawn by Scott we set out just before dusk for a spot where travellers before had seen 'roos and wallabies, and were rewarded by seeing three different types of wallaby including a relatively rare black rock one. My first Australian marsupials!

Returning to the lodge we cooked dinner and were pretty early to sleep - because I was making Josh get up at 4.30 the next morning! I wanted to watch the sunrise which begins at about 5.30. At exactly that time we were positioned on a rock overlooking one of the valleys just down from Shaun's back garden. It was a slow sunrise and the colours and the clouds slowly glowing pink were beautiful. We returned to the lodge for a swift siesta before starting the 50 minute trek complete with backpacks so we could catch the train out of Wollangambe again (Shaun was out at work and he was our only means of transport). It was pretty exhausting but we made the train in time, now bound for Katoomba to see some of the more obvious sights of the blue mountains.

We intended to have just one night at the YHA there, but after being heavily rained on we extended our stay for another night to get in a full day's exploration. Luckily the next day, the rain stopped so we hopped on one of the tourist buses and got off at Gordon Falls. We intended to do the short walk between there and the next falls before getting back on the bus, but us being us, we ended up walking the entire cliff route - still, all this walking is doing wonders for my legs!

The walk includes some absolutely breathtaking views across the blue mountains (so called because of the blue mist that rises from the eucalyptus trees), including the much photographed Three Sisters Rocks. Other highlights included the Leura cascades and falls, the gruelling 900 step climb, and for me the ultimate highlight - getting a lizard to eat bread off my hand!! We'd found it bathing in the sun and I couldn't believe it would be that tame - that definitely made my day. And I introduced Josh to peanut butter and banana sandwiches, which he agreed were good

Next morning was check-out from Katoomba, and we headed back to Sydney. On the way we stopped at Wentworth Falls to follow the Charles Darwin walk down to the waterfalls. They were very beautiful, but personally I was still exhausted after the day before so we didn't really do much walking!

When we got to Sydney we went straight out again for Coogee - which as I've said before is where I hope to settle for a bit - and to the Coogee Beach Backpackers Hostel. Its location by the beach (besides being on a very steep hill) certainly makes it ideal. In the evening we went to the Beach Palace hotel - one of the two main venues in Coogee where you can have a few quiet drinks and a bit of much needed recuperation!

Our next day involved an exploration of the town, and my first attempts at job-hunting as I filled in a couple of application forms at the two biggest bars there. We bought a big pile of fresh groceries from the stunningly good value food shops with the intention of making something with nutritional value - noodle and vegetable stir-fry. I started to think it might be quite nice to live here for a while - life by the beach in a smallish friendly area, while back home I receive reports of cold wet days. . . life is definitely looking good!

Tuesday 9th was Josh's last full day with me, and we spent the morning shopping around Coogee. In the evening we went out for dinner to a funky restaurant called Rice which is just two minutes walk from the hostel and does all manner of Asian-style meals. It also gave me the chance to eat aubergine which is one of my world's favourite foods so I was happy! That's one thing about Australia - when food is such incredibly good value it makes it tempting just to eat out all the time!

The Wednesday morning I saw Josh off at the airport, which was pretty depressing. Still, I picked myself up by writing lots of emails back home, although it was hard suddenly being alone again. I moved into a dorm, which was a good idea - no sooner had I got there than my room-mate invited me out for the evening. A group of us went to the Palace hotel to play 'toss the boss'. You order your drinks and the server flips a coin. If you guess right you get your drink free, if not you pay. I was rewarded with a free jug of beer, so I was pretty pleased!

It was good fun, and they're a decent crowd of people, so I reckon everything's going to work out ok again.. . and tomorrow I've agreed to go and watch tennis at the Olympic park, so I'll be able to report how the champions are getting on.

Until next time (when I'll still be in the sun - it really is a tough life this you know)
Milly

Other highlights included the Leura cascades and falls, the gruelling 900 step climb, and for me the ultimate highlight - getting a lizard to eat bread off my hand!! We'd found it bathing in the sun and I couldn't believe it would be that tame - that definitely made my day. And I introduced Josh to peanut butter and banana sandwiches, which he agreed were good Next morning was check-out from Katoomba, and we headed back to Sydney. On the way we stopped at Wentworth Falls to follow the Charles Darwin walk down to the waterfalls. They were very beautiful, but personally I was still exhausted after the day before so we didn't really do much walking! When we got to Sydney we went straight out again for Coogee - which as I've said before is where I hope to settle for a bit - and to the Coogee Beach Backpackers Hostel. Its location by the beach (besides being on a very steep hill) certainly makes it ideal. In the evening we went to the Beach Palace hotel - one of the two main venues in Coogee where you can have a few quiet drinks and a bit of much needed recuperation! Our next day involved an exploration of the town, and my first attempts at job-hunting as I filled in a couple of application forms at the two biggest bars there. We bought a big pile of fresh groceries from the stunningly good value food shops with the intention of making something with nutritional value - noodle and vegetable stir-fry. I started to think it might be quite nice to live here for a while - life by the beach in a smallish friendly area, while back home I receive reports of cold wet days. . . life is definitely looking good! Tuesday 9th was Josh's last full day with me, and we spent the morning shopping around Coogee. In the evening we went out for dinner to a funky restaurant called Rice which is just two minutes walk from the hostel and does all manner of Asian-style meals. It also gave me the chance to eat aubergine which is one of my world's favourite foods so I was happy! That's one thing about Australia - when food is such incredibly good value it makes it tempting just to eat out all the time! The Wednesday morning I saw Josh off at the airport, which was pretty depressing. Still, I picked myself up by writing lots of emails back home, although it was hard suddenly being alone again. I moved into a dorm, which was a good idea - no sooner had I got there than my room-mate invited me out for the evening. A group of us went to the Palace hotel to play 'toss the boss'. You order your drinks and the server flips a coin. If you guess right you get your drink free, if not you pay. I was rewarded with a free jug of beer, so I was pretty pleased! It was good fun, and they're a decent crowd of people, so I reckon everything's going to work out ok again.. . and tomorrow I've agreed to go and watch tennis at the Olympic park, so I'll be able to report how the champions are getting on. Until next time (when I'll still be in the sun - it really is a tough life this you know) Milly

webTitle: Cainer quits Express for Mirror

fields.headline: Cainer quits Express for Mirror
fields.trailText: 11.15am update: Express astrologer Jonathan Cainer is joining the Mirror less than a year after being lured from the Mail, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Star Express astrologer Jonathan Cainer is joining the Mirror less than a year after being lured from the Mail by Rosie Boycott.

Triumphant Mirror editor Piers Morgan said: "He's seen the future and the future is in the Mirror.

"He's a massive, massive, coup for the Mirror," he continued. "This is the equivalent of David Beckham going to join Arsenal."

The Mirror signed Mr Cainer late last night after "lengthy negotiations", according to Mr Morgan.

It is believed the Daily Mail also tried to lure Mr Cainer with a another big money deal.

The astrologer sensationally defected from the Mail for a £1m salary and £1m bonus last year to join the Express after an argument with the paper over the revenue split from his newspaper phone lines.

After Express editor Rosie Boycott poached him, the Mail moved heaven and earth to try to win Mr Cainer back.

At the time desperate bosses at the Mail offered to cap the Express deal in a contract that would have made Mr Cainer the highest paid writer on any paper.

It is believed that Mr Cainer decided to join the Mirror because of a lucrative deal that will give him a cut of revenue from horoscope telephone lines.

Mr Cainer, who has become the astrologer of choice for Middle England, previously worked at Today.

He used to perform in a band called Strange Cloud, and said in an interview that he read the Guardian by choice.

Mr Morgan refused to discuss details of his salary.

webTitle: Grumpy Gates eclipsed by rising stars at Davos

fields.headline: Grumpy Gates eclipsed by rising stars at Davos
fields.standfirst:
In the second of our exclusive book extracts Microsoft's boss blows his stack

Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Bill Gates was angry when he arrived at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, in January 1998.
fields.body:
Bill Gates was angry when he arrived at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, in January 1998.

His anger was palpable, and it surprised many who did not know him but knew well the multiple reasons he had not to be angry: the planet's richest man was the co-founder of Microsoft, a company that for 23 years had outflanked and outthought its competitors, a company whose Windows software now served as the essential code in about 90% of all personal computers, a company whose stock price made it the world's most highly valued.

Unlike stock market meteors such as Amazon.com and Broadcast.com that produced paper billionaires but globs of red ink, Microsoft's profits, nearly $4.5bn, were twice as large as those of the world's largest company, General Motors.

What's more, Bill Gates had come to look forward to this annual summit of about 2,000 CEOs and government, academic, and media leaders, who came to this tiny Alpine village for three to five days, dipping into seminars on topics from genetic engineering to Islam, listening to and giving speeches, maybe skiing, and, of course, scheduling one-on-one business meetings, all under the protective eye of the machine gun-toting Swiss army.

Not President Clinton or the presidents of China or Russia or the CEO of GE or Warren Beatty was a bigger rock star here than Bill Gates. For the past several years, the coveted Sunday luncheon speech before the international press was reserved for Bill Gates. He enjoyed the attention, and the efficiency of Davos even more. At Microsoft, he carefully budgeted his time, allocating a set number of annual face-time hours to each senior executive and five speeches per year to software developers.

For a busy executive, Davos was like one-stop shopping: in just a few days, Gates could assemble and speak with hundreds of his biggest customers, prearrange appointments to discuss deals, stack up private sessions with CEOs or government chiefs, and gather in one room correspondents from the world's most prestigious publications.

Yet whatever reasons Bill Gates might have had to be ebullient going into Davos were overwhelmed by his burgeoning sense that he was a victim. He believed Microsoft was the engine of the new economy. So why, he wondered, was the US government treating him like Al Capone?

At the Sunday lunch, I was seated next to Gates at a table for 10 that included his wife, Melinda, and the then chairman and CEO of Coca-Cola, Douglas Ivester. Before the salad arrived, he had already berated me for a panel I'd moderated a few nights earlier called "Monopolies and Technology". He complained that I had allowed enemies of Microsoft to pummel his chief technology officer, Nathan Myhrvold. Gates was not mollified to hear that Myhrvold more than held his own in the exchange. Gates sat huddled over, his arms folded across his chest, his brown hair unparted, unwashed, and combed straight down like a boy's. He rocked back and forth in his chair, his eyes fixed on the floor.

His manner was gruff, and he was either unwilling or unable to hide his rage. Melinda Gates, a personable former Microsoft executive, tried discreetly to capture his attention, but he would not look up. The eight other guests at the table stared at him in wonder. Suddenly, his voice rising to a shrill pitch, Gates proclaimed, "Neither Nathan nor anyone from Microsoft will ever appear again on such a panel!" Those of us sharing his luncheon table in Davos were stunned by the rawness of the emotion Bill Gates couldn't contain, but we assumed he would compose himself for his eagerly awaited speech to a room filled with a worldwide press corps.

And, indeed, after he was introduced, Gates at first skillfully camouflaged his rage. He fastened on his best CEO mask and, displaying a half smile, spoke calmly for about 20 minutes.

He responded easily to questions from reporters about Microsoft's legal woes and about whom he saw as its potential business competitors. But then I rose and asked what could have been construed as an innocuous question: "Unlike other companies, Microsoft is now stalked by an 800lb gorilla, the government. And without passing judgment on the merits of the case, the government does have legitimate responsibilities: to seek to protect the public from monopolies, or from price gouging, or from invasions of privacy. What do you say to those who believe Microsoft has behaved arrogantly, as if the government had no right to ask questions?"

Perhaps it was the word arrogant that provoked an eruption, for Gates plunged into a five-minute rant memorable less for what he said than for the deep hurt he betrayed. After curtly taking several more questions, Gates returned to the table and, hovering behind me, bellowed, "What do you mean arrogant?" Douglas Ivester's eyes widened, and the look on his face said: "This is not how Fortune 500 CEOs behave!" Melinda Gates looked stricken."Remember when you said neither Nathan nor anyone from Microsoft would appear on a panel again?" I said. "That was arrogant."

Just as suddenly as it had erupted, the storm subsided, and the belligerent Gates became a vulnerable adolescent. "What should I do?" he asked plaintively, in a subdued voice. Like everyone at the table, I froze in awkward silence until the luncheon mercifully concluded.

Although Bill Gates barely noticed, Microsoft's approach was isolating it from many of the corporate leaders gathered in Davos. At an annual Sun Valley retreat put on by Allen & Company, News Corporation's Rupert Murdoch, NBC's Robert Wright, Sony's Nobuyuki Idei - among others - were shocked during a Gates presentation when he boasted: "I'm going to destroy three companies: Sun Microsystems, Oracle, and Netscape."

Everyone in this audience wanted to beat the competition - but destroy them? Gates seemed so, well, immature. To these executives, business was business; it wasn't personal.

In 2000, it was apparent that, unlike in prior years, Gates was no longer the magnet at this event. Earlier that year Steve Case's America Online deployed $165bn of its "invasion currency" to gobble up the world's largest media company, TimeWarner. Case was the new rock star of Davos. It was Case that US secretary of state Madeleine Albright asked to be seated next to at a dinner Saturday night, and Case that King Abdallah bin al-Hussein of Jordan was seated beside Sunday night.

Case fielded most of the questions in Davos - as if the audience expected this from him. Gates seemed to sink back into his beige leather armchair, hesitant to contribute. Gates looked markedly older than he had the year before. His face was marked by more wrinkles, and the skin under his eyes sagged.

I asked Case if he sensed a shift of focus away from Gates. He acknowledged he was now "a little more" like a rock star and that the spotlight of celebrity now pursued him. "It goes with the territory," he said. He was also struck that Gates, with whom he's been on panels and attended conferences and had more than a few fractious negotiations, was "a little subdued. He seemed to be going out of his way to be more of a statesman."

Not for one minute, however, did Case believe Gates when he said Microsoft would stick to software. "It's highly likely that the destiny of our two companies is to duke it out for many years to come. We are wary of them. We don't see them as a software company. We see them as a to-the-death competitor. And they have determined, probably correctly, that if they want to be the most valuable company in the future they can't just be a software company."

If Gates really meant not to be in the content business, said Case, "then he would have divested MSN and Expedia and all those businesses that are not software businesses". It is second nature for Case not to take Gates at his word.

This lack of trust was increasingly mentioned by other companies who contemplated partnering with Microsoft. Even John Malone, who probably has as many joint ventures with Microsoft as anyone, thought Microsoft's aggressive culture could disadvantage them in the future. "They want to win," he said. "They don't want their team to win. They're not team players by nature. They're ball hogs."

Surely trust was now a missing ingredient in the relationship between Nobuyuki Idei and Gates. Idei is a trained economist who pushes his company to spend about the same on R&D ($3.7bn) as does Microsoft ($3.8bn).

Idei still saw Microsoft as "the biggest competitor of Sony". The two corporations were engaged, he said, in a series of "regional wars, not a world war". They battled in the game market, battled in designing software operating systems for cable boxes, battled in e-commerce, would battle when he launched a Sony-branded portal, as he had in Japan, to compete with MSN and others, and they would battle when the new Sony PlayStation became an inexpensive operating system for all home appliances.

Idei had a private meeting in Davos with Gates, as he did each year, but this year tensions flared. "He feels PlayStation is a real threat to them," Idei said. Microsoft aspired to provide the operating system for PlayStation, as well as for cable boxes or servers or PCs. Idei was unmoved.

Idei thought Gates had reason to be unsure: "Microsoft is very uncertain about their future business model." In the two decades he had known Gates, Idei had never seen him so tentative. In halting English, this thin, taciturn man who wore a white silk shirt with a round collar buttoned at the top, said he thought Microsoft was slipping because their "business model is totally in danger."

"Gates is an OS [operating system] dinosaur," he said, at a time when power is shifting. To get very large, companies required the right ideas, and Idei no longer thought Gates had these. "His mind-set is old," he said. He would no longer be able to license Windows as he once had.

"Bill Gates is the IBM of today _ He wrote a book about the road ahead, but it is really the road back." Microsoft is losing good executives, he continued. Microsoft wants to build its model around MSN, but when they head overseas AOL, Sony, and others have huge head starts.

Microsoft wants to find partners, but human relationships are not its core strength. "Microsoft's soldiers try to behave like Bill Gates. They act more important than you," said Idei, making it clear that this further poisoned partnership prospects. Idei still saw Microsoft and America Online as the two principal future competitors with Sony. He hoped to reduce the battle to a one-on-one fight, which meant he might partner with either foe, though he wasn't sure he could trust Microsoft. However, even if Idei succeeded in eliminating a major enemy, he knew others would surface.

Big companies will be assaulted by hordes of what Idei called "ants" - by free-software programmers using Linux, by copyright pirates, by makers of portable devices that access the internet."A big company, like a dinosaur, will be eaten up by the ants," he said. Only the very large or the very small may survive, with those in between nibbled to death by the ants or crushed.

webTitle: Vinnie's starring debut in doubt after Patsy's departure

fields.headline: Vinnie's starring debut in doubt after Patsy's departure
fields.trailText: Guy Ritchie's forthcoming biopic of boxer Lenny McLean has run into difficulties after leading lady Patsy Kensit pulled out of the project
fields.body:
The film that it was hoped would propel former soccer hardman Vinnie Jones from cameo thug to acclaimed actor has hit rocky round now that the proposed leading lady Patsy Kensit seems unlikely to go ahead with the project.

According to entertainment site PeopleNews, The Guv'nor, a Guy Ritchie film based on the life of bare-knuckle boxer Lenny McLean, ran into difficulties after agents for Kensit said that they have had no contact about the project for months. "We were sent a script early last year," said Kensit's manager, Steve Dagger, "but we've had no offer and no negotiations." The film's production company has even admitted that contracts have yet to be signed and the only commitment to the project so far was "verbal."

It was hoped that the film, which is scheduled to go into pre-production next month, would be ready for general release in Britain by Octobe, but Dagger claims that Kensit already has commitments to honour throughout February, adding that "the project seems like a lot of hot air." However, Arrival Productions, which is making the film, have insisted that the project will go ahead and that Kensit is still likely to co-star.

When the project was first mooted in August, the film's producer Clinton Montague claimed that the part of the boxer would propel Jones into the Hollywood A-list. "This role will be for Vinnie what James Bond was for Sean Connery - a perfect movie marriage. This is what he'll be remembered for and I know he believes that too."

Jones is currently filming the spy-thriller Swordfish in Los Angeles with John Travolta.

webTitle: Saddam: serpent in the Garden of Eden

fields.headline: Saddam: serpent in the Garden of Eden
fields.standfirst: The Gulf war exposed western hypocrisy and made a hero of a tyrant, says Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: The Gulf war exposed western hypocrisy and made a hero of a tyrant, says Middle East editor Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Ten years ago next Wednesday the largest military alliance the world has seen unleashed its weaponry in Operation Desert Storm or, as Saddam Hussein called it, the Mother of Battles. The issue, in the eyes of Margaret Thatcher (prime minister when Iraq invaded Kuwait) was a simple matter of good versus evil: Saddam had invaded a sovereign state and turned it into a province of Iraq. He must not be allowed to get away with it.

Ideally, the "Iron Lady" - whose mettle helped to stiffen President Bush's resolve in the aftermath of the invasion - would also have claimed that this was a war for democracy. Unfortunately Kuwait was not at the time democratic; nor, for that matter, were many of the 28 countries that stepped in to save it.

Defending a small sovereign state against aggression is, nevertheless, a fine principle - if one that the world tends to apply selectively. In Kuwait's case, its oil resources were no small factor.

"What we see is a fight between wolves over a delicious morsel," Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a prominent Iranian radical observed at the time.

Lawrence Koth, a former US assistant defence secretary, agreed - for once - with the Iranians. "If Kuwait grew carrots, we wouldn't give a damn," he said.

Saddam had done his best to muddy the waters before the invasion - just as Hitler had done over Czechoslovakia half a century earlier, producing a string of grievances and territorial claims which, to anyone who wished to believe them, carried a ring of plausibility.

Also, in the case of Kuwait, the sympathy that many people naturally feel for the underdog was not, perhaps, as easily aroused as it might have been: Kuwait was extremely rich, and it is more difficult to feel sorry for the rich than for the poor.

Any idea that the anti-Saddam alliance came about as a result of worldwide indignation was basically a mirage. The Americans ran the show and several of the Arab states, whose participation was vital for political appearances, had to be bribed to join. The Israelis, who would have loved to join, had to be bribed to stay out, lest they frighten away the Arabs.

Among other "allies", Norway sent one supply ship and the Germans simply wrote a cheque for DM3bn.

There were many, at the time, who believed war was not the answer. It was, some said, an Arab problem demanding an Arab solution. A tempting idea, were it not for that fact that so many Arabs constantly lament their inability to produce an "Arab" solution to anything.

Others argued that sanctions - which had been imposed a few days after the invasion - should be allowed time to make their impact felt. Once that happened, Saddam would surely reconsider.

Sanctions, basically, are war by economic means and were seen at the time as a gentler alternative. It is interesting that many who opposed the war and favoured sanctions in 1991 have since changed their minds about sanctions. The last 10 years have shown that they can be just as deadly as guns.

The simple issue of principle that Margaret Thatcher saw so clearly was less readily appreciated in the souqs and cafes of the Arab world.

The Iraqi regime is, almost certainly, the most systematically callous and brutal in the world. But people in the Middle East are more rather inured to authoritarian rule than those in the west and tend to regard what happens in Iraq as a private matter between Saddam and his people.

Regardless of the way Iraq had raped Kuwait, the ensuing conflict was seen by millions as another example of western interference. Furthermore, many noted that the principles on which it was claimed to be based, and the insistence on compliance with UN resolutions, were always applied much more flexibly - if at all - in the case of Israel.

Imagine, for a moment, the uproar if Saddam had offered to return 95% of Kuwait to the Kuwaitis, while establishing Iraqi "settlements" in the best bits and retaining control of all the important highways.

Ever since the death of Gamal Abdul Nasser, the Egyptian president who defied Britain over the Suez canal, Arabs have longed for another great leader, just as Saddam has longed to assume that mantle.

Iraq's Mother of Battles was, in a purely military sense, doomed to failure but it still presented an opportunity for Saddam to become a hero in the eyes of many ordinary Arabs, if not their governments. All he had to do was survive the onslaught.

In fact, he only just survived. There was a brief period in 1991 when the United States could have driven him from Baghdad but chose not to do so.

One reason was the undertakings given to America's Arab allies: that the goal of the war was to liberate Kuwait and nothing else. To go beyond that at the point of victory would have amounted to treachery.

In addition, removing Saddam would have infringed Iraq's sovereignty in the same way that Iraq had infringed Kuwait's. It would also have left the US with the problem of how to replace Saddam and, possibly, how to prevent Iraq from fragmenting at the hands of its Kurdish and Shi'a communities.

Whether or not Bush made the right decision is still debated. The main consequence is that the removal of Saddam was not adopted as explicit US policy until it had become virtually impossible to achieve.

Instead, we have had more than 10 years of sanctions and, as Bush's son prepares for his move to the White House, western policy towards Iraq is in a mess.

Iraq, too, is in a mess - partly as a result of sanctions but mainly as a result of Saddam Hussein. Since he came to power in 1979, Iraq has had only four years or so without military or economic warfare.

Given a different leader it could, by now, have become a prosperous country. Arabs in the Gulf look on its natural resources with envy. "It has both oil and water," they say. "We only have oil".

Tradition has it that the Garden of Eden lay in Iraq, between the Tigris and the Euphrates. But today, despite the fertility of the land, agriculture does not flourish.

Iraq, even under sanctions and with worn-out equipment, remains a major oil producer. Its oil can be produced more cheaply than almost anywhere else in the world.

Through two decades of war, waged by Saddam mainly for the purpose of keeping himself in power, there has been almost no new oil exploration and very little investment in its production. Many experts agree that there is more untapped oil potential in Iraq than anywhere else.

Sadly, the prosperity of Iraq is not a priority for Saddam nor, apparently, for the west.

webTitle: TV ratings January 11

fields.headline: Channel 4's binman bags 2m
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Nearly 2m viewers watched Channel 4's documentary on Benjamin 'the binman' Pell, who makes a fortune from celebrities' dustbins. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Nearly 2m viewers watched Channel 4's documentary on Benjamin "the binman" Pell, the man who makes a fortune from celebrity's dustbins.

Scandal in the Bins had 1.9m viewers and an 11% share from 10pm last night, according to unofficial overnights.

Elsewhere, Channel 5 had a late-night hit on their hands with the unambiguously titled Lesbians Go Mad on Lesbos.

The 60-minute documentary, about a group of lesbians who took a package holiday to the Greek island of Lesbos and got a hostile reception from the local mayor, drew 1.5m and a hefty 16% share from 10.55pm.

BBC2 survival gameshow Bare Necessities returned for a new series last night, with teams of clerics and bookies competing to get through a week living outdoors in Romania.

It drew 2.2m and a 9% share, 8-9pm, beating Channel 4's Lost Gardens, which had 1.7m.
