webTitle: Daum: I took cocaine

fields.headline: Daum: I took cocaine
fields.trailText: Disgraced German coach Christoph Daum has admitted taking cocaine. "I admit I have taken cocaine in the past," he said, after returning from a three-month exile in Florida.
fields.body:
Disgraced German coach Christoph Daum has admitted taking cocaine. "I admit I have taken cocaine in the past," he said, after returning from a three-month exile in Florida.

Daum had been lined up to coach the German national team but was ruled out of contention amid allegations of cocaine-fuelled orgies with prostitutes.

Daum had initially denied the allegations but was caught out after analysis of a hair sample suggested he had taken illegal drugs. A second test proved inconclusive.

But on returning from the United States, the 47-year-old admitted: "I took the drug in private. There's no question of me being an addict or being ill as a side-effect.

"I am aware of the scope of this error and I am ready to assume responsibility for it."

Earlier this week Daum called for the matter to be resolved and said he was anxious to resume his coaching career. "I have had to keep silent for long enough but now I am happy to be home."

Rudi Voller, who has successfully stepped into the breach as German national coach, said he was pleased but surprised to see Daum return.

"I think it's great he's back and I hope things can be sorted out," said Voller, who had originally only been due to steer the national squad through to the summer before giving way to Daum.

webTitle: Stephen Moss' diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • There seems to be some confusion over my item about the Royal Opera House's new boss in yesterday's Gùff. I was simply apologising for having got it so totally wrong earlier in the week, when I insisted that Tony Hall was by no means a shoo-in for the job. The fact that the initial letters of the four sentences spelt HALL was just an amazing coincidence. I would also like to deny the rumours that we had shared a long and intimate lunch earlier in the day.
fields.body:
 There seems to be some confusion over my item about the Royal Opera House's new boss in yesterday's Gùff. I was simply apologising for having got it so totally wrong earlier in the week, when I insisted that Tony Hall was by no means a shoo-in for the job. The fact that the initial letters of the four sentences spelt HALL was just an amazing coincidence. I would also like to deny the rumours that we had shared a long and intimate lunch earlier in the day.

 The huntin'-crazy Lord Bragg of Wigton (aka sensitive writer Melvyn Bragg) has written a letter to accompany a video Labour MPs have received from the Countryside Alliance, asking for their support in the vote on hunting later this month. "In Cumbria, where I live, the right to use dogs to control pest foxes efficiently and humanely can make the difference between survival and financial failure for hill farmers," he says winningly. Just one problem: the address on the letter is Hampstead, London.

 A man in a glass house writes ... The European edition of yesterday's Times had a story on page 3 about Princess Margaret, accompanied by a picture of cock-a-hoop naturist Vincent Bethell. The caption underneath was: "The princess, usually happy to go out, has spent most of the past three weeks in bed." Oh dear.

 Mr Bethell's historic victory was followed by a curious exchange with the judge, George Bathurst Norman. Bethell (naked): "Being human is not a crime." Judge (in wig): "I would not go away too much with that idea." Apart from this being gibberish, is it not a little worrying that our judges appear to believe that being human is a crime? I rest my case.

 Forget Lewis v Tyson. This is the big one: Boris "the Jackal" Johnson v Polly "the Tiger" Toynbee in a new series of half-hour head-to-heads, starting on BBC News 24 at 9.30pm on Sunday. Tax and spend is the subject of the first programme, with "the Tiger" favourite to win. But I would say that, wouldn't I?

 Where is Nigel "lost cause" Hastilow, the bullish Tory candidate for Edgbaston? Labour claim he has fled to Bermuda; his local party says he's away on business; Conservative central office thinks he's on holiday. Nigel, please come home, Mr Hague would like a word.

 The Natural Law Party, having failed to attract the floating voter, thinks the election is a lost cause and is disbanding. Nigel, is this anything to do with you?

 Dr Julian Lewis, rightwing Tory and self-appointed guardian of democracy, confides to next week's House magazine that he wants a wife. "My great regret," the 49-year-old bachelor sighs, "is not to have married and created a loving home. [Can someone pass me a handkerchief. Thanks.] If I had to choose between a glittering career and a happy family home, the career would come a long way second." Any takers?

 From the amour propre department. The wife of Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, has decreed that her ennobled husband must be referred to as Sir Edward. The BBC is kowtowing, but there is one high-level refusenik. The formality-hating Gordon Brown, who doesn't wear DJs or acknowledge titles. So Eddie it is.

 The British Trust for Ornithology is holding its ringing and migration conference today in Swanwick. The press officer at the event is Sue Starling.

 I'm afraid I was lying when I said on Wednesday that we had a major scoop about the break-up of All Saints. Frankly, I thought All Saints was a church near Tottenham Court Road. With my finger manifestly nowhere near the pulse, I am being rested and Oliver Burkeman will produce the Gùff next week.

webTitle: Unionists, Welshmen, and Celts

fields.headline: Unionists, Welshmen, and Celts
fields.trailText: A LOAD OF BULL
fields.body:
A LOAD OF BULL

Hullo, my name's Ray Unionist. Tomorrow, you'll probably see my thick, leathery neck pictured in all the papers. That's because today I levered my flabby, misshapen body into an ill-fitting John Bull costume and spent all day standing outside the FA's Soho Square headquarters protesting at their appointment of Sven-Goran Eriksson. Spit! Hack! He's bleeding well not flipping English! That's very nearly a war criminal! Anyway, look, I'm holding a placard in my pudgy, stumpy fingers, and it says "FA hang your heads in shame" and "No surrender", and I look a complete arse. I'm making a very important point about identity, you know.

I mean, listen to Eriksson desperately trying to curry favour with everyone during today's press conference which officially unveiled him as manager of ... bleh ... I can't even bring myself to say it. "I am here now finally. I look forward to starting. So far there's been a lot of talk in Italy, England and Sweden. But now from tomorrow I am going to start and the talking can stop." Grr, I could think of a way to stop a certain someone talking, matey!

"If we don't get results, they will try to hang me. But if I was an Englishman they would try to hang me." Well, I'm an Englishman, pal, and you'd be wise not to give me any ideas! "I think we have about 10 weeks before we're going to play the game against Finland. I hope to see a lot of the games. I believe that we shall qualify for the World Cup and I must remain positive." Positive? Positive?!? I'll give you pos- [At this point, Ray's bright-red bulbous noggin exploded with rage]

ADVERTISEMENT

Fed up with your team's failures? Overjoyed at your side's success? Find out what genuine fans REALLY think about your club at From The Terrace: http://www.fromtheterrace.co.uk

HOW TO ARRANGE A TRANSFER, THE JOHN HARTSON WAY (PT II)

1. Go to bed. For Christ's sake don't grill any cheese on top of your bedtime steak, or you'll have those dreams where Dick Advocaat and George Graham chase you over a field of surgical knives. Ow! Ow! Ow! Running really hurts!

2. Wake up in cold sweat. Get up. Clean teeth. Wash face. Brush hair (off pillow and into bin). Remember agent Jonathan Barnett is coming round early with the latest on your impending transfer to Coventry. Try to get excited. Give up and make triple-decker breakfast sandwich instead.

3. Barnett arrives. Listen in stunned silence as he announces that the deal is "dead", before adding: "We had agreed terms with Coventry, and the collapse of the deal has nothing to do with John. I don't think the transfer between the two clubs could be agreed."

4. Decide to give up on football career. Listen as Barnett gives stirring rallying speech. "John is obviously upset but he has had disappointments before. He will bounce back and he will remain, as he always has been, committed to Wimbledon." Decide to give up on life as well.

5. Put razor blade down and turn hot taps off as Wimbledon and Coventry suddenly agree £5m cash-plus-player deal, with only the personal terms of striker Cedric Roussel, who is going the other way, still to be resolved. Listen to City chairman Bryan Richardson announce that the deal will be finalised "within the next few days".

6. Say something along the lines of: "I am excited at getting back into the Premiership with Coventry. I was enormously impressed with Gordon Strachan. I know I can improve under him. I will still only be 26 in April and there is a lot more to come from me."

7. Decide to have slap-up celebratory meal. Mmm, chips.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"This is the equivalent of David Beckham going to join Arsenal" - Triumphant Mirror editor Piers Morgan announces his new signing ... top Express astrologer Jonathon Cainer.

FIRE!

Wimbledon's Sam Hammam, the Cardiff chairman, is a crazy man. When he's not smearing extra-strength Fiery Jack ointment onto his players' jockstraps, he's usually announcing plans to change the club's name to the Cardiff Celts, complete with a green-and-white-hooped kit - original, eh? - or dreaming up new ways to deliver Wales from 700 years of English oppression.

With this in mind, Crazy Sam hatched another crazy idea. Wouldn't it be a great wheeze, he thought, to let supporters buy a Cardiff shirt for half price - provided they handed in a strip of an English club for him to burn (along with an effigy of the hated Edward I, no doubt)? "The idea is to get people to wear Welsh club shirts rather than any other football club shirts," explained an innocent sounding club spokesman. "Sam Hammam's view is if you are Welsh, why are you wearing a Manchester United or a Barcelona or any other shirt when you should be wearing a Welsh football club shirt?"

Exactly right, you might think - although if you did, you'd soon get an earful from anti-racist groups and the police. The Kick It Out campaign has condemned Hammam's idea for its "extremely xenophobic and nationalistic overtones". Meanwhile, Gerry Toms of South Wales Police agreed, saying: "I certainly do not support the proposal and believe it needs a rethink." With criticism raining down from all sides, Crazy Sam this afternoon decided to ditch his controversial plans. But don't worry, he's already mulling over a new idea: midnight guerrilla raids on Shrewsbury. Remember, you read it here first.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bulgarian champions Levski Sofia are hoping to sign West Ham's out-of-favour striker Davor Suker. "Our attractive point is the participation in [Big Cup]," said Levski coach Ljupko Petrovic. "I haven't yet got a negative answer."

Meanwhile, West Ham are hoping to sign Alaves striker Javi Moreno - who is the top scorer in the Primera Liga - for around £5.5m. "He's a top quality player," Harry Redknapp admitted. "He has lot of qualities that I admire, but I don't know if we can compete for him. I would love to get a front man in to partner Freddie Kanoute - that would be frightening."

NEWS IN BRIEF

Bradford defender Dan Petrescu has completed his move to Southampton after the two clubs agreed a nominal fee.

Nottingham Forest have completed the signing of David Johnson from Ipswich Town for £3.5m. Manager David Platt admitted: "It's a tremendous lift for us and it's no secret that we've been looking for a goalscorer for a long time. This is a boost for everyone at the club."

Aston Villa manager John Gregory will complete the signing of River Plate's Juan Pablo Angel for £9.5m within the next 48 hours.

Arsenal are hoping to complete the signing of Brazilian midfielder Edu from Corinthians early next week. "Edu is in Portugal at the moment and has the document which gives him Portuguese citizenship and should now bring him the right passport," said Arsene Wenger. "If all goes well the deal to sign him should be completed by Monday or Tuesday."

Sunderland manager Peter Reid has been named Carling Manager of the Month award for December. Southampton striker James Beattie has won the Player of the Month award.

Disgraced German coach Christoph Daum has finally admitted taking cocaine. "I admit I have taken cocaine in the past," he said, after returning from a three-month exile in Florida. Daum had been lined up to coach the German national team but was ruled out of contention amid allegations of cocaine-fuelled orgies with prostitutes.

Nationwide Conference chiefs have attacked the Football League for stalling on an agreement to increase the number of clubs promoted from the Conference to two. A statement on behalf of the Conference read: "It is understood that The Football League have not defined their decision-making process. The Conference are urgently seeking a joint meeting with the FA and The Football League for the purpose of reaching a satisfactory conclusion."

West Ham manager Harry Redknapp is hopeful he can seal the transfer of Rangers defender Lorenzo Amoruso "after the weekend". Redknapp told the official West Ham website: "Lorenzo is very much a player I want. He has said what he wanted and it's not cheap but all things considered it's not silly either." Swindon have failed with a bid to take Bradford striker Stan Collymore on loan until the end of the season.

Blackburn full-back Simon Grayson has joined Stockport on a three-month loan deal.

ITV: World Football (3.40am)

fields.bodyText: A LOAD OF BULL Hullo, my name's Ray Unionist. Tomorrow, you'll probably see my thick, leathery neck pictured in all the papers. That's because today I levered my flabby, misshapen body into an ill-fitting John Bull costume and spent all day standing outside the FA's Soho Square headquarters protesting at their appointment of Sven-Goran Eriksson. Spit! Hack! He's bleeding well not flipping English! That's very nearly a war criminal! Anyway, look, I'm holding a placard in my pudgy, stumpy fingers, and it says "FA hang your heads in shame" and "No surrender", and I look a complete arse. I'm making a very important point about identity, you know. I mean, listen to Eriksson desperately trying to curry favour with everyone during today's press conference which officially unveiled him as manager of ... bleh ... I can't even bring myself to say it. "I am here now finally. I look forward to starting. So far there's been a lot of talk in Italy, England and Sweden. But now from tomorrow I am going to start and the talking can stop." Grr, I could think of a way to stop a certain someone talking, matey! "If we don't get results, they will try to hang me. But if I was an Englishman they would try to hang me." Well, I'm an Englishman, pal, and you'd be wise not to give me any ideas! "I think we have about 10 weeks before we're going to play the game against Finland. I hope to see a lot of the games. I believe that we shall qualify for the World Cup and I must remain positive." Positive? Positive?!? I'll give you pos- [At this point, Ray's bright-red bulbous noggin exploded with rage] ADVERTISEMENT Fed up with your team's failures? Overjoyed at your side's success? Find out what genuine fans REALLY think about your club at From The Terrace: http://www.fromtheterrace.co.uk HOW TO ARRANGE A TRANSFER, THE JOHN HARTSON WAY (PT II) 1. Go to bed. For Christ's sake don't grill any cheese on top of your bedtime steak, or you'll have those dreams where Dick Advocaat and George Graham chase you over a field of surgical knives. Ow! Ow! Ow! Running really hurts! 2. Wake up in cold sweat. Get up. Clean teeth. Wash face. Brush hair (off pillow and into bin). Remember agent Jonathan Barnett is coming round early with the latest on your impending transfer to Coventry. Try to get excited. Give up and make triple-decker breakfast sandwich instead. 3. Barnett arrives. Listen in stunned silence as he announces that the deal is "dead", before adding: "We had agreed terms with Coventry, and the collapse of the deal has nothing to do with John. I don't think the transfer between the two clubs could be agreed." 4. Decide to give up on football career. Listen as Barnett gives stirring rallying speech. "John is obviously upset but he has had disappointments before. He will bounce back and he will remain, as he always has been, committed to Wimbledon." Decide to give up on life as well. 5. Put razor blade down and turn hot taps off as Wimbledon and Coventry suddenly agree £5m cash-plus-player deal, with only the personal terms of striker Cedric Roussel, who is going the other way, still to be resolved. Listen to City chairman Bryan Richardson announce that the deal will be finalised "within the next few days". 6. Say something along the lines of: "I am excited at getting back into the Premiership with Coventry. I was enormously impressed with Gordon Strachan. I know I can improve under him. I will still only be 26 in April and there is a lot more to come from me." 7. Decide to have slap-up celebratory meal. Mmm, chips. Wimbledon's Sam Hammam, the Cardiff chairman, is a crazy man. When he's not smearing extra-strength Fiery Jack ointment onto his players' jockstraps, he's usually announcing plans to change the club's name to the Cardiff Celts, complete with a green-and-white-hooped kit - original, eh? - or dreaming up new ways to deliver Wales from 700 years of English oppression. Wouldn't it be a great wheeze, he thought, to let supporters buy a Cardiff shirt for half price - provided they handed in a strip of an English club for him to burn (along with an effigy of the hated Edward I, no doubt)? The Kick It Out campaign has condemned Hammam's idea for its "extremely xenophobic and nationalistic overtones". webTitle: Doe new editor of TES

fields.headline: Doe named new editor of TES
fields.trailText: 4.45pm The Times has named Bob Doe as new editor of the Times Educational Supplement, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Times has named Bob Doe as the new editor of the Times Educational Supplmement, replacing Caroline St John Brooks, who resigned last year.

Mr Doe was tipped last year as the front-runner, ahead of John O'Leary, the Times's education editor, and Sunday Times columnist Melanie Phillips.

Sir Edward Pickering, chairman of TSL Education, said Mr Doe "impressed us with his vision for the paper and his plans to build on the major redesign that has taken place".

Ms St John Brooks has been editing the TES since 1997.

webTitle: Cornwall wants to go it alone

fields.headline: Cornwall wants to go it alone
fields.trailText: Scotland has its parliament, Wales has its assembly and now the south-west of England wants to be next in line for a dose of devolution. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
Scotland has its parliament, Wales has its assembly and now the south-west of England wants to be next in line for a dose of devolution.

It may sound unlikely, but activists in the region, which sprawls from Gloucestershire to Cornwall, are currently setting up a constitutional convention to decide how directly elected regional government might work in their area. They already have backing from the pro-devolution Campaign for the English Regions, cross-party support and a steering group chaired by the bishop of Exeter.

There's just one problem - the south-west already has a constitutional convention. It's being set up in Cornwall, and its members hate the idea of their county being subsumed into a south-west regional assembly.

"We see a south-west assembly as centralising power that currently exists in Cornwall to places like Bristol and Swindon, which are a different world from here," said Colin Lawry, a member of the Cornish convention. Mr Lawry is also a county councillor and deputy leader of Mebyon Kernow, Cornwall's answer to Plaid Cymru. The party is strongly in favour of self-government for the county, an idea that is already gathering steam among the county's residents - 20,000 have signed a petition calling for an elected Cornish assembly.

Cornwall's special pleading is based partly on its distinctive culture and language, but it is mainly focussed on the county's economy. Its mining, fishing and agricultural industries have declined over the last century, and despite new jobs in manufacturing, service industries and tourism, Cornwall suffers from high unemployment and low wages. The county's gross domestic product in 1995 was £3.4bn - the second lowest in the country after the Isle of Wight. With the Isles of Scilly, it is the only part of the south-west to receive objective one funding, aid from Brussels to help improve the European Union's poorest regions.

Campaigners such as the chair of the Cornish convention, independent county councillor Bert Biscoe, believe an assembly is essential to focus efforts on turning around the area's fortunes: "Cornwall's got a very strong identity and a distinctive economic and cultural profile. It's been in serious decline for many years and the one thing nobody's tried is giving us a voice and making us a region."

The Cornish constitutional convention is still at the steering group stage. Although it has gathered support from all the county's main parties, it currently lacks the working groups and wide-based support that will be necessary to establish a credible model of regional government.

It seems likely, however, that both the Cornish and south-west campaigners will produce something similar to the model proposed by the north-east constitutional convention in late 1999.

That report argued for an assembly funded by Westminster, rather than directly by local tax payers, which would set policy on planning, the regional economy, transport and infrastructure, training, arts and culture. Much of its infrastructure would be taken from existing regional bodies, such as the government regional office, which would become a secretariat. Contrary to Mr Lawry's fears, the aim of the exercise in the north-east was to take powers from central government, rather than local councils.

Mr Biscoe believes that two such bodies could live together in one region, and wants to work with the south west convention to achieve that goal: "There's little point in the south-west convention going to the government knowing that there is dissent over its proposals. And there will be dissent."

The south-west convention's development consultant Mary Southcott argues, however, that Cornwall can only prosper as part of a larger group of counties: "We've tried to say the best way of moving forward is to try and influence the whole region to support Cornwall. It should be accepted as having a vibrant culture and a language some people use, but if we wait and divide our forces we won't get either assembly."

The two sides are currently in discussions aimed at breaking the deadlock, and may commission joint research into how a relatively small area like Cornwall might interact with a larger administrative region.

Whether there will be any real point in conducting the research is another matter. Ministers have yet to decide whether they will allow referendums on English regional government to go ahead. Labour's policy-making body, the National Policy Forum, has called for movement in the issue, and some activists speculate that the government's election manifesto will promise a green or white paper on the regions. Deputy prime minister John Prescott wants the issue back on the agenda, but prime minister Tony Blair is unconvinced that there is any real demand for regional government in England.

The first task for devolution campaigners is to persuade ministers that English devolution could work. If they are unsuccessful, Ms Southcott and the Bishop of Exeter will probably have to wait out at least one more parliamentary term before they have any chance of putting their ideas into practice.

If, however, Mr Blair does decide to go for a green paper, the current politicking of the south-west's factions might one day be looked back on as some of the most important discussions in the region's long history.

webTitle: Cheap and lethal nuclear by-product

fields.headline: Cheap and lethal nuclear by-product
fields.standfirst:
The background: DU weapons

Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Thousands of tonnes of depleted uranium are stored in high security compounds in Britain and other nuclear states with owners having no idea what to do with them. The exact quantity in the UK is an official secret.
fields.body:
Thousands of tonnes of depleted uranium are stored in high security compounds in Britain and other nuclear states with owners having no idea what to do with them. The exact quantity in the UK is an official secret.

Unlike other weapons that cost millions, depleted uranium is free because it is a waste by-product of producing nuclear weapons and has been stockpiled since the 1950s. The big nuclear weapons states, Russia, the US, France and Britain, all use DU in anti-tank weapons.

For the Ministry of Defence the discovery that it could use a waste material as a potent weapon, with 20% better killing power than the expensive alternative tungsten alloy, was a bonus. When a new tungsten-based 120mm tank round developed by BAE Systems and Vickers Defence Systems for the British Army's Challenger 1 and 2 main battle tanks was offered to the MoD last year it was declined, according to the authoritative Jane's Defence Weekly.

It is hard for the military mind to give up a free weapon that works on the unproven grounds it might harm soldiers and civilians after the war is over. The DU is continuing to be produced in large quantities - the unwanted leftover of making fuel for nuclear reactors and of reprocessing spent nuclear fuel to take out the plutonium.

In making fuel from ore the active uranium 235, capable of producing a nuclear reaction, is separated off as fuel and the mildly radioactive "depleted" U238 is stored in giant stockpiles. For every kilogram of nuclear fuel produced there are eight kilograms of waste DU in store at the Capenhurst production plant in Cheshire.

At the other end of the fuel cycle, when the uranium is taken out of reactors and reprocessed at Sellafield in Cumbria for every kilogram of plutonium produced there are 100 kilograms of spent uranium. There are at least 20,000 tonnes of DU in store at Sellafield alone.

Tiny amounts have been used as balancing weights in commercial aircraft such as jumbos and in yacht keels because it is extremely heavy but this is being phased out on safety grounds because of the radioactivity and toxic dangers in case of accident.

The most likely future for unwanted uranium is as nuclear waste - eventually to be dumped in an underground depository. This is especially true of DU recovered from reprocessing plants at Sellafield which is contaminated with other fission products because it has been inside a nuclear reactor.

The discovery in the 1980s that the depleted U238 had properties as a potent armour piercing weapon gave it a new potential value. A series of shells and missiles was developed with DU tips to destroy tanks and other armoured defences. Uranium was also used to shield tanks against attack by conventional armour piercing weapons.

When DU penetrator hits the tank armour both the penetrator and armour partially liquefy under pressure. Once the armour has been perforated that part of the penetrator which has not melted, together with the molten armour and fragments that break away from the interior, ricochet inside the vehicle. This usually causes a fire.

Studies in the US, Britain and France show that when an armoured vehicle burns at about 10,000C, the resulting oxidisation of the materials aboard, including benzene products and depleted uranium, can create particulates that are harmful to the human body; ingested they can affect the lungs and kidneys.

British Nuclear Fuels, which operates MoD reactors at Calder Hall at Sellafield and Chapel Cross in Dumfries, said yesterday that it had supplied DU components to the MoD during the Gulf war but had not done so since. Its DU was safely stored at its plants.

The MoD has consistently refused to disclose its stockpiles of DU but concedes it uses it as an anti-tank weapon "in time of war".

The army fired 88 DU rounds in the Gulf war. None was fired in Kosovo because there was no ground war and because no British aircraft use them.

webTitle: Child abuse pair guilty of Anna murder

fields.headline: Child abuse pair guilty of Anna murder
fields.standfirst:
Analysis: Horrific death of a little girl who longed for a better life

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A woman and her boyfriend were jailed for life today for the murder of an eight-year-old girl who suffered "truly unimaginable" abuse and neglect at their hands.
fields.body:
A woman and her boyfriend were jailed for life today for the murder of an eight-year-old girl who suffered "truly unimaginable" abuse and neglect at their hands.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has ordered a statutory inquiry into the death of Anna Climbie - one of the worst child abuse cases in Britain.

She died at the hands of her great aunt Marie Therese Kouao and Kouao's boyfriend Carl Manning even though police, social workers and hospital staff had been alerted to her plight.

As well as the government inquiry, eight London police officers are facing a police complaints authority probe and a social worker has been suspended pending disciplinary procedures.

The jury in the Old Bailey trial heard harrowing accounts of the tragic life of Anna, who was brought to London by Kouao, a year before she died.

She was tied up in a black plastic bag and made to sleep in a bath for months. She was beaten with a variety of weapons including a bicycle chain and wire coat hanger.

The frail child began to stoop like an old woman, and slowly starved because she was fed leftover scraps "like a dog".

Kouao, 44, and Manning, 28, of Tottenham, north London, stood impassive as the guilty verdicts - by a majority of 10 to two - were delivered on the fifth day of deliberations.

Kouao put her hand over her mouth as she heard the verdicts.

Judge Richard Hawkins said: "What Anna endured was truly unimaginable. She died at both your hands, a lonely drawn out death. I pass the only sentence I am entitled to pass, and that is life imprisonment."

He gave Kouao a 10-year concurrent sentence for child cruelty. Manning was given eight years for child cruelty to run concurrently.

Judge Hawkins said lessons had to be learned "about the failure of social services and police in this case".

A doctor said Anna "felt like a block of ice" when she was taken to hospital. Home Office pathologist Nathaniel Carey said the case was "the worst case of child abuse I have seen".

The little girl, who did not lose her beautiful smile as she hid her suffering from others, died of hypothermia in February last year. She was malnourished and had 128 bruises on her body.

She came to London from Africa via Paris, in search of a better education but never attended a British school.

Bus driver Manning denied murder but admitted manslaughter and child cruelty. He said he was responsibly for only about a third of Anna's injuries and he admitted hitting her over the head with a bicycle chain.

Widowed Kouao, a French citizen, who had three grown up sons in Paris, denied murder, manslaughter and cruelty to Anna at the tiny studio flat the couple shared in Tottenham.

She initially told police the child's condition was caused by witchcraft. In court, she denied all knowledge of cruelty.

The trial, which began on November 20 last year, was frequently interrupted by Kouao's outbursts.

The court was told that Anna was left tied up in the bath sometimes for more than 24-hours. One woman claimed Kouao told her she left Anna there for "two or three days".

And in a chilling confession read in court, Manning told police: "You could beat her and she would not cry at all. She could take the beatings and pain like anything."

In Paris, a girl named Christelle was subject of guardianship proceedings in 1993.

Prison after details of Anna's horrific death were made public. Anna's parents, Berthe Ehouri, 40, and Francis Climbie, left their six other children in their shanty town home in the Ivory Coast to attend court. Mrs Ehouri also testified during the trial.

"She left the Ivory Coast a lovely child full of hope and love."

But by the time Anna reached Britain in the spring of 1999 with Kouao, she had become doubly incontinent due to the "emotional abuse" she subjected her to.

After joining Manning, Anna had become an inconvenience to them and was repeatedly beaten with an array of weapons.

"By her death, she was covered from head to toe in injuries," the judge said.

webTitle: Style: Trousers through the ages

fields.headline: Remembrance of pants past
fields.standfirst: Hadley Freeman looks back at the way we wore
fields.trailText: Hadley Freeman looks back at the way we wore.
fields.body:
Even more than party plans and post-party diets (or "detoxes"), lists mark the start of a new year. Every January, Nick Hornby-like, we pore over lists of record singles from last year, television shows of last year, memorable quotations from last year, indulging in Proustian reminiscences - albeit ones prompted by Moby rather than madeleines.

Studies of the history of fashion are a little different. To look back at the clothing we have worn has more of a sociological bent than the sentimental debates on whether East 17 had the Christmas number one spot in 1994 or 1995. They also reveal the wonderful fluidity of taste: what was once the mass-market norm now seems odd and mannered. To look back at trends from the past is like being a spectator in the crowd when the little boy revealed the truth about the emperor's new clothes.

On the most superficial level, what we wear is prompted by aesthetic preferences. But fashion is also shaped by much larger external events, such as technology (the invention of the car, for example, led to trousers being cut narrow for ease of access to the pedals), religious beliefs (rules regarding modesty and respect) and even wars (rationing of fabric leads to simpler styles). Fashion trends also emerge as a reaction to the present climate: the romantic, 19th century-inspired New Look of the 40s and 50s was a style rebellion against the strictures imposed in wartime, as well as a sepia-hued return to a prewar era.

Obviously, pop culture plays a big part in the shaping of fashion, as anyone wearing a Madonna-inspired ripped T-shirt would admit. Nolan Miller's costumes for Dynasty so successfully captured the zeitgeist and became so popular that the shoulder-padded power suit has become a stylistic shorthand for the 80s as a whole. That this look was copied by so many women at the time reflects both the aspirational "Greed is Good" ethos of the decade and the increasing prominence of women in the workplace and their desire to be seen as a formidable presence there.

To mark the end of the 20th century, Dockers have designed The Century Pants Collection, 10 pairs of khaki trousers for men and women, representing each decade. From the 1910s, the women's khakis are cropped knickerbockers; for the 30s, they have feminine billowing pleats, as though apologetically trying to look like a skirt; the 70s are inevitably represented by flares and the 90s are symbolised by the already anachronistic looking combat pocket.

It would be a cliché, and untrue, to say that you could get away with wearing many of these khakis today. (Anyway, the collection is purely for publicity purposes and not for sale.) It is more correct to say that these trousers provide a sartorial record of the 20th century, particularly of the changing place of women in society.

Women's fashion is a vivid palette of sociological influences, partly because fashion was one of the few forms of expression open to women until a few decades ago. The Elizabethan fashion for nightmarishly impractical and painful hoopskirts and corsets demonstrates what were considered to be a woman's main concerns and purposes: to attract a husband (by showing off her family's wealth through the layers of fabric and detailing) and to bear children (by exaggerating the size of her hips and bust). That these stylish enticements often risked damaging the woman's health speaks further about the value placed on the woman as an object rather than an individual.

The adoption of trousers by women last century is a nicely visual way to chart their changing role. Vogue first mentioned women's trousers in 1911 and debated whether they were "audacious" or "coquettish". The Daily Express had no such qualms and raged over Elsa Schiaparelli's women's trousers: "If any woman dares to appear at Wimbledon in that divided skirt, she should be roundly beaten."

But theirs was a losing battle. With the onset of war and women's entry into the workplace, as well as the rationing of fabric and the rise of motoring and recreational athletics, women wearing trousers was an inevitability. Chanel in the 20s and Yves Saint Laurent in the 60s made them androgynous and sexy. To use a phrase beloved of students of gender, the old divides between the sexes became blurred, leading to the mid-century feminist movement.

Fashion is meant to be fun. But this does not mean it should be seen simply as an irrelevant indulgence. Movements in fashion chart our changing self-perception and indicate what prompts such developments. Retrospectives of what we once wore are retrospectives of the times we lived in and how we responded to them.

webTitle: Style: Jess Cartner-Morley on sales

fields.headline: Cool customers
fields.standfirst: Off to the sales? Ignore trends and go for elegant classics, says  Jess Cartner-Morley
fields.trailText: Off to the sales? Ignore trends and go for elegant classics, says Jess Cartner-Morley.
fields.body:
Maybe this isn't the best weekend to go shopping. There, I've said it. I'm a traitor to my own cause. But I honestly feel there can be just too many pitfalls at this time of year.

First, if you're honest with yourself, surely you haven't got any money in January, so why are you even thinking about shopping? Second, the dog-end of the sale period brings out the very worst in human nature. Do you really want to put yourself at the mercy of the elbows and umbrellas of bargain-hunters hungry for the blood of whoever took the last size 12? But most importantly, is there much out there you genuinely want to buy?

Don't get me wrong, I love a bargain as much as the next girl. I have cupboards full of Top Shop trophies to prove it. But the sales are full of clothes that look on first glance like unmissable bargains, but reveal themselves on closer inspection (that is, once you've got them home and can't return them) to be perfectly live-without-able, with nothing to distinguish them save the scrawled red writing on the price tag.

The most prominent, easily avoidable type of sale faux-bargain is the Trend That Failed. For example, French Connection currently have rails jammed with knee-length trousers in thick wool. They are practically giving them away. Why they ever thought such a ludicrous garment would be anything other than a total disaster is beyond me - how stupid do they think we are? - and frankly, woollen knickerbockers wouldn't be a bargain if they were free.

Party clothes are a little more complicated. You may find something you genuinely like, but (this being a quiet time of year) find that after hanging in your wardrobe for a few months, it has inexplicably lost that essential shiny-newness essential to dressing up. (Clearly if you are about to set off for a paparazzi-swamped month in Barbados, the above does not apply.)

But let's just say, for argument's sake, that you wake up tomorrow just longing to hit the shops. The answer is to ignore anything too of-the-moment and go for cosy, glamorous, elegant, classic winter clothes like these. It is going to be cold for ages, after all, but you're still going to have to leave the house, so think hats and gloves, coats and tights, cashmere and tweed, with a distinctly grown-up, slightly vintage air. That way, you can pretend you're on a train to Venice when you are actually headed to London Bridge.

Of the high street interpretations of these looks, Oasis have gorgeous fur-collared plum woollen coats reduced to £60, while our new favourite Uth has long, beautifully fitted camel/angora mix trench coats, half-price at £159, and pastel leather gloves with stamped-out daisy pattern at £30, reduced from £60. And it goes without saying that if you can get your hands on a pair of shoes even half as fabulous as these glitter ones by Manolo Blahnik for Clements Ribeiro, you'd be a complete and utter idiot to pass them up.

Maybe shopping isn't such a bad idea. But watch out for those elbows.

webTitle: Sky buys Temptation Island

fields.headline: Sky buys Temptation Island
fields.trailText: 4.15pm update: Sky will gatecrash the launch of Channel 4's E4 by airing US reality show Temptation Island, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Sky One will gatecrash next Thursday's launch of Channel 4 entertainment service E4 by premiering controversial US reality show Temptation Island that night.

The US show will debut on Sky One at 10pm next Thursday, January 18, just two hours after rival channel E4 premieres with a special launch night line-up hosted by Ali G.

Temptation Island, in which couples are stranded on a tropical island where a procession of sexy single men and women try to tempt them into transgressions, has faced a storm of outrage in the US over its allegedly immoral premise.

"It's probably going to be one of the most talked about shows of the year," said a spokesman for Sky One parent BSkyB.

"And Sky One has always been about bringing the most talked about US shows to British audiences."

This comment will be seen as a dig at Channel 4, which a year ago snatched the rights to US hits Friends and ER from Sky One, so that the shows could be shown on E4 when it launched.

TV industry insiders have been waiting to see how Sky One would react to the arrival of E4, which, given Channel 4's entertainment pedigree, is expected to provide fierce competition.

Temptation Island made a successful debut on the Fox network in the US on Wednesday.

The show was up against critically-acclaimed NBC drama West Wing, which will be airing on E4 in the UK.

Although West Wing got more viewers overall, Temptation Island took more viewers in the 18-49 age group, which is the Holy Grail for US advertisers.

BSkyB's largest shareholder, NewsCorp, also owns the Fox network.

webTitle: Leonard to publish e-novel

fields.headline: Elmore Leonard to publish e-novel
fields.trailText: 11am: Veteran crime writer Elmore Leonard is to publish an e-novel, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Veteran crime writer Elmore Leonard has become the second high-profile writer to be seduced by the internet, with plans to release his next thriller on the web.

His forthcoming book, Fire in the Hole, will be available from download specialists Contentville from January 17.

Mr Leonard, who does not own a computer, said he was unperturbed by the prospect of writing for a new medium.

"I don't feel that writing an e-book is at all different than writing a story for publication, apart from the fact that I won't be able to read it," he said.

While the e-book market remains minute, some publishers fear that the new, instant technology will encourage writers to bypass traditional outlets for releasing their work.

But success stories remain thin on the ground. The most notable attempt was by Stephen King, who last year serialised his novel The Plant through his own website.

He suspended the book halfway through after declining sales, but called the experiment 'worthwhile' and intends to try again in the future.

fields.trailText:
On Thursday 11 January Guardian defence expert Richard Norton-Taylor, Malcolm Hooper - emeritus professor of medicinal chemistry at Sunderland University and Terry Gooding of the Gulf War Veterans' association (www.editor.uk-gwvn.desert-storm.com) were live on our talkboards to debate the issues around the depleted uranium controversy.
Special report: Uranium
Liveonline
fields.body:
Read the first part of the debate

caymantinsel
Mark, according to the Italian press, it was a wizard wheeze of those at Sellafield who tout for business to dispose of the world's nuclear waste - what better idea than to turn it into weapons, use them on our enemies (who we've already demonised into perceived subhumanity) and then leave them to clear it up.

MalcolmHooper
caymantinsel- there are 4 major reasons why DU is used 1. It is cheap - provided at low cost or at no cost. There are around 1 million tons of the waste product from the nuclear industry lying around the world. It is intermediate nuclear waste and therefore must be monitored, stored and cannot be buried. A very costly process. Anything to reduce this stockpile and make money is welcome 2. It makes a very powerful weapon. 3. Any advantage to the USA and the UK has been lost by selling it other countries- at least 17 have these weapons including Pakistan/India, Taiwan/China, Egypt/Israel etc BIG BUCKS ARE INVOLVED WAR PROFITEERS (INTERNATIONAL ARMS TRADE) WILL LOSE OUT- PRINCIPALLY THE UK AND USA 4. Clean-up costs are colossal for 69 tons of DU fired at the jefferson proving grounds clean-up was estimated at $4-5 BILLION. the USA did not agree to clean up the Gulf battlefields Malcolm H

silvere
I have some few questions about this affair. First, at this stage the talks seem to be limited between NATO members and whether depleted uranium weapons might be toxic or not. But let's do some "politic-fiction", UN soldiers won't be the only ones to show some health troubles, the civil population might be hit as well. So is it possible to see in the future years Kosovo sue at an International Court (TPI in French) NATO and more precisely America for empoisenement? Secondly I really don't see why the ban on depleted uranium weapons shouldn't pass. I remind some people that not so long ago Europe decided a complete ban on the well-know "farines animales". Why do we have the feeling that every time governements are dealing with lobbies the rule seems to be "Let's do whatever we fancy and if afterwards casualties occur we'll correct some drifts"?

Ian70
Mark, the connection is by no means clear. As a question, several posters have pointed to the effects on the local population. Ibrahim Rugova, the elected leader of the Kosovo Albanians, has stated this; 'the depleted uranium scare is being misused by those who opposed the NATO intervention in the hope that it would lead to the withdrawl of the NATO-led peacekeeping force.' This newspaper also quoted Pleurat Sejdiu, joint head of the Kosovo health department, Sejdiu dismissed the concerns as 'propoganda'. What do they know that we don't?

NortonTaylor
Ian70, Sure the wave of concern in Europe is partly political - the Kosovo bombing was very unpopular in Italy for example. But equally Rugova is making a political point. A more general point - raised by others - we talk about Nato veterans, but what about those - including children - close to DU bombsights - in Bosnia, Kosovo, and Iraq ?

NortonTaylor
Hello,I'm Richard Norton-Taylor, security editor of the Guardian. I'm in no way a scientist but i have been following (and trying to uncover) Government secrecy for many years. I'm here now and look forward to seeing your questions. Keep them coming.

youngphilosopher
Why is depleted uranium used at all in the shells?

NortonTaylor
youngphilosopher, because it's hard and because it's a very cheap product - a byproduct of the nuclear industry. Defence companies have developed tungsten shells but it is more expensive and (say governments) not as efficient. Only 3 nuclear powers - the US, Britain, and France, produce DU-coated weapons.

MalcolmHooper
I would add also that DU is pyrophoric- it catches fire on impact giving rise to intense fires of ~10,000 degrees centigrade the dust cloud produced can contain up to 70% of respirable small particles ~1 mg. A sabot fin round contains 5,350 gm of DU other munitions vary down to 200 gm. We are not dealing with DU coated munitions it is solid 100 % uranium (strictly ~ 99.8% uranium -238 and ~ 0.2% uranium -235) that is used in the munitions. Malcolm

GulfWarVeterans
Good Afternoon everybody , I am now online if you have any questions you wish to ask me. To those of you who do not know me ,I am an ex cposa (chief petty officer-stores accountant) - I joined in 1975 and left (sadly) in june 1999 due to increasing health problems which are now of a chronic nature . To find out more please visit my web-site on www.editor.uk-gwvn.desert-storm.com I look forward to receiving your questions . Best wishes Terry Gooding - Editor UK-GWVN Scottish Area Co-Ordinator Gulf Veterans Association. An Active Member of The SNP.

caymantinsel
Hello Richard, I read today that Robertson's answer to the Italian request for a moratorium was an extremely dismissive and disingenous one - nothing to discuss, there's no war now they they're not currently being used anyway. Is this the seriousness that the government of a member state of Nato can expect when it is mandated by parliament to ask about something that is of concern to its population? How much would you like to bet that next time there is a war, Robertson or his successor'll tell us there's not time for such discussions in time of war?

jamalade
Is there the old first world war "gulf" division between the arrogance of the upper echelons of the army and the humble soldier on the ground; do these people have colleagues in the nulcear industry whom they consulted and were informed that DU's were "safe"; and, will we be sure that these "colleagues" will not be benefitting (esp. financially), in the inevitable clean-up industry that will follow when we are sued?

NortonTaylor
caymantinsel - You remind me of a letter a defence minister - Jeremy Hanley - wrote in 1993. He told the Labour MP, Paul Flynn that the government did not give advice to British troops in the 1991 Gulf war about the dangers of DU weapons because of the 'urgency attached to bringing into service such a critical capability which at the start of the crisis was still under development'. Spellar told MPs on Tuesday that DU weapons were 'ideally suited for kinetic-energy penetration'.

Meatloaf
What is the likelihood of Nato forces having used other types of chemical/toxic weapons in recent conflicts?

NortonTaylor
Meatloaf, The ministry of defence is developing a heat-and-pressure-bomb for urban warfare. Devastating effect on anybody caught up in the blast - said by US researchers to be similar to that of a tactical nuclear bomb.

tamara
What did the army use before DU? Were the old weapons really not very good - as the MoD seems to be saying?

jamalade
Is there a difference between using "weapons of mass destruction" and DUs, that may harm populations for generations to come?

Saramago
DU tipped shells are said to be used for armour piercing. We are told that some 31 000 such shells were used in the Kosovo conflict. In view of the fact that only 13 tanks and perhaps double that of armoured vehicles were destroyed, would you say that DU tipped shells were used for other targets in Kosovo?

NortonTaylor
Saramago, Maybe not intentionally. But they could well have landed on other targets which US pilots thought were the sites of Serb tanks and armour.

Ian70
Very good point. Although of course, APC's and trucks will have been attacked raising the number of targets struck, and the potential exposure. Only 26? The alternative explanation is that a lot of shells are lying around, that missed their targets, that pose no threat to anyone.

NortonTaylor
To all, One of the problems in all this is that history has shown you cannot trust the Ministry of Defence, certainly can't take its assurances at face value. It is not surprising, it has a huge vested interest - not least, in protecting itself against claims for compensation and negligence. (Secrecy and bureaucratic and financial considerations are not, of course, confined to the MoD in Whitehall. The MoD refused even to recognise the existence of a 'Gulf War syndrome' until well after the US agreed there was reason for concern. (Not that the US has been completely open, far from it). There is another point - in complex areas involving scientific research, ministers have to rely on their expert advisers. Too many ministers don't ask the difficult questions.

jsd104
Depleted Uranium is radioactive. Radioactivity is dangerous. QED. The idea that DU is safe, being pedalled by the likes of George Robertson is patently false. He is either a liar, or he is stupid. Of course, it is unfortunate if soldiers from any country have been contaminated by this poison. But they at least could have been expected to have some idea that it was dangerous. But what about the Kosovan Albanians for whom our politicians shed such huge crocodile tears in 1999? Here are some of the reported effects of DU.

Journalist Felicity Arbuthnot visited southern Iraq and reported in 1999 that "Iraq's leukemia rate has leapt 70 percent since the Gulf War". As well as such cancers, she found "an astonishing rise in congenital abnormalities".

She described seeing in one hospital a typical victim, "a baby born an hour ago. "The tiny being made small bleating noises. It had no genitalia, no eyes, nose, tongue, oesophagus or hands. Twisted legs were joined by a thick web of flesh from the knees." She reported that "vegetation in the area shows up to 84 times background radiation". The potential effects on pregnant women are all too obvious. Bosnia has suffered similarly.

After US forces bombed the Ramont Institute near the town of Brataunac in 1995 Yugoslav scientists reported: "There are unusual and unnatural occurrences in vegetation, among animals and human beings. Bizarre, massive illness has affected cows. Rapid hair loss is happening to boys of school age." An official investigation by the United Nations Environment Programme in Kosovo this year confirmed fears of depleted uranium contamination. Head of the programme Pekka Haavisto said, "There remains a risk for the local population. Much ammunition is deep in the ground and affects groundwater."

DU is a weapon of mass destruction and those authorising its use are guilty of war crimes.

Ian70
DU has very low levels of radioactivity, so do many other materials, everywhere has background radioactivity. Everywhere is not dangerous. You have proved nothing.

See my other post to bring some doubt on the role of DU in Iraq.

Quoting official sources from Yugoslavia, prior to October 2000, is even more dangerous than trusting the MOD.

NortonTaylor

Well, I'm off now to hear what the MoD is saying next. Keep at it and thanks for your contributions. My email address is: richard.norton-taylor@theguardian.com Cheerio

webTitle: ASA clears Queercompany.com poster

fields.headline: Watchdog clears Queercompany's lesbian ads
fields.standfirst: Jan 2: Inquiry into lesbian kiss ads
fields.trailText:
4pm: A controversial poster for Queercompany.com featuring two women kissing has been cleared by the ASA, reports Dan Milmo.
Jan 2: Inquiry into lesbian kiss ads
fields.body:
The Advertising Standards Authority has cleared a controversial lesbian poster campaign by Queercompany.com.

The watchdog ruled that the giant poster featuring two women kissing on a bed, which was on display in London's Charing Cross Road, was not sexually explicit and was unlikely to affect children.

Queercompany said that the image was located in the heart of Soho, which is an area with a large gay community, and that the campaign would have a positive impact on children coming to terms with their sexuality.

However, an ASA spokesman said that the authority would launch further investigations when the campaign moves to other sites.

"If we get further complaints about posters going elsewhere, then we will have to look into it. The council will look at the posters if and when the campaign expands," said the spokesman.

A Queercompany spokesman confirmed that the billboard campaign will be launched at 10 other London sites over the weekend, and will be located at major road junctions.

He added that Queercompany, which was "delighted" with the ruling, did not expect the ASA to uphold any further complaints.

The company, which offers financial products and services to the gay and lesbian market, is also launching its male version of the posters this weekend.

The Queercompany poster received 50 complaints from members of the public, although the ASA said in its ruling that "it was clear that many of the complainants had not seen the poster".

On Thursday 11 January Guardian defence expert Richard Norton-Taylor, Malcolm Hooper - emeritus professor of medicinal chemistry at Sunderland University and Terry Gooding of the Gulf War Veterans' association (www.editor.uk-gwvn.desert-storm.com) were live on our talkboards to debate the issues around the depleted uranium controversy.
Special report: Uranium
Liveonline
fields.body:
diva631
Why is so little attention being given to the hapless civilian populations which cannot avoid ongoing exposure to depleted uranium all over their environment? I refer specifically to Iraqis as well as those living in Serbia and Kosovo. It seems that unless a NATO soldier gets ill, there is simply no problem.

GulfWarVeterans
Diva631 I totally agree with you ,a few media articles and programmes have highlighted these very points. It is also worth mentioning the many civilians who assisted our forces in this time of need, the gallant men and women of The Royal Fleet AUX and the many civilian engineers and specialists who assited us testing and maintaing our equipment, one who springs too mind is Paul Connelly, like our campaign more media coverage will quosh public apathy and misunderstanding about this subject.


wilsontown
I have a couple of questions on this. The first thing I want to know is what are the risks of DU ammunition, and are these risks a result of radioactivity or heavy metal toxicity, or a combination of both? Assuming that DU is a problem, how long will areas affected be contaminated for?
Concerns about NATO use of DU ammunition were raised at the time of the Kosovo conflict. Why has it taken so long for this issue to be addressed in any way by the UK government?

MalcolmHooper
At low level of exposure where the material is INSOLUBLE, INTERNALISED, IMMOBILISED following INHALATION into the lung it is the CUMULATIVE radiological dose that is the danger. The toxic metal effects are concentration dependent - generally lower concentration = lower toxicity. But the cumulative radiological toxicity increases with time - eg 1 mg of DU give 12.4 alpha particles and 24.8 beta particles per SECOND. Over 1 year this accumulates to >390 million alpha particles and 780 million beta particles. Some Gulf Veterans have been found to be excreting small amounts of DU 8 years after the Gulf War They have therefore been exposed to an increasing radiological dose vastly in excess of any limits ~8000 times in 1 year according to Leonard Dietz. Alpha particles are 20 times more damaging to tissues when internalised - Malcolm H

Koldo10
I do not want to give any opinion about the toxicity or not of the DU ammunition. I am not an expert and I believe that scientists have the last say. But should this "say" be positive as so far it looks like, should the Iraqi Goverment or Iraqi people be elegible for any kind of compensation? What about the Serbs? These weapons may be the cause of dangerous illness for innocent civilians but... surely and sadly they will not be compensated at all. At the end of the day they are nationals of a defeated "enemy country" so who cares? well I do.

sdmawby
Who was it who first thought of using depleted Uranium in weapons and how did he justify it?

bbobb
DU is like many heavy metals toxic, in that when it is ingested, or inhaled in some gaseous compound is not good for you, but radioactivity is very low (you will find basements in many houses in Cornwall are far worse). It should be noted that lead when vaporised in a collision as a high velocity projectile, forms compounds which are not particulary good for you (lead paint, pipes, petrol). Maybe we should also ban lead as a projectile in ammunition.

inks
Could exposure to DU produce the symptoms that appear to constitute "Gulf War syndrome"? It was certainly mentioned at the time, along with organophosphates and anti-nerve gas pills.
Are these symptoms similar to the illnesses affecting Balkan war veterans?
I understood that the UK did not use DU at the time of the Gulf War, instead we had anti-tank weapons that exploded a lump of explosive on the outside of the tank shell to kill the crew.

If so, when did we change to using DU ammunition?

Does DU have any other applications? Is it used commercially?

Is the manufacture of DU ammunition a convenient way of disposing of radioactive waste?

NortonTaylor
Inks, in reply to your last question, yes, though not sure 'convenient' is quite the right word. A Nato spokesman proudly said yesterday it is also used in airlines and in boat keels.

damngoodraddle
A Nato spokesman proudly said yesterday it is also used in airlines where the risks have long been known by the US Federal Aviation Administration.

U.S. FAA Advisory Circular No. 20-123: Avoiding Or Minimizing Encounters With Aircraft Equipped With Depleted Uranium Balance Weights During Accident Investigations , Dec. 20, 1984

http://www.faa.gov/fsdo/orl/files/ADVCIR/ac20-123.asc (it's a text file - open with notepad or somesuch )

some studies following crashes: Risk analysis of depleted uranium following an aircraft crash http://www.cyclone.nl/bijlmer/bijlmer.htm

MalcolmHooper
Yes- but the situation is complicated by the presence of other toxins on the battlefield that can also cause cancers, and other chronic illnesses including 1. vaccines given incorrectly or without proper research - this happened with anthrax/pertussis. 2. organophosphate and other pesticides. 3. oil and smoke from the fires. 4. chemical war agents - nerve agents and mustard gases. 5 use of pyridostigmine bromide as a prophyllactic against Soman nerve gas. - Malcolm H

zoestec
I too am very puzzled about what exactly the problem is. One man was reported to have everything wrong bar his leg falling off the other day,and not all the symptoms sounded like radiation sickness or leukaemia. Surely the fact that it is a heavy metal can partly account for some of the symptoms? Why was a metal with a long half-life chosen? Was it traded off for a low radiation emission metal? That means that the indigenous people will have to put up with long exposure to low doses. Nice! That is quite an effective way to get leukaemia some people believe...

Adira
Hapless civilians indeed! I saw the John Pilger documentary about Iraq a couple of months ago, and a number of doctors there have noticed that cancer rates have greatly increased since the Gulf War. Of course sanctions mean that there is no way of treating these cancer patients properly...

Amazonas
When one takes into account the little regard that these governments have for their own forces, it becomes all too apparent just how little thought the plight of innocent civilians occupies in their minds. Of course, there is nothing new in this attitude, as we know from the cases of Iraq and Vietnam to mention a few.

Hence, in the statement made to Parliament yesterday by the Secretary of State for Defence, reference of the risks to civilian populations exposed to this type of contamination was only made superficially. Not surprisingly, the likelihood that these civilian populations get the treatment and care they need and deserve is what it has always been - zero.

mwm24
Journalists should speak to Doug Rokke, professor of environmental engineering and nuclear physics at Jacksonville State University, Alabama, USA. Rokke was the head of the US Army Theatre DU Assessment Team in the Gulf and was recalled to active duty in the US Army as DU Project Director. He has a 1943 Memorandum from the Manhattan Project to Brigadier General Groves discussing the use of DU as a terrain contaminant, a gas warfare instrument for inhalation amd a contaminator of the environment. Rokke has become a major campaigner against DU after seeing the men of his team sick and die, the US government refuse to circulate the reports he himself wrote. Rokke spoke in the conference of the Cambridge Campaign against Sanctions in Iraq last year (see website http://welcome.to/CASI) and, by his honour, knowledge and Southern American religiosity, reduced the audience to tears.

csemmens
I have two contributions to make to this debate:

I hear the distinction being made between the "radiation hazard" and the "toxic hazard".There is some potential for confusion here and I would like you to make things clearer for everyone.

When the uranium is outside the body, any radiation only impinges upon the body while it is close to the source of the radiation. Assuming this is only for a short time, the total damage caused by the radiation will be small. In addition, external radiation is attenuated by passage through any clothing and skin, before reaching live cells. In the case of alpha radiation, this attenuation is significant.

Once swallowed or inhaled, the uranium may remain in the body for much longer periods of time. This increases the time during which damage can be caused, and also increases the proportion of radiation that reaches live cells - very substantially in the case of alpha radiation. This can be described as internal contamination with radioactive material.

webTitle: Letsbuyit shares soar

fields.headline: Letsbuyit shares soar
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Letsbuyit.com could be set for a miraculous escape from the clutches of liquidators. By Dan Milmo
fields.body:
Shares in Letsbuyit.com have soared as the online retailer looks set for a miraculous escape from the clutches of liquidators.

The stock rocketed 103% to E0.52 (33p) in Frankfurt after French rival Dealpartners.com said it was in "exploratory" talks with the stricken company's administrators.

Letsbuyit's Amsterdam-based administrators refused to comment on speculation that an agreement was imminent.

Dealpartners offers a similar service to Letsbuyit by grouping customers together to secure low prices for electrical goods.

Letsbuyit needs £50m to stay afloat and has been given protection from restless creditors until March 14.

Analysts said Letsbuyit will attract attention from acquisitive companies because of its vulnerable position, but it will take a Herculean effort to turn the company around.

It has been a spectacular fall from grace for the pan-European company, which raised £39m from its July flotation but now has just £11m left in the bank after costly ad campaigns featuring groups of computer-generated ants.

Chief executive Martin Coles and other members of the company's management jumped ship last week, leaving the administrators to co-ordinate a rescue.

UK retailer Kingfisher and mail order group Great Universal Stores had also been linked with Letsbuyit, but their interest has since cooled.

webTitle: Oxford dons go quackers

fields.headline: Oxford dons go quackers
fields.trailText: On Sunday night more than 100 very clever Oxford dons will be parading around a college quad behind a duck on a pole, singing "It was a swapping, swapping mallard".
fields.body:
On Sunday night more than 100 very clever Oxford dons will be parading around a college quad behind a duck on a pole, singing "It was a swapping, swapping mallard".

The Mallard ceremony is a once in a century event at All Souls, a college which has 75 fellows but no students. In a ceremony dating from the 17th century a torchlit procession carries the Lord Mallard shoulder high on a chair on a route which takes in the college roofs while he sings the Mallard song and they join in the chorus.

Former fellows of the college, including former Tory minister John Redwood, have also been invited and in total 118 (including women!) are expected to attend. The public are not admitted although they may not be able to avoid the singing.

The revels will be less rowdy than they were in the old days, according to the present Lord Mallard, Martin West. A senior classics research fellow, he has penned some new verses to add to the song which, he promises, will be a surprise for everyone.

Under Cromwell's rule it was reported that the Mallard song was sung "after a rude manner about 2 or 3 in ye morning, which giving great alarm to ye Oliverian soldiery then in Oxon they would have forced ye gate open to have appeased ye noise."

The procession lapsed in the 18th century but was revived in 1801 to celebrate the new century and the event was repeated on 14th January 1901. On that occasion Cosmo Gordon Lang, the future archbishop of Canterbury, was Lord Mallard.

The procession is centennial but the song itself which dates from about 1660 and is still sung twice a year. It starts: The Griffine, Bustard, Turkey & Capon Lett other hungry Mortalls gape on And on theire bones with Stomacks fall hard, But lett Allsouls' Men have ye Mallard. Hough the bloud of King Edward, by ye bloud of King Edward, It was a swapping, swapping mallard!

One verse was "expunged on grounds of decency in 1821". Hee was swapping all from bill to eye, Hee was swapping all from wing to Thigh; His swapping tool of Generation oute swapped all ye wingged Nation.

The mallard has been the totem of the College of All Souls of the Faithful Departed founded by Henry VI and Henry Chichele, archbishop of Canterbury. According to legend a giant mallard flew out of a drain when workmen were digging the foundations in 1437.

webTitle: Departing GMTV chief Stoddart interviewed

fields.headline: Stoddart looking to leave GMTV 'for past two years'
fields.standfirst:
Jan 12: Former execs tipped for GMTV job
Jan 12: Stoddart quits GMTV
fields.trailText:
3.45pm update: Christopher Stoddart revealed today that he has been "looking for the right opportunity" outside GMTV for the past two years, writes Jason Deans.
Jan 12: Former execs tipped for GMTV job
Jan 12: Stoddart quits GMTV
fields.body:
Christopher Stoddart revealed today that he has been "looking for the right opportunity" outside GMTV for the past two years.

Mr Stoddart, who is leaving in May to become chief executive of TV horseracing consortium Go Racing, said he "had had previous opportunities to move", but turned them down.

He added: "I decided I had to stay and see GMTV into profitability. But since the licence renewal I have been looking for the right opportunity."

Mr Stoddart joined GMTV in 1992 before it launched. Of the broadcaster's troubled early years, he said: "At the beginning there was a lot more competition more quickly than we could have contemplated. But we got through that quite quickly."

He added that he had enjoyed the buzz of being with a live TV outfit, with a "team working hard to bring fresh stories and features to viewers each day".

Commercially, Mr Stoddart said securing the licence renewal had been a high point.

He said that he was also proud that so many GMTV staff had stayed with the station so long. "Something like 50 staff out of 250 have been here since 1993."

Fittingly, the November 1998 renewal of GMTV's broadcasting licence by the Independent Television Commission is regarded as the greatest achievement of Mr Stoddart's tenure at the firm.

For the new licence came with a £30m reduction in the £50m annual licence payment to the Treasury that nearly sank GMTV after it went on air on January 1 1993.

In those early years the breakfast broadcaster lost money and was criticised by the ITC fine over the poor quality of its programming.

Mr Stoddart has since guided the company into calmer financial and editorial waters. GMTV broke even in 1995 and in 2000 posted 20% year-on-year increase in profit before tax to £7.6m.

fields.standfirst: Visit World dispatch now
fields.trailText: World dispatch is a Guardian Unlimited feature devoted to daily foreign news, analysis and comment, exclusive to the site. fields.body:
World dispatch is a Guardian Unlimited feature devoted to daily foreign news, analysis and comment, exclusive to the site. Every weekday our outstanding network of foreign correspondents file dispatches providing new angles on international news stories, directly from the centre of the action.

You'll find in-depth analysis, background and new perspectives on the big stories making the news around the world, as well as fascinating reports on events and issues that don't reach the British press.

Our team of experts in bureaux around the world includes Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles, John Gittings in China, Luke Harding in New Delhi and Chris McGreal in South Africa. John Hooper writes from Berlin, Jon Henley from Paris, and Martin Kettle from Washington.

Recent dispatches include Ian Black's analysis of the EU summit in Nice (read it here), and a moving article by our Jerusalem correspondent, Suzanne Goldenberg, about a row over olive picking in her own backyard that provides a microcosm of the whole Arab-Israeli dispute (read it here). You'll also find Michael Ellison's report on the New York jazz revival here and Ian Traynor's profile of President Vladimir Putin, Russia's unlikely sex symbol here.

If you want to read more, all our dispatches provide quick, easy links to related websites and to more articles by our foreign correspondents. You can read our correspondents' biographies here. You can even mail your views on an article to the person who wrote it.

So to ensure you're always well informed on international news, bookmark this page and visit it regularly.

webTitle: Horrific death of a little girl who hoped for a better life

fields.headline: Horrific death of a little girl who hoped for a better life
fields.standfirst:
Eight-year-old Anna Climbie came to Britain to get a good education but she was killed by her great aunt under the nose of child protection officials, writes Audrey Gillan

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Eight-year-old Anna Climbie came to Britain to get a good education but she was killed by her great aunt under the nose of child protection officials, writes Audrey Gillan.
fields.body:
When Anna Climbie left the crumbling shacks of the sprawling shanty suburb of Abobo on the Ivory Coast in November 1997 she was "happy and excited". She was going to a new life with her great aunt.

The seven-year-old was leaving home for a better education and standard of living, leaving a country with a low life expectancy and where only 40% of women over 15 can read and write.

To her mother and father, the move would bring a great honour on the family and eventually Anna might earn money and send some back to them.

But instead of honour the family found only grief. Anna never got an education, because she didn't even get to go to school. Just over a year after leaving the Ivory Coast, she was dead.

The victim of horrendous physical and emotional abuse, she was failed by all those who were bound up in her care. Her death, in February of last year, was "the worst case of child abuse" the home office pathologist who examined her battered body had ever seen.

Just eight years old when she died, Anna's last long months were a tortuous, savage existence. She was bound hand and foot, naked in a bathtub in a tiny flat in Tottenham in the middle of winter, starved and told she was possessed by the devil.

Anna simply got in the way of her demented aunt Marie Therese Kouao - a woman the Old Bailey was told was "evil" - and her bus driver boyfriend Carl Manning who she picked up on a number 18 bus in Wembley. She was not the meal ticket to social security benefits her devious aunt had first thought.

Over months Anna was beaten, burned with cigarettes and had boiling water poured over her head. She "stooped like an old woman" after being confined to the bath. After all this, she was dragged to a church to be exorcised because her aunt said she had evil spirits in her.

And all the while those who should have been concerned with her welfare - doctors, police and social services - let Anna down.

In spite of being referred to social services on a number of occasions, no one ever checked on her properly. In spite of the marks on her body the child was returned to Kouao because a doctor believed her story that Anna had scabies.

Two police protection orders were taken out on the child in July 1999 but nothing was done and a social services strategy meeting decided a home visit should be conducted but it never was because the social worker and police officer were too scared of catching scabies.

Eventually, this small child (people remarked that she was half the size she should have been for her age) died from hypothermia due to exposure to cold and wet conditions. The underlying cause was severe neglect and malnutrition.

Pathologist Dr Nathaniel Carey found 128 marks on her body. He said: "This little girl was covered in scars. All cases of child abuse leading to death are pretty horrific but this one, in nature and extent of injury, is quite exceptional."

It will be some time before Anna's body will be allowed to return home. A coup in the Ivory Coast has prevented her parents from coming to the UK to hear the jury's verdict and to take their daughter home. Instead, Anna must wait a while more in a country that failed her terribly, a place which for this child proved less safe than her own trouble-torn country.
