The Church charged incumbents a kind of levy for propping up its crumbling real estate and those five syllables were the key. If only Grandfather could cut down on the dilapidations there'd be a new dawn of amenity and comfort, and possibly some change left over. Leaks, dry rot, broken panes and crazy hinges (of which we had plenty) were, looked at rightly, a potential source of income. Whether he ever succeeded I don't know. Since the word went on and on, he can't have got more than a small rebate and no one ever plugged the leaks. What's certain is that we were frequently penniless and there were always embarrassments about credit. Food rationing and clothes coupons must have been a godsend since they provided a cover for our indigence. As long as austerity lasted, the vicarage could maintain its shaky claims to gentility. There was virtue in shabbiness. Grandfather had his rusty cassock, Grandmother her mothballed wardrobe and my mother had one or two pre-war outfits that just about served. Underwear was yellowed and full of holes, minus elastic. Indoors, our top layers were ragged too: matted jumpers, socks and stockings laddered and in wrinkles round the ankles, safety pins galore. Outside we could pass muster, even if my overcoat was at first too big (I would grow into it), then all at once too small, without ever for a moment being the right size. In those years almost the whole country wore this ill-fitting uniform designed for non-combatants - serviceable colours, grating textures, tell-tale unfaded hems that had been let down, bulky tucks. Our true household craziness and indifference didn't express itself in clothes, but in more intimate kinds of squalor: for instance, nearly never washing the bits no one could see. This was almost a point of vicarage principle, a measure of our hostility to the world outside and separateness from it. Inside our clothes civilisation had lapsed. And this wasn't to do with money. Grandma had the scented soap, but she didn't use it - she bought it for its smell, and kept it wrapped in tissue paper in drawers and trunks. Her line was that her skin was too sensitive for soap and water. We even had a bathroom, but somehow the only way to wash was to boil the kettle and fill a bowl, and do bits - very little bits and usually the same bits - at a time. The resulting tidemarks, in my case round my neck, wrists and legs, would be desperately scrubbed at from time to time. Hair was another problem, a tangle of troubles: brushing was usually felt to be enough of a trauma, without the business of tangling it up all over again with washing, so that my pigtails stayed plaited for days on end. Our secret grubbiness was yet another thing that set us apart. If other children were dirty, that meant they were common, their parents were foully neglectful and slummy, you could catch things from them. One of Grandma's favourite terms of abuse, in fact, was 'dirty' - villagers were dirty, callers were dirty, I mustn't play with dirty children. So there were two different kinds of dirt, theirs and ours. It was a most metaphysical distinction, as befitted the vicarage. As if to demonstrate the point, next door to us, also fronting on to the square, was a sixteenth-century tumbledown timber and brick cottage crammed with children I wasn't supposed to mix with - the Duckets, one of Hanmer's most shameless tribes. The wall that divided us from them provided me with a perch from which I could look down into their back garden. Our side had a lawn with borders and apple trees, and was neglected and overgrown and peaceful. Theirs was like a bomb-site, a muddy, cratered expanse with twisted pieces of old prams and bike frames, and shards of crockery embedded among straggly weeds and currant bushes. The Duckets epitomised what my grandmother meant by 'dirty': they were openly poor (the father was a farm labourer), they bred like rabbits and they spilled out of their house wearing their ragged hand-me-downs for all to see. The vicarage was a secret slum, but the Duckets' doors were always open, so you could see Mrs Ducket with her hair in curlers running about bare-legged in slippers, or - even more scandalously - sitting down with a cup of tea and a fag. They had no secrets. Their kitchen drain (on the opposite side to us) disgorged a slow stream of soapy slime and tea-leaves into the open gutter that ran along the main village street. The Duckets kept yappy dogs and skinny cats, and had kittens and ferrets in their pockets; they didn't go to church, although sometimes one or two of the children would be spruced up and sent to Sunday School. While I was forbidden the square, they were positively driven out of their house, back and front, in all weathers, clutching wedges of bread and damson jam. They reached over our wall and picked the apples, according to Grandma. And (the crowning horror) they had bugs in their hair. The Duckets made me feel lonely. Even the bugs were more fascinating than frightening. Once or twice I managed to 'play' with Edna, the girl nearest to my own age, through the crack in our side gate. She squatted in the square, I squatted in the vicarage kitchen yard; I squeezed my dolls through the gap one by one for her to look at and she squeezed them back. But otherwise I'd climb the wall and sit astride, watching Duckets in the plural, whenever I was left to my own devices. Which wasn't often. Grandpa and I must have pottered about in church almost every day, and the echoing spaces, the stained glass and the smell of Brasso, chrysanthemums, damp pew-oak and iron mould from the choir's surplices were heady compensations for isolation. He'd tell me stories and read me to sleep at night, when he'd often drop off first, stretched out on the couch, mouth open, snoring, his beaky profile lit up by the candle. In fact, he got so impatient with my favourite books (which both he and I knew by heart) that one momentous day, before I was four, he taught me to read in self-defence. This confirmed me as his creature. I knew my name came out of one of the blacked-out books - Lorna from Lorna Doone - and that he'd chosen it. Now he'd given me a special key to his world. We were even closer allies afterwards, so that when he took me with him in the rattling Singer to Whitchurch, and into the bar of the Fox and Goose down Green End, it never occurred to me to tell on him. There were several expeditions like that. He was well known in drinking circles and was looked on as something of a speciality act, a cynical and colourful talker, always with his dog-collar to set him apart. I was the perfect alibi, since neither my mother nor my grandmother had any idea that there were pubs so low and lawless that they would turn a blind eye to children. Few were willing to, however; and there were other times when I found myself sitting outside on the steps of one of his favourite haunts, an unfriendly place with a revolving door called the Lord Hill, in the company of streetwise kids a lot more scary than the Duckets. Perhaps I did tell about that, or perhaps someone spotted me: at any rate, the pub outings came to an end. Not the collusion, though. I'd kneel on the threadbare rug in his study while he worked on his sermon, or talked to the odd visitor, pulling out the books and puzzling over big words. Sometimes he'd show off my reading to strangers, but for the most part I was meant (this was the point of it, after all) to be quiet. When he was in very good moods he would draw pictures for me, starting mysteriously from the vanishing point and drawing out the rest into perspective. I learned that trick too, never very well, but well enough to disconcert people. Our mutual 'minding' turned by untidy stages into a sort of education. Since he was a man of many wasted talents, not only with words and images but also music, I might have had a full set of pre-school 'accomplishments', except that I was tone-deaf. Despite that, I was made a member of the choir as soon as I could sit still long enough - under strict instructions to open and shut my mouth in silence, along with the words. I was quite useful, in fact: I could be shifted across from the girls' bench to the boys' (my pigtails bundled up into my cap) depending on where there were the most gaps. Watching Grandpa dress up in the vestry, processing behind him, listening to him intone the liturgy and preach, I basked in his reflected glory. I took to lining up my toys in a corner of the garden I called 'the secondary school', where I lectured them and told them stories. More than once they got left out overnight and were brought in sodden in the morning, to be dried out in the oven of the kitchen range. My teddy, a utility bear with a flabby square stomach made out of flowered cotton, was scorched ever after. An omen there. I was going to have to go to school soon and that meant the village school, which would make nonsense of the dirt distinction, and - as it turned out - leave scorch-marks on my spoiled soul too. There was some reluctance to send me there sooner than need be, but the temptation must have become irresistible. When Grandpa was out, or hung-over, or not in the mood, I would wander the house in an ecstasy of self-pity, wailing 'What can I do-o-o?' over and over again, tears dripping down. This was my own precocious contribution to the economy of frustration and want, and nobody could stand it. If the day was fine, Grandma might take me out into the garden, where we'd exorcise my misery by attacking the brambles and nettles with sharp scissors, pretending they were Grandpa, or Duckets, or other people on her hit list ('Ugh! Nasty old thing! Wicked old devil!'). She got even more fun out of this than I did, but she often didn't feel energetic enough for such games. So at four and a bit I went to school, and the whole village gave a shake and rearranged itself. I got bugs in my hair and started to lead a double life: one of the many - Hanmer school had a hundred-odd pupils, aged four to fourteen, in 1947 - and yet the sole vicarage child. I put about the story that you could play in the churchyard if you played with me.

webTitle: Hopes for Middle East peace in Clinton's final hours

fields.headline: Hopes for Middle East peace in Clinton's final hours
fields.trailText: An extraordinary new mood of urgency has gripped Israeli and Palestinian negotiators in their last-ditch attempt to cobble together a peace settlement before President Bill Clinton leaves the White House.
fields.body:
An extraordinary new mood of urgency has gripped Israeli and Palestinian negotiators in their last-ditch attempt to cobble together a peace settlement before President Bill Clinton leaves the White House.

Prodded along by CIA chief George Tenet, senior military officers on both sides are cooperating again to reduce friction on the front line, bloodied by 16 weeks of violent confrontation. With the tension palpably easing, Israel has begun to relax its blockade of the Palestinian territories.

Meanwhile, the main focus of attention has shifted, abruptly, from the drama of the intifada (uprising) to the latest high-pressure talks at the Erez checkpoint, on Israel's border with the Gaza Strip.

Top-flight officials are trying to smooth the last wrinkles from Clinton's hotly controversial blueprint for a final settlement which would give the Palestinians a state of their own. Crucial differences of interpretation remain, and there is an inevitable last-minute haggle over territory.

But after months of bitter recrimination and bloodshed - indeed, after some eight weary years of negotiation - there is a very real chance this weekend that Israel and the Palestinians will hammer out the outline of their new permanent relationship.

Although both sides are cautiously avoiding talk of a breakthrough, there is intense speculation that Shimon Peres and Yasser Arafat, the two main architects of the peace process, are preparing for a decisive meeting on Sunday.

That will leave just a week before Clinton steps down. Yet even now, there is talk of a three-way summit, in Washington or in Egypt, at which the outgoing president will finally grasp the diplomatic prize for which he has always lusted.

Whatever happens will not be definitive. That's not the way they do things in the Middle East. But it could carry the region far beyond the state of perpetual negotiation in which it has been mired for so many years.

In essence, the talks are about settling the main issues and leaving the final detail for later - exactly the reverse of the so-called Oslo agreement which kicked off the peace process in the early 1990s. Then, the two sides reached a deal only by ignoring all the truly big issues. Now, they have at last addressed those issues, and are tantalisingly close to a final treaty.

The essence of the Clinton formula is the creation of a Palestinian sovereign state in the Gaza Strip, and roughly 95% of the West Bank. Both territories have been militarily occupied by Israel since the Six Day War of 1967, though in recent years Arafat has been in charge of steadily increasing chunks of territory.

Now, he is within reach of his coveted goal of establishing a Palestinian capital in Jerusalem, which Clinton insists must be divided again into its Jewish and Arab component parts.

That is the single most painful part of the emerging agreement for Israelis and indeed for the Jewish diaspora. They have an almost mystic regard for Jerusalem as their own eternal and undivided capital, and the proposal to divide the city has deeply shocked them.

For Palestinians, the most emotional issue is the fate of their own diaspora: the 4m refugees and their descendants who have fled or been herded out of the old Palestine since the establishment of Israel in 1948.

Arafat and his negotiators have long insisted that any true peace must include a right of return. That phrase has become almost a mantra - and might well remain just that, according to rumours seeping out of the latest talks.

It seems that the Palestinians are still adamant that Israel must recognise the rights and grievances of the refugees - but not to the extent of allowing more than a token trickle of them to return to their homes in Israel proper. They will, however, have an unqualified right to settle in the new Palestine.

As with any delicate negotiation, emotions get ragged and the rhetoric more shrill as the talks reach a climax. Dozens of outstanding issues, large and small, could still send the process skidding off-track. But driving the negotiators on is a growing awareness of two looming deadlines.

One is just eight days away, when US foreign policy under President George W Bush is likely to take an entirely new direction. The second is on February 6, when Israeli voters choose a new prime minister. All the polls point to a victory for Ariel Sharon, a far-rightwinger who has warned that he will not honour any agreement which, in his view, compromises Israel's security or its 'right' to colonise the West Bank with Jewish settlements.

Sharon does not issue threats lightly. He is a genuine hawk, through and through. But if a final settlement emerges in coming days and is duly blessed by Washington, even he will find it hard to revoke. That reality adds new urgency to the current talks, and new hope that Israel and a new Palestine will at last be neighbours, not enemies.

webTitle: Ursula Andress's Bond bikini up for auction

fields.headline: Ursula Andress's Bond bikini up for auction
fields.trailText: The legendary swimsuit which launched the Swiss star to stardom in the first James Bond film is expected to sell for £50,000 when it is auctioned in London next month
fields.body:
One of the most famous bikinis in movie history is set to make a fortune for the woman it helped turn into a star. Ursula Andress is selling the famous two-piece she wore as she emerged from the sea dripping wet in the 1962 film, Dr No, the first entry in what was to become the most profitable movie series of all time, James Bond.

The actress, cast in the film as Honey Rider, helped design the costume from her own bra. The bikini could become the most expensive in the world when it is auctioned in London next month as it is likely to sell for £50,000 or more.

According to Ananova, the James Bond series is also in the news after claims that US President Bill Clinton has been asked to star in the next film in the 007 series. Producers are said to have offered the US President a cameo role when he leaves office in a few days time. The scene in which he may appear involves Bond attending a reception at the White House with Clinton playing the President

The President - whose stay at the White House ends in a matter of days - is said to be fascinated by the idea of doing a "Reagan-in-reverse" - that is stepping into movies after being in the White House. Some might say that Clinton has always been a good performer and is at his best in front of a camera.

webTitle: Study claims MMR vaccination is safe

fields.headline: Study claims MMR vaccination is safe
fields.trailText: The largest study of the controversial MMR vaccination ever undertaken has ruled out any link to other conditions in children, it was reported today.
fields.body:
The largest study of the controversial MMR vaccination ever undertaken has ruled out any link to other conditions in children, it was reported today.

The research, revealed on the same day a study highlighted widespread concerns with MMR among British health professionals, will be welcomed by campaigners concerned about falling immunisation levels in the UK and the risk of a measles outbreak.

Finnish researchers followed up three million doses of the vaccination against measles, mumps and rubella and found no link to cases of autism and serious bowel disorders.

Previous studies have suggested a possible link between MMR and these conditions although supporters claim the vast majority of research has given MMR a clean bill of health.

With MMR, children are a given a combined jab against measles, mumps and rubella at 12 to 15 months and a second booster dose at between three and five years old.

Because of the concerns, opponents of MMR, including Tory MP Julie Kirkbride, want children to be immunised separately against the three diseases.

Around 2,000 families in Britain have taken legal action claiming their children have been damaged by the MMR jab, with many believing it has triggered autism.

The Finnish research will bolster claims by health officials in the UK that the single doses are unnecessary and costly.

However, another study, published today in the British Medical Journal, suggests that many health professionals in the UK are yet to be totally convinced that MMR is entirely risk free.

The survey found that nearly half of family doctors, health visitors and practice nurses have reservations about giving children their second dose of the MMR vaccination.

Almost one in five GPs had not read official advice about the combined jab and 46% said they wanted more information and training. Up to a third of nurses believe the triple vaccine is linked to serious adverse side effects such as Crohn's disease and autism.

The study was published a week after government experts warned that the UK was at risk of a potentially fatal outbreak of measles because immunisation levels had dropped dramatically.

Public fears that the vaccine could be linked to autism and Crohn's disease have led to thousands of parents refusing to have their children vaccinated.

Immunisation levels in some parts of the country have fallen to as low as 75%, way below the World Health Organisation threshold of 95% needed to guarantee so-called "herd immunity" for the whole population.

Doctors' own concerns about the jab may be exacerbating the worrying fall in immunisation levels, the study authors said. One doctor said: "I personally will not let my children have their second MMR but I don't influence parents in any way.

"I would be frightened to urge parents to have the second MMR in case there were problems afterwards. I would not want anyone to blame me for persuading them."

A Department of Health spokesman said that in the study, which he said was carried out more than two years ago, GPs were not questioning the giving of the MMR vaccine.

The study highlighted that some health professionals lacked awareness of up-to-date information on the rationale for the second dose of MMR, he said.

"It is important for health professionals to keep up to date with all of the available scientific literature and this study shows that those health professionals who were more informed were more confident about the vaccine."

The spokesman added: "Repeated studies have given MMR a clean bill of health - it is the safest way of protecting children against these potentially life-threatening diseases."

The head of vaccination at the Department of Health, Dr David Salisbury, said that if vaccinations were administered separately, instead of the combined MMR jab, it would increase the risks to children.

"They will get measles, some of them will die," he said. "They will get rubella and they will infect their pregnant mothers and they will infect their mothers' pregnant friends and they will have children who will be severely damaged by rubella. "This is bad advice. It is dangerous to separate the vaccines."

He said that in Japan, where the vaccinations were administered separately, there had been 79 deaths from measles between 1992 and 1997.

"They export measles like they export cars," he said.

However, shadow health secretary Liam Fox said that, while he accepted the MMR vaccination was safe, the vaccinations should be available separately until public confidence was restored in MMR.

"There is no point in sitting on the high moral ground watching an epidemic taking place. "It has been a failure of government public health policy neither to reassure the public about the safety of MMR successfully nor to provide an alternative.

"We have to get immunisation rates up one way or another because children are being put at risk."

Marilyn Smith, a member of the anti-vaccination group, Jabs, said: "When you've got a child it's the most precious thing in the world and no amount of figures can change the concerns we have about MMR."

webTitle: Hytner takes hat out of the ring

fields.headline: Hytner takes hat out of the ring
fields.standfirst: Dec 15: Laing takes acting role.
fields.trailText: 12pm: The BBC's search for a marketing director continues - but without Jim Hytner who has pulled out of the race, reports Media Monkey.
fields.body:
The BBC's search for a marketing director continues - but without Jim Hytner who was one of the leading candidates for the post.

Mr Hytner, a former marketing boss at Sega and Sky TV and currently marketing director at Channel 5, has written to Greg Dyke removing himself from the race on the eve of his interview with the BBC director-general.

Apparently Channel 5 chief executive Dawn Airey has pulled a two-month spell at Wharton Business School in Philadelphia out of the bag to persuade Mr Hytner to stay.

The lure of a stint at an American business school was a tactic once used to persuade Ms Airey to stay at the station.

Mr Hytner has apparently told friends he wants to move into general management within the next two years so has decided not to pursue other marketing opportunities.

His decision means that the smart money at the BBC is now on Jane Frost, the corporation's sales and marketing director for BBC technology.

She has been the favourite from the start even though the BBC hired headhunters to find candidates.

Ms Frost was the woman behind the BBC's highly acclaimed Perfect Day video featuring a galaxy of rock stars including Tom Jones, Elton John, Tammy Wynette and Heather Small.

As there were only two on the very short shortlist for the job, it seems the job will be Ms Frost's.

Either that or the headhunters will have to start all over again.
fields.bodyText: The BBC's search for a marketing director continues - but without Jim Hytner who was one of the leading candidates for the post. Mr Hytner, a former marketing boss at Sega and Sky TV and currently marketing director at Channel 5, has written to Greg Dyke removing himself from the race on the eve of his interview with the BBC director-general. Apparently Channel 5 chief executive Dawn Airey has pulled a two-month spell at Wharton Business School in Philadelphia out of the bag to persuade Mr Hytner to stay. The lure of a stint at an American business school was a tactic once used to persuade Ms Airey to stay at the station. Mr Hytner has apparently told friends he wants to move into general management within the next two years so has decided not to pursue other marketing opportunities. His decision means that the smart money at the BBC is now on Jane Frost, the corporation's sales and marketing director for BBC technology. She has been the favourite from the start even though the BBC hired headhunters to find candidates. Ms Frost was the woman behind the BBC's highly acclaimed Perfect Day video featuring a galaxy of rock stars including Tom Jones, Elton John, Tammy Wynette and Heather Small. As there were only two on the very short shortlist for the job, it seems the job will be Ms Frost's. Either that or the headhunters will have to start all over again.

webTitle: MPs attack move to let carers smack with parents' consent

fields.headline: MPs attack move to let carers smack with parents' consent
fields.trailText: The government's decision to allow childminders to smack and smoke in front of children with parental consent was condemned yesterday as "totally unacceptable" by an all-party committee of MPs.
fields.body:
The government's decision to allow childminders to smack and smoke in front of children with parental consent was condemned yesterday as "totally unacceptable" by an all-party committee of MPs.

Barry Sheerman, chairman of the education select committee, said: "We had not one piece of evidence that suggested smacking or indeed smoking in front of children was advisable."

Nick St Aubyn, a Tory member of the committee, said the government should have made its decision after a free vote in the Commons.

The move, widely condemned by children's rights groups, was taken after poll of parents, which showed 84% wanted the right to decide whether their childminder should smack.

The criticisms on smacking and smoking were outlined in a report on early years education. Margaret Hodge, the education minister, countered: "If a parent doesn't want their child to be smacked by a childminder then the childminder won't be permitted to do so.

"The report has failed to distinguish between safety and abuse on one hand and rights of parents to their own discipline policy on the other."

The committee also warned against children being pushed into formal education too early and urged that reception classes should have a staff/child ratio of 1/15. It asked the government to look at ways of attracting men to childcare and suggested creating a single department to produce policy for early years.

Maggie Smith was yesterday appointed director of the new early years directorate at the inspection service, Ofsted. She will be in charge of registering childminders.

 English children are less enthusiastic about school than their counterparts in France and Denmark, according to research by Bristol university.

webTitle: Child abuse pair guilty of Anna murder

fields.headline: Child abuse pair guilty of Anna murder
fields.trailText: A woman and her boyfriend were jailed for life today for the murder of an eight-year-old girl who suffered "truly unimaginable" abuse and neglect at their hands.
fields.body:
A woman and her boyfriend were jailed for life today for the murder of an eight-year-old girl who suffered "truly unimaginable" abuse and neglect at their hands.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has ordered a statutory inquiry into the death of Anna Climbié - one of the worst child abuse cases in Britain.

She died at the hands of her great aunt Marie Thérèse Kouao and Kouao's boyfriend Carl Manning even though police, social workers and hospital staff had been alerted to her plight.

As well as the government inquiry, eight London police officers are facing a Police Complaints Authority probe and a social worker has been suspended pending disciplinary procedures.

The jury in the Old Bailey trial heard harrowing accounts of the tragic life of Anna, who was brought to London by Kouao, a year before she died.

She was tied up in a black plastic bag and made to sleep in a bath for months. She was beaten with a variety of weapons including a bicycle chain and wire coat hanger.

The frail child began to stoop like an old woman, and slowly starved because she was fed left-over scraps "like a dog".

Kouao, 44, and Manning, 28, of Tottenham, north London, stood impassive as the guilty verdicts - by a majority of 10 to 2 - were delivered on the fifth day of deliberations.

Kouao put her hand over her mouth as she heard the verdicts.

Judge Richard Hawkins said: "What Anna endured was truly unimaginable. She died at both your hands, a lonely drawn out death. I pass the only sentence I am entitled to pass, and that is life imprisonment."

He gave Kouao a 10 year concurrent sentence for child cruelty. Manning was given eight years for child cruelty to run concurrently.

Judge Hawkins said lessons had to be learned "about the failure of social services and police in this case".

A doctor said Anna "felt like a block of ice" when she was taken to hospital. Home Office pathologist Dr Nathaniel Carey said the case was "the worst case of child abuse I have seen".

The little girl, who did not lose her beautiful smile as she hid her suffering from others, died of hypothermia in February last year. She was malnourished and had 128 bruises on her body.

She came to London from Africa via Paris, in search of a better education but never attended a British school.

Bus driver Manning denied murder but admitted manslaughter and child cruelty. He said he was responsibly for only about a third of Anna's injuries and he admitted hitting her over the head with a bicycle chain.

Widowed Kouao, a French citizen, who had three grown up sons in Paris, denied murder, manslaughter and cruelty to Anna at the tiny studio flat the couple shared in Tottenham.

She initially told police the child's condition was caused by witchcraft. In court, she denied all knowledge of cruelty.

The trial, which began on November 20 last year, was frequently interrupted by Kouao's outbursts.

The court was told that Anna was left tied up in the bath sometimes for more than 24-hours. One woman claimed Kouao told her she left Anna there for "two or three days".

And in a chilling confession read in court, Manning told police: "You could beat her and she would not cry at all. She could take the beatings and pain like anything."

Anna's death resulted in two inquires by police, health officials and social services.

Incredibly, the little girl died even though police child protection officers and social service workers from three London boroughs were involved in her case, and she was admitted to two hospitals.

A Child Protection Team investigation of Anna's case, which allowed her to be returned to Kouao and Manning, was criticised in court as "blindingly incompetent".

Miss Linda Stern QC, prosecuting, told the jury: "You may think they did not do their jobs properly because if they had, she would not have been returned, and her death may have been prevented."

The results of internal inquiries to be held as a result of Anna's death will be sent to the Department of Health to see what lessons can be learned.

Haringey social worker Lisa Arthurworrey has been suspended and child protection officer Pc Karen Jones is one of eight police officers who are subject to the second inquiry by the Police Complaints Authority.

The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children today called for a complete overhaul of child protection procedures to develop a new national strategy.

Director Mary Marsh said: "Anna suffered a living hell of misery and terror at the hands of her carers."

She said one or two children died each week at the hands of parents or carers - and the figure had not fallen over the past 25 years.

Detectives are still trying to trace two other children who may have been handed to Kouao so that she could bring them to Europe from the Ivory Coast.

Court records show an adoption hearing involving a boy named Aime, who was 15, took place in the Ivory Coast in 1996.

In Paris, a girl named Christelle was subject of guardianship proceedings in 1993.

Detective Inspector Keith Niven said: "We are still actively inquiring into the whereabouts of these children. We will keep going until we find the answers."

A third child, Claudine, said to be Kouao's adoptive daughter, is now 17 and is still living in France.

Kouao and Manning face having to serve their sentences in isolation. Kouao told the court that she was attacked and abused in Holloway Prison after details of Anna's horrific death were made public. Anna's parents, Berthe Ehouri, 40, and Francis Climbié, left their six other children in their shanty town home in the Ivory Coast to attend court. Mrs Ehouri also testified during the trial.

But the couple were prevented from returning for the verdict - they returned to the Ivory Coast for the Christmas recess - and collecting Anna's body because of civil unrest in their country.

Mrs Ehouri said she had trusted Kouao with her child - but that by the time she received a card saying her daughter was well, Anna was already dead.

Det Insp Niven said: "The family has been emotionally destroyed by what happened to Anna. It beggars belief. One cannot imagine why anyone would inflict such injuries on a child."

Judge Hawkins said today: "Plainly, lessons must be learnt about the failure of social services and the police inquiry following Anna's release from the North Middlesex Hospital in august 1999.

"It is not for me to go into detail. I would like to be kept informed as to the result of any inquiry."

Manning and Kouao showed no emotion as the sentence was passed.Extra security staff stood in the dock, but the couple left quietly - Kouao clutching a bible.

Judge Hawkins had told them: "This very serious case of murder concerns a lovely child, Anna.

"She left the Ivory Coast a lovely child full of hope and love."

But by the time Anna reached Britain in the Spring of 1999 with Kouao, she had become doubly incontinent due to the "emotional abuse" she subjected her to.

After joining Manning, Anna had become an inconvenience to them and was repeatedly beaten with an array of weapons.

"By her death, she was covered from head to toe in injuries," the judge said.

webTitle: Ang Lee follows-up Crouching Tiger with Hulk

fields.headline: Ang Lee follows-up Crouching Tiger with Hulk
fields.trailText: The director of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is in early talks to direct a big budget film about the Marvel Comics character
fields.body:
Director Ang Lee, currently Hollywood's flavour of the month after the box office success of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, is in early talks to direct Hulk for Universal Pictures.

According to Variety, Lee's version of the film will, unsurprisingly, be both big budget and effects-driven. The movie is intended for release in 2003, although no cast members have been confirmed as yet.

"Ang will bring the characters and the drama to the foreground, and in addition to his visual storytelling ability, I can't think of anyone today who is operating at a higher level across the board," said Gale Anne Hurd, who will produce the project.

The story will be familiar to people who grew up watching The Incredible Hulk on television in the 70s and 80s as both that series and the film are based on the Marvel Comics character. The story concerns research scientist Bruce (known, strangely, as David in the television series) Banner. After being caught in a nuclear explosion, Banner finds that, when under stress, he transforms into the Hulk, a green-skinned giant possessing superhuman strength. As if that weren't bad enough, Banner is also being pursued by the military for a crime he did not commit.

Lee's acclaimed martial arts romance, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, has been a surprise success in the United States and overseas. It is up for two Golden Globes (with Lee in the running for best director) and is also hotly tipped for Oscar success.

webTitle: Horrific death of a little girl who hoped for a better life

fields.headline: Horrific death of a little girl who hoped for a better life
fields.trailText: Analysis: Eight-year-old Anna Climbié came to Britain to get a good education but she was killed by her aunt under the nose of child protection officials, writes Audrey Gillan.
fields.body:
When Anna Climbié left the crumbling shacks of the sprawling shanty suburb of Abobo on the Ivory Coast in November 1997 she was "happy and excited". She was going to a new life with her aunt.

The seven-year-old was leaving home for a better education and standard of living, leaving a country with a low life expectancy and where only 40% of women over 15 can read and write.

To her mother and father, the move would bring a great honour on the family and eventually Anna might earn money and send some back to them.

But instead of honour the family found only grief. Anna never got an education, because she didn't even get to go to school. Just over a year after leaving the Ivory Coast, she was dead.

The victim of horrendous physical and emotional abuse, she was failed by all those who were bound up in her care. Her death, in February of last year, was "the worst case of child abuse" the home office pathologist who examined her battered body had ever seen.

Just eight years old when she died, Anna's last long months were a tortuous, savage existence. She was bound hand and foot, naked in a bathtub in a tiny flat in Tottenham in the middle of winter, starved and told she was possessed by the devil.

Anna simply got in the way of her demented aunt Marie Thérèse Kouao - a woman the Old Bailey was told was "evil" - and her bus driver boyfriend Carl Manning who she picked up on a number 18 bus in Wembley. She was not the meal ticket to social security benefits her devious aunt had first thought.

Over months Anna was beaten, burned with cigarettes and had boiling water poured over her head. She "stooped like an old woman" after being confined to the bath. After all this, she was dragged to a church to be exorcised because her aunt said she had evil spirits in her.

And all the while those who should have been concerned with her welfare - doctors, police and social services - let Anna down.

In spite of being referred to social services on a number of occasions, no one ever checked on her properly. In spite of the marks on her body the child was returned to Kouao because a doctor believed her story that Anna had scabies.

Two police protection orders were taken out on the child in July 1999 but nothing was done and a social services strategy meeting decided a home visit should be conducted but it never was because the social worker and police officer were too scared of catching scabies.

Eventually, this small child (people remarked that she was half the size she should have been for her age) died from hypothermia due to exposure to cold and wet conditions. The underlying cause was severe neglect and malnutrition.

Pathologist Dr Nathaniel Carey found 128 marks on her body. He said: "This little girl was covered in scars. All cases of child abuse leading to death are pretty horrific but this one, in nature and extent of injury, is quite exceptional."

It will be some time before Anna's body will be allowed to return home. A coup in the Ivory Coast has prevented her parents from coming to the UK to hear the jury's verdict and to take their daughter home. Instead, Anna must wait a while more in a country that failed her terribly, a place which for this child proved less safe than her own trouble-torn country.

webTitle: Food: The guzzler

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText:
Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15

Aroma II, 118 Shaftesbury Avenue, W1. Tel: 020-7437 0370
fields.body:
Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15
Aroma II, 118 Shaftesbury Avenue, W1. Tel: 020-7437 0370

Winner of the best oriental restaurant section in last year's Moet et Chandon London Restaurant Awards. It is bright and breezy, if a touch kitsch and cluttered. Big roll call of Cantonese and Peking dishes. It's a pity that the Guzzler's financial prescriptions take braised sea slug with spring onions and shrimp roe off limits.

Stick to lunchtime bargains, eg stir-fried, hand-pulled noodles with sea food or king prawn or Singapore fried rice noodle or braised soft egg noodle with shredded pork and mushroom. Of course you can fit a few of the more esoteric numbers under the £15 limit. Anyone for baked eel with spicy salt & pepper?

Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

New World, 1 Gerrard Place, W1. Tel: 020-7734 0396.

Faster than burgers; faster than noodles; faster than pizza; faster than fish and chips; and more, much more interesting than any of them. Yes, it's time for dim sum.

Dim sum are those gorgeous little dishes - dumplings in a dozen forms; bean curd rolls; soups; brawn balls; chickens' feet in black bean sauce; taro croquettes; deep-fried wanton; char siu buns; lotus leaf stuffed with glutinous rice mixed with meat - that come in a round on heated trolleys in a kind of endless chariot race between 11am and 6pm.

Eat yourself to a standstill for under a tenner. Large numbers of Chinese families chomping away testify to standards. Be prepared for a short queue.

On the menu: Malfatti

A minor mafioso? How wrong can you be.

Well, what is it, then? A form of pasta.

Any form in particular? Gnoccho, or gnocchi in the plural.

What's so different about these gnocchi? They're green.

From? Spinach. They are made from stale bread.

As opposed to? The more usual potato and flour or semolina.

Anything else we should know? Yes. It was much favoured by the Medici in Tuscany of old, it seems, and by dinky pasta snobs in London today.

Just out: Belaxu toasted hazelnut oil

Form: Rich, luminous oil, with a hint of golden green to it.

Flavour: Definitely toasted; definitely nutty; incontestably rich; lingers on, but not in a crude or vulgar fashion.

Verdict: Cold pressed oil, from the Loire valley, apparently. It's classy stuff.

But what do you do with it? Add to winter salads, drizzle (dread word) over a grilled goats' cheese (dreadful dish), splash over grilled chicken or fish (maybe). The trouble with these fancy oils is that you buy them in a fit of enthusiasm, use them for a week, and lose interest until several months later. They only have a larder life of maybe three months in prime condition, and that's assuming you've got a proper larder. Probably worth it in this case.

Price: £5.99 for 250ml bottle.

Food on the net: Uncle Joe's

Uncle Joe's Mint Balls are the toffees of the gods: an oh-so-suckable, pepperminty confection that'll put hairs on your chest. The charmingly animated figure of Uncle Joe beckons you into his homepage with a cheery grin and a flurry of hard-boiled sweets. And who could resist such a welcome? Inside, there's a detailed history of the Santus Toffee company, a handy guide to "making a mint", plus the lyrics and sheet music to the Uncle Joe's song, should you wish to sing, or indeed whistle, along. Do I ever.

Pros: Keeps you all a-glow.

Cons: Absence of on-line ordering service means suckers must resort to snail-mail or "stockists". Pah.

The taste test: bagels

Cult munch in New York. Still a minority gourmet treasure here. The name comes from the Yiddish beygel, which in turn comes from the German beugel, meaning ring or bracelet. According to the divine Claudia Roden, the circular bagel symbolises the eternal cycle of life. Should be eaten fresh from the oven. Supermarket versions are better toasted, in my view. fields.bodyText: Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15 Aroma II, 118 Shaftesbury Avenue, W1. Tel: 020-7437 0370 Winner of the best oriental restaurant section in last year's Moet et Chandon London Restaurant Awards. It is bright and breezy, if a touch kitsch and cluttered. Big roll call of Cantonese and Peking dishes. It's a pity that the Guzzler's financial prescriptions take braised sea slug with spring onions and shrimp roe off limits. Stick to lunchtime bargains, eg stir-fried, hand-pulled noodles with sea food or king prawn or Singapore fried rice noodle or braised soft egg noodle with shredded pork and mushroom. Of course you can fit a few of the more esoteric numbers under the £15 limit. Anyone for baked eel with spicy salt & pepper? Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes New World, 1 Gerrard Place, W1. Tel: 020-7734 0396. Faster than burgers; faster than noodles; faster than pizza; faster than fish and chips; and more, much more interesting than any of them. Yes, it's time for dim sum. Dim sum are those gorgeous little dishes - dumplings in a dozen forms; bean curd rolls; soups; brawn balls; chickens' feet in black bean sauce; taro croquettes; deep-fried wanton; char siu buns; lotus leaf stuffed with glutinous rice mixed with meat - that come in a round on heated trolleys in a kind of endless chariot race between 11am and 6pm. Eat yourself to a standstill for under a tenner. Large numbers of Chinese families chomping away testify to standards. Be prepared for a short queue. On the menu: Malfatti A minor mafioso? How wrong can you be. Well, what is it, then? A form of pasta. Any form in particular? Gnoccho, or gnocchi in the plural. What's so different about these gnocchi? They're green. From? Spinach. They are made from stale bread. As opposed to? The more usual potato and flour or semolina. Anything else we should know? Yes. It was much favoured by the Medici in Tuscany of old, it seems, and by dinky pasta snobs in London today. Just out: Belaxu toasted hazelnut oil Form: Rich, luminous oil, with a hint of golden green to it. Flavour: Definitely toasted; definitely nutty; incontestably rich; lingers on, but not in a crude or vulgar fashion. Verdict: Cold pressed oil, from the Loire valley, apparently. It's classy stuff. But what do you do with it? Add to winter salads, drizzle (dread word) over a grilled goats' cheese (dreadful dish), splash over grilled chicken or fish (maybe). The trouble with these fancy oils is that you buy them in a fit of enthusiasm, use them for a week, and lose interest until several months later. They only have a larder life of maybe three months in prime condition, and that's assuming you've got a proper larder. Probably worth it in this case. Price: £5.99 for 250ml bottle. Food on the net: Uncle Joe's Uncle Joe's Mint Balls are the toffees of the gods: an oh-so-suckable, pepperminty confection that'll put hairs on your chest. The charmingly animated figure of Uncle Joe beckons you into his homepage with a cheery grin and a flurry of hard-boiled sweets. And who could resist such a welcome? Inside, there's a detailed history of the Santus Toffee company, a handy guide to "making a mint", plus the lyrics and sheet music to the Uncle Joe's song, should you wish to sing, or indeed whistle, along. Do I ever. Pros: Keeps you all a-glow. Cons: Absence of on-line ordering service means suckers must resort to snail-mail or "stockists". Pah. The taste test: bagels Cult munch in New York. Still a minority gourmet treasure here. The name comes from the Yiddish beygel, which in turn comes from the German beugel, meaning ring or bracelet. According to the divine Claudia Roden, the circular bagel symbolises the eternal cycle of life. Should be eaten fresh from the oven. Supermarket versions are better toasted, in my view. webTitle: DoubleClick posts profit warning

fields.headline: DoubleClick posts profit warning
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Online ad agency DoubleClick has posted a profit warning after predicting a tough year ahead, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online advertising agency DoubleClick has posted a profit warning after predicting a tough year ahead for the sector.

DoubleClick said that revenues from its media division, which sells advertising over the net, would fall by up to 30% in 2001 due to the absence of search engine AltaVista as a client and a slump in the US economy.

The statement was issued alongside fourth quarter earnings figures, which showed a profit of £144,000 against a loss of £1.19m for the same period last year.

Kevin Ryan, chief executive of the globe-spanning group, said that DoubleClick's £585m cash pile and innovative Dart advertising monitoring technology would see it through the rocky patch ahead.

"I am very proud of how well our organisation executed in a tough industry environment," he said. "Our strong balance sheet and relentless focus on productivity position us very well going into 2001."

DoubleClick remains bullish about its long-term prospects, confident that the internet's share of the advertising market can only improve and its technology business will continue to boost income.

Stephen Collins, chief financial officer of DoubleClick, said: "Today, by some estimates, 2% of media spending goes to the internet while 9% of people's media time is spent on the internet.

"We believe these figures will inevitably converge, as they have in virtually every other type of media over time.

"At the end of the day, this is the most fundamental argument as to why internet advertising will be a fast growing, large segment of worldwide media spend for years to come."

However, the company's announcement is the latest in a series of blows to rain down on the advertising sector over the last few days.

US internet giant Yahoo! issued a profit warning on Wednesday after experiencing a slowdown in advertising growth, and yesterday it was revealed that spending by the UK's top 30 advertisers fell by £64m last year.

Advertising trends are a bellwether for the media sector, as they provide a significant slice of companies' income. Analysts will be keeping a very close eye US media giant Viacom, owner of MTV and CBS, which relies heavily on advertising for its income.

Advertising has been hit by a downturn in the US economy and spending cutbacks at cash-strapped dotcom startups.

Nervous media companies are hoping that a 0.5% cut in US interest rates will be enough to kickstart the economy and revive revenues, although the effects of the move will not filter through for another six months.

webTitle: Telewest takes 10% stake in software company

fields.headline: Telewest takes 10% stake in software company
fields.trailText: 11am: Telewest is set to plough £2m into Scottish game software company Vis Entertainment, reports Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Telewest is set to plough £2m into Scottish game software company Vis Entertainment in exchange for a 10% stake.

The cable interactive TV company's investment is part of a £3.3m funding package due to close by the end of this month.

The stake is in addition to a £4m agreement struck last year with Vis to develop content for Telewest's digital TV platform.

The announcement follows speculation that Telewest is poised to buy Thus, the Scottish telecoms operator.

Shares in Telewest have risen 25.25p to 136.75p since the rumours of a takeover broke on Tuesday.

webTitle: Study claims MMR vaccination is safe

fields.headline: Study claims MMR vaccination is safe
fields.trailText: The largest study of the controversial MMR vaccination ever undertaken has ruled out any link to other conditions in children, it was reported today.
fields.body:
The largest study of the controversial MMR vaccination ever undertaken has ruled out any link to other conditions in children, it was reported today.

The research, revealed on the same day a study highlighted widespread concerns with MMR among British health professionals, will be welcomed by campaigners concerned about falling immunisation levels in the UK and the risk of a measles outbreak.

Finnish researchers followed up three million doses of the vaccination against measles, mumps and rubella and found no link to cases of autism and serious bowel disorders.

Previous studies have suggested a possible link between MMR and these conditions although supporters claim the vast majority of research has given MMR a clean bill of health.

With MMR, children are a given a combined jab against measles, mumps and rubella at 12 to 15 months and a second booster dose at between three and five years old.

Because of the concerns, opponents of MMR, including Tory MP Julie Kirkbride, want children to be immunised separately against the three diseases.

Around 2,000 families in Britain have taken legal action claiming their children have been damaged by the MMR jab, with many believing it has triggered autism.

The Finnish research will bolster claims by health officials in the UK that the single doses are unnecessary and costly.

However, another study, published today in the British Medical Journal, suggests that many health professionals in the UK are yet to be totally convinced that MMR is entirely risk free.

The survey found that nearly half of family doctors, health visitors and practice nurses have reservations about giving children their second dose of the MMR vaccination.

Almost one in five GPs had not read official advice about the combined jab and 46% said they wanted more information and training. Up to a third of nurses believe the triple vaccine is linked to serious adverse side effects such as Crohn's disease and autism.

The study was published a week after government experts warned that the UK was at risk of a potentially fatal outbreak of measles because immunisation levels had dropped dramatically.

Public fears that the vaccine could be linked to autism and Crohn's disease have led to thousands of parents refusing to have their children vaccinated.

Immunisation levels in some parts of the country have fallen to as low as 75%, way below the World Health Organisation threshold of 95% needed to guarantee so-called "herd immunity" for the whole population.

Doctors' own concerns about the jab may be exacerbating the worrying fall in immunisation levels, the study authors said. One doctor said: "I personally will not let my children have their second MMR but I don't influence parents in any way.

"I would be frightened to urge parents to have the second MMR in case there were problems afterwards. I would not want anyone to blame me for persuading them."

A Department of Health spokesman said that in the study, which he said was carried out more than two years ago, GPs were not questioning the giving of the MMR vaccine.

The study highlighted that some health professionals lacked awareness of up-to-date information on the rationale for the second dose of MMR, he said.

"It is important for health professionals to keep up to date with all of the available scientific literature and this study shows that those health professionals who were more informed were more confident about the vaccine."

The spokesman added: "Repeated studies have given MMR a clean bill of health - it is the safest way of protecting children against these potentially life-threatening diseases."

The head of vaccination at the Department of Health, Dr David Salisbury, said that if vaccinations were administered separately, instead of the combined MMR jab, it would increase the risks to children.

"They will get measles, some of them will die," he said. "They will get rubella and they will infect their pregnant mothers and they will infect their mothers' pregnant friends and they will have children who will be severely damaged by rubella. "This is bad advice. It is dangerous to separate the vaccines."

He said that in Japan, where the vaccinations were administered separately, there had been 79 deaths from measles between 1992 and 1997.

"They export measles like they export cars," he said.

However, shadow health secretary Liam Fox said that, while he accepted the MMR vaccination was safe, the vaccinations should be available separately until public confidence was restored in MMR.

"There is no point in sitting on the high moral ground watching an epidemic taking place. "It has been a failure of government public health policy neither to reassure the public about the safety of MMR successfully nor to provide an alternative.

"We have to get immunisation rates up one way or another because children are being put at risk."

Marilyn Smith, a member of the anti-vaccination group, Jabs, said: "When you've got a child it's the most precious thing in the world and no amount of figures can change the concerns we have about MMR."

webTitle: Style: The Comfort Station label

fields.headline: Oversubscribed
fields.standfirst: Comfort Station
fields.trailText: Comfort Station
fields.body:
The name alone would be enough to make this label a bit of a cult favourite: a comfort station is a euphemism for a toilet in America.

Amy Anderson, the designer behind the label, launched it last year to fund her fledgling art career. However, her first collection of bags, cuffs and earrings proved so popular at Portobello and Spitalsfield markets that her career as an artist has been temporarily suspended. Well, sort of. Her artistic tendencies are wonderfully apparent in Comfort Station's products, in the fabulous cut-outs on the vinyl bags, the colourful cuffs, and the complex tailoring of the scarves.

Their appeal lies in their whiff of East End cool combined with their artistry. Unlike too many accessories sold in the markets, Comfort Station products are beautifully made, imaginative and very wearable. They are made for you and me, not just overly trendy fashion stylists. Speaking as a besotted owner of two of the bags, I can say with conviction that these products last. Mine have been stuffed to the gills with heavy items, dropped in the mud and knocked about on evenings out, yet they still look new. The new line of choker-like scarves (you'll have to see them to understand, I'm afraid) are smartly stylish and very desirable.

Anderson's refusal to use any animal by-products has, incredibly, caused her a few problems. One major department store in London wanted to stock Comfort Station cuffs, but only if they were made out of leather instead of vinyl. Anderson refused, despite the store's high profile.

To dub her a Stella McCartney for accessories is a bit simplistic, but with stores such as Kokon To Zai, Urban Outfitters and Controversy already stocking her products (enquiries, 07947 395 454), visiting the Comfort Station has never been such a delightfully stylish pursuit.

webTitle: Style: Chronic costume changing is overexposed

fields.headline: Overexposed
fields.standfirst: Chronic costume changing
fields.trailText: Chronic costume changing
fields.body:
These have been bad, bad weeks. To see not one but two idols take up residence in fashion victim territory is enough to cause disillusionment in the stoutest of souls.

First there was Madonna at her wedding where, our sources can reveal, she wore Stella McCartney for the ceremony, Gaultier for the dinner, Versace for the party. We hesitated between appreciating her reliably on-the-fashion-button taste and retching at this display of designer overload (all, incidentally, were at her intimate do). Monday settled our indecision when Britney Spears wore five outfits to the American Music Awards, demonstrating all too clearly that too many frocks spoil the celebrity.

Britney, petal, you did not look imaginative, you did not demonstrate fashion nous. You looked like an over-stylised, spoilt little teenager with too many PRs clamouring for product placement on your overexposed body. Unable to decide which outfit to sport, you settled on the whole wardrobe. It suggests that your personality is insufficient and you need to divert others with this fashion bingeing.

Foolish fashion bingeing, it turns out. This week, the misguided clothes horse topped the annual American list, Blackwell's Worst Dressed Women.

Sarah Jessica Parker tried to make a joke of this celebrity costume changing craze at the MTV Movie Awards last summer, when she changed outfits 12 times. Unfortunately, she looked quite good in each of them, which seems to have encouraged fellow celebrities. Ladies, enough. At least have the fashion sense to choose a dress that is good enough to wear for an hour.

webTitle: Style: New fashion ads

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about
fields.standfirst: New fashion ads
fields.trailText: New fashion ads.
fields.body:
There are some people who complain about the number of adverts in magazines. But come January, when the new campaigns hit the glossies, fashionistas just can't get enough. This week, these high-budget images have started to make their first appearances in magazines like Elle and i-D, revealing how the designers want their work to be seen over the coming months. And this season, with some labels having mixed reactions to their catwalk shows, the campaigns have got the tough job of damage limitation even before they sell any frocks.

Most successful is Gucci, whose bitch-chic vamp left some spectators cold when Kate Moss hammered down the runway last October. Tom Ford must have realised S&M bodices were not going to pull in the punters on Bond Street, since the ads have gone for the sensual, rather than the sexual. Moss is now laid languid on a bed, her conical bra no longer terrifying, her still-peroxide hair wavy instead of stuck in a scary Phil Oakey crop.

Meanwhile Prada has ditched the Stepford secretary look for a softer approach. The models, still in their 50s officeworker finest, have now been cast away on a pale, sea-less beach. Clearly Miuccia has understood that skiving is a more attractive proposition than sitting in the typing pool.

With other campaigns, it's business as usual. Nick Knight continues his wham-bam theme for Christian Dior, this time with girls smeared in engine oil. Chanel is like a moody out-take from Pretty in Pink, and Versace has gone big on lingerie. Meanwhile, least original ad award goes to Bottega Veneta, whose 80s airbrushing overload looks suspiciously like the cover of last May's Face anniversary issue. Surprising? Nope - uber-stylist Katie Grand was behind them both.

fields.body:
Aston Villa are the latest club to have a £12m bid for Robbie Fowler rejected. Liverpool manager Gerald Houllier said: "As soon as I heard the Angel deal had collapsed I expected some kind of approach from Villa so this is no surprise. I told Robbie about it and I told him we didn't want him to go. But if he wants to leave there are offers for him, and not just from Villa."

West Ham are hoping to sign Alaves striker Javi Moreno - who is top scorer in the Primera Liga - for around £5.5m. "He's a top quality player," Harry Redknapp told Planet Football. "He has lot of qualities that I admire, but I don't know if we can compete for him. I would love to get a front man in to partner Freddie Kanoute - that would be frightening."

webTitle: Lessons should be learned from tragic death

fields.headline: Lessons should be learned from tragic death
fields.trailText: Comment: The horrific death of Anna Climbié clearly illustrates the need for a national strategy to reduce the number of child deaths from abuse and neglect, writes Phillip Noyes, director of public policy for the NSPCC
fields.body:
The Anna Climbié case is horrific. This little girl was burned with cigarettes, beaten with bicycle chains, starved of food and ultimately froze to death. She died what the judge called a drawn out and lonely death.

While agencies protect tens of thousands of children from abuse and neglect every year, child killings continue to happen far too often. Week in and week out at least one child dies at the hands of parents and carers. It is an outrage that in each generation of children more than 1,000 children will die of abuse before reaching adulthood.

Nothing that has been done during the last 25 years has cut this terrible toll. There has been no informed public debate about child abuse deaths for many years and no concerted national effort to prevent them.

The NSPCC welcomes the inquiry into Anna's death but the government must ensure that its remit enables the lessons of this case to be fully learned, widely disseminated and applied effectively across the country. It must appoint a multi-disciplinary panel with expertise in child protection to take this forward.

The NSPCC believes the government must develop a national strategy to reduce the number of child deaths from abuse and neglect. Child wellbeing indicators should be introduced to monitor outcomes for all children at risk, measure improvements and set future policy goals. These should include national targets to reduce the number of deaths from child abuse and neglect.

Unfortunately, it has been estimated that the real incidence of child killings in England and Wales may be double the official homicide rate. Lack of information on the causes and circumstances of many unexpected or suspicious child deaths means the full extent of the problem remains hidden, which is why we advocate the introduction of independent, multi-disciplinary child death review teams (CDRTs). Such teams would carry out a thorough investigation of all child deaths, not just those where a child known to local agencies has died from abuse.

Crucially, the CDRTs would get behind professional practice and examine the family dynamics in each case of unexpected and unexplained child deaths. Currently the reviews carried out in cases where the child was previously known to local agencies focus on the professional systems not on the family as such. The teams would provide full reports on reviewed deaths to local and central government, gathering information and significantly making recommendations to help future deaths.

The last vital part of the national strategy has to be the appointment of independent children's commissioners in each of the four UK countries to monitor progress by government and public agencies towards the set targets on reducing child killings. Children's commissioners could oversee and carry out their own inquiries into cases of child abuse and child death causing major concern.

What is equally clear from Anna's tortuous path towards death is that we need better training in child care and child protection for everyone who has contact with children in a professional capacity. However, ultimately we need to encourage an attitude that the care and protection of children is everyone's responsibility not just the professionals. The NSPCC is seeking to promote this with the full stop campaign. The aim to stop child cruelty is ambitious but for the sake of all vulnerable children out there it's an ambition worth fighting for.

 Phillip Noyes is director of public policy for the NSPCC

webTitle: GMTV boss quits

fields.headline: GMTV boss quits for horseracing consortium
fields.trailText: 11am update: GMTV managing director Christopher Stoddart is leaving the company after nine years, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
GMTV managing director Christopher Stoddart is leaving the company after nine years.

He told staff last night that he had decided to accept an irresistable offer to become chief executive of the new TV racing consortium, Go Racing.

Mr Stoddart, 50, who is believed to be the longest serving head of a UK commercial TV outfit, will take up his new role in May.

Mr Stoddart said: "Having steered GMTV onto the air, to editorial and commercial success and through licence renewal, Go Racing represents a fresh challenge for me."

The move has shocked GMTV staff, many of whom have been there almost as long as Mr Stoddart.

But it means he is returning to his first love - horseracing.

Before joining GMTV in 1992 to guide the breakfast broadcaster's launch, Mr Stoddart was managing director of the Racing Channel's parent compan,y Satellite Information Services.

Go Racing, which is backed by Channel 4, BSkyB and racecourse owner Arena Leisure, is currently in exclusive negotiations with the Racecourse Association to secure a £750m deal for TV and all other media rights to UK horseracing.

The consortium is planning to launch a pay-TV racing channel and an interactive betting service.

webTitle: Stars pledge millions for theatre ventures

fields.headline: The next stage
fields.standfirst: Stars pledge millions for theatre ventures
fields.trailText: Natural Nylon, the film production company owned by Jude Law, Sadie Frost, Ewan McGregor, Sean Pertwee and Jonny Lee miller, pledges millions for theatre ventures.
fields.body:
Nicole Kidman started it by performing a peek-a-boo striptease in the Blue Room. Then Kathleen Turner went the whole hog in The Graduate.

Now the two glamour boys of the British Hollywood brat pack, Ewan McGregor and Jude Law, are staging a series of plays in London, but they are keeping their shirts on.

They are pouring millions of pounds through Natural Nylon, the production company they run with fellow actors Sadie Frost, Jonny Lee Miller and Sean Pertwee, into backing new writing and bringing classics to a younger audience.

With American stars nowadays seemingly unable to step on to a West End stage without shedding their clothes, the pair insisted there was nothing gimmicky about their joint venture with the Ambassador Theatre Group and the Young Vic. "We are not doing this to make work for ourselves," said McGregor. "It is about finding new writers and working with really good people. This is purely an attempt to do some good theatre, commission new writing, adapt the classics and to do our own thing."

He hoped some of the plays might eventually make it on to the screen, "although I'm well aware of the pitfalls. It's all about finding and developing talent".

Natural Nylon has already produced the David Cronenburg film eXistenZ and Nora, in which McGregor played a young James Joyce.

Asked if he would be appearing at the Young Vic where the plays will open, McGregor said, "Possibly. No, I'm not telling you. Oh all right, very probably."

Law, who has just finished shooting Steven Spielberg's new sci-fi film AI, was more forthcoming, saying he would love to appear on stage with McGregor. "There is only so long you can go from film to film to film. Theatre is a more raw experience. I don't want to sound pretentious, but for an actor a live audience is creative inspiration."

Two of the first three plays to be produced by Natural Nylon are classics - Dr Faustus and Christopher Hampton's translation of Chekhov's Three Sisters. The third will be an adaptation of John Fowles's novel The Collector.

webTitle: Evans joins Dennis

fields.headline: Evans to launch The Week in the US
fields.trailText: 10am Former Sunday Times editor Harold Evans is joining Dennis Publishing for the American launch of The Week. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Sunday Times editor Harold Evans is to join the US arm of Felix Dennis's publishing empire for the American launch of The Week.

Mr Evans will be acting as a consultant for Mr Dennis, who is spending £11m on the US launch of the magazine.

The Week has proved a success in the UK with a circulation of 62,000 copies per week.

Mr Dennis hopes to take on the US's established news magazines like Newsweek and Time.

The launch comes as Mr Dennis announces plans for Blender, a US music magazine, headed by former Q editor Andy Pemberton.

Dennis Publishing is also launching Maxim Fashion, a spin-off from its successful Maxim men's magazine brand, which has been a huge hit with a guaranteed circulation of 2.25m.

Mr Evans, who had a distinguished career on the Sunday Times before being ousted by Rupert Murdoch, has since worked for Random House, and is married to the editor-in-chief of American society magazine Talk.

webTitle: Son of Star Wars

fields.headline: Son of Star Wars
fields.standfirst:
American plans for a national missile defence system (NMD) have been strongly criticised by British MPs worried about the impact on international relations and the risk that it will fuel an arms race. Mark Tran explains what the NMD is and examines the political implications of such a system

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: American plans for a national missile defence system (NMD) have been strongly criticised by British MPs worried about the risk that it will fuel an arms race. We explain what the NMD is and examine the political implications of such a system.
fields.body:
What is the difference between NMD and previous plans for an American anti-missile shield?
All are designed to shoot down incoming missiles. The original idea, the strategic defense initiative or Star Wars, conceived under President Ronald Reagan, was to deploy an ambitious space-based arsenal of military satellites which could detect and destroy enemy missiles. Son of Star Wars more modestly relies on missiles fired from the ground or ships.

Doesn't Britain fit into NMD somehow?
Yes. The system relies on early-warning radars in Massachusetts, California, Alaska, Greenland and Britain. To operate NMD, computer software codes at the US satellite base at Fylingdales at Menwith Hill in North Yorkshire would have to be changed. Later, the US would have to expand another base in the UK.

How is the national missile defence system seen in the UK?
Members of the Commons all-party foreign affairs select committee have called on ministers to voice the strong concerns felt in Britain about NMD, which critics claim will fuel an arms race. The US project is also opposed by Britain's European allies. The MPs say there are apparently contradictory views of the project between the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence.

How is the NMD system seen in other countries?
Russia says it would breach the 1972 anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty. Considered a landmark in arms control, the treaty prohibits the US and Russia from deploying nationwide defence systems. China also views NMD as highly provocative and has threatened a massive build-up in nuclear missiles. The French have suggested the US share the technology with Russia in return for an amendment to the ABM treaty. Russia appears to be winning the battle for public opinion by appearing flexible on arms control while insisting that there be no change to the ABM pact.

How is NMD supposed to work?
Once an enemy missile is detected by early-warning radars, the information is fed into a war room. After a point of interception is decided, a missile is launched. The interceptor is made up of a booster rocket and a kill vehicle. The kill vehicle would try to distinguish between the warhead and any debris or decoys. Using thrusters, it would separate from the booster rocket and manoeuvre into a high-speed collision that would destroy the warhead. The process has been described as shooting a bullet with a bullet.

What do scientists think of NMD?
Leading scientists have criticised the concept. Even if all the tests had been successful, there are doubts as to whether such a system would work. The Patriot missile, the only missile defence system ever used in combat, had a perfect test. But during the Gulf war in 1991, it failed most of its 44 attempts to destroy Iraqi Scud missiles.

So why is the Clinton administration going ahead with deployment?
When the Republicans took over the US Congress in 1994, they pushed hard for a national missile defence system. In 1996, the Clinton administration buckled under Republican pressure and announced it would develop a system capable of covering the entire US. Al Gore cannot afford to scrap NMD as he does not want to appear weak next to Mr Bush.

What is the reasoning behind the system?
Backers say the system is needed to protect the US against rogue states such as Iran, Iraq and North Korea, which in 1998 launched a three-stage missile program capable of hitting Alaska. Another justification is to safeguard against an accidental launch of Russian missiles, unlikely as that may seem.

How much will it cost and when is it going to be deployed?
According to a recent report from a US government watchdog, the general accounting office, a limited system would cost between $18bn and $28bn - but estimates run as high as $50bn. In any event, it is the most expensive weapons project on the Pentagon's books. The US says 2005 would be a realistic date for deployment.

Why NMD won't work (in Scientific American)

US department of defense
The Institute of International Strategic Studies on NMD

webTitle: Award winning author Sage dies

fields.headline: Award winning author Sage dies
fields.trailText: The author and academic Lorna Sage, whose memoir Bad Blood won the Whitbread biography of the year award last week, died yesterday. She was 57 and had been suffering from emphysema and related chest infections.
fields.body:
The author and academic Lorna Sage, whose memoir Bad Blood won the Whitbread biography of the year award last week, died yesterday. She was 57 and had been suffering from emphysema and related chest infections.

Bad Blood tells of a 1950s childhood in which Sage became pregnant at 16, then defied convention to marry the 17-year-old father of her child and go with him to study English at Durham University, where they both gained firsts.

The memoir is considered to be one of the strongest contenders for the overall Whitbread book of the year award, to be announced on January 23.

An influential literary critic, Sage was also professor of English at the University of East Anglia. Her editor Nicholas Pearson said: "She has been ill for a number of years. I am devastated, firstly because she has become a friend and secondly because as an editor one dreams of working with writers like this.

"I derive some consolation in that, before she died she wrote a masterpiece of autobiography. The book has had a tremendous impact on the thousands who have read it."

Sage's literary agent and friend, Faith Evans, said: "She was a brilliant writer whose literary criticism has inspired a whole generation of readers and students. She was thrilled that Bad Blood, the result of 15 years work, won the Whitbread biography award."
