webTitle: The Weakest Link to make BBC millions

fields.headline: The Weakest Link to make BBC millions
fields.trailText: 10.15am: The BBC has signed deals for The Weakest Link worth £6m in 12 countries including America, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC is on the verge of making millions from The Weakest Link.

It has signed deals worth £6m in 12 foreign countries including America, where the cult quiz will be showcased on NBC.

The deal could potentially be worth millions more if the US version of The Weakest Link proves a success.

The US network is planning a 13-part peak-time series and a second version of the format for the lucrative daytime or early evening syndication market.

A pilot for the NBC Weakest Link was shot in London yesterday fronted by Anne Robinson, the presenter of the BBC show.

But NBC is also planning to shoot a second pilot hosted by America's answer to "Nasty" Nick Bateman, the scheming winner of US reality hit Survivor, Richard Hatch.

The US version of the quiz show format is a BBC/NBC co-production, with BBC head of light entertainment David Young executive producing the pilot.

But Mr Young is leaving the BBC to join indie producer Hat Trick Productions in a £1m-plus deal in April, before the US Weakest Link series is due to go into production.

The US deal was brokered by the William Morris Agency, with the BBC Worldwide end handled by director of programming and operations Colin Jarvis.

BBC Worldwide is talking to broadcasters in 14 other territories about selling the Weakest Link format.

webTitle: G2: Lorna Sage on her grandfather

fields.headline: Past imperfect
fields.standfirst: The 57-year-old academic  Lorna Sage shot to prominence last year with her Whitbread prize-winning memoir Bad Blood. Before she died yesterday, she wrote this article about the philandering vicar grandfather who shaped her - and the dark family secrets she uncovered while exploring her past
fields.trailText: The 57-year-old academic Lorna Sage shot to prominence last year with her Whitbread prize-winning memoir Bad Blood. Before she died yesterday, she wrote this article about the philandering vicar grandfather who shaped her - and the dark family secrets she uncovered while exploring her past.
fields.body:
Starting a memoir, you open a door on to the past. The moment Bad Blood became real to me was when, in my mind's eye, I saw just which door, and who was leading the way:

"Grandfather's skirts would flap in the wind along the churchyard path and I would hang on."

I am still pleased with the book's first words, though I had no idea what I was letting myself in for. My bitter, theatrical vicar-grandfather, stagnating in the remote rural parish of Hanmer in North Wales for his sins (women and drink, mostly), was my reference point, my black flag on the map of the past, my arrow pointing - "You were here", this is where you begin.

"He often found things to do in the vestry, excuses for getting out of the vicarage (kicking the swollen door, cursing) and so long as he took me he couldn't get up to much. I was a sort of hobble, he was my minder and I was his. He'd have liked to get further away, but petrol was rationed. The church was at least safe. My grandmother never went near it - except feet first in her coffin, but that was years later, when she was buried in the same grave with him.

"Rotting together for eternity, one flesh at the last after a lifetime's mutual loathing. In life, though, she never invaded his patch; once inside the churchyard gate he was on his own ground, in his element. He was good at funerals, being gaunt and lined and marked with mortality. He had a scar down his hollow cheek, too, which Grandma had done with the carving knife one of the many times when he came home pissed and incapable."

He died when I was only nine, but that strengthened his hold on my imagination. He did not let me down as he had all the others, starting with my grandmother and my mother, their daughter. Instead he vanished into the dark with his mystique intact.

When, in my teens, I quarrelled with my mother, she would say in despair and disgust, "You're just like your grandfather," meaning that I was promiscuous, sex-obsessed, that the bad blood was coming out. My bookishness was part of that inheritance too, and though she and my father approved in theory of my love of reading, and my coming top in exams, we all knew that books had a sinister, Grandpa side to them. You could always tell which were his books because he had had the bright idea of inking out their titles and authors' names in case visitors to his study asked to borrow a Dickens or a Marie Corelli.

My name, Lorna, came out of one of the blacked-out books, Lorna Doone, and he had chosen it when my father was away in the war. He also taught me to read when I was three, and that confirmed me as his creature. After he was dead I'd commune with him in the vicarage books that no one else read. My mother never opened them; she had given up on all that when she turned against him and chose Grandma's side.

Writing about him, trying to bring him back to life, I succeeded in ways I hadn't expected. Family legend had it that my grandmother, who slept at the opposite end of the house and did not speak to him, had blackmailed him for years with the threat of showing his diaries to the bishop. Certainly she had a tidy sum in the post office, and it was true that he was always completely broke, but was that why? My mother was dead, but my father had no hesitation.

Certainly it was true. But how did he know? Well, he had the diaries; my mother had kept them: two small volumes filled with cramped handwriting covering the years 1933 and 1934, when he had first arrived in Hanmer, and - as it turned out - fallen from grace almost immediately.

Suddenly, instead of my own vivid but patchy childhood memories, I had his words before me, with ironical marginalia from Grandma: "Here the fun begins" and "Love begins (fool!)". I transcribed them with difficulty, and with growing fascination, all one summer, peering back to the very different summer of 1933, when he arrived in his new parish, and tried to recapture how it was:

He must take up his duties immediately, now that the old Canon, long ailing, has finally admitted defeat and been persuaded to go.

His two churches are three miles apart down shaggy, meandering country roads blistered with cowpats and hemmed in by weedy ditches. He acquires a bicycle, and finds himself walking it up gentle hills (no mountains here) and freewheeling down again the other side. The diary shows him threading his way along a necklace of new place names - Bangor-on-Dee, Wrexham, Ellesmere, Horseman's Green, Eglwys Cross, Bronington, Bettisfield, Whitchurch - marking out a map on which, more and more often, his path crosses that of the District Nurse, Nurse Burgess, who of course has a bicycle too.

Just days before, ironically enough, he is all prepared to be lonely and bored. "Hanmer is very quiet," he notes ominously, "very ... Time hangs somewhat on my hands in this place." Then the new bike arrives.

There is an August heatwave, the kids are swimming in the mere just as we would 20 years on (except that in 1933 it's only the boys) and on the very day he admits taking his first ride with the nurse ("Here the fun begins") they are both summoned to the mereside in their professional capacities, because one of the young men has drowned ... His body doesn't surface for three days and the whole of Hanmer keeps a vigil, people standing in hot huddles talking under their breath, gazing at the innocent flat water only dimpled with fish taking flies.

He was a strong swimmer, too, so there's a niggling element of mystery about his death: cramp, or weed, or cold currents must have got him, and it's true - was still true 20 years later - that sometimes when the water near the edge was soupy warm you'd suddenly find your legs entwined with cold streams snaking in under the lily pads, just before the bottom shelved right away.

Grandpa was swiftly out of his depth as well, but he was having a marvellous time and only noticed how far he'd gone when his family actually turned up. Out of his depth and in his element. He and Nurse Burgess, now MB for short in the diary, pedal to paradise every day of the week, including Sunday. Trailing a cloud of midges, they'd hump their bikes off the road, through some muddy gateway and, behind the hedge, hug and knead each other among the mallows and Queen Anne's lace and nettles dusty with pollen.

Perhaps they spread his tobacco-scented black cassock on the ground to protect them from ants and the crawling wasps drunk on crab apples. Or more likely they'd keep their uniforms on and each get to know the other's body in hits. He is lean and wiry, MB in her starched blue linen is substantial but not yet stout, well muscled because of all the exercise she gets, her arms mottled pink and white from soap and sun. She has a midwife's hands.

His fingers are inky and curve to caress an imaginary pipe bowl, or a preacher's palmful of air, and - now - the generous breast where her watch ticks away. It's nearly always afternoon, they are supposed to be out to tea, strawberry jam and fruitcake, and so they are, so they are ..."

A voyeur across the years, I conjured them up in as much fleshly and fruity detail as I could, thinking of the paintings of Arcimbaldo, in defiance of my puritanical mother. Well, yes, I am like him.

But as I read on, the picture darkened: Grandma arrived and of course found out, and there were epic, all-night rows. Taking stock at the end of the year, he hands the whole messy intrigue over to God: "So ends a most memorable year for me. I have had the move I wished for to a lovely country church ... I have met MB and therein hangs all the tale of the future. What will that be I wonder? God knows, since it is his doing that all this has come about. So then I commit the future to God."

After reading between his lines for long weeks at a time, I became convinced that this solemn talk meant that he was wondering if God was proposing to make him a widower. He had made some sort of vow to MB on the Bible, and Hilda had been very ill indeed with asthma in south Wales ... If I'm right, he must have felt cheated, for the move from the Rhondda to Hanmer proved very good for Grandma, who got much stronger in the country.

Certainly his relationship with MB now rapidly soured, to the point where he found himself longing to believe that she had, as gossip suggested, another lover. But in the event it was he himself who was unfaithful to her, and this was another of the diaries' revelations. I had known vaguely about the affair with Nurse Burgess - it was part of village mythology - but not about Marjorie, "Marj" for short. People knew about that too, but did not talk about it, because it was too shocking, for Marj was my 16-year-old mother's best friend, only 17 herself.

"This was the sin that spoiled his relationship with my mother for good, prevented his promotion in the church, and made him such a shady character in Hanmer, though people flocked to hear his sermons. And even that wasn't quite the end of the diary story either, for it looks as if MB wasn't the first. Perhaps he was on the run when he arrived in Hanmer.

"I realised that I didn't really want to take after Grandpa when it came to deviousness and self-pity and self-dramatisation. There were moments when he seemed to reach a skinny hand out of the past to take hold of me, as when he confided to the diary, "Today" (October 7 1934) "I had the old inspiration back again to write"; and again in December, "I make another resolution to spend my time in journalism and writing. I think I can make good now ..." Well he didn't, but in a strange way he was now doing it through me."

I still thought of him - still think of him - as my great familiar and mentor, the making of me, though I now see that that carries all sorts of baggage with it that I had not expected. Writing about his sins, his sermons, his last illness (he had a stroke in mid-flow in the pulpit, I was there in the front row of the choir), I gave myself the impetus to go on to explore my parent's lives and my own first marriage, at 16.

Indeed, marriage, and its changing nature over the years, became one of the book's themes, and so did secrets and lies. He represents for me now the glamour of the past, and its sinister pull, like the force of gravity inside your life. He refuses to die. When Grandma was packing up to move out of the vicarage I called by on my way from school and she told me that she had met him on the stairs.

I was thrilled, but she took it in her stride - it was just the kind of theatrical trick he would pull. "If the old bugger thinks he can frighten me that way," she wheezed, "he's got another think coming." And I treasured up the story for future reference, though it took me nearly half a century to get around to writing it down.

Stephen Moss

The young Lorna was educated at Whitchurch Girls' High School, where she met and married fellow pupil Victor Sage, by whom she had become pregnant.

Her daughter was born in 1959. They later divorced. She was married a second time, to Rupert Hodson, in 1979, but she and Victor remained lifelong friends.

 Studied at the University of Durham (1964-66), where she got a first in English, and did an MA at Birmingham University. Her thesis was on 17th-century poetry.

 Went into academe, but was always a little resistant to its embrace. "I always wanted to write like a writer, not an academic," she said, "to show there's someone behind the words, someone from a specific place."

Last week it won the Whitbread biography prize.

webTitle: NBC plans to axe 600 staff

fields.headline: NBC plans to axe 600 staff
fields.trailText: 10am: US TV channel NBC is planning to axe up to 600 staff amid fears of a advertising slump, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
NBC, the home of hit TV shows Friends and ER, is planning to axe up to 600 staff amid fears of a slump in TV advertising.

The drastic cutbacks could start as early as next month as the US giant seeks to trim up to 10% of its workforce.

According to reports in America's Variety, plans were drawn up before Christmas.

An NBC spokesman confirmed that the company had a hiring freeze in place, but declined to comment further on possible job cuts.

NBC's last round of lay-offs came two years ago, when up to 300 jobs went in a belt-tightening exercise prompted by the increased cost of hanging on to hit shows such as Friends and ER.

The move comes as media in the US and the UK experience decline in advertising revenues.

Yesterday rumours were circulating that CNN is considering axing up to 1,000 jobs in a streamlining operation partly triggered by the merger of parent group Time Warner with AOL.

And late last year Rupert Murdoch imposed a worldwide recruitment freeze on his global media operations including News International in the UK.

webTitle: Bush administration committed to missile defence shield

fields.headline: Pentagon's new man unshaken on defence shield
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush's administration is committed to introducing the controversial national missile defence system as part of a huge expansion of America's military might, the prospective new defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, said yesterday.
fields.body:
George W Bush's administration is committed to introducing the controversial national missile defence system as part of a huge expansion of America's military might, the prospective new defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, said yesterday.

"Missile defence must be achieved in the most cost-effective manner that modern technology offers," he told the Senate armed services committee on Capitol Hill as he began his confirmation hearings in Washington.

"Forces in world politics have created a more diverse and less predictable set of potential adversaries," he said.

"We must develop the capabilities to defend against missiles, terrorism, the newer threats against space assets and information systems."

Mr Rumsfeld confirmed that the new administration will conduct "a comprehensive review of US defence policy", but he gave no indication that the review would reconsider proceeding with the missile-defence project.

He made it clear to a session closely watched by foreign governments that Amrica's allies, including Britain, will be consulted in the evolution of plans to introduce the missile-defence shield. But there was no suggestion that the new administration might not go ahead with its stated plans.

America needed "to make darned sure that we are dealing with our allies in a way that they are brought along", he said.

"We're not alone in this world. We have some enormously important allies in Asia and in Europe, and friends in other parts of the world."

Asked about the European rapid reaction force, Mr Rumsfeld's answer was notable for its lack of enthusiasm and for its insistence that any European defence development must be in the context of the Atlantic alliance.

"I think anything that damages the Nato cohesion would be unwise for Europe, for the United States, and for our ability to contribute to peace and stability in that part of the world," he said.

Mr Rumsfeld, 68, is expected to meet little if any resistance from the Senate to his second tour of duty in charge of America's armed forces. He held the post under President Gerald Ford in 1974-77. More recently, he chaired the commission appointed by President Clinton which recommended building and deploying a US national missile shield.

"He's going to fly through [the Senate confirmation process] like a stealth aircraft through enemy defences, unscathed and with high impact," Patrick Cronin, of the US Institute of Peace, said.

"But they'll try to pin him down on priorities, because you just can't pay for everything."

The Democratic senator Carl Levin of Michigan led a number of colleagues in warning Mr Rumsfeld against introducing the missile defence system without proper research and testing.

"Missile attack is a threat, but it is one we have successfully deterred," Mr Levin said.

The Bush administration "will inherit the most dominant military force in the history of the world", he added.

Senator John Warner of Virginia, the committee's senior Republican, said the new administration deserved time to sort out its priorities, which included substantial increases to military pay and the Pentagon's weapons budget.

"How much more defence spending?" Mr Warner asked. "He's [Mr Rumsfeld] not prepared to do that until he's made a good analysis."

fields.trailText: William Hague will today set out his pre-election claims to global statesmanship by pledging a Conservative government to support President-elect George W Bush's plans for a "star wars" national missile defence (NMD) system.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Berlin and  Michael White in London
fields.body:
William Hague will today set out his pre-election claims to global statesmanship by pledging a Conservative government to support President-elect George W Bush's plans for a "star wars" national missile defence (NMD) system in the same way that Margaret Thatcher once embraced the deployment of US cruise missles at Greenham Common.

The Tory leader's promise, to be made to a meeting in London of fellow conservatives from Europe and the US, comes 24 hours after he had claimed that his own brand of Eurosceptic realism is better-placed to protect Britain's interests in Europe - and to revitalise the EU - than Tony Blair's "heart of Europe" strategy. Both propositions are controversial.

But Mr Hague's endorsement of NMD will put him at odds with the very European allies he courted in Berlin yesterday. They fear that, if Britain allows the US to update its early warning radar system at Fylingdales in North Yorkshire, it will allow America to acquire unilateral protection from missile attack by "rogue states" like Iraq or North Korea.

As the incoming US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, confirmed on Capitol Hill that the Republican administration wants to push ahead with NMD, Mr Hague planned to say: "We should act as leaders of Europe as we did in the 1980s over cruise missiles. There is a need to support the US effort" by upgrading Fylingdales.

Addressing a conference of the European Democratic Union of rightwing European party leaders in Berlin, the Tory leader rehearsed another election theme: to put reform of the EU's farm policy at the centre of the drive to achieve enlargement of the 15-nation union by 2003 if possible.

Coincidentally it was confirmed last night that the unnamed media tycoon to whom Mr Blair has promised no referendum on the euro for the first year of a re-elected Labour government was Rupert Murdoch. Neither his identity, nor the pledge, was surprising given Labour's problems with the single currency - not wanted by 56% of voters, according to a new ICM poll for the Business for Sterling lobby.

webTitle: Volunteers plan stirs up unions

fields.headline: Volunteers plan stirs up unions
fields.trailText: A £300m boost for community volunteering by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, could create havoc in the public services and undercut paid jobs, leaders of the public services union Unison warned yesterday. Patrick Wintour reports
fields.body:
A £300m boost for community volunteering by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, could create havoc in the public services and undercut paid jobs, leaders of the public services union Unison warned yesterday.

Announcing the initiative yesterday, Mr Brown said the cash would help to create a society based on mutuality, in which the state would no longer hold centre stage.

However, some left of centre thinkers claimed that the empowerment of British citizens could not be led by the state. The Conservatives said the initiative was ludicrous.

Unison's deputy general secretary, Keith Sonnet, said: "If this is intended to use unpaid volunteers to do the work of paid public employers, then it is a daft idea that won't work. It could lead to major havoc. These are people who will not be trained and they will be expected to do a job of work when they are not paid. How are the authorities going to deal with vast numbers of volunteers walking around hospitals and going into schools?"

Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office minister, launched an immediate damage limitation exercise, stressing that none of the volunteers would replace existing paid jobs in the public sector. He insisted that the idea was to find innovative ways of tapping into community involvement.

He added: "This isn't substitution for doctors or nurses."

The chancellor announced allocations of £300m over three years, including £120m to fund volunteering in the public services and a National Experience Corps for over-50s.

"The next five years will see the role of government shift even more from the old directing and controlling to enabling and empowering voluntary action," Mr Brown said. "It's not government seeing the voluntary sector as a cut-price alternative. We want to recognise the contribution voluntary action can make."

He claimed that the voluntary sector would play a greater role in provision for the under-fives, preventative health, adult learning and the war against poverty.

In addition to the £120m for the public sector, £60m will be paid to develop mentoring and to modernise the infrastructure of community organisations. Mr Brown has also allocated £70m for the Children's Fund, announced as part of the summer spending review. A further £50m will be given to community groups in deprived areas to recruit volunteers, especially the over-50s.

Research has shown that volunteering is declining among older people. A survey of 1,000 people in December for CitizensConnection.net revealed that 40% had no involvement in their community.

Up to 170,000 people already volunteer in the NHS, while 350,000 are school governors.

Julia Middleton, chief executive of CitizensConnection and a trustee of the thinktank Demos, said the announcement was flawed, since "government and civil servants do not have a great track record in motivating citizens".

The shadow home affairs spokesman, David Lidington, derided Labour's "conversion" to volunteering: "As a party and a government, they have championed centralisation."

webTitle: Leader: Good causes are starved of volunteers

fields.headline: Your country needs you
fields.standfirst: Good causes are starved of volunteers
fields.trailText: Good causes are starved of volunteers.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown launched a new initiative yesterday to recruit more volunteers. Do we need them? We certainly do. Policy-makers - from the left and right - recognised years ago that no matter how much is invested in the welfare state, there would still be a huge shortfall in meeting everybody's needs. Ask the voluntary sector. There are 185,000 registered charities and another 200,000 voluntary and neighbourhood groups, almost all of which could do with more volunteers. They have recruited 3m, but their helplines, advice centres, and support schemes could all open for much longer with more volunteers. Or ask the public services. There is a 3m-strong army of volunteers helping in schools, the health service and social services. But there are still hundreds of primary schools where teachers would embrace more support from parents and volunteers ready to come in and listen to children read.

Should we be suspicious of a government seeking to promote more volunteers? Certainly, if the aim was to use them to squeeze and reduce the service provided by paid professionals. But this government in the next four years is making the largest investment in public services since the welfare state was founded 50 years ago - an almost unbelievable real terms increase of over one-third in health and education. Mr Brown is not searching for a cheapskate way of cutting services. The prime minister has already signalled that further large investments will be needed beyond the second comprehensive spending period.

It will not be easy to find all these new recruits. Voluntary organisations have been struggling with the dip in volunteering for a decade. One reason for the fall is the longer working hours - of men, but particularly women - and the increased demand an ageing population places on its carers. But about 23m still do some form of voluntary work. There are three age groups - the young, the early retired and the retired - where more could be recruited. They have more time, but do less volunteering than other age groups. The last two categories - and the unemployed - would benefit from the sense of satisfaction that volunteering can generate.

The mechanisms which ministers have sponsored are sensible: TimeBank, which has compiled separate national registers to help match people wanting to volunteer with voluntary organisations seeking more help; the promotion of employer-based volunteering programmes; and myriad anti-poverty programmes, such as Sure Start for under four-year-olds in deprived areas, which uses a mix of paid and unpaid workers. Crucially, ministers have recognised that voluntary groups need paid staff to recruit and organise. An extra £180m is being added to the existing £120m planned for the three years from next April.

There are, though, more potential problems here than Mr Brown's confident tones might suggest. A chancellor who concedes that Whitehall does not know better than the playgroup volunteer needs to extend that principle to local councillors too. Some of his claims are too sweeping. A mere £100m a year cannot create the biggest transformation in a century. And the chancellor's communitarian dream may badly underestimate the difficulties of changing the current individualistic culture. Any sense of a government trying to control and direct a sector which by definition depends on the choices of individuals will dent the appeal of his project. There are limits which even a centralising government like this one has in the end to respect.

webTitle: Local democratic muscle to halt future misery

fields.headline: Local democratic muscle to halt future misery
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: When the river Derwent destroyed Bridget Jackson's job as well as wrecking her home for the third time in 14 months, it did a favour for local democracy.
fields.body:
When the river Derwent destroyed Bridget Jackson's job as well as wrecking her home for the third time in 14 months, it did a favour for local democracy.

Collecting her cards from the local factory shop, which went under financially as well as physically last November, she found she had time to study the local flood defence system and go to council meetings.

"Home isn't home at the moment," she said yesterday. "It can't be when you've got just solid earth floors in the kitchen and sitting room and your front garden wall is demolished so they can fit in the skips." The din of dehumidifiers in Church Street, Norton, in Yorkshire, would also drive out anyone sane.

Mrs Jackson now spends her time lobbying for Norton and neighbouring Malton at meetings all over Yorkshire, part of a citizens' army which wants to end for ever the terrible pre-Christmas scenes of drenched fridges and underwater TVs.

"The funding system has got to change," she said. "We need the flood defences desperately but none of us see how local authorities can be expected to be responsible for so much of the bill."

More than 200 people in Malton and Norton are still to move back to their homes, most of them living, like Bridget and her family, in temporary local houses, but some in caravans or surplus Ministry of Defence homes.

"We thought it would be four months - realistically six," said Bridget, who moved out with her husband Glenn and sons Matthew, 18, and Luke, 12, on the first weekend in November. "Now we are completely unsure, because the river has gone up high again several times recently, and Church Street may go under for the fourth time."

Mrs Jackson was in the crowded public gallery at yesterday's flood defence committee meeting, at North Yorkshire county council, clapping with the others every time members acknowledged that the work of repairing flood walls must go on - whatever the problems with the £10.8m levy.

"What we really need are proper defences, including a flood wall through the town. It'll cost a lot of money, but the savings in the long term will pay for it."

webTitle: Tory doubt on shorter hospital wait lists

fields.headline: Tory doubt on shorter hospital wait lists
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Hospital waiting lists for in-patient treatment have fallen by 137,000 in England since the general election, according to figures published yesterday by the Department of Health.
fields.body:
Hospital waiting lists for in-patient treatment have fallen by 137,000 in England since the general election, according to figures published yesterday by the Department of Health.

Ministers said the drop was decisive evidence that Labour would beat its key manifesto target for the NHS - to cut the waiting list by 100,000 over the lifetime of the parliament.

But Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said the "waiting list for the waiting list" - those awaiting a first appointment with a consultant as out-patients - was 180,000 more than when Labour came to power.

The Patients Association said people cared more about how long they had to wait for diagnosis and treatment than how many people there might be on the lists. Official statistics on waiting times were sketchy and inconclusive.

John Denham, the health minister, said there were 1,021,200 people waiting to be admitted to NHS hospitals in England at the end of November. This was 3,600 less than a month before and 50,200 less than a year before.

The number of patients waiting longer then 12 months for an operation was 47,800 - 34% below its peak in June 1998. Mr Denham warned that lists were likely to lengthen slightly over the winter, reflecting normal seasonal patterns. "But the combination of big new investment and modern working means the NHS is now in a position to win the war on waiting."

Under the NHS plan, the maximum wait for an NHS operation would fall to six months and the maximum for an outpatient appointment would fall to three months by 2005.

Dr Fox said the government's figures were becoming increasingly distorted and meaningless. "There are now 180,000 more people on the waiting lists for the waiting lists. Any fool can get in-patient waiting lists down by simply stopping people from seeing a consultant.

"In addition, since Labour came to power, over 450,000 patients have simply got fed up waiting and have used their savings to buy treatment in the private sector. It is unacceptable that life savings should be used for life saving treatment," he said.

Nick Harvey, the Liberal Democrat health spokesman, said: "Waiting longer to see a consultant increases patient anxiety, causes unnecessary suffering and in the worst case scenario the delay means patients become inoperable.

"In some cases the delay is fatal. In effect, lengthening waiting times are becoming a macabre part of the NHS rationing mechanism. Liberal Democrats would introduce booked appointments so people have a guarantee of when they are going to be treated from the outset."

The Department of Health admitted the outpatient waiting list was 180,000 higher than in May 1997. But the number peaked at 512,041 in September 1999 and had fallen to 435,768 in the latest available estimate for September last year.

Mike Stone, director of the Patients Association, said people waiting a year or 18 months after referral by a GP for a hip operation would not be impressed by claims of cuts in the waiting lists.

 A 47-year-old man with a lump in his throat was told he would have to wait more than four years for an appointment to see a consultant plastic surgeon at St James's hospital, Leeds.

Barry Roberts from Kippax, Leeds, said he had been referred by his GP, but told he could not be seen for 209 weeks. A spokesman for Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust said the delay would have been less if the GP had not specified a particular consultant whose services were in high demand.

webTitle: HIV-positive nurses defended by health chiefs

fields.headline: HIV-positive nurses defended by health chiefs
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Aids crisis
fields.trailText: Health chiefs today defended their decision to allow trainee African nurses diagnosed as HIV positive to come into contact with patients.
fields.body:
Health chiefs today defended their decision to allow trainee African nurses diagnosed as HIV positive to come into contact with patients.

They confirmed that between five and ten men and women with the illness are currently either working at hospitals in Wolverhampton or completing a three-year nursing course.

Wolverhampton Health Authority said their condition had been detected through checks carried out on arrival in the country.

However, it moved quickly to reassure the public the group would not be allowed to carry out "high-risk procedures" such as operations.

The authority said it was acting within NHS guidelines and added that Wolverhampton was not unique. It said staff from overseas with HIV are likely to be working in hospitals elsewhere in the country.

Revelations about the African nurses were made in an article in the Sun newspaper which said the identities of the group would be kept secret from colleagues because of "employee confidentiality".

It said in the region of Africa the group are from, one in four of the adult population has been infected with HIV through heterosexual sex.

Jane Eminson, chief executive of Wolverhampton Health Authority confirmed tonight that the group were on a course at the Wolverhampton University School of Nursing and Midwifery.

She said: "The nurses are from the sub Sahara region of Africa, mainly Zimbabwean. They were asked questions about their state of health before applying.

"Under NHS guidelines there is nothing to stop them either applying for a staff position or a place on a nursing course.

"I am happy that everything in this case has been done correctly and we are acting within those guidelines."

Ms Eminson added: "The risk of people getting HIV from unprotected sex or needles is far higher than contracting it from medical staff.

"In fact, there are no cases where HIV has been transmitted from health care worker to patients."

She said the group would have undergone an occupational health assessment on arrival and after that offered an HIV test.

Anyone refusing a test is not allowed to carry out high risk procedures and all staff are obliged to have a test if they believe they may have become infected, explained Ms Eminson.

She urged anyone worried about the situation to telephone the NHS direct number.

webTitle: Jobs go as AOL/Time Warner merger gets go-ahead

fields.headline: Jobs go as AOL/Time Warner merger gets go-ahead
fields.trailText: Regulators last night cleared the $106bn merger of America Online and Time Warner, paving the way for the creation of the US's largest media empire, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Regulators last night cleared the $106bn merger of America Online and Time Warner, paving the way for the creation of the US's largest media empire.

The Federal Communications Commission's approval of the deal sparked fears that at least 1,000 job cuts would result at the global news and internet network CNN, part of Time Warner.

The clearance allows the two companies to forge ahead to complete a deal announced a year ago and originally valued at $165 billion.

The new business, to be called AOL Time Warner, combines the largest US internet provider, with 26 million subscribers, and a media company that owns CNN, HBO, Sports Illustrated and Warner Bros.

The commission approved the deal after requiring the companies to take steps to open AOL's instant messaging service to rival providers.

Regulators cleared the deal in December but imposed restrictions to preserve consumer choice.

The fears of cuts at CNN came as NBC, one of the US's largest TV outfits, was also understood to be considering job cuts.

In recent days, News Corporation and the New York Times have announced plans to cut staff in their online divisions. The severity and extent of the cuts reflect the rapidly deteriorating business outlook for the media sector, with advertising revenues falling as a result of the slowing economy and the collapse of the dot.com sector.

The cuts at NBC, if enacted, are not expected to hit internet jobs alone. A spokesman for the New York-based company, which is owned by General Electric, declined to comment last night.

The axe is expected to fall hardest on CNN's internet operations, although all parts of the business are likely to be affected. Company websites, such as CNN.com and CNNFN.com, employ about 750. Total job cuts could be as high as 1,000.

CNN International, which has been one of the fastest growing parts of the company's operations, is expected to be spared much of the pain. "The international operation is very, very healthy and strong," a source close to the organisation said.

CNN International's European headquarters in London has been expanded in recent years with several high-profile appointments - such as that of former BBC political editor Robin Oakley - in the past few months. CNN's non-US viewers now outnumber its domestic ones by two to one.

The company, which was founded by Ted Turner 20 years ago, employs 2,800 people in its home town of Atlanta.

Staff were told in early De cember to expect "aggressive changes" early in the new year as part of the Time Warner's merger with America Online, the world's largest internet service provider.

The job cuts are understood to have been initiated by Terence McGuirk, head of Time Warner's Turner Broadcasting unit. Once the merger is officially agreed, Mr McGuirk will report to Bob Pittman, the number two at AOL rather than Mr Turner, who has been stripped of all operating responsibilities for CNN.

CNN refused to comment on reports about the job cuts.

webTitle: Comment: Chancellor prescribes local involvement

fields.headline: Local involvement - that's the new prescription
fields.standfirst: Empowerment is the buzzword. If you hanker to join committees
fields.trailText: Empowerment is the buzzword. If you hanker to join committees.
fields.body:
The government's vision of the good society is there, even if it blinks on and off erratically sometimes. Yesterday the chancellor spelt it out again. Announcing new funds for encouraging a million more people to volunteer, he spoke eloquently: "A new era - the age of active citizenship and the enabling state - is within our grasp and at its core is a renewal of civic society". He proclaimed an end to "centralising government". He said the man from Whitehall no longer knows best, but the woman from the WRVS does.

Ministers keep saying it - the key to success in social programmes is through breathing new life into communities. Research into what works in urban renewal finds engaging the people is the only answer. On Monday the new "neighbourhood renewal action plan" is launched, designed to reach down into the heart of the poorest places, promising to rebuild communities from the bottom upwards. The word is local "empowerment".

The vision of the celestial city looks something like this: parents are involved daily with schools. Churches and local groups run after-school clubs, tenants on estates control their own budgets. All local departments pool their budgets, working together to offer whatever local people want most. Mentors guide and support young offenders, aspirant businesses, struggling readers, prisoners or depressed young mothers, connecting the disconnected. Thus local government is re born as people use the rusty levers of power in their communities. City mayors breathe new pride into public works. The comfortable aid the miserable, and in doing so find new meaning in their own lives. Happiness comes not from money - neither in high pay, nor in benefit cheque - but from a sense of inclusion and purpose, fulfilment for rich and poor alike. Community participation spreads warmth and becomes a good in itself, regardless of its output. "You get more out than you put in" is the slogan of the government's TimeBank* initiative, run by the BBC, the gateway to draw in new volunteers. Two thirds of the population should be giving two hours a week by 2005: the good society will wrap us all in its embrace.

And it is a good vision. But it sounds odd on the government's lips, an afterthought like a dusting of icing sugar, not the cake. The Tories were quick to point out the contradictions. This highly centralising government is suddenly "empowering" others? The woman from the WRVS knows better than Ofsted? Under Labour every social programme comes with rigorous targets to be monitored ruthlessly. Every penny of public money is tied up in a public service agreement, where departments deliver or die on their Treasury contracts. Yet suddenly the chancellor talks of letting go?

Labour has just tripped over the great dilemma for all modern social democracies. Progressives rightly believe in the power of government to do good. And yet as central government takes command and delivers, the democratic roots dry up. Evidence-based policy making means centralised policy making. But if the good society means people doing things for themselves and one another, then communities need to be given a long rein and money without strings, free to make mistakes. Schools are the most thriving focus for communities, but would David Blunkett entrust them to the local whims of parents?

Community decisions may often be better than Whitehall's but they might also be much worse. Currently all the target-setting, league tables, national plans and Whitehall thumb-screws are beginning to deliver measurably better services. Is the Whitehall whip to be hung up? Universal standards and community empowerment are admirable but contradictory goals.

Another oddity: there is no clamour for community involvement. It is a top-down prescription in a time when people have deserted the churches, the Rotary Club, the WI, political parties and trade unions. They don't tell the pollsters they hanker after committees, minutes and points of order. Suggesting turning out for a neighbourhood meeting gets a dusty answer. Thatcherite individualism bred the idea that all fun is private and paid for, not public and communal. It is television at home, a meal at a restaurant table, a cinema ticket in the dark. With money now for luxury leisure, who but the desperate and the divinely dedicated seeks fun in a chilly Boy Scout hall with neon strip lights? The government is urging people to do it because it's good for them, like exercise and eating greens. "Enabling" sounds splendid, but how will people be levered out of their armchairs?

Can a new volunteering age happen? Can government do it? It will need a new spirit of enthusiasm for public things. Perhaps if people see local groups have real power and money, then investing time would seem worthwhile. If this is a serious policy then spending needs to bend towards what does induce a genuine sense of community. For parents, a beautiful nursery and creche with after-school clubs all sited together, right on their doorstep would build the first geographical bond between city-dwellers seeking company and mutual support.

If public places like these were welcoming and enjoyable, if schools and doctors' surgeries were pleasant places to meet, then local activism might spring naturally out of these hubs. Imagine adult education centres for fun or for employable skills that weren't run-down, filthy places starved of funds.

Why not free sports centres better than private gyms? Public places have to match the comfort and pleasure of private homes if people are to be enticed back into the public sphere to do communal things. In Joseph Chamberlain's day the civic offered things to be proud of - magnificent public libraries, colleges, swimming pools, schools and meeting rooms that outshone anything people had at home. Now the reverse its true, where most council flat front rooms are more comfortable. Gordon Brown said this was not a left/right issue, but it is. The right would abandon the welfare state to private philanthropy, forcing charity to take over. The progressive approach has to be a generous and enabling state welcoming people lavishly back into a proud public life.

The time is right. There is an emptiness in many well-off lives and many would welcome involvement beyond their narrow worlds. But government exhortation sounds suspect while disconnected from any other policy. Citizens giving their time freely for the common good needs the government to give up some things too. Time is in short supply because Labour policy has made us the hardest worked nation in Europe, in desperate need of a better work/life balance, which only the government can effect. As for empowering the people, will the chancellor be first to let go?

TimeBank

There is an emptiness in many well-off lives and many would welcome involvement beyond their narrow worlds. But government exhortation sounds suspect while disconnected from any other policy. Citizens giving their time freely for the common good needs the government to give up some things too. Time is in short supply because Labour policy has made us the hardest worked nation in Europe, in desperate need of a better work/life balance, which only the government can effect. As for empowering the people, will the chancellor be first to let go? TimeBank polly.toynbee@theguardian.com

webTitle: Industrial towns turn on to tourism

fields.headline: Industrial towns turn on to tourism
fields.standfirst: Urban delights to lure visitors in search of a short break
fields.trailText: Urban delights to lure visitors in search of a short break.
fields.body:
Forget Bath, York and Edinburgh; the chic new destinations for short breaks are towns and cities way off the tourist beat.

Many have rich industrial pasts but are now anxious to market other delights to discerning visitors with open minds.

Yesterday tourism officials from Sunderland, the city that gave Britain glass, were among 1,400 exhibitors selling their wares at the Holiday Show in Manchester. They were competing with hard-nosed marketeers from the US, Canada, India, Spain - and with Southport, Chorley (Lancashire), Leicestershire, South Shields, and the Wrekin in Shropshire.

Meanwhile Bolton, home of the spinning mule, is boldly advertising itself as "altogether better" to readers of the Sky television magazine. And Walsall, famous for locks, leather and Jerome K Jerome, is welcoming a rush of visitors from all over the world to its New Art Gallery.

Marketing teams all agree that they have image problems to overcome but still sell their wares with boundless optimism. "You're in for a surprise the next time you visit Sunderland," boasts a leaflet aimed at short-breakers.

"Sunderland, the city by the sea, is undergoing one of the greatest transformations in its history."

Marketing officer Anya Hocking adds: "We were given city status in 1992 and that has given an enormous boost to our image. There are so many things to do here that people might not have thought of, and Sunderland is an excellent base from which to tour the region."

The city's big draws are the £16m National Glass Centre, part funded by the lottery to narrate developments from church windows to Pyrex dishes, the Stadium of Light, home to a resurgent Sunderland AFC (tours available), the Empire Theatre (where comedian Sid James died on stage), the riverside art trail and new Winter Gardens - "a green oasis right in the heart of the city centre".

Bolton, once trumpeted as Britain's first 24-hour town, is not shy about promoting itself as a "non-traditional destination". "First-time visitors are often amazed to find a bright, attractive but above all forward-looking town," says a cheery council website.

Attractions include the Reebok stadium (tours available), the Octagon Theatre, garlanded with awards, a new Hindu temple and one of the finest town halls in the country (more tours).

Groups can also tour Warburton's bakery but most visitors may choose to skip the factory of the local manufacturer of bedpans.

The town makes much of its booming markets and the historic attractions of 14th century Smithills Hall and Hall i' th' Wood, birthplace of Samuel Crompton, inventor of the spinning mule which helped revolutionise cotton production.

Tourism officials accept the image problem (anyone who saw Hayley Mills in The Family Way, filmed in Bolton, will know what they mean) but beat it by inviting conference organisers and others in the trade to come to discover for themselves "a friendly, welcoming town with so much beautiful countryside on its doorstep".

They also claim that, in the right light, Le Mans Crescent, a graceful curve of municipal buildings, can look like Bath.

"We are delighted that our continuing promotion of Bolton as a tourism destination is attracting interest and visitors from as far afield as Australia, Canada and America," said John Byrne, a councillor and Bolton's executive member for culture.

Until last year, Walsall's biggest tourist draw was its annual autumnal light show in the local arboretum ("Britain's biggest inland illuminations"), 50 years old in 2001.

"Initially visitors came from the Black Country and Birmingham," said Adrian King, Walsall's senior marketing officer.

"But now we have coach parties from an area bounded by London, Bristol, Manchester and Leeds, and some people come from as far away as the west country and Scotland."

But Walsall's fortunes have been hugely boosted by the opening of the New Art Gallery last year. It has been widely praised and visitor numbers have been way above initial estimates.

"Before we moved into the new building, 90% of our visitors came from five local boroughs," said Peter Jenkinson, the gallery's director.

"Now people have come from as far as Scotland, Wales and Cornwall. But visitors are also coming from across Europe and around the world. That's amazing and something we had never anticipated.

"Recently we have had visitors from Cairo, Beijing, Kuala Lumpur. And we have had our first group of Japanese visitors who spent about five hours in the gallery."

There have even been reports of visitors from London.

webTitle: Flood zones rebel against emergency levy increase

fields.headline: Flood zones rebel against emergency levy increase
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Councils in Britain's worst hit flood region united in rebellion yesterday against an emergency levy which threatens to add £7 per house to local council tax each year.
fields.body:
Councils in Britain's worst hit flood region united in rebellion yesterday against an emergency levy which threatens to add £7 per house to local council tax each year.

Authorities controlled by all three parties joined the revolt in Yorkshire, where the regional flood defence committee refused to back the environment agency's request for an extra £10.8m to strengthen battered river defences.

Councillors demanded that the burden - caused by a flood lake bigger than Windermere which engulfed low-lying areas - be shared nationally. A delegation will put the case to the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, before a second regional meeting decides a final figure next month.

"John Prescott came to Yorkshire and stood up to his waist in water and said 'Don't worry chaps, I'll pay'," said Peter Sowray of North Yorkshire county council. "We've got to keep him to his promise. There's no way councils can pay for all of this."

The proposed 63% rise in the annual flood levy, much the highest of any of the flooded regions, has been triggered by the undermining of barriers along the river Ouse in particular and by the worst strain since 1947 on those barriers which held.

"The floods affected Yorkshire far worse than any of the other 10 flood defence regions in Britain," said the committee's chairman, Roy Ward, emeritus geography professor and flooding specialist at Hull University. "More than a third of the total emergency response and repair costs for the whole of England were incurred in the Yorkshire region."

Paying the full levy would mean council tax increases of £8 in Leeds, £6 in Sheffield and £7 in Kirklees, with similar sums for middle band D houses across the region. Jack Goodhand, representing Barnsley, Rotherham and Doncaster on the flood defence committee, said: "What are we supposed to do? Sack school staff? Sack social workers? Tell the fire service they can't have what they need? Something will have to give if we get a bill like this."

The toll of the floods is already adding a burden to council spending on other repairs, including a £3m bill for road and bridge repairs in North Yorkshire. George Horsfall, representing Bradford and Calderdale councils where towns along the rivers Aire and Calder were devastated, said: "I have been to a round of meetings with council departments and the message is unanimous - there's no more money available."

The committee voted to defer a decision for three weeks, but agreed that emergency defence repairs should continue. Although Christmas and new year saw a let-up in the almost constant wet weather of the autumn, fears of more flooding before the summer are widespread.

The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions said yesterday that the problem of flood levy payments was included in the government's review of local government financing.

A spokeswoman said the government understood concerns about the pressure that dealing with local flooding was placing on other services. She said Mr Prescott had announced changes to a scheme providing emergency financial help for local authorities.

These included raising government support above the threshold which triggers national help for exceptional crises from 85% to 100%. The government had also provided an extra £51m for flood defences, she said.

The environment agency warned that if councils cut the levy in Yorkshire the region would risk losing its full share of the £51m. Before last year's floods the region's levy had been budgeted to rise by 5%.

webTitle: Channel 5 latest gameshow

fields.headline: Hands-on way to win a truck
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Channel 5 has a reputation for the bizarre, but its latest idea for a gameshow is weird, its top prize even weirder, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has a reputation for the bizarre, but its latest idea for a gameshow is weird, its top prize even weirder, and it appears to rival drying paint for entertainment value.

Participants must stand with their hands on a truck, while being filmed for television. The prize: the last person left awake walks away with the £50,000 four-wheel drive vehicle.

Chris Shaw, Channel 5 programme controller, said Touch a Truck, to be screened in spring, would be worth watching: "We've taken a deceptively simple idea which we believe will make a compelling TV event. The physical and mental endurance involved will be extraordinary to watch."

Glenn Barden of the production company, Vashca, said: "The competition will see raw emotional drama as it pushes people to their absolute limit."

For viewers who just cannot get enough excitement from the daily prime-time show, the spectacle will be carried live on the Channel 5 website. In the US it was called Hands on a Hardbody. The winner, Warren Hearne, lasted 125 hours and 37 minutes.

The search is on for 26 contestants to take part in the event, at Lakeside shopping centre in Thurrock, Essex.

Participants must not fall asleep and must touch the vehicle at all times, except during appointed breaks. They will strive to distract each other to take their hand off the prize, and friends or family will try to keep them awake.

webTitle: BBC chief takes pay cut to head ROH

fields.headline: BBC chief takes £120,000 pay cut to head Royal Opera House
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It has been variously described as "a slow crucifixion", "a never-ending nightmare" and "good preparation for purgatory". But yesterday Tony Hall, the BBC executive best known for removing newsreader Martyn Lewis, took on the poisoned chalice of running the Royal Opera House.
fields.body:
It has been variously described as "a slow crucifixion", "a never-ending nightmare" and "good preparation for purgatory". But yesterday Tony Hall, the BBC executive best known for removing newsreader Martyn Lewis, took on the poisoned chalice of running the Royal Opera House.

So keen was the director of BBC News on a job that has dented many a shining reputation, he is believed to have taken a £120,000 pay cut to go to Covent Garden.

He takes over as executive director from the American Michael Kaiser, who, after steering the opera house through a fraught first year of reopening after rebuilding without any major disasters, has got out while the going is good.

Mr Hall, 49, an opera fan, whose experience of running a theatre is limited to a directorship of the defiantly working-class Theatre Royal, Stratford East, is seen as a hard-nosed administrator who demonstrated at the BBC that nothing, not even Martyn Lewis was sacred.

Sir Colin Southgate, the chairman of the opera house board, said they were lucky to get Mr Hall, who would be consulted about major decisions before he officially takes over in April. A head of a continental opera house had also been on the shortlist, but Mr Hall - with his powerful connections in broadcasting and within the government - got the nod because of his success in reorganising the equally tricky and much larger BBC news department.

"His extensive experience of managing complex budgets and working in a fast-moving, creative environment make him ideally suited to this position at the Royal Opera House," Mr Southgate said.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, who is believed to have been consulted, last night described Mr Hall as a "very capable administrator".

"I am delighted that Tony Hall has been selected," he said. "Michael Kaiser has done an extremely good job at turning round the fortunes of the opera house over the last couple of years and I am sure that Tony Hall will be able to continue the progress that has been made."

The appointment comes at a time of great change at Covent Garden, with artistic leadership of both the Royal Opera and Royal Ballet being passed on to a younger generation. Antonio Pappano arrives to takes over from Sir Bernard Haitink as music director in September next year, while Sir Anthony Dowell is handing over the reins of the Royal Ballet to the Australian Ross Stretton at the end of the current season.

Mr Hall, who has been head of BBC news for 10 years, said: "The Royal Opera House means so much to so many people and as a lifelong devotee it means a huge amount to me.

"My directorship of Theatre Royal, Stratford East, has introduced me to some of the complexities of running a theatre, and I look forward to immersing myself completely in this new and stimulating environment."

But the opera impresario Raymond Gubbay, one of Covent Garden's fiercest critics as it has reeled from crisis to crisis over the past decade, urged Mr Hall "not to give up the day job just yet".

"I don't think a man who revamped the Nine O'Clock News by replacing an older Welshman [Martyn Lewis] with a younger one needs any advice from me about turning around disasters."

Mr Gubbay said the opera house was probably in a better shape now than it had been in years, but it would have been "complete tragedy if it wasn't, given the vast amount of public money that has been poured into it".

Related story:
From Belfast to Covent Garden

webTitle: Lego signs up with Microsoft's Xbox

fields.headline: Lego signs up with Microsoft's Xbox
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Lego has jumped on the computer games bandwagon with a deal to develop games for Microsoft's upcoming Xbox console, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
For generations, the multi-coloured building blocks have been parents' first choice in the playroom.

They stimulate imaginations and help teach that all important co-ordination in the young.

But now Lego has succumbed to market pressure and decided finally to jump on the computer games bandwagon.

It has just signed a pact to develop games for Xbox, Microsoft's soon-to-be launched games console.

The agreement also involves the 70-year-old Danish toy-maker creating online games for Microsoft's websites.

Neither company would put a value on the agreement but analysts see it as a wise move for Lego, which expects to be £44m in the red this year.

Lego's Xbox games will roll out in 2002 while the Microsoft children's websites will launch in Europe late this year.

Kina Paegert a senior Lego spokeswoman in the US, said: "People shouldn't be disappointed by this. As children are changing so are we. Kids are spending more time on the computer and we're providing new interactive opportunities using our well-known imagination and creativity."

The hype surrounding Xbox - Microsoft's serious challenge to Sony PlayStation, Sega and Nintendo - moved up a gear at the weekend when chairman Bill Gates demonstrated the console at a computer games fair in Las Vegas.

Although the boxes won't reach Europe until the first quarter of 2002, Microsoft is on the verge of finalising its advertising arrangements here.

Speculation is mounting that Bartle Bogle Hegarty, in alliance with the DDB network, had scooped the £50m pan-European account.

However, European marketing manager Harvey Eagle dismissed reports that any deal had been done and said that an announcement was expected in mid-February.

The original pitch list included the cream of London agencies but is now a shoot-out between BBH and Lowe Lintas.

webTitle: Profile: Tony Hall

fields.headline: From Belfast to Covent Garden
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: As the manager who presided over the shift of BBC radio journalists from central London to the wilderness of White City, Tony Hall has never been forgiven by old hands at the corporation.
fields.body:
As the manager who presided over the shift of BBC radio journalists from central London to the wilderness of White City, Tony Hall has never been forgiven by old hands at the corporation.

But as one of the key figures in the launch of Radio 5 Live and the development of the BBC's online service, he has transformed the corporation's news service into a highly competitive operation.

An Oxford graduate, Hall began at the BBC as a news trainee in the 1970s, cutting his teeth in Belfast at the height of the Troubles. He became editor of the Nine O'Clock News aged 34. John Birt spotted his work during the 1987 election campaign before he became director general, making him head of television news and current affairs, and then director.

Hall has likened the job, presiding over a department with more than 1,200 staff, to being the home secretary. "You can never be quite sure if prisoners aren't digging their way out somewhere in the empire," he once said.

Friends say he has been an impressive manager: "News has been pretty well run under him. And he's a thoroughly decent man," one said.

But detractors say he is distant and that the launch of the rolling news channel BBC News 24 was not handled well. The channel had to be restyled and is still not seen as a wholehearted success.

Hall is an opera fan - he travels to Verona in Italy every year and is a regular at Glyndebourne. A colleague said he would not have left the BBC for any other job.

His departure, before the expected May election, will be a blow. His deputy, Richard Sambrook, is the frontrunner to succeed him. Other names in the frame are World Service chief Mark Byford, and assistant news director Mark Damazer.

Related story:

BBC chief takes £120,000 pay cut to head Royal Opera House

webTitle: Channel 4 stunt flouts EU privacy laws

fields.headline: Channel 4 stunt flouts EU privacy laws
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 4 may have contravened European privacy laws during a stunt carried out this week by comedian Mark Thomas, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has admitted it may have contravened the privacy laws of several European Union states during an internet stunt carried out by comedian Mark Thomas on Wednesday night.

The Mark Thomas Comedy Product programme featured the comedian trying to gain access to information on MEPs' financial interests, which are only accessible by visiting Brussels.

Records of the interests are hand-written and photocopying or filming is prohibited.

However, the programme got around this by using a team of researchers to copy the register of interests by hand at the parliament's offices, which is permitted.

A database was built from the records and then released on to the specially created website, www.mepsinterests.com, which also has a link from the Channel 4 site.

An EU Quaestor or "prefect MEP" warned Mr Thomas that the programme could be contravening the privacy laws of various member states as he was filmed downloading the database on to the web.

But a Channel 4 spokesman countered that "in the interests of free speech", the broadcaster had decided to flout the laws.

"We may have contravened a few countries' privacy laws, but we took the view that the contravention was minimal," he added.

No charges have been brought by MEPs or the EU so far.

Mark Stephens, partner at law firm Finer Stephens Innocent, said the right to free speech would probably ensure no action.

"There are restrictive privacy laws that in some of the EU states designed to protect corrupt politicians," he said.

"None of this would stand the test of being pierced by Article 10 of the European Convention of Human Rights. In short, it would blow them out of the water."

webTitle: ANDi, first GM primate. Will humans be next?

fields.headline: ANDi, first GM primate. Will humans be next?
fields.standfirst:
Scientists plant alien gene in monkey for first time

Special report on the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Scientists plant alien gene in monkey for first time.
fields.body:
The prospect of genetically modified human beings moved a step closer yesterday with the announcement that scientists had for the first time implanted an alien gene in a monkey, a species closely related to man.

ANDi - "inserted DNA" backwards - a rhesus monkey, carries a gene which makes jellyfish glow green in almost every one of his trillions of natural cells. If he has offspring, they will also carry the gene.

The US researchers who enabled ANDi's birth are not seeking to make GM people. They are trying to create transgenic monkeys which perfectly mimic human diseases, so that ways can be found to cure them.

But rhesus monkeys and humans are so similar - they belong to the same order, the primates - that gene modification success in one is convincing evidence it would work in the other.

"We're not interested in using this technique in humans," said Anthony Chan, of the Oregon Regional Primate Research Centre, where ANDi was born on October 2. "We don't find any reason to do so. But I think there will be a lot of discussion."

Even setting aside the distant prospect of GM people, alarm was already being voiced yesterday about a future increase in experiments on transgenic monkeys.

In ANDi, the jellyfish gene was used as a trial run. "We could just as easily introduce, for example, an Alzheimer's gene, to accelerate the development of a vaccine for that disease," said Dr Chan's colleague Gerald Schatten. "We're at an extraordinary moment in the history of humans."

The easy availability of transgenic mice, modified to mimic human conditions like Alzheimer's disease and obesity, has already led to an increase in the number of animal experiments in Britain.

"Experimentation on primates is particularly problematic because they are closer to us, because we know they are much more likely to suffer in similar ways to us," said Sue Mayer, of GeneWatch UK. "We should think extremely deeply before turning the clock back and increasing the number of experiments we sanction on primates."

Last year the Oregon centre successfully cloned a monkey for the first time.

The birth of ANDi, reported in today's edition of the journal Science, leaves researchers a long way from their goal: to take a primate egg, suppress or remove an inherited gene and insert another gene in exactly the right place.

To create ANDi - who will probably now be patented - the Oregon team took 224 monkey eggs and used a modified virus to carry the jellyfish gene inside each one. The gene was then written into one of the monkey's chromosomes.

A few hours later, the eggs were fertilised with monkey sperm. A little over half developed into full-fledged embryos, and scientists implanted 40 of these in 20 surrogate monkey mothers.

Only three monkey foetuses survived to be born, and the jellyfish gene was detected in only one, christened ANDi. Even in ANDi, the gene does not seem to be producing the chemical it should, since the monkey's hair roots and toenails do not glow under fluorescent light.

Two monkeys which were stillborn did glow, however.

"Efforts to make a fluorescent green monkey are not quite a glowing success - yet," commented Science magazine. "... the cumbersome technique is not likely to lead to transgenic humans, green or otherwise."

Yet scientists point out that ANDi does represent the first evidence that primate eggs can develop normally after genetic manipulation. "Ethics considerations aside, the project might have been easier to achieve in humans, for whom IVF technology is much more advanced," the journal wrote.

Dave King, a campaigner against human genetic engineering, said yesterday: "This is yet another step on the slippery slope to designer babies ... It is science out of control and at its most irresponsible. People should wake up to the fact that genetic engineering of people could be just around the corner."

If a more reliable technique to silence and replace targeted primate genes could be developed, without the huge wastage of eggs involved, some doctors argue that human couples who carry inheritable diseases should be offered the opportunity to have GM babies.

"It all falls into the anti-cloning debate, the slippery slope, the Boys from Brazil - but I think we have to sideline that," said Simon Fishel, head of the IVF clinic at the Park Hospital, Nottingham.

"We've been striving for hundreds of thousands of years to eliminate human diseases. If we get to the stage in human development where the only way to do that is to attack the errors in our blueprint, then we have to try to attack those errors. It doesn't mean attacking God's work.

"I see this as positive research. It just can't be moved into the human dimension until we get, as best we can, a guarantee of the technology."

Dominic Wells, a reader in transgenic biology at Imperial College carrying out research into gene therapy for muscular dystrophy, said of the ANDi work: "This sort of technology would be totally forbidden in humans because of the risk of damaging human genes."

That might not always be the case, he went on. "At the moment, most of us hide behind the fact we couldn't conduct these sorts of techniques with any sort of certainty. If the technology gets to the point where you could, where we have eliminated many of the risks, we would carefully have to consider whether it was ethical or not."

He said the world was caught between trying to restrict research which could have huge medical benefits and allowing transgenic technology to fall into unscrupulous hands.

"Either we risk delaying medically important technologies, or we risk entering Brave New World," he said.

Dr Mayer argued that interfering in human DNA at the egg stage would never be acceptable. "You would be experimenting on babies and the mothers who carry them.

"All the animal work that goes on at the moment involves huge failure rates and huge suffering. I don't think we could even contemplate that with babies. The downside might not come out in the first generation but in the second or later."

webTitle: Peckham library closes to change light bulbs

fields.headline: Library sheds light on bulb riddle
fields.trailText: How many people does it take to change a light bulb? If it's in Peckham library, south London, the answer is four workers toiling for four days.
fields.body:
How many people does it take to change a light bulb? If it's in Peckham library, south London, the answer is four workers toiling for four days.

It might sound like an old joke, but to Southwark council it is no laughing matter. The award-winning £4.5m building was closed this week without warning as electricians began replacing all of its 300 bulbs.

Instead of propping up a ladder, the workers had to move bookshelves and build platforms to reach the bulbs, which are set in the high ceiling of the spectacular structure.

Health and safety experts told the council that staff and the public would have to be kept away while the work was carried out. The library was due to reopen this morning.

The closure angered Southwark council leader Stephanie Elsy. "This is just not acceptable and we can't allow it to happen again," she said. "It's quite incredible that it has to be closed to do routine maintenance work. I can't believe this is the only approach."

Will Alsop, whose radical design for the building won him the £20,000 Stirling Prize, said the council had chosen a difficult method to change the bulbs. "I was surprised to hear it had closed, because there are other ways of doing it beyond scaffolding," he said.

"You could use a mini cherry picker. I think they were a little nervous because it's the first time they have ever done it."

He said his only concern was that the story would provide fuel for critics of innovative architecture. "If we went to all the boring buildings to look at their problems, you would probably find many more."
