fields.headline: Meeting the challenge of the pistachio problem
fields.trailText: New Labour jargon just keeps coming at you, and nowhere as thick and as fast as at the Department for Education and Employment.
fields.body:
New Labour jargon just keeps coming at you, and nowhere as thick and as fast as at the Department for Education and Employment. Yesterday Mr Alan Simpson solemnly asked David Blunkett to address himself to "the pistachio problem, in relation to the new deal."

The pistachio problem? What could he mean? Was it similar to the poppadum poser or the kumquat quandary? The pistachio problem, according to Mr Simpson, is that "they may be moreish, but the ones that get thrown back into the bowl are the ones that are impossible to open".

We were little the wiser at this point, though Mr Simpson went on to explain that these particular nuts might be hard to crack because the employee is stupid, or undereducated, or has a drink or drugs problem - heroin, for instance, being even more moreish than pistachios.

The same is obviously true of backbench Labour MPs, many of whom deeply resent being thrown back into the bowl without being given ministerial jobs. The troubIe is, I fear, that if you used a hammer to open a few of them up, you would find something wrinkled, flaky and rather unsavoury.

In spite of this, I somehow doubt that the pistachio problem will catch on as a phrase or saying, except perhaps in "there's your problem, lady, your processor's full of pistachio shells." But there is a more sinister word emerging. It is "challenge" and it was used yesterday by the schools minister, Estelle Morris, when she was talking about the teacher shortage.

I suspect that there is a New Labour office somewhere, similar to the one where people were paid huge sums to change the name of the Royal Mail to "Consignia" - a word we Godfather fans thought meant the trusted adviser to a Mafia boss.

"Look," ministers say, "these solemn promises we made on our election pledge card in 1997, they're all rubbish. Not one of them has happened. Oh, when we're asked, we say they're 'on track', but only in the sense that a modern train is on the track even when it's standing still. What can we do?"

The consultant, who wears a black Armani suit, a black shirt and shiny black tie, plus hair shorter than William Hague after an accident with a Flymo, says he will need two months to ponder it, and the fee will be 50 grand. He then announces that instead of the pledge (the promise) and instead of the reality (a failure) the policy will be designated a "challenge".

As with all re-branding operations, it will have to be repeated interminably. "Unlike the Conservatives, we are ready and prepared to face the challenge of getting class sizes down!" "The law and order challenge is one that we will not shirk!" "The extra money we are pouring into the health service will enable us to meet the challenge of reducing waiting lists!"

But the election campaign is well under way. Question time ceased to be a means of eliciting information months ago. Yesterday Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said bitterly: "When the prime minister said 'education, education, education,' nobody knew that's the number of days a week our schoolchildren would be educated!"

Pitiful stuff, right? But not as pitiful as Mr Blunkett's reply. "That's three, isn't it? Which government had a three-day week? Wasn't it the Tory government in 1973-4?"

The Speaker, in a rare display of ferocity, twice instructed Mr Blunkett to answer the question and not score points. Fat chance. For months we are doomed to hear ministers saying: "Unlike the Tories who neglected it, we are fully prepared to face up to the challenge of the pistachio problem!"

webTitle: Plavsic pleads not guilty to genocide

fields.headline: Plavsic pleads not guilty to genocide
fields.standfirst:
Ex-Bosnian Serb leader denies tribunal's charges at UN tribunal

Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Biljana Plavsic, the most senior Bosnian Serb politician to stand trial for crimes against humanity, made her first appearance at the international criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia in the Hague yesterday and calmly protested her innocence.
fields.body:
Biljana Plavsic, the most senior Bosnian Serb politician to stand trial for crimes against humanity, made her first appearance at the international criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia in the Hague yesterday and calmly protested her innocence.

Mrs Plavsic, 70, once known as the Iron Lady of the Bosnian Serbs, betrayed no emotion as she stood in the dock to hear the presiding judge read out a series of charges relating to the 1992-95 Bosnian war.

Dressed in a lavender suit and wearing a crucifix necklace, she held her head high as she was accused of genocide, crimes against humanity, violation of the laws or customs of war, and a grave breach of the Geneva Convention.

"I received the indictment yesterday, I have fully understood it and I plead not guilty on all counts," she said.

Mrs Plavsic, who turned herself in earlier this week, is accused of masterminding the systematic ethnic cleansing of thousands of Bosnian Muslims and Croats in the years before and during the Bosnian war.

She is the first woman indicted by the tribunal, and arguably its most significant prisoner after Momcilo Krajisnik, chairman of the Bosnian Serb wartime assembly, who was arrested last year.

"She is a very significant catch for us and this is very important for the prosecutor's strategy of ... bringing the most senior people responsible for what happened in the former Yugoslavia to justice," the tribunal spokesman Christian Chartier said after the hearing.

The chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, asked the court to try Mrs Plavsic jointly with Mr Krajisnik, because they are accused of many of the same crimes.

Together with the tribunal's most wanted man, Radovan Karadzic, they were members of the Bosnian Serb presidency in charge during the war.

Mrs Plavsic, a former biology professor, became president in 1996, when Mr Karadzic was forced from office, and held the post until 1998.

The long indictment alleges that she was aware that terrible crimes were being perpetrated by Bosnian Serb forces under her control but did not use her power to intervene or punish the guilty.

"Having knowledge of such crimes, Biljana Plavsic instead condoned and publicly congratulated the forces that had taken part," it says.

Mrs Plavsic was in fact one of the most fervent proponents of ethnic cleansing as part of the drive to create a Greater Serbia, and even the former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic criticised her for being too extreme.

He said she belonged in a mental hospital while his wife Mirjana Markovic once famously called her "a female Mengele" - a reference to the Nazi doctor who carried out appalling medical experiments on live victims.

A 1992 photograph shows her stepping over the body of a dead Muslim to congratulate the hated Serb paramilitary leader Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic, who was assassinated in Belgrade last year.

Mrs Plavsic's lawyer tried to have her moved out of the tribunal's maximum security prison in nearby Scheveningen, arguing that it had been designed only for men and was therefore unsuitable for his client, who is the only woman held there.

The Bosnian Serb government asked for her return yesterday, promising to ensure that she attended her trial in the Hague, which may not start for some time.

webTitle: Court comes of age with her surrender

fields.headline: Court comes of age with her surrender
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Yesterday, at around 11am, when a woman of 70 stood in the dock, the international criminal tribunal finally came of age.
fields.body:
It is eight years since lawyers began arriving in the empty offices once occupied by an insurance company in the Hague.

At first the international criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia looked pathetically ineffective. The US did note like it, the Europeans did not want to put their soldiers at risk picking up indicted war criminals, and the long arm of international law did not appear to stretch to Bosnia.

The massacres went on. One war criminal was so terrified of his indictment that he rented his summer-house to the French soldiers sent to arrest him.

But yesterday, at around 11am, when a woman of 70 stood in the dock, the tribunal finally came of age.

Biljana Plavsic, a former Bosnian Serb leader who once said that Muslims were "genetically deformed" and ethnic cleansing was a "natural phenomenon", may or may not have her hands covered in the blood of Bosnian Muslims.

It is known that she kept bad company for most of 90s. Infamously, she was photographed stepping over the body of an executed Muslim in the town of Bijlena in April 1992, to kiss Arkan, Serbia's most brutal paramilitary leader. She told reporters: "I exchange kisses only with heroes."

It will be years before the meticulous and methodical tribunal will reach a verdict.

Her decision to surrender herself to the tribunal could mean that she genuinely believes that she had nothing to do with the mass killing of hundreds of thousands of Muslims.

Equally, it could mean that, even for the highest of Bosnian Serb leaders, there is now no escape from international justice, and that by cooperating now she may shorten her eventual sentence.

Next month the tribunal will set up an office in Belgrade, just streets away from the office from where its most wanted man, Slobodan Milosevic, helped orchestrate the destruction of a multi-ethnic Yugoslavia.

At first the international criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia looked pathetically ineffective. webTitle: MoD backtracks on cancer report

fields.headline: MoD backtracks on cancer report
fields.standfirst:
Advice on shells came from senior officers, ministry admits


Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Attempts by the Ministry of Defence to dismiss a leaked report highlighting increased risks from exposure to depleted uranium in shells backfired spectacularly yesterday when it emerged that not only was it written by an experienced military officer but it was endorsed by senior officers.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor and  Peter Capella  in Geneva
fields.body:
Attempts by the Ministry of Defence to dismiss a leaked report highlighting increased risks from exposure to depleted uranium in shells backfired spectacularly yesterday when it emerged that not only was it written by an experienced military officer but it was endorsed by senior officers.

With defence ministers coming under renewed pressure to say what they knew of the health risks of depleted uranium (DU), officials first tried to discredit the report as the work of a "trainee".

But the MoD admitted last night that the report had been written by an "experienced officer". It added: "He was new to the post, with no experience of that particular area".

The report was then given more credence by a second internal MoD document. It emerged yesterday that the report - stressing long-term health risks from DU contamination - was attached to a covering letter from the office of the army's quartermaster general recommending its distribution to military and civilian personnel likely to come into contact with the armour-piercing shells.

The letter was signed by a senior retired officer on behalf of the quartermaster general's chief of staff. Dated April 1997, it warns that on impact "toxic and radioactive dust can be spread inside and outside of the [target] vehicle".

A further army document, dated August 1999, warns soldiers not to "enter or climb a damaged hard target or loiter within 50 metres", adding: "do not eat, drink, or smoke near the damaged vehicle.

"When an AFV [armoured vehicle] is penetrated by a DU round, the core becomes molten and may spread radioactive particles in the air."

In a letter to Geoffrey Hoon, the defence secretary, his shadow minister, Iain Duncan Smith, demanded to know if ministers were advised of the concerns about DU-tipped shells or told that the warnings were wrong.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, said: "The government's efforts to explain away documents relating to depleted uranium lacks credibility."

Faced with a growing problem of credibility, the MoD yesterday promised to publish the leaked documents with what it called a "suitable commentary" as soon as possible.

"Whilst accurate in the main, they contain some significant errors of scientific fact," it said. It referred to the warning in the 1997 document that uranium dust had been shown to increase the risks of developing lung, lymph and brain cancers. "It has not," the MoD said.

Its chief scientific adviser, Sir Keith O'Nions, said the report contained "many, many scientific errors" and did not form any part of the advice given to ministers.

Mr Hoon told Channel 4 News last night that he had not seen the document before it was leaked. "That document is not a document that was passed down the chain of command." He added: "What we are saying is that the risks are very small and have not led in any case that we have been able to establish by the best scientific evidence to any illness for any soldier."

John Spellar, the junior defence minister, infuriated Gulf war veterans earlier this week by announcing voluntary screening for Balkans veterans, without referring to them. Yet some 900,000 DU-tipped shells were fired in the Gulf, most by US aircraft, compared with 40,000 in the Balkans.

The Guardian has found that defence ministers claimed in 1993 that the shells did not produce "soluble depleted uranium". The MoD now says the risk is more from soluble DU than insoluble radiated dust.

The UN yesterday stepped up pressure for a survey of the areas hit by DU-tipped shells in Bosnia - and raised the prospect of a similar mission to Iraq - after traces of radioactivity and pieces of DU were found during a preliminary assessment of sites in Kosovo.

webTitle: Wanted: the seven deadly sinners

fields.headline: Wanted: the seven deadly sinners
fields.standfirst: Story of Texas prison escapees could be a film plot. But a policeman lies dead and there are no heroes in this gang
fields.trailText: Story of Texas prison escapees could be a film plot. But a policeman lies dead and there are no heroes in this gang.
fields.body:
The lawyer's evaluation of George Rivas might have sounded more chilling when the town on the border with Mexico was known as America's six-gun capital. "He is the most dangerous man in El Paso," said the prosecutor. "He never gives up, he's always got a plan and that's what makes him so dangerous."

That was six years ago and 30-year-old Rivas has since been upgraded to the most dangerous man in Texas. Whether he and the six other prison escapees he is thought to lead are in the state at all is a different matter. Since they broke out of jail about 60 miles south-east of San Antonio a month ago tomorrow, there have been "sightings" in Texas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Colorado and Oklahoma - some of them simultaneous.

About one thing, though, there is no doubt. All seven face the death penalty after a policeman was shot dead in a raid on a sports shop in a Dallas suburb. The gang has contradicted the Texas rule of three - that prison escapees invariably are caught within three days and three miles of the breakout - and stoked a mythology to fill the void created by their success in avoiding arrest. A $200,000 (£135,000) reward offered for information leading to their arrest has failed so far to stretch the loyalty of those thought to be harbouring them.

At first they were The Malevolent Seven, a corruption of the title of the 1960 John Sturges movie, The Magnificent Seven, starring Yul Brynner and Steve McQueen; the hunt is the most extensive in the south since that in the 1930s for the bank robbers Bonnie and Clyde (Arthur Penn, 1967); now they are being described as the Seven Deadly Sins (Claude Chabrol, Jean-Luc Godard and others, 1962).

It is only a matter of time before someone recalls The Long Riders, Walter Hill's 1980 elegy to the passing of the old West expressed through the story of Jesse James and his cohorts. But Rivas and his gang, aged between 23 and 38, are anything but romantic figures: two murderers, two rapists, a robber, a kidnapper and a child abuser, all serving long sentences.

"I guarantee you that with the life sentences these people are facing, they're not going to go easily," said Richard "Bo" Dietel, a private eye and former detective. "People are going to be hurt, if not killed. They know they're going to fry because, whoever killed that cop, it's a conspiracy. They're not going to want to go back. They'll definitely get the death penalty. They know that."

Three notes left behind by the fugitives when they made their escape helped to intensify the belief that it will end in bloodshed. "You haven't heard the last of us yet," said one. Another, fantasising about starting a revolution and railing against the "tyranny of the Texas prison system," quoted from the Kris Kristofferson song Me and Bobby McGee: "Freedom's just another word for nothing left to lose."

Rivas put his escape plan into action on December 13, leading the others out of the maximum security Connally Unit in Kenedy, south of San Antonio, in a prison pick-up truck with 14 stolen handguns, a rifle, a shotgun and more than 200 rounds of ammunition.

Two days later came the first of only two confirmed sightings: two of the convicts robbed a Radio Shack electrical store 250 miles away in Houston and got away with walkie-talkies and police scanners. Then, on Christmas Eve, all seven are thought to have taken part in a robbery at a sports shop near Dallas, another 230 miles to the north. This one netted $70,000, 25 weapons and ammunition, and left a 29-year-old police officer dead, his body run over after taking 11 bullets, six in the head.

Roadblocks

Since then, the police, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Texas Rangers have received more than 1,200 tips, but little else to show for roadblocks throughout the state and wanted posters under the counter in hotels and shops.

They have been "spotted" eating fried chicken in San Marcos, 30 miles south of Austin, the state capital, using computers in the town's public library, in a pizza parlour and whiling away an afternoon in a pool hall.

At the same time, they have been "seen" on Greyhound buses headed for Austin and Laredo, city buses in Dallas and in a barn far away in the midwest. "The majority of the calls are law-abiding citizens that want to assist and we deeply appreciate their help," said Larry Todd, a spokesman for the Texas department of criminal justice. "But it's also brought out the weirdos, the bored and the psychics. The people who have seen Elvis have called and, yes, I've had one call from Hollywood. They want the story to make a movie."

The ending is still in question, but another piece of the narrative was put in place yesterday when a report to the criminal justice department said that the seven overpowered a prison supervisor and then other members of staff as they returned to the maintenance room from lunch. Over two-and-a-half hours they made their way to the prison tower, where they stole weapons after getting in when an officer failed to check their identities. Security guards did not respond after a fire alarm was set off and an officer who saw unsupervised men did nothing, said the report.

Prison officers, though, said that the blame went deeper than lapses by a few individuals. "Mistakes are made but, be that as it may, I am still under the belief that lack of staffing is at the root of the problem," said Brian Olsen, deputy director of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The Connally Unit was about 22 officers below its complement of 600 on the day of the escape.

"Someone has to take some responsibility and I think it's at the capitol," said Mr Olsen. The capitol, of course, has just been relinquished by George W Bush, in between jobs as governor of Texas and president of the United States.

Prison officers in Texas start on $1,577 a month and Mr Olsen said that one had resigned recently to work at a taco franchise. "He made better money and the benefits were better."

The Texas prison system is 2,476 officers short of its 26,218 staffing level and their pay puts them 43rd out of the 50 states. An experienced officer receives a salary of $28,000, against a national average of $34,000.

But whoever is to blame, the principals are still at large. "We haven't seen something like this since the 1920s and 30s," said Tony Caeti, assistant professor of criminal justice at the University of North Texas. "Seven guys escape from prison and stay together, commit crimes together. This is the kind of thing you don't see in modern-day crime. In this case you've got some clearly intelligent leadership going on."

Rivas, a former employee at a car parts store who is serving a life sentence for aggravated robbery and robbery, is considered the only one of the seven capable of fulfilling this role.

Richard Coons, a forensic psychiatrist who examined Rivas for his 1994 kidnapping trial, said: "He demonstrates an unusual degree of interest, creativity and intensity in his craft. He is a mastermind and a leader. He is confident and arrogant. He has no conscience and does not speak the truth."

Rivas, whose interest in guns was so great that he called his dogs Ruger and Beretta, told friends that he had but one ambition, even as he started on his career of crime more than 10 years ago: he wanted to be a policeman.

webTitle: PM opts for fox hunting ban as cabinet divisions widen

fields.headline: PM opts for fox hunting ban as cabinet divisions widen
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Tony Blair gave the anti-hunting lobby a boost last night when it emerged he would back a full ban on fox hunting if he were at Westminster when MPs vote on the issue next Wednesday.
fields.body:
Tony Blair gave the anti-hunting lobby a boost last night when it emerged he would back a full ban on fox hunting if he were at Westminster when MPs vote on the issue next Wednesday.

Downing Street confirmed his support but, reluctant to confirm details of the prime minister's diary in advance, could not guarantee he would vote if he was taking a call in his offices. He was, however, expected to be in Westminster.

The prime minister's backing - which advisers hope will strike a chord with 20- and 30-something voters in the run-up to the anticipated election - emphasised cabinet divisions over the issue, on which MPs have a free vote. Introducing the bill last month, the home secretary, Jack Straw, revealed he would support the compromise option of tighter licensing of hunts.

Last night, the social security minister, Jeff Rooker, said he too would vote for licensing. "I don't accept the arguments of either the anti-hunters or pro-hunters completely," he said.

The home secretary's lead is also expected to encourage other cabinet ministers, such as Robin Cook, to support licensing, although leading supporters of the middle way option, Liberal Democrat Lembit Opik and Tory Peter Luff, expect to secure no more than 50 votes on Wednesday.

Labour peer Melvyn Bragg yesterday added his name to those of pro-hunting Countryside Alliance campaigners by urging MPs not to back a foxhunting ban. As pro-hunt demonstrators said they would extend a vigil outside parliament by 24 hours after debate on bill was put back a day, Lord Bragg appealed to MPs to think carefully before supporting a ban.

In a letter sent to MPs and peers with a video about how a Lakeland farmer would be affected, the broadcaster wrote: "The vote could affect fundamentally the livelihood of thousands of families across the country."

The bill is expected to run into severe difficulties when it goes to the Lords next month, but before that MPs will vote sequentially on the three options of: retaining the status quo, adopting the so-called middle way of licensed hunts, or backing an outright ban.

webTitle: Matalan shares fall by nearly 50%

fields.headline: Matalan shares fall by nearly 50%
fields.standfirst: Retailer responds with fury after Christmas trading figures cause City dealers to take flight
fields.trailText: Retailer responds with fury after Christmas trading figures cause City dealers to take flight.
fields.body:
The City's love affair with discount retail group Matalan ended abruptly yesterday after the group released a disappointing trading statement which sent the shares into near-freefall.

They slumped by almost 50% as the market digested the implications of the statement, closing down 247p, or 34%, at 480p. The plunge wiped more than £1bn off the value of the retailer - and £550m off the family fortune of the group's chairman and founder, John Hargreaves.

Matalan's collapse came as the market also took fright at Christmas trading news from home shopping group GUS and fashion group Next. GUS closed down 82p at 462.5p as it warned that fears of a slowdown in the US had hit business levels at its Experian credit information group.

Next finished down 15.5p at 781p after admitting to a £4m overstock problem - although earlier in the day the shares had dipped to 693p.

Matalan's bald figures looked good, with a 16.3% increase in like-for-like sales in the six weeks to January 6.

But the growth fell short of last year's bumper 22.6%, and the group was forced to warn that it had shifted too little stock and would be forced to clear it out by slashing margins, which would hit profits by some £6m. Over the past 19 weeks, like-for-like sales were ahead 13.4%, compared to 22% last year.

"I think the margins have spooked the market, and the sales numbers were not that exciting," said one analyst. Another said Matalan was "a victim of its own success because people had high expectations".

Analysts at Deutsche Bank dropped their profits forecast from £90m to £77m for this year and from £125m to £99m for next, and warned: "We believe that a further hit to profits could be on the horizon."

Matalan outperformed the stock market by 100% last year and until yesterday was on the verge of entry into the FTSE 100 index.

The scale of the share price reaction angered the group's management. Group finance director Ian Smith said: "We told everyone that we would not replicate last year's 22%. We said we anticipated doing 15%, and have come in with 13.4%. How many of our competitors would like to be sitting on 13%? The answer is: all of them.

"I told the analysts they were expecting too much, but they said we always beat our expectations and that we would do it again this year. I think I am speaking in Swahili and they are listening in Aborigine. We are pleased with our trading statement. Our profits will grow by more than 50% this year. That is hardly an accident".

David Jones, the chief executive of Next, sympathised with the Matalan management. "I can't understand why the price has dropped so much," he said. "The stock market is a most peculiar animal."

Like-for-like sales at Next in the 19 weeks to December 24 were 6% ahead of last year's levels, but the stores group admitted they were "below our expectations". The resulting stock overhang would result in a "maximum charge of £4m more than we had anticipated".

Nevertheless, Mr Jones remained upbeat. "Some of the analysts would be stupid not to put their forecasts up for us," he said.

GUS reported a 6% like-for-like improvement in sales at its Argos business in the 14 weeks to January 6 - driven by "strong growth in electricals, furniture, mobile phones and jewellery", and sales climbed by some 35% at its Burberry luxury brand business.

But the shares were hit by problems in the US at its Experian credit rating operation. Experian is widely considered a growth business but its sales were down 2% as companies which use the GUS offshoot to generate mailing lists for direct sales have halted their campaigns in order to cut costs.

webTitle: Business news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: DTI to help Cammell Laird | Vauxhall unions seek redress | Börse shortens listing schedule
fields.body:
DTI to help Cammell Laird

The government is to increase aid to bring a life-saving shipbuilding contract to Cammell Laird. The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, will make a revised offer within weeks on underwriting the bid by the US Luxos Group to build two cruise liners at Birkenhead.

Ministers originally offered to guarantee 60% of the £300m cost but with strings attached to protect taxpayers' money.

Luxos, who had been seeking an 80% underwriting deal, said the offer would not secure the investment needed. At stake are 500 long-term jobs, 500 apprenticeships and spin-offs in supply industries.

Vauxhall unions seek redress

Union leaders are seeking to mount a legal challenge to General Motors' decision to close its Vauxhall car plant at Luton with the loss of up to 2,000 jobs.

Tony Woodley, the T&G's car industry negotiator, yesterday told MPs that GM had broken British and European labour laws. "We have taken legal advice and are still awaiting the outcome of that."

The unions believe GM should have consulted workers' representatives before deciding to close the plant. They claim the closure was a short-term measure to cut costs and had nothing to do with GM's overcapacity in Europe.

Mr Woodley said that in 1998 Vauxhall workers had sacrificed pay in return from an undertaking from Vauxhall that the replacement for the Vectra model would be built at Luton.

But Nick Reilly, Vauxhall's chairman, told the Commons trade and industry select committee that a clause in the deal entitled it to "revisit" its undertaking in the event of a dramatic change in circumstances.

Börse shortens listing schedule

The Deutsche Börse yesterday underlined its determination to fast track its stock market listing when it dropped two proposed elements threatening to complicate the offer. Shares in the Frankfurt exchange are expected to start trading on February 5, well ahead of initial projections of a May listing. The speed with which the bourse is moving will be seen as indicating that it wants the flotation out of the way in order to increase its freedom of manoeuvre amid increasing European consolidation and competition.

webTitle: At this price?  Medisys

fields.headline: At this price?  Medisys
fields.trailText: Suffolk-based safety syringes company Medisys reckons that within a year its name will be known to doctors and nurses throughout the US.
fields.body:
Suffolk-based safety syringes company Medisys reckons that within a year its name will be known to doctors and nurses throughout the US.

The loss-making company is about to introduce Futura, a special type of needle which pops back into its casing to avoid the risk of accidental jabs to health workers.

Medisys yesterday cleared the last hurdle before beginning to sell the device by signing up a distribution partner. The deal was with McKesson, America's biggest distributor of medical supplies, which pleased the City, sending Medisys' shares up 12p to 133p.

The market opportunity is enormous - 66bn syringes are used by health workers in the US each year. President Clinton signed a bill in November requiring hospitals to use safety devices wherever possible to avoid the risk of accidental jabs, which can spread diseases such as Aids and hepatitis.

Research shows that the present sheathed needles still require users to put fingers close to the tips.

Other companies including Scottish firm NMT and US group RTI have developed devices which use springs to retract needles. Medisys uses a type of elastic band which is cheaper. Futura syringes have only four components, instead of seven or 11, making them much simpler to manufacture.

Having received approval for Futura from the food and drug administration last summer, Medisys signed up Nypro, a Massachusetts plastics company, to make the products. There are still risks - the syringes need to be produced to exacting specifications and there can be problems: at one stage, NMT syringes were coming out crooked.

House broker Nomura reckons the company could make profits of £30m next year, rising sharply beyond that. The firm is valued at £440m, hefty for a loss-making business. But if Medisys can grasp the opportunity the price will soar. Buy.

webTitle: BSkyB wins support

fields.headline: BSkyB wins support
fields.trailText: Ever since Vivendi agreed to jettison its 23% stake in BSkyB to win regulatory approval for its merger with Seagram of Canada, the share price of the satellite broadcaster has been under a cloud.
fields.body:
Ever since Vivendi agreed to jettison its 23% stake in BSkyB to win regulatory approval for its merger with Seagram of Canada, the share price of the satellite broadcaster has been under a cloud.

Fears that the overhang will be dumped on the open market has prevented analysts from issuing positive recommendations on the firm and investors from buying its shares.

However, that could all be about to change. Word reached dealers yesterday, from a media conference hosted by Schroder Salomon Smith Barney in Arizona, that Vivendi is not going to sell the stake in the open market.

In fact, Jean-Marie Messier, the boss of merged company now called Vivendi Universal, told conference delegates that it remains his intention to swap the stake for other assets and he hinted that more than one party is interested in the stake.

 BSkyB shares rose 23p to £12.08 yesterday.

webTitle: Business: Three find festive cheer

fields.headline: Three find festive cheer
fields.trailText: Perfume retailer and department stores group Merchant Retail Group, Clinton Cards and supermarket chain William Morrison all announced positive Christmas trading figures yesterday.
fields.body:
Perfume retailer and department stores group Merchant Retail Group, Clinton Cards and supermarket chain William Morrison all announced positive Christmas trading figures yesterday.

Merchant Retail Group reported an increase of 6%on last year in sales for the six weeks to the end of December. Like-for-like sales were up 5%.

Clinton Cards was also upbeat about results for its busiest time of year. The greeting cards retailer said that in the five weeks to the end of December last year like-for-like sales increased 6%. Overall sales from the company's 680 shops were up 7.5% on last year when the group had 695 shops.

Clinton Cards' share price fell 3p yesterday but MRG shares remained stable.

William Morrison's statement, issued after the market closed, reported that trading in the week to Christmas Eve "easily surpassed previous records", despite the strong result last year in the run-up to millennium celebrations.

Like-for-sales, excluding income from new store openings, were up 8% and, after stripping out a 31.8% increase in petrol forecourt sales, they were ahead 5.5%.

Total sales for the Christmas period, including at new stores, were ahead 16.7% on last year.

With four weeks left to the end of the group's financial year, total takings in the past 49 weeks were 15.9% ahead of the same point last year, with sales up 16.2% year on year in the past 22 weeks, the company said.

webTitle: Inquiry into website offering miners fraudulent advice

fields.headline: Inquiry into website offering miners fraudulent advice
fields.trailText: The government yesterday called in its lawyers to investigate a website apparently encouraging thousands of former miners to make fraudulent compensation claims for an industrial disease known as vibration white finger.
fields.body:
The government yesterday called in its lawyers to investigate a website apparently encouraging thousands of former miners to make fraudulent compensation claims for an industrial disease known as vibration white finger.

Police are also investigating the site which gives precise instructions on how to "beat the tests" carried out by doctors at 15 centres in coalfields and former mining areas.

More than 200 former miners contact the government each week about vibration white finger. The Department of Trade and Industry said it was seeking legal advice on the website and had alerted doctors at testing centres amid fears that fraudulent claims could cost the taxpayer hundreds of millions of pounds and jeopardise genuine demands for compensation.

The DTI has paid out £206m in compensation for vibration white finger, a disorder affecting the blood vessels in the body's extremities such as fingers and toes and caused by prolonged use of pneumatic tools at the coalface.

It has settled just over 19,000 cases at a total cost of £131m, and made interim payments in a further 21,000 cases. But nearly 116,000 claims have been lodged - almost three times the numbers expected by officials.

Sources said that if all the claims were settled the cost to the taxpayer could be £800m. But Whitehall officials suggested that the website, which came to the government's attention on Tuesday, might not have been active for very long.

"We are very concerned about this bogus website but it's difficult to know how many cases have been fraudulent," an official said. "We are pretty confident that the majority of cases tested so far are genuine."

Government sources pointed out that it might be difficult to prosecute the people running the site.

The site gives detailed instructions on how to convince doctors that the claimant is suffering from VWF. It tells claimants to make sure their working history tallies with the period VWF is known to have been a problem in the coal industry - after 1975 and before August 1990 when new health and safety provisions came into effect.

Whitehall officials insisted that the tests had been designed to be individually based so anything that encouraged people to exaggerate their symptoms was unfair on the majority of genuine claimants, many of whom would be suffering severe symptoms.

webTitle: Construction group Taylor Woodrow makes late bid

fields.headline: Taylor makes late bid
fields.standfirst: Link with Bryant seen as ideal for housebuilder
fields.trailText: Link with Bryant seen as ideal for housebuilder.
fields.body:
Construction group Taylor Woodrow yesterday gatecrashed the planned marriage of two UK housebuilders, Bryant and Beazer, by making an unsolicited £507m cash-and-paper offer for Bryant just four days before the nuptials.

The Bryant board, which had ignored Taylor Woodrow's initial overtures, first made on Monday, met all day yesterday to consider the offer which was said by insiders to represent a 32% premium, and offered shareholders considerably more cash than the Beazer proposal. The outcome was said to be "finely balanced".

The board, which announced its planned merger with Beazer to create a £870m group called Domus on December 14, is due to seek shareholder approval at a meeting on Monday but Taylor, which made its offer late on Wednesday, urged shareholders to reject it.

The group, frustrated by Bryant's failure to respond, felt it had no alternative but to make its offer of 45p cash and 0.831 new Taylor shares for each Bryant share, valuing its target's shares at 184.5p. The alternative merger is worth 24p a share in cash, comprising a 5.6p special dividend and a half share in a £100m buy-back.

The battle for Bryant is evidence of a new drive for consolidation in Britain's housebuilding industry. Taylor's offer would make the enlarged group the country's biggest in terms of market capitalisation and fifth largest by volume - behind Wimpey, Barratt, Persimmon and Beazer.

Sources close to the company said Taylor's strategy of expanding its presence in housebuilding - it ranks 14th - could only be achieved with a partner and Bryant fitted the bill in terms of geographical spread, land bank and management. The Bryant brand would be retained.

But the Bryant board was said to consider that its agreed merger with Beazer would create a pure UK housebuilder while marriage with Taylor would expose the company to the uncertainties surrounding the US economy. Taylor earns 70% of its profits outside the UK - and half the total comes from the US housing market.

webTitle: Business Notebook: Matalan's fallibility shows

fields.headline: Former favourite is given a stock response
fields.standfirst: Discounter's fallibility shows
fields.trailText: Discounter's fallibility shows.
fields.body:
So the men from Matalan do not walk on water. If there was one retailer the City had decided would be a Christmas winner it was the mob from Skelmersdale who have turned discounting into an art form.

Yesterday's trading statement showed that the group is still showing strong growth, with total sales for the six weeks to January 6 - up a whopping 49% on last year - and like for like sales up 16.3%. They are figures Marks & Spencer would die for, but Matalan has set an astonishing pace in the last couple of years. Clearly, such heady growth could not go on forever, but sometimes the City's finest are lacking in the reality department.

Hence yesterday's quite astonishing share price reaction, which wiped £1bn off the value of the company. An over-reaction? Almost certainly.

But Matalan has now proved that it is fallible. The company insists it has been telling analysts for some time that growth would slow, and that they simply were not listening.

However, Matalan's problem is not just one of a maturing market. Its growth is hinged on an aggressive programme of store openings. In November, that growth stalled when some of the 10 stores scheduled to open that month were delayed. That left too much stock, which must now be cleared with half-price sales.

Prior to the delayed openings, the group had cut back on the marketing campaigns it had traditionally used to bolster new store openings, fearing its distribution system could not cope. The net result saw sales growth of 15% in October slashed to 4% the next month.

There are now suspicions that Matalan is not telling the full story. Analysts fear there could be more bad news to come. They are concerned about the demands on the warehousing system. Overstocks still have to be cleared. When buyers have been left with an overhang they often lose their nerve, then have the problem of stock shortages. They fear another profit warning in the spring after customers spend their cash on sale goods rather than new lines. Matalan has lost its shiny halo.

London Bridge

On the face of things, London Bridge Software is a great British hi-tech success story. Founded 14 years ago by Gordon Crawford - who remains as executive chairman - the company has built an enviable reputation around the world for its specialised software used for managing both corporate and consumer debt.

A client list which includes names such as Lloyds TSB, Ford Motor Credit and Chase Manhattan saw the company's stock market value soar to £2.6bn at one stage during last year's tech investment mania.

Yesterday, however, the City took a big bat to London Bridge's rating after it issued profits warning. Four key contracts which it expected to sign up before its end of December year-end were "delayed by customers", since London Bridge "was not prepared to offer additional discounts, conditional payment terms, or other onerous conditions to obtain signature in 2000".

So profits will now be less than £10m, rather than the £15m or so the market was expecting. The shares slumped 25% initially before settling 40p lower at 310p, bringing the company's value back to £530m.

So far, so routine. But what was really shocking about this statement was that it followed another from London Bridge just three weeks ago, which began: "London Bridge ... is pleased to announce that it has recently concluded negotiations upon four significant orders", before going on for more than 14 substantial paragraphs to celebrate the company's great progress.

Only a forensic reading of the ninth paragraph of that earlier statement, which refers to the company not yet having met its US budgets, would have given a clue as to what was coming. Indeed, investors were left to wonder whether the four contracts concluded before Christmas might be the same as the four unsigned contracts cited yesterday - something which Mr Crawford was subsequently able to clarify is not the case.

The December statement itself was triggered by an continuing spat London Bridge has been having with a City analyst named Tim Steer, from the stockbroker Collins Stewart, whose complex share valuation techniques give the company a dud rating. Mr Steer is reckoned to be one of the very best smaller to medium companies specialists, but London Bridge thinks he is not taking a fair view of its accounting procedures and fears a whispering campaign is under way.

It has become very messy, and while Mr Crawford, who continues to own half the shares in issue, believes he has a perfectly good relationship with everyone else in the City other than Mr Steer, the proof is in his share price, which has all but halved over the past month.

An intensive course on communication skills would seem to be in order.

A client list which includes names such as Lloyds TSB, Ford Motor Credit and Chase Manhattan saw the company's stock market value soar to £2.6bn at one stage during last year's tech investment mania. Yesterday, however, the City took a big bat to London Bridge's rating after it issued profits warning. Four key contracts which it expected to sign up before its end of December year-end were "delayed by customers", since London Bridge "was not prepared to offer additional discounts, conditional payment terms, or other onerous conditions to obtain signature in 2000". So profits will now be less than £10m, rather than the £15m or so the market was expecting. The shares slumped 25% initially before settling 40p lower at 310p, bringing the company's value back to £530m. So far, so routine. But what was really shocking about this statement was that it followed another from London Bridge just three weeks ago, which began: "London Bridge ... is pleased to announce that it has recently concluded negotiations upon four significant orders", before going on for more than 14 substantial paragraphs to celebrate the company's great progress. Only a forensic reading of the ninth paragraph of that earlier statement, which refers to the company not yet having met its US budgets, would have given a clue as to what was coming. Indeed, investors were left to wonder whether the four contracts concluded before Christmas might be the same as the four unsigned contracts cited yesterday - something which Mr Crawford was subsequently able to clarify is not the case. The December statement itself was triggered by an continuing spat London Bridge has been having with a City analyst named Tim Steer, from the stockbroker Collins Stewart, whose complex share valuation techniques give the company a dud rating. Mr Steer is reckoned to be one of the very best smaller to medium companies specialists, but London Bridge thinks he is not taking a fair view of its accounting procedures and fears a whispering campaign is under way. It has become very messy, and while Mr Crawford, who continues to own half the shares in issue, believes he has a perfectly good relationship with everyone else in the City other than Mr Steer, the proof is in his share price, which has all but halved over the past month. An intensive course on communication skills would seem to be in order.

webTitle: Jeb Bush grilled on voting irregularities

fields.headline: Jeb Bush grilled on voting irregularities
fields.standfirst:
Civil rights commission asks Florida governor to explain why many black voters were disenfranchised

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Civil rights commission asks Florida governor to explain why many black voters were disenfranchised.
fields.body:
Jeb Bush, the governor of Florida and brother of president-elect George W Bush, was hauled in front of the US civil rights commission yesterday to face questions about the irregularities which allegedly discriminated against voters from ethnic minorities.

He was one of the first called to testify at the two-day hearing of the allegations that thousands of people were denied the right to vote in Florida on November 7 by harassment, registration irregularities, illegal polling purges and intimidating police road blocks.

On Wednesday campaigners began a legal action against state officials for institutionalised racism.

Mr Bush told the eight commissioner: "I am delighted that you are here to sort out any discrepancies that might exist [in the election process]."

As he did during the controversial recounting of votes, he tried to distance himself from the proceedings, saying he had no "direct responsibility" for state elections.

But campaigners in Florida accused him of turning a blind eye to the real issues with his "politic" appearance before the commission.

Larry Spalding, legislative counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union in Florida, said: "What the governor wants to focus on is technology, but what needs to be discussed is ... why some people were not permitted to vote, and why so many problems were found in minority or Hispanic-speaking areas."

JoNel Newman, speaking for the Florida Equal Voting Rights Project, told the commissioners that many voters arrived at polling booths only to find that they had been purged from the electoral lists or that they were mistakenly listed as felons and thus barred from voting.

He also said that many election officials refused to provide bilingual ballots or assistance to disabled voters on election day.

In Florida, 93% of black votes counted were for Vice-President Al Gore.

Mr Newman's group has called for extensive reform of the Florida system. It urged the commission to recommend sweeping changes, and not just the improvement of "poor and unequal voting technology".

Mr Spalding said the ACLU was a party to the lawsuit as well as the government hearings because it lacked faith in the local legislature. "The people asked to make the changes benefited from the system the way it is," he said.

George W Bush was eventually named the winner after the supreme court decided to stop manual recounts in Florida. The Republicans had won there by less than a 1,000 votes, and allegations of irregularities emerged.

This week's lawsuit asked a federal judge to outlaw the use of the punch-card ballots used in 25 Florida counties.

The counting of "chads" - the punched-out pieces of paper - became a key source of contention.

The National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People and the ACLU are also demanding federal oversight of Florida elections for the next 10 years.

The Florida allegations come at a sensitive time as the president-elect prepares for nomination hearings on several controversial cabinet appointments.

He has made a huge effort to portray his party as inclusive but his cabinet has been rocked this week by the revelation that Gale Norton, his nominee for secretary of the interior, delivered a speech in 1996 invoking the Confederacy and slavery in fighting for states' rights.

The civil rights commission is expected to recommend remedies to Congress and the president in a final report this summer.

webTitle: California close to blackout

fields.headline: California close to blackout
fields.trailText: California's electricity crisis worsened last night and the state authorities issued a warning that blackouts could be imminent.
fields.body:
California's electricity crisis worsened last night and the state authorities issued a warning that blackouts could be imminent.

The independent agency which runs the state's power grid declared a stage-three emergency to protect the network from collapse after more than a third of California's power generation capacity was taken out of production.

The crisis has caused a huge political row and threatens California's two big private sector utilities with bankruptcy. Pacific Gas & Electricity and Southern California Edison are having to pay the generating companies 10 times as much but are prevented by Californian law from passing on the increase to their customers.

The two companies are estimated to have run up uncovered costs of $12bn.

"We are spending more than $1m an hour to keep the lights on," a PG&E official said this week.

Under the deregulation programme which came into effect in 1998 the utilities were forced to sell off the bulk of their generating capacity, much of which went to out-of-state companies.

The utilities blame the generators for the escalating prices.

With reserves down to less than 1.5%, talks were under way in Washington yesterday to find a solution to the crisis.

webTitle: Obituary: Sir Denys Lasdun

fields.headline: Sir Denys Lasdun
fields.standfirst:
Towering figure of modern British architecture whose buildings - such as the National Theatre - continue to attract controversy

Architects pay tribute to Denys Lasdun
fields.trailText: Towering figure of modern British architecture whose buildings - such as the National Theatre - continue to attract controversy.
fields.body:
The architect of the Royal National Theatre, Sir Denys Lasdun, who has died aged 86, was already an impressive figure as a student at the Architectural Association in the 1930s. His upright carriage, the sculpted head and commanding eyes, perfectly expressed the sureness with which he was to chart his way through an embattled profession.

At coffee time in Ching's Bar, Denys would not be engaged in noisy debate. He would sit with one other person, honing his architectural beliefs. Tradition, for him - as for the rest of us - was the modern movement. He saw classicism as a constant, discreetly hidden in every revolution, and recognised the paradoxical link between the desire for total renewal in art and a deep attachment to the past.

Although the principal, EAA Rowse, was a lifelong influence - along with Maxwell Fry and Berthold Lubetkin - Lasdun left the AA early, without a diploma, to work with Wells Coates, a member of the MARS Group, the intellectual sounding board of modernism. Two years later, he joined Tecton, Lubetkin's practice, on which all modern eyes were turned. Before war put a stop to such things, he built a house, 32 Newton Road, Paddington, strictly following Le Corbusier's domino principle. Later, Ronald Searle bought it and dreamed up the awful girls of St Trinian's there.

From 1939 to 1945, Lasdun served with the Royal Engineers, and was awarded an MBE before returning to Tecton as a partner. When the firm was dissolved in 1947, he set up in practice with Lindsay Drake, and continued to work on a Paddington housing scheme, the Hallfield estate.

Links with the London County Council architect's department, a centre of excellence, brought them the commission for Hallfield primary school, on which they were able to demonstrate, they believed for the first time, that a primary school should appear physically as the centre of an area. This was a generation of architects excited by the possibilities offered by reinforced concrete, and powered by social commitment.

Next came the chance to build cluster blocks for Bethnal Green, east London. This innovative idea consisted of four 14-storey stacks of flats linked to a central stair and lift tower. It allowed for piecemeal renewal on bombed sites, and and was probably the most interesting built example of Le Corbusier's "streets in the air".

Art was endemic in the Lasdun family. His father, an engineer and businessman who died when Denys was only five, was a cousin of the artist Leon Bakst, who worked with the Ballets Russes. His mother was a pianist, so his childhood was spent among music and musicians. He was educated at Rugby school.

His marriage to Susan Bendit, in 1954, continued the artistic tradition. She had been at Camberwell art school, and went on to study graphics, and to write. Their honeymoon was spent visiting the classic modern buildings of America. Susan understood the nature and the problems of architecture, and later worked on the interiors and colour of the National Theatre, among other buildings.

Late in the 1950s - and a far cry from Bethnal Green - a stunningly simple block of flats arose overlooking Green Park, in the West End of London, and gracefully took its place between two classical buildings without a single cry of outrage. 26 St James's Place was London's first experience of strata, though the idea had been fermenting in Lasdun's mind for 20 years.

He said that "strata express the visual organisation of social spaces in geometrical terms; they recall the streets and squares of the city and contour lines of the hills; and, at a more profound level, they bear witness to the roots of an architectural language inspired by natural geological forms." When fighting his corner against the derangement of strata at the National Theatre, Lasdun claimed, "strata have given the Thames back to London."

The 1950s ended triumphantly for Lasdun with the commission for the Royal College of Physicians (RCP), on a site in the circle of Nash's terraces overlooking Regent's Park, north London. I believe that the prestige of the college, and the honour of designing for such a site, gave this son of Russian Jewry a place he had desired in Britain's establishment - and the Royal Institute of British Architects' 1992 trustees' medal.

I remember Lasdun saying that he regretted not having been to university, and wondering what a man of such presence, with such marvellous command of English, and of so philosophical a bent, imagined a university could do for him. The RCP became his favourite among his buildings: "It accorded with the Nash terraces without imitating them." And 30 years later, a meeting room he added to the building turned out to be one of the three "entirely satisfactory spaces" of his oeuvre.

The National Theatre was a live project in the office, by then Denys Lasdun and Partners, for 13 years. The architect was appointed in 1963. While other contenders faced the board as a multi-professional team, Sir Peter Hall has recalled the drama - amounting to pathos - of Lasdun's solo performance.

Any building called upon to accommodate three theatres (one seating 1,100 people), their audiences, scenery, props, workshops, foyers, restaurants and bars, is bound to provoke controversy. At the National, admiration tends to centre on the magic of the foyers and the Olivier Theatre, which was inspired by the ancient amphitheatre at Epidaurus - the largest of Lasdun's "entirely satisfactory" spaces. Criticism is mostly of backstage arrangements, the lack of signposting, and, of course, the concrete. This material enabled Lasdun to open up the public spaces of the building to the public view. He likened the project to planning a small city.

Lasdun was very skilled in the use of concrete. He told Sir Peter Hall: "Concrete is a very intractable material, but it can be a beautiful material if it is used in the way its own nature intends it to be used ... It is a sort of sculpture that you can only do with reinforced concrete, but you need to work to a certain scale ... It is not a cosy little material."

In 1976, Lasdun's long struggle to reconcile the wishes of a many-headed client with his own highly disciplined vision was marked by a knighthood. I think the award of the Royal Gold Medal for Architecture represented a consensus of British architects in acknowledging his stature.

With such architects' work, the question repeatedly arises: should the key buildings of an architectural epoch be altered as their use continually demands? The fact that user requirements change was the reason why modern theory favoured lightweight and demountable buildings. At the National Theatre, the absence of weightbearing walls is conducive to change, but the reinforced concrete strata are not. Is the masterpiece in reinforced concrete on the South Bank not as worthy of preservation as Somerset House, that earlier masterpiece on the north bank?

At Christ's College, Cambridge, Lasdun's superb, stepped residential building met with disaster, when the college, pressed for more accommodation, allowed a lesser building to be tacked on to the street facade, and so to prevent the terraced block from being seen ever again in its entirety.

He was luckier at the University of East Anglia, where the architects who succeeded him as master planner have respected his plan and its intentions. Chief among these is the protection of the site's natural form. The Teaching Wall, which follows a contour line, is still the dominating presence, and the sheen produced by skilled casting is still visible.

Like other architects, Lasdun designed many projects that never got built. Among these is a powerful, geometric design, defined by four pairs of towers, for the ancient site of the Hurvah synagogue in Jerusalem. After Louis Kahn's death in 1974, it looked as though it might go ahead, but this now seems unlikely.

I do not know when Lasdun wrote, "Every building has, at its heart, a generating idea, which must express itself through every part and in every detail." Looking back at the Hallfield school, its plan now appears overdesigned. With each building of his since then, the details, still lovingly designed, seem to merge more smoothly into the impression of the whole, which is of ever increasing scale.

The latest, and largest, of the stratified designs is the European Investment Bank, in Luxembourg. The spacious, woodland site has allowed a simpler plan, which may adapt more readily to change than more condensed buildings. At the centre of this cruciform plan is the Water Room, one of the spaces that Lasdun found "entirely satisfactory". William Curtis has the last word on the Luxembourg building: "It reaffirms," he has said, "that it is under statement that makes powerful art." Art of this kind demands a lifetime's dedication of working and thinking.

Denys Lasdun is survived by his wife and three children, all of whom work in the arts; Louisa as a composer, James as a writer and William as a sculptor.

 Fiona MacCarthy writes: Denys was in ebullient mood, greeting his friends with bear hugs, when I saw him last month at the opening of the British Museum great court. As a fellow architect, who loved to work on the grand scale, he was full of admiration for Norman Foster's scheme.

He dismissed the controversy over the new stone portico as irrelevant, mean-minded criticism of a kind to which he had himself become all too accustomed in a lifetime of architectural slings and arrows. We planned to visit him and Susan in their house in Hammersmith as soon as the builders (yes, the builders) had moved out.

Denys's enthusiasms had always seemed unstoppable. He was, more than anyone, my architectural mentor. I first got to know him well on holidays in southern Tuscany, staying with our shared friends, Sally and Graham Greene. My perceptions of Grosetto and its hill towns, of Massa Maritima and the Etruscan tombs, will always be entwined with my memories of Denys's affectionate lucidity.

His friendships crossed the generations; my young daughter Clare adored him. All companions of honour should be forced to take a Lasdun test in lack of pomposity and openness of mind.

Those who think of Lasdun as an architectural brutalist get him wrong completely. They miss out on the imaginative richness of his buildings. He was a subtle, deeply knowledgeable man. His feeling for the ebb and flow of cities, the disconcerting beauties of modern urban life, transmitted itself in a strange way to his son James, whose success delighted Denys. My favourite late Lasdun building, the meeting room at the Royal College of Physicians, seems energised by the traffic circulating frenziedly round Regent's Park.

The retrospective at the Royal Academy in 1997 confirmed Lasdun as the most important British architect of the last half century. A detail that entranced him was the peephole through from his exhibition to the late Braque show beyond it. These were the sort of juxtapositions Denys loved.

 Denys Louis Lasdun, architect, born September 8 1914; died January 11 2001.

webTitle: Smith faces museums retreat

fields.headline: Smith faces museums retreat
fields.standfirst: Minister may have to strike deal on trustee independence
fields.trailText: The government's plans to curb the independence of the trustees of Britain's national musems is facing certain defeat at the hands of a cross-party alliance of peers, unless ministers are prepared to compromise.
fields.body:
The government's plans to curb the independence of the trustees of Britain's national musems is facing certain defeat at the hands of a cross-party alliance of peers, unless ministers are prepared to compromise.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, is in trouble with the powerful museum and gallery lobby because his culture and recreation bill will give him sweeping powers to be "consulted" about the appointment of their chairmen and to amend their constitutions without consulting parliament.

At issue is the independence of publicly-funded bodies - from the Royal Armouries in Leeds to research institutions like the Natural History Museum in Kensington - from excessive interference by ministers in both parties seeking to promote their own cultural agenda.

Mr Smith, who denies that he has been "bounced" by his officials into dishonouring a promise last autumn not to go down this road, believes the museums, opposition MPs and peers and the media are over-excited about "a storm in a teacup".

He also denies any "Stalinist" ambitions in what Whitehall calls a simple "tidying up" exercise on museum powers.

Though Mr Smith is publicly resisting further compromise he may be willing to insert changes that would entrench the principle of "consent" by the trustees.

He meets his critics to try and thrash out a deal in private on Monday, three days before the bill gets its second reading in the Lords.

webTitle: Call to catch loyalist pipe bombers

fields.headline: Call to catch pipe bombers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Politicians yesterday urged Protestant communities to help the police catch loyalist pipe bombers terrorising Northern Ireland's Roman Catholics.
fields.body:
Politicians yesterday urged Protestant communities to help the police catch loyalist pipe bombers terrorising Northern Ireland's Roman Catholics.

The call came as a family narrowly avoided injury when a pipe bomb was hurled through the window of their house, the second such attack in Larne, Co Antrim, within 24 hours. A 16-year-old boy had a lucky escape after carrying a device from his garden in Kilrea, Co Londonderry.

William McCambridge, who has four children, said after the attack: "This is happening week in week out. Eventually someone is going to get killed."

He appealed to the loyalist Ulster Democratic party and Progressive Unionists to try to end the violence.

There have been more than 30 pipe bombings, an average of two a week, since October. Nationalist SDLP assemblyman Danny O'Connor, who represents Larne where most of the attacks have occurred, accused loyalists of trying to drive out all Catholics.

"A lot of people don't want to admit it, but there is a form of ethnic cleansing going on in Larne," he said. "If this goes on, sooner or later someone is going to die. Catholics just don't feel safe anywhere."

Mr O'Connor, whose brother escaped injury when a nail bomb went off in his flat a few months ago, has given a dossier on 160 incidents in the past two years to the British and Irish governments.

He called on the RUC to stage more covert operations to catch those responsible. He appealed to the Protestant community to help.

"Someone knows the bully boys who are doing this. Please help the police, so the decent citizens of Larne, Protestant and Catholic, can sleep soundly in their beds," he said.

Larne's Ulster Unionist mayor, David Fleck, also condemned the attacks, as did Sean Neeson, leader of the Alliance party.

The RUC sub-divisional commander, Superintendent Karen Kennedy, said the attacks were "cowardly and reckless" and urged anyone with information to contact the police. She said her officers had carried out more than 300 operations specifically to combat sectarianism in Larne in recent months.

webTitle: Police investigate 62 deaths linked to Shipman

fields.headline: Police investigate 62 deaths linked to Shipman
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Detectives in Greater Manchester yesterday began an inquiry into the deaths of 62 more patients of serial killer Harold Shipman, who was convicted a year ago of 15 murders.
fields.body:
Detectives in Greater Manchester yesterday began an inquiry into the deaths of 62 more patients of serial killer Harold Shipman, who was convicted a year ago of 15 murders.

The deaths, not previously investigated, emerged as suspicious during a clinical audit commissioned by the Department of Health and published last week.

Families of the 62 patients had not made contact with the police when the original investigation began in 1998 after the exhumation of the body of Kathleen Grundy, Shipman's last known victim.

The clinical audit, carried out by Richard Baker of Leicester University, suggested that Shipman could have been responsible for up to 300 murders.

Detective Chief Superintendent Bernard Postles said that police had carried out a comparison between the deaths originally investigated and those classified by Professor Baker as suspicious or highly suspicious.

"This has identified 62 deaths which have not yet been investigated by police," said Mr Postles.

He said the original inquiry, which he headed, had examined cases where relatives and friends had come forward with suspicions.

"The priority at this stage is for the police to make contact with the relatives or friends of the people whose deaths are regarded as suspicious," said Mr Postles.

"We are in the process of carrying this out, although this will obviously take some time."

The investigation is unlikely to bring Shipman back to court since the crown prosecution service had already ruled out further prosecutions.

The fresh inquiry means that police will have investigated the deaths of a total of 254 patients of the GP, who practised first in Todmorden, west Yorkshire, and for 20 years in Hyde, Greater Manchester.

Fifteen cases led to Shipman's prosecution and conviction at Preston crown court.

Police also drew up a list of 24 other cases in which they believed there was enough evidence to convict. Inquests have this week been held on the first three of those 24 and the south Manchester coroner John Pollard has recorded that each patient was unlawfully killed.

Prof Baker's examination of Shipman's clinical records found that Shipman had certified 297 more deaths among his patients than doctors in similar practices.

He said that, allowing for error, the figure could be as high as 345. But he believed the true total to be 236, the number of patients who had died at home.

Later this month, Prof Baker will travel to the north-west to explain to relatives of Shipman's patients how he identified potential victims.

The new police inquiry was welcomed by the families of Shipman's former patients and the lawyers who represent them.

webTitle: G2: Private lives

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: As a transsexual, should I demand to go to a friend's wedding as a woman?
fields.trailText: As a transsexual, should I demand to go to a friend's wedding as a woman?
fields.body:
Recently I was invited to my friend's wedding. I have known her for more than 10 years and, naturally, I was delighted. I went out with my friend a couple of days later and, hesitantly but forthrightly, she told me that the invitation may be withdrawn. I am a male-to-female transsexual in the process of transition, living and working as a woman.

However, my friend's husband to be has said that I can only come as a man as he does not appear to be able to treat my needs seriously and is worried about how his extensive family may react to my presence. I sympathise with my friend's position but am extremely angry about her fiance's attitude, especially as he is a very active member of the local Labour party and purports to have a commitment to socialist ideals and human rights. What can I do?

It is their day, not yours

A few years ago I would have recoiled in horror from the insensitivity of your friend and her fiance. Now, having lived for a while beside the transitional phases of a friend's transsexual journey, I see both sides of the story. Your personal path is a minefield, but so is the path that your friends are taking in relation to you. They used to have a man friend; you're asking them to have a woman friend. For people of either gender that's a very different sort of friendship.

For people who meet you for the first time, who might be uncertain whether you're male or female or something in between, it's a strange and discomforting experience - and not one to be undertaken in the goldfish-bowl atmosphere of a wedding.

This is their day, not yours. Thank your friend warmly and say you'll cut the ceremony if they don't mind, but you'd love to come and see them in their own home a few weeks later. Go as a woman, take your present and a bunch of flowers, and give your friend and her new husband time to adjust to your new identity at a time when you all feel more relaxed.
Alison Leonard
Chester

She should fight for you

These people are not enlightened and it is best to stay out of it. Something similar happened to me in 1995 when my brother was to marry. He phoned me after sending out the invitations to let me know that it was "inappropriate" that I bring my same-gender partner to the wedding. It was the usual argument that I should keep my sexuality to myself. My partner was reduced to my sexuality, just as you as a person have been reduced to your transsexuality by both your friend and her future husband.

A decision about a wedding and its guests involves two people, and if one of the parties has reservations in inviting someone based not on somebody's character or friendship but on their transsexuality, sexuality or skin colour, then it is up to the friend or relative of the guest in question to stand up for their values.

Otherwise their own values and opinions get swallowed up in those of their partner, which means that you are persona non grata to your friend as well as for your friend's husband. I know how painful this is, and I also know what violent recriminations can ensue if one starts calling each other names over it. I did not go to the wedding and wouldn't have, even if all hell hadn't broken loose, which of course it did.

Let your friend know that it is just as much her decision as his whether you come to the wedding. If you are not invited it is a sign that your friend is not able to be an equal partner in their relationship and is unable to stand up for who you are. In short, let them know how you feel without making any attacks on them, and then remove yourself from the scene. There are better people in this world, and I recommend spending more time with the latter than with people who can't stand up for you and who you are.
Vicky Temperton
Berlin

Make no concessions

I have been a transvestite for three years, dressing properly at every possible opportunity. I go cross-dressed to all sorts of events - cinema, theatre, parties and church services - and am often the only cross-dresser present. Furthermore I use public transport.

Transvestites and transsexuals may be a small minority but we are becoming recognised and accepted, so there is no excuse for the ignorance and attitudes of your friend's fiance. Make no concessions. At the least attend the wedding service or civil ceremony properly dressed - that is open to the public. If the groom does not relent and tries to bar you from the reception then he deserves to be shamed in public. Joanie Nichols
Wolverhampton

Don't allow blackmail

Of course, you cannot allow your friend's fiance to emotionally blackmail you in this manner. You have made the decision that you are going openly to live and work as the woman you have always inwardly known you should be, a decision that involves enormous courage and conviction, and to revert to being "a man", even for a day, to appease your friend's fiance would be a retrograde step.

I hope your friend will understand this and that she will continue to count you as a friend even if her husband cannot; but if she doesn't, the possibility that you would lose some of your friends must have been one of the painful consequences you considered before you took your decision. You will eventually make new and valuable friends.
Helena Newton
Ilford

Next week

In 1980 our elder daughter, then 13, developed permanent tinnitus. This was a terrible strain. Then, aged around 21, she showed increasing signs of mental illness. She was sectioned three times and eventually went into a care home, which she left to do a degree.

She demands attention and unrealistic "help" from us almost daily, by agitated phone calls or hours of sobbing or shouting in our house. She cannot make friends normally, organise or plan ahead, and often loses money, keys, etc. She is verbally and sometimes physically aggressive. She does not hallucinate but lacks empathy and, though articulate, has problems with rational discourse, so we suspect her diagnosis should lean towards Asperger's syndrome rather than "schizophrenia"; but she resists professional help.

Our health has been severely damaged by our daughter's illness. She could fail or even abandon her college course this year and return to our house, where she will make normal life impossible. What future for her - or us as we enter our 60s?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words.
