webTitle: Dyslexia therapy 'getting results'

fields.headline: Dyslexia therapy 'getting results'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pioneers of a revolutionary therapy for dyslexia, which includes physical exercises designed for astronauts, hope it may eradicate the problem among children within a decade.
fields.body:
Pioneers of a revolutionary therapy for dyslexia, which includes physical exercises designed for astronauts, hope it may eradicate the problem among children within a decade.

They say children attending their private treatment centre show astonishing improvements in reading, spelling and writing and that their methods, if approved by outside experts, could bring vast economic benefits while improving the self-esteem of those with learning difficulties.

Staff at the centre in Kenilworth, Warwickshire, say nearly all children show significant results within three months of starting the treatment. It includes techniques employed by the US space agency, Nasa, to treat astronauts who suffer a form of temporary dyslexia, perhaps linked to experience of weightlessness, which disrupts links within the cerebellum, the part of the brain that controls coordination.

The exercises, and a special machine designed for the agency, remind the brain how to function smoothly. The Dyslexia, Dyspraxia and Attention Treatment Centre uses a £100,000 machine to screen children and help prescribe exercises which range from passing an object from one hand to another behind the back to passing a bean bag from one hand to another above eye level while standing one-legged on a cushion and reciting a multiplication table.

Parents pay £475 for an assessment and exercise package and may have to make subsequent visits at £75 a time. So far just under 100 sufferers have undergone the treatment, which challenges the traditional targeted teaching programmes used to combat the condition.

Bodies campaigning on dyslexia, thought to be a severe problem for about one in 25 people, are interested in the work, but advise caution against hailing a miracle cure.

The centre's main funder Wynford Dore, whose daughter Susie, 28, suffered from dyslexia, said: "I have lived with the guilt she suffered so badly, underachieving through her school years despite excellent help from her teachers."

He added: "The results at the centre are beyond my wildest dreams. It is a national scandal that many children with learning difficulties are not identified, let alone helped."

David Reynolds, a professor at Exeter University and former head of the government's numeracy task force, is conducting an outside review of the work.

He said: "If it works, everyone should get it quickly. If it doesn't, I don't want people to be disillusioned and led down the garden path."

webTitle: Virgin cuts fares by half to kick start rail revival

fields.headline: Virgin cuts fares by half to kick start rail revival
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson yesterday heralded a round of price cuts on the railways by announcing a 50% reduction in Virgin train fares in an effort to win passengers back after the Hatfield crash.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson yesterday heralded a round of price cuts on the railways by announcing a 50% reduction in Virgin train fares in an effort to win passengers back after the Hatfield crash.

He described it as the world's biggest rail offer, saying he hoped it would give a "kick start" to rail's recovery. It will cost Virgin £10m, but Sir Richard said it was worth it to regain passengers' confidence.

Other companies, on the back of a promise by Railtrack that 85% of the network will be back to normal by the end of the month, are expected to follow suit. South West Trains, which operates commuter and long distance services to the West Country, is planning a similar promotion.

Within hours of Sir Richard's announcement Great North Eastern Railway said it would be reducing scheduled journey times by up to 74 minutes in its latest timetable. It was now able to run 85% of its services on the east coast main line.

Christopher Garnett, GNER chief executive, said: "We are well on the way to restoring the full level of fast, frequent services that passengers have come to expect."

Promising "no catch" deals, Sir Richard said it would be possible to travel between London and Manchester and Liverpool for £10 return.

A first class return from London to Manchester will be reduced from £230 to £115, and from London to Birmingham from £137 to £68.50. Cut price returns from London to Glasgow are reduced from £77 to £38.50.

Sir Richard said that the risk was worth taking and that over the next 12 months Virgin would get its money back. Virgin expects to attract an extra 1m passengers during the promotion, which will apply to most tickets.

The industry's continuing problems were highlighted yesterday by the revelation that up to 800 passengers on seven trains outside Brighton were abandoned for several hours in the dark in an incident several months ago.

Some got out of their trains and walked through a tunnel along electrified lines to get to safety.

Wendy Toms, chairwoman of the rail passengers' committee for southern England, last night warned that the situation was becoming so critical that passengers were threatening staff.

"It is incredible that this is happening, but one can hardly blame them.

"The driver of the first train which broke down abandoned his post and no other staff were around to explain what was happening."

Ms Toms said that staff at Brighton station became so alarmed for their safety that they called police, who dispersed the angry crowds.

Connex, one of the two companies involved in the incident, has promised to pay each passenger £25, regardless of the ticket type held, for the inconvenience, although the weakness of current franchise agreements on the railway means that it is not obliged to do so.

Rory Cantwell, a passenger in one of the trains, said: "The only way to get any redress is for passengers to revolt en masse. Connex should be sued for its failure to live up to its basic contract between a passenger and a transport system."

He said: "It took people more than six hours to complete an hour's journey from London. Consumers are the least important element in the hierarchy as they are tied to a monopoly service intent on making a guaranteed profit."

Connex said it would give "more careful consideration to any future incidents of a similar nature".

webTitle: More heads quit despite pay rises, says report

fields.headline: More heads quit despite pay rises, says report
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than 2,700 headteachers' posts became vacant last year, as salary levels soared, according to an annual survey published today.
fields.body:
More than 2,700 headteachers' posts became vacant last year, as salary levels soared, according to an annual survey published today.

Some 2,177 primary, 444 secondary and 99 special school headships were advertised in national newspapers. The figure is higher than in any other year since the survey began in 1985 - except 1997, when many heads and deputies left before the introduction of new rules making it harder to retire early.

The report was compiled by John Howson of Education Data Services, in association with the National Association of Head Teachers.

Nearly a third of primary schools (31%) and one in five secondary schools (19%) were forced to readvertise more than a month afterwards. In inner London, six out of 10 did so. "The situation in London was dire," Professor Howson said.

David Hart, general secretary of the NAHT, said: "The record level of vacancies for school leaders is alarming. Headteachers are leaving their jobs in almost unparalleled numbers.

"The turbulence caused by such a heavy turnover of senior staff threatens the drive for higher standards. This is not just a pay issue. The need to provide state school leaders with the resources and the support that their counterparts in independent schools enjoy becomes ever more urgent."

In church schools the situation was worse, with over half of Roman Catholic schools having to readvertise their vacancies for teachers. The number of deputy headship vacancies also rose, from 2,132 in 1999 to 2,417.

The education department said it had relaxed retirement rules between 1999 and 2000, making it easier for headteachers to leave. Mr Hart said that was "a drop in the ocean" of the overall increase.

But the survey also showed that pay levels for headteachers continued to rise. In March 1999 the average secondary head earned nearly £45,000 and the average primary head £32,500. But Prof Howson's report said few secondary schools advertised at less than £60,000 and primary headships had broken through the £50,000 barrier.

Michael Murphy was appointed as head of Crown Woods comprehensive in Eltham, south-east London, last year on £90,000. Prof Howson predicts the first £100,000 head could be appointed within two years.

Yesterday David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, clashed with MPs in the Commons over staff shortages. He said 73,000 people registered with the Teacher Training Agency's information line in the last four months of 2000 - double the number for the same period in 1999. Of those, 14,000 had contacted the line since Christmas.

Mr Blunkett said there were now 2,250 more trainee teachers in England and Wales compared with last year and 7,500 more in post since 1998.

But Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said: "Children are being sent home early. There have been schools on a four day week and some schools are threatened with a four day week.

"When the prime minister said 'education, education, education', no one knew he meant that was the number of days in a week children would be going to school."

Mr Blunkett told the cabinet yesterday morning that there "was not a single school on a four day week". He acknowledged that there were pressures, and problems in particular areas, but they were not about investment, said the prime minister's official spokesman.

 The government announced yesterday, after pressure from headteachers, that pupils who have been expelled from school would no longer be included in data used for the annual performance tables.

webTitle: Bomb explodes in packed chip shop

fields.headline: Bomb explodes in packed chip shop
fields.trailText: Police around Britain were put on alert last night after a letter bomb packed with nails exploded in a crowded chip shop in Holywell, north Wales.
fields.body:
Police around Britain were put on alert last night after a letter bomb packed with nails exploded in a crowded chip shop in Holywell, north Wales.

The shop owner's son, Jonathan Davies, a father of two, narrowly escaped injury when he opened the envelope at 9.40am yesterday.

His father, Robert, said everyone nearby was lucky to be alive, although no one was injured. He said the explosion was "like a shotgun going off".

The bomb is the latest in a series of attacks on homes and businesses across the country, but Holywell residents said they could see no reason why the Davies family would be targeted.

A North Wales police spokesman said: "We are keeping an open mind at the moment and as the investigation continues we are liaising with other forces across the country to see if there is any connection with other incidents."

The envelope had been delivered to the shop in the town's High Street 10 minutes before it exploded.

The shop owner said the postman delivered the mail by hand every day to counter staff.

A Post Office spokeswoman said: "We are working closely with North Wales police on this matter. We are very relieved that no one was injured and deplore any action that puts the safety of our customers and staff at risk.

"There are security measures in place to uncover suspect packages but obviously this one passed those measures and didn't raise any cause for concern."

The postman has been interviewed by police as a matter of routine, the spokeswoman added.

Similar incidents include one on December 31 last year when the six-year-old daughter of the owner of a pest control company in Congleton, Cheshire, sustained superficial leg and foot injuries after a letter bomb exploded.

A week later, a 58-year-old man suffered facial injuries when he opened a small package containing nails at his farm in Ripon, North Yorkshire.

A female member of staff at a farm in Patrington, Humberside, was hurt after opening a letter containing a small device.

On Wednesday morning this week a retired doctor, Richard Cockerill, 64, was targeted by animal rights protesters who set off a car bomb outside his home in Hurst Green, near Oxted, Surrey. No one was injured but two vehicles were damaged.

Police sealed off part of Holywell town centre yesterday to carry out forensic tests. They have asked people to be vigilant and to report any suspect packages received through the post.

webTitle: G2: Shagufta Yaqub on his pilgrimage to Meccah

fields.headline: My first real holiday
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Shagufta Yaqub: Coming from a working-class Pakistani family that migrated to England in the 70s, I never really understood what my fellow Britons would describe as a holiday.
fields.body:
Coming from a working-class Pakistani family that migrated to England in the 70s, I never really understood what my fellow Britons would describe as a holiday. My family would save their pennies and every few years we'd go back to the "homeland", making that all-important trip to Pakistan. It was the most exciting thing we ever did, but looking back now I would hardly describe it as a holiday.

I suppose the common understanding of a holiday is a break from the norm, a journey to a different place made purely for the sake of pleasure. In that sense of the word I had never had a holiday in my life. I started to become aware of this fact a few years ago and suddenly felt cheated that what I thought of as holidays were in fact family necessities. Births, deaths and marriages were the real reason we'd go to Pakistan, coupled with the fact that the family wanted to meet their relatives.

That's when I decided that I was going to make up for lost years by going on "real holidays". For a Muslim the concept of a holiday is not a familiar one. But an inherent part of the Islamic tradition is the idea of making a journey for the sake of God. The pilgrimage to Mecca was something I had grown up hearing about.

As a child I would sit for hour after hour listening to stories about the journey that millions of Muslims still describe as the most amazing experience of their life. These tales of Mecca had such a mythical quality that they belonged more to the realm of fantasy than reality. It was as though Mecca was, quite literally, out of this world.

As the yearning for Mecca was sown in my heart from early childhood, it was naturally the first place I wanted to go. As a Muslim I couldn't justify travelling anywhere merely for the sake of pleasure before first travelling to the most sacred place on earth for the sake of God. I remember telling a friend that I had been deprived of holidays all my life and that I was going to start taking them - after first going to Mecca. "The only problem is," she said, "once you've been to Mecca you'll never want to go anywhere else."

That sounded like a romantic idea; I did not expect that it would bear so much truth. Last year, in the Christmas break that coincided with the Islamic month of Ramadan, I made my first pilgrimage to Mecca. This year I did the same thing. Now I have barely been back in England a week and my plans for next year are already starting to take shape. The thought of spending more than a year away from Mecca is almost unbearable.

People often ask what it's like going to Mecca, but if words could describe it millions would not make the journey to experience it for themselves. Going to Mecca is more than fulfilling a religious obligation. It is travelling to the spiritual centre of the Muslim world, to the House of God, towards which Muslims across the globe face five times a day in prayer. It is an opportunity to stand before God in humility, admitting your faults, seeking His forgiveness and relying on His mercy.

There, in detachment from the world they leave behind, pilgrims see their lives in their real context. When all worldly distractions are put aside, the magnificence of God starts to become apparent and pilgrims can only bow down in prostration and praise, recognising themselves as nothing but the servants of God.

Leaving Mecca is like leaving your heart and home. Those who have been once long to go back, and every time they leave they depart making one prayer: "O Lord, invite me here again." Having been to the most sacred of places, my desire to go anywhere else was diminished. I suppose now I might never get a chance to understand what a holiday means to the average British person.

Even as a child I would wonder why people don't live in the present and why they constantly dream of that annual escape. It is as though life is what happens in those two weeks abroad - the other 50 weeks of the year just fill the time in between. But somewhat ironically, it is also only after going back to Mecca that I can start to comprehend this British obsession with holidays.

While the desires that drive a holidaymaker to the beach and a pilgrim to Mecca are as different as heaven and earth, there is an interesting analogy in the need to get away from everyday life. It is in the sun, sea and sand that the tourist takes relief from the strains of life by escaping to the most pleasurable parts of the world, living out fantasies and dreaming of better days to come. The pilgrim, on the other hand, takes refuge in God from the world itself, seeking forgiveness and praying for a better predicament in the afterlife.

Unlike the holidaymaker, the pleasure of the pilgrim is not in escaping from reality but in going to the place where it can be seen most clearly. For both however, there is something inherently human in the need to live in hope of a better future. The only difference between the holidaymaker and the pilgrim is that the former's dreams are lived out within the confines of the earth; the latter's are located far beyond.

webTitle: ABB to change focus

fields.headline: ABB to change focus
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Electrical engineering group ABB yesterday announced a corporate overhaul designed to equip the company for the competitive demands of the internet age.
fields.body:
Electrical engineering group ABB yesterday announced a corporate overhaul designed to equip the company for the competitive demands of the internet age.

Its new president and chief executive, Jörgen Centerman, has decided the company should focus on customer groups rather than the traditional business segments and has given the job of implementing the change to Eric Drewery, head of ABB's UK operations.

"We are responding to a silent revolution in the market that is completely changing the business landscape. Faced with increasing complexity and speed - much of it driven by the internet - our customers want clarity and simplicity," Mr Centerman said yesterday.

"Instead of the mass marketing of the past, the internet allows us to interact with our customers one-on-one and deliver customised information, products and services on a massive scale."

webTitle: Comment: A Palestinian's tale of Israel's travel restrictions

fields.headline: When I tried to go to the airport ...
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A Palestinian describes the never-ending travel restrictions imposed by Israel.
fields.body:
I am a Palestinian Christian, born and raised in Bethlehem, and pastor of the Christmas Lutheran Church. I am also director of the International Centre of Bethlehem.

Recently, I was supposed to visit the United States with my wife, who happens to hold a US green card. We were invited by friends and fellow Christians from Florida, Illinois, Kansas and Missouri, who were looking forward our visit as much as we were. They had worked hard to organise a series of lectures, preaching engagements and important meetings for me. However, I found myself sitting in my office in Bethlehem writing this instead.

What would it take for an average American to travel abroad, besides a valid passport, a visa and a ticket? Not much more, I would say. Yet a Palestinian cannot leave the country without a travel permit. The permits are issued by the Israeli military based in the illegally built settlement bloc by the name of Gosh Ezion, six miles south of Bethlehem. Yet, how can one reach Gosh Ezion if Bethlehem is sealed off and one is allowed to drive, in a Palestinian green licence-plate car, in a one-mile radius only? First, I had to get a yellow licence-plate taxi to travel on one of the so called bypass roads built on confiscated Palestinian land, yet designed mainly for the use of Israeli settlers. I met the taxi on December 28 at one of the many roadblocks.

Once we reached our destination, my wife and I submitted our applications. We were told that it was forbidden for Palestinians to leave the country unless they had foreign passports. We were instructed to come back in three days. Then I was told that my wife had been given a permit, but that I had not. The reason given was that my wife had a green card and I didn't. I told them that I have, as a clergyman, a Vatican passport. The soldier said: "Then, you should fill new forms, attach a copy of your passport and apply again." I did as I was told. I drove to the roadblock, but found that there was a small opening in the road that would allow my car through. I decided to take a chance. During the six-mile journey my wife and I were afraid of what might happen if a settler decided that our presence on the road is not to his or her liking. Finally, we reached our destination and got our permits. We returned to the roadblock, but an Israeli military vehicle blocked the way. A gun was pointed at us and we were told to go back to the place we'd come from.

For more than an hour we drove from roadblock to roadblock, looking for an opening. Finally, we found one and were able to pass through before the soldiers saw us and closed it.

On January 4 at 09:30 we set off (in a yellow licence-plate car) for Ben Gurion airport, which is about 30 miles north-west of Bethlehem, to catch our 16:35 flight. The soldiers at the entrance of Bethlehem stopped the car, asked for the permits, checked them and allowed us through. We arrived at the airport early and were first in line.

We handed our passports, tickets and permits to the security official, who looked at the permit and then at us and at the permits again. She said our permits were not valid and that we could not fly. "But the people who issued them reassured me yesterday on the phone that they are," I argued. She said that she would check with the airport police, who then told her that the permits were invalid. Being prepared for anything, I had the phone number of the military authorities who issued the permits and I called them.

I spoke to the captain, who reassured me that the permits were valid. I gave my cell phone to the security officer to hear it for herself. She sent another officer to the airport police, who returned with the answer: "No Palestinian is allowed to leave the country." "Let me talk to the police authorities myself," I said.

Meanwhile, her boss arrived and shouted at her for wasting her time talking to us. I went in search of the police (leaving my wife at the counter with the luggage), but one can reach the airport police only if you already have a boarding pass.

Finally, I was told to walk to police headquarters, which is outside the main building in the airport. When I got there, they wouldn't let me in. The woman at the desk dialled a number and handed me the phone. I explained to the policewoman on the other end what was going on and her answer was: "No Palestinian is allowed to leave the country. These are our instructions." She refused to take the number of the military authorities to talk to them and insisted that they should ring her. I called the military authorities again and asked them to talk to the airport police, which they promised to do. For the next three hours we were caught between the military authorities, airport police and airport security.

At 15:35 I called the captain at Gosh Ezion, who told me that he had tried his best, but that there were orders which he could not overrule. I should wait until things calmed down. But how can things calm down if they continue to treat people like this? I am not talking about the financial loss, the taxis and tickets, nor about lost time and stress. Rather, I am talking about basic human rights of free movement and of living in dignity.

What would you do if you were in my shoes? Many Palestinians, especially Christians, choose to emigrate. Others are radicalised. The constant, inhumane treatment eliminates their imagination of a better life here and now. But we Palestinians are here to stay. For better or for worse we have to live with whichever agreement is brokered by the US.

What would I do if I were in President Clinton's shoes? I would make sure that the Palestinians had real sovereignty, control over their borders, their roads, their airspace, so that tomorrow not one single Palestinian would be treated the way I was treated yesterday. I am not talking about luxury, but rather about living without humiliation.

If I were in Clinton's shoes I would follow the footprints of Christ and do everything possible to bring justice, healing and hope to the land in which the Divine gave humanity its meaning, dignity and promise.

webTitle: Obituary: James Carr

fields.headline: James Carr
fields.standfirst: Lack of ambition and instability blighted his career as a gifted and widely admired soul singer
fields.trailText: Lack of ambition and instability blighted his career as a gifted and widely admired soul singer.
fields.body:
When Dan Penn and Chips Moman paused during a poker session to write The Dark End Of The Street, in a Nashville hotel room in 1966, they created probably the most beautifully proportioned and viscerally affecting of all soul ballads. The song was to enter the repertoire of many great singers and musicians, from Aretha Franklin to Ry Cooder. But in James Carr, who has died aged 58, the composers were fortunate to find its first and finest interpreter.

There are plenty of eminent observers - Peter Gural- nick, Charlie Gillett, Barney Hoskyns, Andy Kershaw, and the Memphis music historian Robert Gordon among them - who consider Carr to have been among the most remarkable singers of his type.

Soul fans notoriously reserve a special affection for the fugitive and the obscure, and, in recent years, Carr has been widely championed as a better man than the far more widely known Otis Redding, whose origins and style were comparable. Certainly, anyone who wants to know how good a singer James Carr was needs only listen closely to his delivery of The Dark End Of The Street: "At the dark end of the street/ That's where we always meet/ Hiding in shadows, where we don't belong/ Living in darkness to hide our wrong."

The song is 44 bars long, in an AABA structure - a kind of modified 12-bar blues with an eight-bar bridge passage. The recording, made at the Hi studios in Memphis, opens with a shivering, tremolo-laden guitar arpeggio before the entry of Carr's dark, gaunt baritone voice. When he gets to the third line of the first verse, he does something that establishes his right to be considered a great singer.

Over the sort of medium-slow tempo that would encourage most soul singers to lay back behind the rhythm, Carr chooses instead to push the word "hiding" ahead of the beat, an effect suggesting the urgent catharsis of confession. And at the end of the line, he lingers over "belong", lightly ornamenting the second syllable in a way that freights a single word with a world of sorrow.

Throughout the record, Carr sounds deeply troubled. He usually did; the best of his mid-60s recordings were filled with grief and lamentation. Some of this was the result of conscious artistry, but there seems to have been another cause. His life, as it turned out, was an unhappy and confused journey, whose detours prevented him from capitalising on his undoubted talent.

The son of a Baptist preacher, he was born in Coahoma, Mississippi, in Delta blues territory, but, when he was three, the family migrated north to the relative prosperity of Memphis. At six, James was singing solos in church. At nine, he was a member of a gospel quartet, the Harmony Echoes. In his teens, he began to take engagements as a solo artist in the distinctly secular clubs clustered around Beale Street, while earning a living in a furniture factory.

Roosevelt Jamison, an amb-itious young songwriter, became his manager and mentor. In 1965, they signed a deal with a new record label, Goldwax, run by Quinton Claunch, a former air-conditioning salesman who planned to challenge the local hegemony of Stax Records, whose stars included Redding.

Carr's initial releases made little impact but, with the intense She's Better Than You, it was evident that he had found his voice. You've Got My Mind Messed Up gave him his first hit, followed by Love Attack, Pouring Water On A Drowning Man and, in the last weeks of 1966, The Dark End Of The Street.

But as success came, so Carr became more difficult to work with. A simple man, who had been taught to read and write only when Jamison took him in hand, he was prone to vagueness at the best of times, a trait exacerbated by a fondness for reefer and by the medication he took to counter fits of depression. He needed patient handling if he was to be coaxed into giving a performance.

His lack of ambition, and inclination to drift into semi-catatonic trances, sabotaged all attempts to further his career, whether by Jamison or by Otis Redding's management team, which briefly assumed control of his affairs, before recognising the impossibility of the task. He recorded unsuccessfully for Atlantic in 1971, but then lapsed into a silence briefly broken by tours of Japan and Italy. On his last night in the Far East, he seized up on stage.

In his absence, the legend grew. Admiring articles were written, and he was among the central figures in two authoritative studies of southern soul, Guralnick's Sweet Soul Music and Hoskyns's Say It One Time For The Broken Hearted. Meanwhile, he was living in a housing project in South Memphis and, although reunited with Claunch for two albums, Take Me To The Limit (1991) and Soul Survivor (1993), was never fit to launch a serious comeback. Treatment for cancer preceded his death.

On a tour of Britain and Ireland in 1998, Dan Penn made a striking introduction to his best known song. "Everybody keeps asking me which is my favourite version of Dark End Of The Street," he said, "as if there was any other than James Carr's. Not even mine. I'll sing it anyway. But I wish I had James here."

 James Carr, singer, born June 13 1942; died January 7 2001.

webTitle: Letters: Renovating Berlaymont

fields.headline: Renovating Berlaymont
fields.trailText: Your readers may have gained the impression that the costs of removal of asbestos from the Berlaymont building in Brussels and of the related renovation have risen from an original estimate of £100m to £700m (EU inquiry into £700m revamp, January 6).
fields.body:
Your readers may have gained the impression that the costs of removal of asbestos from the Berlaymont building in Brussels and of the related renovation have risen from an original estimate of £100m to £700m (EU inquiry into £700m revamp, January 6). The impression was also given that such costs would be "shared" between the Belgian state and the European commission. Any such impression would be seriously misleading.

The figure of £700m appears to be an estimate by two Belgian MPs of the total costs to the Belgian state of the removal of asbestos from the building, of the renovation of the building, and of the net annual cost of providing replacement accommodation to the commission during the period since 1991 when the building was closed. However, the commission's obligations relate solely to renovation and acquisition costs totalling £238m. The commission will not, therefore, be faced with the prospect of having to "share" the total costs.

We are, nevertheless, concerned by the prospect of any cost overruns and notified the Belgian authorities of the commission's profound concerns (and they began their own inquiries and actions). The various actions will be pursued with the purpose of ensuring the satisfactory completion of the Berlaymont project, without unnecessary further delay and with proper safeguards for public funds.
Neil Kinnock
Vice president, European commission

webTitle: Letters: Met's damage limitation

fields.headline: Met's damage limitation
fields.trailText: I am a friend of Sonia and Delroy Lindo and have witnessed the trauma that they and their children have suffered at the hands of the Metropolitan police (Met ready to settle £1m claim by activist, January 11).
fields.body:
I am a friend of Sonia and Delroy Lindo and have witnessed the trauma that they and their children have suffered at the hands of the Metropolitan police (Met ready to settle £1m claim by activist, January 11). The campaign of victimisation was bad enough, but now they have to witness the squalid spectacle of senior officers turning cartwheels to deny the findings of the report that they themselves commissioned.

It is deeply ironic that "high-ranking officers" are now attempting to discredit the report on the basis that the conclusions were drawn "without proper analysis" - because deputy assistant commissioner Tarique Ghaffur did not interview any of the 47 officers who came into contact with Mr Lindo. The form the inquiry took was decided on by Ian Blair, the assistant commissioner.

The police involved should have been interviewed, and where appropriate disciplined and prosecuted for their actions - after all, as we are repeatedly told by the Met, racism is a crime. The fact that they were not was entirely the fault of senior police officers. Once again the Met are showing that they are more concerned with damage limitation than justice.
Jenny Sutton
London

webTitle: Leader: The MoD is short-changing itself

fields.headline: A crisis of credibility
fields.standfirst:
The MoD is short-changing itself

Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: The MoD is short-changing itself.
fields.body:
There are now two issues involved in the rising concern over the use of depleted uranium shells by British and allied forces. One is the damage they may have done to servicemen and to local civilians. That is far from resolved, though in our view the evidence that the risks were significant cannot be lightly dismissed. The second is the credibility of the Ministry of Defence. That grows weaker daily.

Britain has maintained all along that the risks are not significant. Other Nato members see things differently: Germany and Italy think its use should be banned. The scientific advice, at home and abroad, is conflicting. But attempts at reassurance fall on sceptical ears in a nation which was told by complacent ministers that scientists were giving a clean bill of health to beef during the BSE crisis. Or which has more recently learned how the health of volunteers was indefensibly risked in experiments at Porton. The offence was long ago, but the cover-up continued for many years after.

That would make it hard at any time for the MoD to say to those who came through the Gulf and Balkan wars: "We know the facts. You can trust us." But what little chance the MoD had of getting the benefit of the doubt must have been blown by the way it has handled the issue this week. On Monday night, as the Guardian went to press with a report that the government was about to concede the case for a full investigation, the department was still telling the BBC that this was nonsense. Next day, they had to confirm it - though in another last minute rewriting of scripts, the concession was now confined to those who had served in Bosnia and Kosovo; those who fought in the Gulf were excluded. Yesterday, the pattern was repeated as the Guardian disclosed that army doctors had warned of the dangers four years ago. Again the first response was to rubbish the report: a "discredited draft prepared by a trainee", they called it. That story was hardly out of MoD mouths before it started to crumble.

We said a few days ago in the context of Labour's botched handling of the issue of party political funding that the best advice must always be this: at times like these, do not try to wriggle your way out of trouble; come as clean as you can, as soon as you can. That advice applies in spades to the MoD. It is no good asking for trust if those who make the appeal are behaving in ways which seem so plainly untrustworthy.

webTitle: Letters: Pack drill

fields.headline: Pack drill
fields.trailText: The Law Society is not bolstering restrictive practices in its opposition to the homes bill (Leader, January 9).
fields.body:
The Law Society is not bolstering restrictive practices in its opposition to the homes bill (Leader, January 9). The society supports many aspects of the bill and welcomes the government's initiatives on homelessness and the allocation of social housing. We support the idea of a seller's pack but do not think the inclusion of the survey should be a compulsory element. This will disadvantage those whose homes are of low value and who have low incomes. The criminal law should not be used to make people comply with this provision.

The society has also been at the forefront of electronic conveyancing developments which could make home buying faster and more efficient.
Michael Napier
President, The Law Society

webTitle: Letters: Fickle voters

fields.headline: Fickle voters
fields.trailText: Jeremy Hardy's sneering at Andrew Marr (You have to be an idiot at the BBC, January 10) suggests that, unlike Marr, he knows little of academic work on elections over the past 20 years.
fields.body:
Jeremy Hardy's sneering at Andrew Marr (You have to be an idiot at the BBC, January 10) suggests that, unlike Marr, he knows little of academic work on elections over the past 20 years. By common consent among psephologists, the modern British electorate is fickle and volatile as was dramatically illustrated last September. No one knows how tactical voting will work at the next election or what the effects of the widely expected lower turnout of former Labour voters will be. Despite the state of the Conservatives, Marr is right to be cautious.
Prof David Denver
Lancaster University D.Denver@lancaster.ac.uk

webTitle: Leader: New regime for Royal Opera House

fields.headline: Making the Garden grow
fields.standfirst: A new regime requires a fresh approach
fields.trailText: A new regime requires a fresh approach.
fields.body:
In matters cultural, an executive appointment by the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden - handling the business side, moreover, rather than deciding who gets to wear Darcy's tutu while she is temporarily a little too big for it - is small earthquake territory. Grand things are happening in opera, but they tend to be in Cardiff, Leeds, at Glyndebourne and - now minus its internal scaffolding - the Coliseum. Compared with the royal battles being fought in Berlin, Floral Street is these days an oasis of peace. Much more is to be expected from Antonio Pappano's arrival next year as musical director to succeed Sir Bernard Haitink than from the transfer across London of BBC apparatchik Tony Hall.

Yet because of where it is and the amount of subsidy it gets, Covent Garden will always be in line of sight. Mr Hall, it is true, arrives postwar. Sir Richard Eyre's elegant but radical plan for reorganising London's lyric theatre is history. At the ROH an even keel is now in place, thanks to Michael Kaiser, who picked up the pieces after the Isaacs-Gummer-McIntosh soap opera. Money is a worry, but name a major venue where it is not. A background in news journalism and buttering up John Birt is not the most obvious preparation for adding to Covent Garden's artistic lustre, so perhaps Mr Hall should just strive to keep the vessel afloat and leave the mise en scène to others. But he is supposed to be a professional communicator and Covent Garden could sorely do with an enthusiastic and public champion, with the mental muscle to defend quality's expense. What the ROH lacks are vocalists - spokespeople to defend, say, the decision to re-run Hans Pfitzner's Palestrina despite recent findings about his Nazi complicity. Back-to-back Cinderellas and Nutcrackers (pretty much this month's fare) have their place, but Covent Garden's future as the national centre for dance and singing must surely lie with works, old as well as new, that break ground.

webTitle: Letters: Consignia - what's in a name?

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.trailText: Those who criticise names like Consignia and Accenture (Diary, January 11) for being meaningless miss the point.
fields.body:
Those who criticise names like Consignia and Accenture (Diary, January 11) for being meaningless miss the point. They are meant to be meaningless, confusing the public, whilst freeing the company from the shackles of national identity and product identification. Along with Carillon, Corus, Uniq and the rest this rebranding will allow them to operate all over the world, buying, selling, locating, relocating, hiring, firing, shedding and diversifying without anyone knowing where they're from and what they make. It reminds me of a fashion item I once saw around the waist of a solemn, expensively dressed Japanese woman in Tokyo. It was a black leather belt carefully embossed at regular intervals with the single English word "Bullshit".
Michael Palin
London

Will "Consignia" still publish the Post Office Guide, which told us not to send bees or leeches to the Seychelles, or playing cards to Vanuatu, or perfumes and saccharin to the Vatican?
Adrian Smith
Leeds

Goodbye, postie. Hello, consigniere?
Joe Ross
Lewes, E Sussex

Consign it to the bin.
Neil Croll
Derby

The gender of snow people has little to do with carrots (Letters, January 11). Snow-balls make the difference.
Tony Gaskin
Penrith, Cumbria

I am appalled. It has been established in these pages that size is measured in Isle of Wights, Waleses and if absolutely necessary, Belgiums (Letters, June 5, 2000). In yesterday's report the asteroid Eros was described as the size of Manhattan! Readers may wish to know this is about half an Isle of Wight.
Copland Smith
Manchester

webTitle: Letters: Bush's war in Colombia

fields.headline: Bush's war in Colombia
fields.trailText: It seems the new US administration is setting its stall out early in escalating US aggression in Colombia (20,000 grams under the sea, G2, January 8).
fields.body:
Following the statement from Robert Zoellick, senior adviser to President Bush, that "we cannot continue to make a false distinction between counter-insurgency and counter-narcotics efforts ... the narco-traffickers and guerrillas compose one dangerous network", it seems the new US administration is setting its stall out early in escalating US aggression in Colombia (20,000 grams under the sea, G2, January 8).

Still, I suppose you've got to respect their odd kind of honesty. While the assertion that narco-traffickers and guerrillas represent one network is a total falsehood, at least the new administration has stopped pretending that the war is only about drugs, as Clinton's more touchy-feely office was prone to do. Typically, the Republicans are making no bones about the fact that this is a counter-insurgency war against the guerrilla forces; a war in which Washington has no legitimate involvement.

Similar to the US's other illegitimate acts of aggression against internal insurgency movements (Vietnam, Nicaragua, El Salvador etc), the guerrillas' main crime is not their acceptance of coca growing among peasants in regions under their "control" but the obstacle they pose to the exploitation of the vast mineral and oil resources by US and European mining and oil companies; unchecked mastery of the local economy that is deemed an unassailable right of multinational corporations.

The Bush administration will help escalate the civil war and the massacres and displacements: 2001 promises to be perhaps the most tragic year yet for the butchered, exiled and terrorised people of Colombia.
Matt Dykes
Colombian Peace Association

webTitle: Letters: Still time to turn green

fields.headline: Still time to turn green
fields.trailText: Richard Sennett and Tony Grayling (Comment, January 10) both assume Railtrack is in the present situation through its own failings and the operation of the wicked marketplace. Neither mention the effects of political interference.
fields.body:
Richard Sennett and Tony Grayling (Comment, January 10) both assume Railtrack is in the present situation through its own failings and the operation of the wicked marketplace. Neither mention the effects of political interference. But since nationalisation in 1948, on average there has been a major political change nearly every five years. In terms of staff per freight tonne or passenger carried, Britain's railways are among the most efficient in Europe. But private US railroads carry 44% of all US freight traffic, compared to only 7% by rail in the UK.

Since the hysteria after Hatfield, some rail lines have lost up to 50% of their traffic, mostly to roads, which nationally have seen volumes increase by 3%. There already is a body of opinion which believes that outside London there is no future for railways. The 1982 Serpell report found a profitable core railway of only 1,000 miles. Many UK industries receive considerable aid from state funds, but why should only railways be fingered for renationalisation? The privatised water, gas and electricity companies are more crucial to the national economy.
Prof Lewis Lesley
Liverpool John Moores University transport-science@rapid.co.uk

The real tragedy with the Labour and Conservative competition to see who can build the most road schemes (Leader, January 5) is that it will worsen rather than solve congestion and will run counter the commitment by both main parties to reduce greenfield development. Smaller, cheaper measures such as employer travel plans, safe routes to school and high-quality bus and cycle priority schemes, as well as road-charging schemes will do far more in actually tackling congestion, as well as reducing road casualties and pollution. But they don't have the glamour of roads and are opposed or ridiculed by Jeremy Clarkson in the Sun.

Meanwhile, traffic continues to increase (the government's own plan expects 17% traffic growth in the next 10 years) and rail refranchising will leave untouched complex and often expensive rail fare structures. As you suggest, this will all play extremely badly with precisely the Middle England voters both parties are trying to woo.
Stephen Joseph
Director, Transport 2000

You omit any reference to the biggest emitters of carbon dioxide - buildings. We all know we have a rottenly energy-inefficient building stock. But why are we continuing to construct leaky buildings? Despite endless commitments from the planning minister, Nick Raynsford, that higher insulation standards would be introduced, this parliament will almost certainly have run its course without any specific energy conservation improvements having been announced, let alone implemented.
Andrew Warren
Association for the Conservation of Energy

There are some simple steps Labour could still take to restore its battered green reputation before the election. For example, it could pledge to provide every UK household with a doorstep recycling scheme, which would remove any need for environmentally damaging and contentious new incinerators.

Labour could also mitigate the effects of Mr Blair's partiality to the biotech companies by announcing it will introduce a robust liability regime for any damage that GM food and crops may cause. It could also redirect agricultural subsidies to encourage organic and low-chemical farming and reward green land management. Finally, it could promise a serious programme of public support for renewable energy.
Charles Secrett
Friends of the Earth

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
 Carol Gould: an apology. On December 20 last year Ms Gould, a supporter of the Israeli peace movement and of the Three Faiths Forum (a meeting point for Christianity, Islam and Judaism) wrote to the readers' editor of the Guardian questioning the paper's decision to publish an article by Ahdaf Soueif (Living under Israeli occupation, December 18).

Ms Gould's letter was addressed to the readers' editor personally and not intended for publication. It was mistakenly passed to the letters editor without reference to Ms Gould and extracts were published on page 17, December 22. The strongly expressed views contained in the letter were a digest of those put to Ms Gould by friends and neighbours concerned about the Middle East crisis and knowing her interest in the promotion of peace. The publication of the letter was an error on our part and we sincerely apologise for the considerable embarrassment caused to Ms Gould.

 We were wrong to suggest in an editorial, Webwise Widdecombe, page 25, yesterday, that the MP for Monmouth (Huw Edwards) could not be contacted by email. He is readily contactable at edwardsh@parliament.uk

 The photograph illustrating a report, British troops shot unarmed Irish prisoners, page 13, yesterday, did not, contrary to the suggestion in the caption, show "troops in action during the Easter Rising". The picture clearly showed three armed men in the uniform of the Auxiliaries, the "Black and Tans", a force that did not exist in 1916. It probably dates from 1919 or 1920.

 In Pass notes on Stonehenge, page 3, G2, January 10, we said the monument was given a number of face lifts in the first half of this century.

 Maths department, from page 5, January 10, Girl band All Saints expected to break up: "All seven of the All Saints' singles have made the top 10, with half going straight to the top."

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Fax 020-7239 9897.

webTitle: Ewen MacAskill on Palestinians forced out from their homes

fields.headline: Building unbearable lives
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Haythem Abdel Aziz looked bewildered as he stood in the early morning sun amid the tangled iron rods and rubble of what just hours earlier had been his home.
fields.body:
Haythem Abdel Aziz looked bewildered as he stood in the early morning sun amid the tangled iron rods and rubble of what just hours earlier had been his home. Aziz, a carpenter, aged 42, had been having breakfast with his wife, four sons and his parents on January 2 in the village of Ein-Yabroud on the West Bank when the Israeli Defence Force (IDF) arrived with a bulldozer. He was not allowed time to take out all his belongings.

He pointed to various spots where he thought his fridge, washing-machine, chairs, bed and sofa might be buried, crushed under concrete. His wife, Jihad, aged 34, said yesterday: "I saw the bulldozer coming with soldiers and five Jeeps. I hoped it was to clear the road but it was soon obvious it was coming here."

Four other homes in the village were bulldozed the same day. The presence in strength of the IDF was because 48 hours earlier a Jewish extremist, Binyamin Kahane, and his wife had been killed by Palestinians in a roadside ambush. He lived at the Jewish settlement of Ofra, only a few hundred yards from Ein-Yabroud. The two communities are divided by a road.

Why had the IDF bulldozed the homes? Maybe the IDF had spotted someone firing a shot the previous night from Mr Aziz's roof and turned up in the morning to punish him? Maybe the IDF had intelligence that Mr Aziz, in spite of his air of innocence, was a Palestinian gunman? A request for an explanation from the IDF mentioned neither shots from his roof or any terrorist background. The IDF explanation was more mundane: "There were five cases of unlawful building in the area of the fatal terrorist attack which were bulldozed."

It is an inadequate explanation for destroying a family's home and belongings. There are tens of thousands of homes on the West Bank without planning permission because the Israeli government, while permitting Jewish settlers to build, give the okay only to a small percentage of Palestinians. Mr Aziz had applied for planning permission, failed to get a permit and, like everyone else on the West Bank, had just gone ahead anyway. That was 17 years ago.

The reason for the bulldozing is that it was a punitive measure because Jewish settlers had been killed. On the same day that the homes were destroyed, the IDF cut off all access roads to Ein-Yabroud, using the bulldozers to build up 6ft high mounds of earth across the tarmac. A lawyer, farmers, a taxi driver, an American Palestinian over on holiday for a fortnight, a local councillor: all were standing around, unable to leave, facing a long day of inactivity. The lawyer, Haithim al-Sheik, ready for work in suit and tie, sympathised with Mr Aziz and complained about how it was impossible for a Palestinian to lead a normal life. They did not know how many days they would be cut off.

There are hundreds of Ein-Yabrouds throughout the West Bank and Gaza every day: abuses, small and large, committed by the IDF again and again. The West Bank and Gaza are supposed to be run by the Palestinian Authority, a step on the way eventually to complete independence. In reality, it is occupied territory: the IDF is the oppressor and the Palestinians the oppressed. Any time spent on either the West Bank or Gaza shows it is as stark as that.

Gaza is totally cut off. As in the film Escape from New York, all the ways in and out are sealed and those inside are left to make do as best they can in a community isolated from the rest of the world. The West Bank, with its long borders, is harder to block off totally.

Every day the Israelis make new enemies. Israeli soldiers on the West Bank and Gaza are predominantly 18- and 19-year-olds doing national service. They often behave badly out of fear, knowing that a bullet or a rock may not be far away. But their disdainful attitude is often born out of racism, a sense that Palestinians are inferior. It is evident in the remarks they make and in the contempt an Israeli soldier at a checkpoint shows to a Palestinian old enough to be his grandfather.

The Palestinians face lots of indignities, frustrations and anger every day. It is the lorrydriver stuck nosedown in a ditch, having foolishly attempted to drive across the desert because the roads to his village were blocked. It is the lost days of employment; it is the cessation of economic activity; it is the man raging at the Israeli-Gaza border because he is refused permission to visit his wife; it is the destruction of an olive grove because it is claimed Palestinian snipers could hide there; it is a newborn child dead because an ambulance would not be allowed through.

Members of the Palestinian leadership, from senior officials to representatives of the Fatah youth movement, are assassinated by the IDF. The British government always denied such a policy in Northern Ireland. The Israeli government boasts about it.

Reporters have been writing about the assassinations policy in recent days, prompted by the killing last week of a high-ranking Palestinian. But most of the other human rights abuses in the West Bank and Gaza are poorly covered, and often not at all. Few Israeli journalists now go to the West Bank and Gaza, afraid of being killed. Many American journalists self-censor their copy, knowing that their editors will tend to be pro-Israeli, reflecting the strength of the Jewish lobby in the United States.

The disastrous consequence of the Israeli treatment of the Palestinians is to create hostility where it had not existed before. A new generation has learnt hatred. Israel was never going to stop Islamic Jihad or Hamas but, since the Israeli-Palestinian agreement at Oslo in 1993, there were signs of the two communities at least coexisting, even if uneasily. That is now gone.

The tentative discussions in Washington towards a peace settlement are now irrelevant. A settlement is possible on paper: compromises can be worked out over the Palestinian refugees, the territorial boundaries, the division of Jerusalem and sovereignty over the holy site in the Old City. The problem is how to make it work on the ground. Even if the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, put their signatures to a deal today, it would not hold on for even 24 hours, such is the level of distrust and acrimony created since the Palestinian uprising began in September.

Israeli officers and officials defend their behaviour on the West Bank, saying it is a war. Would it not be better, given that they are always going to have Palestinians as neighbours, to treat them in a civilised manner? An officer in the IDF said a soldier at a checkpoint did not know whether the Palestinian in front of him was an innocent or a Hamas bomber. He said the Palestinians had opted for violence: it had not been sparked by the visit of the former Israeli defence minister, Ariel Sharon, near the Muslim holy site, the Dome on the Rock, but had been deliberately sought by the Palestinians to secure more concessions in negotiations. Would it not be better to try to build up the Palestinian economy instead of trying to destroy it: Palestinians with jobs and a good standard of living might be less inclined to fight? The Israeli officer agreed but asked what was the point of giving money to the Palestinian Authority when so much of it was squandered by corrupt leaders.

Why does Israel just not pull out of the West Bank and Gaza and let the Palestinian Authority leader, Yasser Arafat, declare independence? The Israeli answer is that too many questions about the border would remain unanswered, a permanent source of aggravation and conflict.

An Israeli human rights group, B'Tselem, published a report yesterday on abuses on the West Bank and Gaza. It said the restrictions imposed by Israel on movement was "one of the primary reasons for the increasing destitution and despair in the Occupied Territories and has made the lives of the population unbearable". It added the sweeping restrictions on the entire population rather than specific individuals were justified by the Israeli government on security grounds but the organisation disputed the effectiveness of the policy and pointed to the "blatant discrimination between the two populations living in the Occupied Territories ... solely on the basis of nationality. The restrictions are imposed exclusively on the Palestinian population."

The Israelis have a siege mentality, touchy about any criticism of their behaviour, present or past. They refuse to acknowledge the injustice of what they did in the first place, taking the land from the Palestinians in 1948. That refusal is central of the main Palestinian claim of a right of return for refugees to Israel. When Benny Morris, one of the new generation of Israeli historians, wrote that the Israelis had been less than lily-white in their behaviour in 1948, he was vilified by Israelis.

He opens a history of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict with a quote from WH Auden about the second world war. It is as relevant to the present uprising as it was to the last 53 years of conflict.

"I and the public know

What the schoolchildren learn,

Those to whom evil is done

Do evil in return."

Yesterday, amid the ruins of what had been her home up until last week, Mrs Aziz said she had asked a soldier why they were planning to bulldoze her house and he had replied "revenge". In a sad reply, she told him: "There is no peace between us and it is getting worse every day."

It is the lorrydriver stuck nosedown in a ditch, having foolishly attempted to drive across the desert because the roads to his village were blocked. It is the lost days of employment; it is the cessation of economic activity; it is the man raging at the Israeli-Gaza border because he is refused permission to visit his wife; it is the destruction of an olive grove because it is claimed Palestinian snipers could hide there; it is a newborn child dead because an ambulance would not be allowed through. Members of the Palestinian leadership, from senior officials to representatives of the Fatah youth movement, are assassinated by the IDF. The British government always denied such a policy in Northern Ireland. The Israeli government boasts about it. Reporters have been writing about the assassinations policy in recent days, prompted by the killing last week of a high-ranking Palestinian. But most of the other human rights abuses in the West Bank and Gaza are poorly covered, and often not at all. Few Israeli journalists now go to the West Bank and Gaza, afraid of being killed. Many American journalists self-censor their copy, knowing that their editors will tend to be pro-Israeli, reflecting the strength of the Jewish lobby in the United States. The disastrous consequence of the Israeli treatment of the Palestinians is to create hostility where it had not existed before. A new generation has learnt hatred. Israel was never going to stop Islamic Jihad or Hamas but, since the Israeli-Palestinian agreement at Oslo in 1993, there were signs of the two communities at least coexisting, even if uneasily. That is now gone. The tentative discussions in Washington towards a peace settlement are now irrelevant. A settlement is possible on paper: compromises can be worked out over the Palestinian refugees, the territorial boundaries, the division of Jerusalem and sovereignty over the holy site in the Old City. The problem is how to make it work on the ground. Even if the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, put their signatures to a deal today, it would not hold on for even 24 hours, such is the level of distrust and acrimony created since the Palestinian uprising began in September. Israeli officers and officials defend their behaviour on the West Bank, saying it is a war. Would it not be better, given that they are always going to have Palestinians as neighbours, to treat them in a civilised manner? An officer in the IDF said a soldier at a checkpoint did not know whether the Palestinian in front of him was an innocent or a Hamas bomber. He said the Palestinians had opted for violence: it had not been sparked by the visit of the former Israeli defence minister, Ariel Sharon, near the Muslim holy site, the Dome on the Rock, but had been deliberately sought by the Palestinians to secure more concessions in negotiations. Would it not be better to try to build up the Palestinian economy instead of trying to destroy it: Palestinians with jobs and a good standard of living might be less inclined to fight? The Israeli officer agreed but asked what was the point of giving money to the Palestinian Authority when so much of it was squandered by corrupt leaders. Why does Israel just not pull out of the West Bank and Gaza and let the Palestinian Authority leader, Yasser Arafat, declare independence? The Israeli answer is that too many questions about the border would remain unanswered, a permanent source of aggravation and conflict. An Israeli human rights group, B'Tselem, published a report yesterday on abuses on the West Bank and Gaza. It said the restrictions imposed by Israel on movement was "one of the primary reasons for the increasing destitution and despair in the Occupied Territories and has made the lives of the population unbearable". It added the sweeping restrictions on the entire population rather than specific individuals were justified by the Israeli government on security grounds but the organisation disputed the effectiveness of the policy and pointed to the "blatant discrimination between the two populations living in the Occupied Territories ... solely on the basis of nationality. The restrictions are imposed exclusively on the Palestinian population." The Israelis have a siege mentality, touchy about any criticism of their behaviour, present or past. They refuse to acknowledge the injustice of what they did in the first place, taking the land from the Palestinians in 1948. That refusal is central of the main Palestinian claim of a right of return for refugees to Israel. When Benny Morris, one of the new generation of Israeli historians, wrote that the Israelis had been less than lily-white in their behaviour in 1948, he was vilified by Israelis. He opens a history of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict with a quote from WH Auden about the second world war. It is as relevant to the present uprising as it was to the last 53 years of conflict. "I and the public know What the schoolchildren learn, Those to whom evil is done Do evil in return." Yesterday, amid the ruins of what had been her home up until last week, Mrs Aziz said she had asked a soldier why they were planning to bulldoze her house and he had replied "revenge". In a sad reply, she told him: "There is no peace between us and it is getting worse every day."

webTitle: Sharon's shadow clouds new talks

fields.headline: Sharon's shadow clouds new talks
fields.standfirst:
Special report on Israel and the Middle East
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Senior Israeli and Palestinian officials were to meet last night to try to plot the course of negotiations after President Clinton leaves the White House.
fields.body:
Senior Israeli and Palestinian officials were to meet last night to try to plot the course of negotiations after President Clinton leaves the White House.

Israel Radio said the foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, and a prime ministerial aide, Gilead Sher, were to meet the Palestinian negotiators Yasser Abed Rabbo and Saeb Erakat.

The Nobel peace laureate Shimon Peres might join in the talks, the radio said. Other reports said the speaker of the Palestinian parliament, Abu Ala, might also attend.

Last night's hastily arranged meeting followed signs earlier yesterday that, after giving up hope of reaching a full-scale agreement in the nine days remaining of Mr Clinton's term, the two sides were stepping up their efforts to agree on the principles that will guide future negotiations.

But the burst of diplomatic activity is overshadowed by the instability of Israeli politics.

Four weeks before the prime ministerial election the incumbent, Ehud Barak, is trailing far behind the hawkish Likud party challenger, Ariel Sharon, in opinion polls.

Mr Sharon has said he will not honour agreements made by Mr Barak, and that the Oslo accords, which have governed the negotiations for seven years, "no longer exist".

The moves in the diplomatic arena reflect positive changes on the ground, where the Israeli army removed the roadblocks which sliced the Gaza strip in two and eased its blockade in some parts of the West Bank yesterday.

The joint Israeli-Palestinian security patrols, which were suspended within days of the eruption of the intifada, may be resumed in the coming days, Palestinian officials said.

In public, Palestinian officials have sharply criticised Mr Clinton's proposals for peace.

These include a Palestinian state covering all of Gaza and parts of the West Bank, the latter divided into three or four cantons by the preservation of the main Jewish settlement blocks; Palestinian sovereignty over the Arab, and Israeli sovereignty over the Jewish, quarters of Jerusalem; and the surrender by the Palestinians of the right of return for 3.7m registered refugees.

But the newspaper al-Ayyam, which generally reflects the policy of the Palestinian Authority, reported that officials had agreed to enter into negotiations with Israel on a declaration of principles.

webTitle: Oil guru warns against hasty supply cuts

fields.headline: Oil guru warns against hasty supply cuts
fields.standfirst:
Sheikh Yamani urges Opec to watch Iraq before decreasing output

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Cuts in oil production, coupled with Iraqi political machination, could drive world energy prices to a new peak, members of Opec were warned yesterday. The cartel of 11 oil-producing countries is expected to agree quota cuts next week in an attempt to reverse the slide in world oil prices, which have dropped by more than $10 (£6.70) a barrel below their peak last autumn. The move comes as the US economy threatens to fall into a recession.
fields.body:
Cuts in oil production, coupled with Iraqi political machination, could drive world energy prices to a new peak, members of Opec were warned yesterday. The cartel of 11 oil-producing countries is expected to agree quota cuts next week in an attempt to reverse the slide in world oil prices, which have dropped by more than $10 (£6.70) a barrel below their peak last autumn. The move comes as the US economy threatens to fall into a recession.

Prices surged yesterday after Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest producer, said it was preparing to cut February deliveries, hardening the expectation that the cartel will agree a cut of 1.5m barrels at its meeting in Vienna next week.

Qatar, a small producer by comparison, urged Opec to cut output by 2m barrels a day or more.

But the man who masterminded Opec's dominance of the world economy in the 1970s warned that his successors' calculations were likely to be thrown out of line by President Saddam Hussein's continuing fight to get the UN to withdraw its sanctions against Iraq.

Sheikh Ahmed Zaki Yamani, a former Saudi oil minister, said: "Opec's cut will be too much unless the Iraqis come back into the picture. If they cut production, prices could go to $30-35 a barrel."

When crude soared above $30 (£19) a barrel in the autumn, the rise in petrol prices brought consumer protests throughout Europe and demands from western capitals for Opec to increase production.

Sheikh Yamani said Opec should wait to see what Iraq decided to do before implementing any production cuts. "If they don't cut, Iraq will think twice and may come back to the market," he said.

Iraq slashed its production last month, the latest move in its battle with the UN, and is demanding that its customers pay a premium of 40 cents a barrel into an account controlled by the regime, outside the UN's oil-for-food programme.

The UN sanctions committee threatened to prosecute oil companies if they paid the premium. In protest, Iraq halted oil production, which had been running at 2.3m barrels a day. It resumed production a few days later, but at only 600,000 barrels a day.

Reputable oil companies have refused to pay the premium and are no longer buying Iraqi oil.

"The companies lifting it at present are from the Ukraine, Sudan, South Africa and Malaysia," Sheikh Yamani said. It is not known if they are paying the premium.

He said that if Iraqi production had continued normally there would be a real surplus of oil and production cuts would be necessary next month. "But Iraq's cuts in December will be felt in the market only in January, because of the time the tankers take to deliver. There is a shortage in the market.

"Saddam Hussein wants to break the embargo and there is a good chance he will succeed. The price will jump ... It can go way above what it was. It depends on how long he will be absent.

"Then the oil companies will come running. They will definitely pay the 40 cents under the table. This is exactly what he wants." He added: "Who will detect the payments?"

Sheikh Yamani said a new rise in prices would not be a problem for Opec. "They're happy with a high price but, longer term, they will pay very heavily. If I were in the Opec meeting I would say: 'Don't take action until we see what is the Iraqi situation, then take action accordingly'."

Saudi Arabia ought to bring prices down to prevent other suppliers and alternative energy sources undercutting it, he said. "If Saudis looked at their long-term interests, they would definitely bring prices down below $20 a barrel to delay new exploration and to prevent consumption from falling."

webTitle: Mugabe's opponents 'thrown to the lions'

fields.headline: Mugabe's opponents 'thrown to the lions'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean police threw 13 young opposition supporters to the lions this week after subjecting them to days of beatings and torture, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean police threw 13 young opposition supporters to the lions this week after subjecting them to days of beatings and torture, it was claimed yesterday.

The youths said they were dumped in the middle of Gonarezhou national park, which teems with wildlife, including lions and leopards, and one of the policemen told them to "go and campaign to the lions".

They managed to make their way to the capital, Harare, and tell their story to the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

A police spokesman, Wayne Bvudzijena, said the allegations were "unlikely to be true".

The incident is one of the many violent acts that have marred campaigning in this weekend's Bikita West byelection in the south-east of Zimbabwe.

The war veterans' leader and MP Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi threw a petrol bomb at a group of MDC officials last week and ordered a gang of veterans to attack MDC politicians, according to witnesses.

Several MDC supporters were arrested after an official of President Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF party was stabbed to death. The MDC denies responsibility, blaming faction-fighting in Zanu-PF.

The MDC won the seat in the June parliamentary elections, a bitter blow to Zanu-PF in one of its rural strongholds. The MP's death from cancer in November forced the contest.

webTitle: Judge Jackson tackles the titans

fields.headline: Judge Jackson tackles the titans
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: When Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson picked up his copy of the Washington Post on April 19, he read of a visit Microsoft's chief executive officer Steve Ballmer had made to the paper the previous day.
fields.body:
When Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson picked up his copy of the Washington Post on April 19, he read of a visit Microsoft's chief executive officer Steve Ballmer had made to the paper the previous day.

To a roomful of reporters and editors, Ballmer said: "I do not think we broke the law in any way, shape, or form. I feel deeply that we behaved in every instance with super integrity. I'm not saying we don't talk tough, that people don't get a little 'grrr' in their email and all that."

They simply had bad social graces, he insisted. Microsoft's problem was bad manners, not bad behaviour.

Judge Jackson was livid. "They don't act like grown-ups," he told me that same afternoon. He interpreted what Ballmer said this way: "We're a little rough around the edges, but you have to be tolerant!" Ballmer's interview proved to Jackson that "to this day they continue to deny they did anything wrong".

Jackson appears a safe conformist, an upright member of the Rotary Club and the vestry of All Saints' Episcopal Church. At the end of his workday, he often races to catch the train in order to walk his dog. His taste tending to all things British, especially to the twenty sea novels of Patrick O'Brian.

A few inches shy of six feet tall, from the neck down Jackson looks like a barrel-chested high-school football coach, his belly pressing against his belt.

While Jackson can display a deep, authoritative voice, spectators usually have to lean forward, straining to hear; what most spectators cannot see is that he has a small flesh-coloured hearing aid in his right ear, which might account for his quiet voice.

Jackson, 62, was the first judge appointed by president Reagan to this district court. He prides himself on being a straight-shooter and his contemporary heroes are blunt men such as John McCain and Barry Goldwater.

Privately, Microsoft feared that Judge Jackson was a foe. He had made a number of pretrial rulings deemed hostile to the company.

In 1998 Jackson had a knot of complicated facts to untangle: did Microsoft really gain on Netscape because Internet Explorer was technically superior to Netscape Navigator, as Microsoft claimed, or did Microsoft gain because they coerced companies, as Netscape claimed?

This was no easy task for Jackson, who does not use email or a browser or a PC. Microsoft was convinced Jackson was uncomfortable with technology, and therefore it worried that he could not comprehend the case.

Jackson also had the weight of history to think about. Jackson knew that this was the case of a lifetime. Jackson had presided over cases that attracted media firestorms, but none that might be deemed truly historic. "Many people have referred to it as the biggest thing since the Standard Oil case," Jackson told me. "I don't know that. It is the biggest case I've ever had."

The federal trial began in October 1998 and on June 7 2000 Judge Jackson issued his final judgment, ordering that Microsoft be broken up into two companies and imposing conduct restrictions on the company's behaviour for several years.

Jackson ordered Microsoft to submit a plan not later than four months after the appeals process ended describing how it would split Microsoft in two. If an appeals court did not stay this order, in three months he would impose on Microsoft the various conduct remedies proposed by the government. In addition, Jackson refused to rely on CEO Steve Ballmer to appoint a compliance officer, as the government had proposed.

Displaying his disdain for Ballmer, Jackson gave Microsoft directors 90 days to establish a compliance committee consisting of no less than three board members "who are not present or former employees of Microsoft", and empowering this committee - not the CEO of the company - to appoint a chief compliance officer to report to both the committee and the CEO.

Although they had the barrel of a gun stuck deep down its throat, Microsoft remained strangely upbeat. Bill Neukom, the company's lawyer, told reporters he was confident Microsoft would win on appeal. This is, Gates told reporters, "the first day of the rest of this case".

Throughout the trial, Jackson later told me, he could not get out of his mind the group picture he had seen of Bill Gates and Paul Allen and their shaggy-haired first employees at Microsoft.

What Jackson saw there was not a portrait of a CEO and lieutenants who would create one of the world's most profitable corporations.

Rather, Jackson said, what he saw was "a smart-mouthed young kid who has extraordinary ability and needs a little discipline. I've often said to colleagues that Gates would be better off if he had finished Harvard."
