webTitle: Briton fears for life of abducted stepchild

fields.headline: Briton fears for life of abducted stepchild
fields.standfirst:
Islamic rebels with assault rifles snatch girl, six, from her home on Philippine island after mother could not pay extortion demand

Basilan is home to separatist violence and kidnappings
fields.trailText: Islamic rebels with assault rifles snatch girl, six, from her home on Philippine island after mother could not pay extortion demand.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  in Jakarta and  Kirsty Scott
fields.body:
A British man yesterday said he feared for the life of his stepdaughter, aged six, who was kidnapped by Islamic extremists in the Philippines.

Douglas Grant, 50, from Inverness, was waiting for news of Eiman April Grant, who was snatched from her home on the island of Basilan on Wednesday night after her mother was unable to pay an extortion demand.

The island, 550 miles south of the capital, Manila, is a hotbed of Islamic secessionist groups in the predominantly Roman Catholic country.

A military spokesman on the neighbouring island of Mindanao, Fredesivindo Covarrubias, said Eiman had been watching television with her mother, Mina Rasul Grant, when four men armed with assault rifles burst in.

Mr Covarrubias said the abductors asked for a drink of water, then demanded 100,000 pesos (£1,300). When Mrs Grant said she had only 1,000 pesos the men grabbed the girl and fled to two speedboats waiting on the nearby river.

The kidnappers, who have not made a ransom demand, are thought to be members of the radical Abu Sayyaf separatist group.

Mrs Grant pleaded for her daughter's life on a local radio broadcast: "Please don't hurt her. Please, I beg you to free my daughter." She said the kidnappers threatened to kill the child if she informed the police or armed forces.

The family were due to travel to Scotland in April to join Mr Grant, who returned home last summer because his parents were ill.

Speaking from Inverness, he said he and his wife were distraught. "There is a tremendous culture of hospitality in the Philippines, and while Mina was giving them the water they grabbed Eiman ... I think they might have taken the whole family but had second thoughts because Mina and I have an 18-month-old daughter, Khadija, and that might have been a hindrance to them.

"My biggest fear is that these guys have killed before. About a year ago they kidnapped priests, teachers and children from a school in one of the other islands. webTitle: Basilan is home to separatist violence and kidnappings

fields.headline: Basilan is home to separatist violence and kidnappings
fields.standfirst: Briton fears for life of abducted stepchild
fields.trailText: As Basilan is in a region of the Philippines where private armies are commonplace, kidnappings happen regularly and it is rare to settle disputes without drawing assault rifles, the list of potential kidnappers of April Grant is enormous.
fields.body:
As Basilan is in a region of the Philippines where private armies are commonplace, kidnappings happen regularly and it is rare to settle disputes without drawing assault rifles, the list of potential kidnappers of April Grant is enormous.

But the authorities believe the perpetrators are probably one of two militant Islamic separatist groups fighting separately for an independent state in the southern Philippines.

The main suspect is an element of the Abu Sayyaf, an organisation that has become notorious for its terrorist approach to campaigning for independence, specialising in abductions and bombings.

It shot to international prominence last year when it seized 21 hostages from a Malaysian diving resort and took them to the inhospitable island of Jolo, about 100 miles south-west of Basilan. One of them, a Malaysian man, is still being held along with an American seized later.

Abu Sayyaf made well over £10m from that exercise in ransom money, as a result of which its numbers ballooned from less than 400 to more than 4,000. This sudden growth, combined with the Philippine army's continual military operation against the guerrillas on Jolo since September, made the organisation unmanageable and it has splintered into several factions.

It is thought there is little left of last year's ransom money and so the abduction of April could well be one group's latest fund-raising bid.

Abu Sayyaf has engaged in kidnapping on Basilan for years. One of its operations a year ago - when 31 people were seized in a school - backfired when another armed gang kidnapped the local Abu Sayyaf leader's pregnant wife and son and threatened to kill them unless the first group of captives was freed.

As with most such cases on the island, the dispute was eventually resolved but not before several innocent people had been killed.

If none of the Abu Sayyaf factions is responsible for April's disappearance the next most likely candidate is the Moro Islamic Liberation Front. This group is based on the larger island of Mindanao, north-east of Basilan.

The MILF, a breakaway arm of the Moro National Liberation Front, has been fighting for a separate country for almost three decades. Last year it suffered a string of setbacks when the Philippine army overran almost all of its armed camps on Mindanao.

Philippine police commanders believe the MILF, as it gets increasingly desperate, has started using more terrorist tactics.

MILF leaders deny these accusations, claiming it is a regular army fighting for freedom.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man denies Dando killing | £1.4m award for disabled child | Squatter hid in woman's house
fields.body:
Man denies Dando killing

A man accused of murdering the television presenter Jill Dando formally denied the charge when he appeared at a brief hearing at the Old Bailey yesterday. Barry Michael George, 40, from Fulham, west London, will stand trial at the Old Bailey on February 26. He was remanded in custody to that date.

£1.4m award for disabled child

A child left with learning and physical disabilities after doctors allegedly gave his mother too much of an epilepsy drug during her pregnancy has received £1.4m compensation. Health chiefs in Southampton and south-west Hampshire have agreed the out of court payment without admitting liability. The boy is now six.

Squatter hid in woman's house

A 91-year-old pensioner who thought she had mice in her attic was shocked to discover a squatter had set up home for at least nine months. Grace Kendal-Ward's relatives were baffled about items going missing until they discovered a bed in her home in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, had been slept in. Police were called and confirmed an intruder, thought to be a young woman, had been using the attic room.

Weakest Link goes west

The hit quiz show The Weakest Link has been bought by the US broadcaster NBC. Pilot versions are being filmed using the BBC's Anne Robinson and American presenters.

Head to be told of charges

Crucial documents relating to disciplinary action being taken against the headteacher cleared of slapping a 10-year-old pupil will be given to her legal representatives within three weeks, the high court heard yesterday. It will be the first time Marjorie Evans, 56, will learn of the allegations of pupil mistreatment being levelled at her. She is seeking reinstatement at St Mary's junior school in Caldicot, Monmouthshire.

Dig for bodies called off

A search for the bodies of 10 children reported by a woman to have been killed and buried on the rundown Craigmillar estate in Edinburgh in the 1970s was abandoned yesterday. No remains have been found and there are no unsolved cases of missing children.

Motorcycle sales soar

Motorcycle sales hit an 18-year high last year, with 170,072 motorcycles, scooters and mopeds sold, according to figures from the Motor Cycle Industry Association yesterday.

The association said the boom owed much to city commuters switching from cars to beat congestion. Scooter sales rose 40% to 70,603.

Paddington survivor ill

The founder of the Paddington Survivors Group, Pam Warren, 33, is recovering at a clinic after suffering an emotional and physical collapse. Mrs Warren, from Whitchurch, Oxfordshire, suffered burns in the 1999 rail disaster.

Reporting crime online

The government is planning to allow the public to report minor crimes to the police through the internet, it emerged yesterday.

The Home Office minister Charles Clarke said the project was "part of a wider vision for delivering police services electronically to the public."

Most teachers back Labour

Most teachers will vote Labour at the election, according to a poll in the Times Education Supplement yesterday.

Of those surveyed, 54% said they would back Labour with 20% each for the Tories and Liberal Democrats.

Concorde flies again

A Concorde is next week expected to fly for the first time since one crashed near Paris last July. The Air France jet will fly from Paris to Istres, near Marseille, for ground tests.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: The wild bunch
fields.trailText: Bare Necessities | EastEnders | Horizon
fields.body:
As prizes go, a stay in a luxury hotel in Romania is right up there with a night of passion with Gloria Hunniford. As prizes go, you might like to come second. Unless the runner-up's prize was a night of passion with Eammon Holmes. Of course, Bare Necessities (BBC2) isn't about the prize, it's about the experience of surviving in a wilderness for a week with only your wits and the proverbial bare necessities to help you.

It's about climbing out from under the big duvet of civilisation and - however unsure you may be of your strength and confidence - battling with nature to prove you aren't a big jessie. It's about working in a team to solve problems and surmount obstacles, both physical and psychological. It's about learning all about the real you, and being proud of yourself.

OK, so it's about the prize. That being the case, the bookies and the ministers who competed in the wilds of Transylvania (bear population: 5,500; wolf population: 2,500, as a graphic helpfully informed us) for a luxurious weekend might have felt hard done by. It was, said presenter Ed Hall, "Europe's last great wilderness" (he's obviously never visited Aberdeenshire, where the locals make Royston Vasey look like Melrose Place) and it was there that the two teams were challenged to survive.

You might not think bookmakers and ministers - Neal the Mormon, Basil the Gospel Singer and C of E Richenda - have much in common, but they were perfectly matched. Della, Alan and Tim rely on people's gambling to earn a living, and so do the ministers (though the gamble on the existence of God is slightly more existential than Silver Lady winning the 3.40 at Musselburgh).

So it was marvellous watching them build fires and shelters, kill chickens, fell trees and do other stuff that the service industry was invented for. For Christians, the ministers were remarkably adept at killing the chicken, and had a right jolly discussion about its eggs and entrails. When it came to skinning, gutting and cooking a deer - "a baby deer," one bookie noted - Richenda seemed overly keen ("We're gonna eat Bambi!").

The bookies, on the other hand, had problems with their headless bird's nervous twitching and were marked down by survival expert "Mad" Hugh McManners for not being hard enough. They considered cheating to win - always a good sign in a bookie - but in the end didn't need to, even when one of their team-mates retired due to a sore foot. Moral of the story? Teamwork is a recipe for defeat.

Speaking of sore feet, Nick Cotton has discharged himself from Walford General in EastEnders (BBC1). This means Ashley won't have to sit at the end of his bed any more, his Ermintrude eyelashes contrasting with the crisp white linen of NHS sheets. At least we know what he did after he pulled the legs off spiders.

And speaking of spiders, life on Mars (Ziggy played guitar, don't you know) was under the microscope in Horizon (BBC2). It had to be under the microscope because it was so darn minuscule, though it might have survived a night in Transylvania more comfortably than the ministers and bookies.

Apparently, depending on whom you believed, microscopic life could have lived on Mars in freezing temperatures for millions of years. Well, whoopee. It may have been engrossing in a worthy way, but Horizon failed to understand that, to your average Joe, it's no big deal if microscopic life existed on Mars.

He - me, if you will - wants proper aliens with legs and arms and plans to take over the Earth. Microscopic organisms are so dull. They just organise microscopically. Hardly The X-Files, is it? Hell, it's not even Invasion: Earth. And with an enemy that could be dispatched with a judicious dose of kitchen cleaner, it's certainly not an opportunity to do your bit in a battle for Earth, all daring missions and exploding spaceships.

I'd like to give Channel 4 marks for perseverance, but seeing as they're persevering with The Richard Blackwood Show (Channel 4), despite the obvious talent vacuum at the heart of the concept, it's nil points for them. Billed as "a comedy and music show", you can at least see where the music comes from - people play instruments, some of them quite well. It's the comedy bit that seems sadly amiss. The man deserves a night in a Romanian youth hostel. Or a night of passion with himself.

webTitle: TV and Radio: The Halifax ad

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Halifax ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Halifax ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: A man from the Halifax leaves his branch on a mission to deliver a new current account to a customer. We follow him as he travels (strangely) backwards across fields of corn, through woods and by the sea, encountering surreal singing fish and over-friendly birds. All the while he sings a reworked version of the Tom Jones hit Sex Bomb, with lines like " Maybe I'm a banker that's completely obsessed/ But I've got a little something, that's bound to impress/This current account/Pays a higher amount/Of extraordinary in-ter-est. "

The jargon: This lavish 60-seconder aims to promote Halifax's new current account, which pays four per cent interest, and to portray the bank as a "human brand" rather than a "corporate brand", according to agency Delaney Lund Knox Warren. The message is that Halifax treats its workers as its stars - not just filming them as staff in uniforms but actually making them into pop stars.

Personality: You're aged 20-54 and are "financially passive" - ie couldn't be less interested in scouring the financial pages for the latest offers. You find finance boring. You just want to find a good deal and forget about it.

Financial status: You've got to deposit £1,000 a month into the account so you have to mandate your salary. This is a mainstream current account for the many, not the few, so just about anyone qualifies financially.

Telling lifestyle detail: Rather scary statistics show that folk are more likely to divorce than to change their current account. People stay with the same bank they joined as students/first-jobbers.

Other relevant data: The "star" of the ad is 37-year-old Howard Brown who works at the Sheldon, Birmingham branch. He won an in-house talent contest, beating 800 other hopefuls. Sadly, he's now back behind the counter. Word has it the next in the series will feature another staffer doing a specially reworked version of Ricky Martin's Livin' La Vida Loca.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Defence Of The Realm | The Manchurian Candidate | American History X
fields.body:
Defence Of The Realm
(David Drury, 1985)
8pm, FilmFour

Excellent Brit-noir thriller, with investigative reporter Gabriel Byrne uncovering MP Ian Bannen's indiscretions and an establishment conspiracy. The atmosphere, from bleak fens to despondent London, is laden with menace, and a superior cast has Denholm Elliott as the reporter's old-soak colleague, and a truth-seeking Greta Scacchi.

The Manchurian Candidate
(John Frankenheimer, 1962)
10pm, FilmFour

Subversive stuff: Korean war hero Laurence Harvey is in fact a brainwashed assassin, primed to murder the president and sweep the far right into the White House. What's more, the trigger is Mom, Angela Lansbury, in a neat perversion of the apple-pie type. Frank Sinatra is the killer's former comrade who learns the awful truth. JFK leant his personal authority to the making of this controversial, chilling thriller - just a year before he himself was shot.

American History X
(Tony Kaye, 1998)
12.15am, Sky Premier

An awesome performance from Edward Norton centres this compelling study of American neo-Nazism. His charismatic Derek, a hate-filled skinhead, kills two black car thieves and, after rehabilitation, emerges from prison a changed man, struggling to free his brother Danny (Edward Furlong) from the grip of fascist gang leader Cameron (Stacy Keach). Norton reportedly re-edited the film, and Kaye disowned the final cut, but it remains a highly charged, thought- provoking movie.

Hackers
(Iain Softley, 1995)
3.45am, FilmFour

A bunch of baby-faced hackers match wits with the villain known as The Plague, who's framed them for his multi-million-dollar scam. Jonny Lee Miller's Zero Cool and Angelina Jolie's Acid Burn smoulder over the keyboards at each other while the whizzy visuals and mind-stunning electro-soundtrack create a reality as virtual as you could wish for.

fields.headline: No: 1799
fields.standfirst: Lisa Snowdon
fields.trailText: Lisa Snowdon
fields.body:
Age: Good question.

Is it? Well, the official line is 25. But her former classmates all seem to be 28. You do the maths.

Occupation: Underwear model. And self-made woman.

Self-made? But she's a Snowdon! I think I was at Harrow with her great-uncle. I doubt it.

Fine chap, if memory serves. Filled his rugger shorts well ... Different branch of the Snowdons, old bean. She's actually one of the Essex "Snawdons", to be exact. Seems it's not just her age that Lisa has been tinkering with.

So what's this Snowdon lassie been up to then? New job? Kind of.

Loaded cover girl? Big Breakfast presenter? Nothing so demanding. Try "professional arm candy".

Not Michael Winner again! The old dog! George Clooney, actually. The Harlow lovely has shot to the top of the Hollywood A-list after winning the heart of every red-blooded woman's fantasy gynaecologist.

How did she meet him then? Table-dancing at Spangles in Chelmsford? No, they met while filming a Martini advert in Spain three months ago, and it's been luuurve ever since. Now Clooney apparently wants her to move into his LA pad.

Bet she was a bit of a goer when she was younger ... Oh, do calm down. Actually, the Mirror has managed to unearth "friends" who remember "a shy, skinny girl who had a passion for dancing but cried a lot". "She would cry at the drop of a hat," said a "pal".

Hmm, that puts me in mind of ... Céline Balitran, yes. Clooney's former squeeze, a Parisian student, was reportedly devastated when he failed to marry her, preferring to spend time with his pot-bellied pig.

You keep bringing Michael Winner into this. Stop it right now.

So how long do we give this one? Well Clooney is not known for his great affection for marriage, and the clash of cultures might prove too much to overcome, but even the most cynical observer needs to bear in mind those three little words ...

"I love you"? No, "Catherine Zeta Jones".

webTitle: There are no flies on the Old Lady's committee room wall

fields.headline: There are no flies on the Old Lady's committee room wall
fields.trailText: Docu-soaps have been all the rage in recent years. The police, Heathrow, the Royal Opera House and even the Treasury have all had the full fly-on-the-wall treatment as the lid has been lifted on nearly every aspect of life in modern Britain. Nearly, but not quite all.
fields.body:
Docu-soaps have been all the rage in recent years. The police, Heathrow, the Royal Opera House and even the Treasury have all had the full fly-on-the-wall treatment as the lid has been lifted on nearly every aspect of life in modern Britain. Nearly, but not quite all.

One body where the stones have been left unturned is the Bank of England's monetary policy committee. Its nine members have yet to suffer the full TV treatment - the prying eyes, the hushed voice-overs, the public airing of spats. Those keen to find out what has gone on behind Threadneedle Street's closed doors have to wait a couple of weeks for the release of the minutes of the meetings.

Even so, its possible to hazard a reasonably good guess at the MPC's deliberations over the past couple of days. One group, the minority, would have returned to the argument they deployed before Christmas - namely that inflation in the UK has consistently turned out to be better behaved than most experts have predicted, largely because of the supply-side improve ments in the economy. With the outlook for the global economy darkening, they argued that there was a case for lower UK rates even before the Federal Reserve reduced US rates last week. Alan Greenspan's surprise move merely reinforced the point.

This view was rejected by a majority of the committee. There were probably three main reasons for this caution - only two of which will be made explicit in the minutes.

Firstly, there has been little evidence that the UK economy is about to crash land. Consumer spending remains robust, the labour market is tight, there are signs that manufacturing is inching out of the doldrums. Yes, the housing market dipped in December, but people have other things on their mind in December than buying a house. As things stand, the economy looks good for growth of about 3% this year.

Secondly, there is the recent weakness in sterling, which has fallen against the euro in tandem with the dollar and is now around 3% lower than the Bank predicted at the time of its November inflation report. Although the coun terpart to a weaker US economy and a lower dollar has been cheaper oil, the Bank associated a weaker pound with increased inflationary pressure.

Finally, and this may not show up the minutes, there may be some private concern about what might be in the Budget. There are no real signs that Gordon Brown is planning an old-fashioned giveaway package, but a lot can happen in politics in a couple of months. With so many uncertainties, the Bank will want harder evidence of a real slowdown before taking the rate-cutting plunge.

webTitle: Interbrew reviews options

fields.headline: Interbrew reviews options
fields.trailText: Interbrew is considering a high-risk option of defying the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, by selling its Whitbread breweries, instead of its Bass beer operations.
fields.body:
Interbrew is considering a high-risk option of defying the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, by selling its Whitbread breweries, instead of its Bass beer operations.

Advisers have suggested that if it sold the much smaller Whitbread business, Interbrew could be in a position to seek an order from the European authorities overturning the British government's regulatory review.

Sources close to the Belgian company stress that this is only one of a variety of possibilities under consideration. However, Interbrew is determined to hang on to at least part of its Bass acquisition.

Interbrew paid £400m for the Whitbread breweries, in Manchester, Salmesbury and Magor, Gwent, last May. The business owns brands such as Boddingtons, Wadworth 6X and Murphy's Irish Stout.

This deal was eclipsed later in the year by the Belgian firm's £2.3bn purchase of Bass Brewers, which makes Carling, Tennent's and Worthington.

Mr Byers last week ordered Interbrew to sell its Bass operations, following a recommendation from the competition commission, on the grounds that the two deals gave the firm a dominant market share of between 33% and 37%.

Some advisers believe that by substantially diminishing this share by disposing of Whitbread, Interbrew could argue that the landscape had changed, and the entire regulatory process should be re-started. However, if the gamble failed, the company could be left with no breweries in Britain at all.

Interbrew is unlikely to decide on its next move for at least another week.

webTitle: CNN to cut staff by 25%

fields.headline: CNN to cut staff by 25%
fields.trailText: CNN, the cable television news outfit, is preparing to cut up to a quarter of its 4,000-strong workforce in the latest indication of a slowdown among global media groups.
fields.body:
CNN, the cable television news outfit, is preparing to cut up to a quarter of its 4,000-strong workforce in the latest indication of a slowdown among global media groups.

The job cuts at CNN, expected early next week, come a week after News Corporation and New York Times Digital scaled back their internet ambitions with significant staff reduction plans.

NBC, one ofthe US's biggest TV outfits, is also rumoured to be preparing to make cuts to stem losses at its own internet operations. The New York-based media business, which is owned by General Electric, was not returning calls for comment yesterday.

The severity and extent of the cutbacks reflects the rapidly deteriorating business outlook for the media sector, with advertising revenues falling as a result of the slowing economy as well as the collapse of the dot.com sector.

The axe is expected to fall hardest on CNN's internet operations. Total job cuts could be as high as 1,000, although the impact is likely to be spread over some time. Executives are thought to be keen to use natural reduction and reorganisation in order to avoid redundancies.

CNN International, one of the fastest growing parts of the group's operations, is expected to be spared much of the pain of this reorganisation, according to insiders.

Its European headquarters in London has been expanded with several high-profile appointments recently such as that of former BBC political editor Robin Oakley. CNN's non-US viewers now outnumber its domestic audience by two to one.

webTitle: BP embroiled in price row

fields.headline: BP embroiled in price row
fields.trailText: British oil company BP is facing huge embarrassment over the public release of 4,000 internal emails and other company material suggesting it considered using its dominant position supplying the Californian petrol market with crude oil to manipulate prices and squeeze consumers.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  Terry Macalister
fields.body:
British oil company BP is facing huge embarrassment over the public release of 4,000 internal emails and other company material suggesting it considered using its dominant position supplying the Californian petrol market with crude oil to manipulate prices and squeeze consumers.

The cache of documentation has been unsealed in the United States this week in the wake of BP's two-year battle with American regulators over the British company's £18bn takeover of its American rival, Arco, which was allowed to proceed only after BP agreed to sell the bulk of its oil assets in Alaska, which supplies much of the gas-guzzling west coast of the US.

Most damaging for BP, whose chief executive, Sir John Browne, has extolled the group's ethical standards, are two emails dating from 1995 in which two company managers - Robert Aicher and Linda Adamany - refer to "shorting the west coast market" to achieve "west coast price uplift scenarios" - seemingly discussing restricting crude supplies to force up forecourt prices.

The documentation relates to potential court action prepared by the federal trade commission, which challenged BP's grip over the local oil market after the Arco takeover, and the affair is bound to draw comparisons with the American justice department's mammoth anti-monopoly battle with Microsoft, where much of the government's case was based on the disclosure of damaging internal company emails.

The allegations of market manipulation also come at an acutely sensitive time, since rising pump costs combined with the highest industry prof its for 15 years have left so-called "big oil" under attack from politicians and consumers on both sides of the Atlantic.

BP completely rejects the charges of manipulation, while industry analysts have said that they believed the company is being used as a scapegoat by consumer champions looking for blood.

But R Preston McAfee, a professor at the University of Texas and an expert witness for the FTC, claimed to the Guardian that BP was able to artificially inflate west coast prices by abusing its dominant position.

Describing BP's use of a computer model called "the optimiser," he said: "I had already drawn the conclusion that BP was able to manipulate prices ... because it had a procedure which described how it was going to do it."

The British oil company's chief spokesman in London denied all charges of acting improperly or illegally and dismissed the email exchange between what he described as two traders employed by BP to buy and sell oil on the west coast.

"We are absolutely certain that whatever these guys may have thought or said, there was no impact on prices and that was demonstrable," he said.

The BP spokesman drew support from a New York-based oil sector think tank - the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation - which questioned whether BP could manipulate the market.

John Lichtblau, its chairman, said: "Oil companies will always try to maximise profits but in an open market like California where refiners could import oil from elsewhere a strategy of trying to manipulate prices on anything other than a short-term basis would never work."

webTitle: US 'regrets' killing Korean war refugees

fields.headline: US 'regrets' killing Korean war refugees
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton issued an unprecedented statement of regret yesterday for the killing of Korean refugees at No Gun Ri during the Korean war, after an investigation lasting 15 months.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton issued an unprecedented statement of regret yesterday for the killing of Korean refugees at No Gun Ri during the Korean war, after an investigation lasting 15 months.

"I deeply regret that Korean civilians lost their lives at No Gun Ri," he said, but he did not refer to the role of US troops in the incident. "We have been unable to determine the exact events," he said, calling the episode a "painful reminder of the tragedies of war".

Although the statement stopped short of the formal apology and acceptance of guilt sought by many in South Korea, the Pentagon is reported to have agreed to pay $1m to build a monument near the now infamous South Korean village, and $750,000 to create a memorial scholarship for Korean students.

Pentagon investigators examined more than 1m documents and interviewed about 170 veterans of the 1950-53 Korean war after reports of the massacre by US troops appeared in 1999.

They found that young, poorly trained recruits fired on a group of refugees sheltering under a railway bridge during the early days of the war, in July 1950.

The soldiers, who were in confused retreat, were said to have panicked because they had been warned that enemy North Korean troops were disguised as civilians.

The refugees were killed by "small arms, machine guns, mortar and artillery fire", the report quoted US veterans as saying. It also cited Korean witnesses, who said the refugees were strafed by US planes.

The investigators said they had found no evidence that the massacre was carried out on the orders of military leaders, however, contradicting the Associated Press articles which broke the story in 1999.

According to AP, the 25th infantry division was told that civilians should be "considered as unfriendly and shot".

Yesterday's report said only that US soldiers "were legitimately fearful of the possible infiltration of North Korean soldiers who routinely entered American lines in groups disguised as civilians in refugee columns and then attacked American positions from the rear".

Mr Clinton decided that an apology was unnecessary and no financial compensation would be paid directly to the survivors or victims' families. It remains to be seen whether his statement will be sufficient to quell rising anti-US sentiment.

Although officials from Washington and Seoul have spent more than a month trying to harmonise their response to the investigation, they remain far apart in their estimates of the scale of the massacre.

In a statement of "mutual understanding", the South Koreans claim that 248 people were killed or wounded. The US says this figure is exaggerated, but does not give an alternative. Pentagon advisers told the investigators that the number was probably between 50 and 100.

Fear of a deterioration in relations between Seoul and Washington has increased as North and South Korea have entered their closest rapprochement since the war, and the number of protests against US bases in South Korea has grown.

webTitle: G2: Emma Brockes discovers professional darts

fields.headline: 'It isn't the Six Nations, granted, but the drinking is unbeatable'
fields.standfirst: It's full of lethal hairdos, lethal drinks and nail-biting drama.  Emma Brockes  on the glamorous world of professional darts
fields.trailText: It's full of lethal hairdos, lethal drinks and nail-biting drama. Emma Brockes on the glamorous world of professional darts.
fields.body:
In the auditorium of the Lakeside country club, Frimley, two heavily disguised women are wrestling to contain their excitement. Raising their false moustaches for a cigarette and mindful not to ignite their chest hair, they keen in their seats for a better view of the stage door.

Enquiries as to who they are dressed as - Kevin Keegan seems a strong possibility - elicit a pitying response. "We're Steve," says Mel Barlow after a short silence. She is an officer for the Cheshire police. "Beaton," clarifies her friend Kate Davies, who has flown in from Majorca and will change her costume three times over the course of the evening. "The Adonis," they say in unison.

Backstage at the Embassy World Darts Championship, Steve "the Adonis" Beaton is warming up at the practice board. The 36-year-old from Coventry is only 20th in the world, but his resemblance to a 70s porn star - crinkle-cut mullet, heavy moustache, runaway chest hair - commands the sort of fanship that other darts players can only envy.

Of the 32 players entered in this year's championship, only Andy "The Viking" Fordham has the right combination of swirly chin growth and thunderous belt-size to inspire this level of kitsch devotion (Mel and Kate are later to be seen in Viking helmets and wizardy beards). As the championship moves into its second week, so a small corner of Surrey succumbs to such excesses as are inspired by the immortal rejoinder, "Let's ... play ... darts."

The tenor of the darts world can be measured by a section of its governing body's website devoted to local clubs "from around the world", in which the world is represented by Harlow, Bolton and Bideford, north Devon. While other sports stars hustle for the Nike or the Adidas contract, premiere darts players eke out sponsorship on more modest slopes.

John "John Boy" Walton, the top-10 player from Yorkshire, is supplied courtesy of Jim's Darts of Kirkby. Trina Gulliver, the women's world number one, is sponsored by Reeves Boatbuilders of Napton, Warwickshire and has appearances coming up at the Fox and Hounds, Daventry, and Ketton Sports Complex, Leicestershire. Martin "Wolfie" Adams, England team captain and a competition favourite, would like to thank the Towngate Inn, Lakeside, for its continuing support.

The Lakeside country club can hold up to 1,000 people, the majority of whom, at Wednesday night's second round match, are arranged around long trestle tables groaning beneath plates of curry and pint glasses. The compere eases the crowd into a state of ecstasy with a joke that turns on the line, "Sorry love, I thought you were a bloke".

While Beaton limbers up beneath the framed photos of former Lakeside acts - Gary Wilmot, Edwina Curry and Spit the Dog - the sound system pumps out hooks from Ricky Martin's Livin' La Vida Loca and Queen's Another One Bites the Dust.

Beaton's opponent in this round is the number two seed, Raymond Barneveld, a 33-year-old Dutchman notable for his cleft chin and dynamic fans, who, on this occasion have travelled from the Hague dressed in "Barney" T-shirts and orange fright wigs. "It's a very exciting game," says Andres Brugmans, 29, who comes from Barney's hometown and wears an alice band sprouting two silver orbs on springs. "I prefer soccer, of course, but you go to a soccer match and you get your head kicked in."

The only aggression to be found at Lakeside tonight is the camp, "hoo-ya" showmanship more familiar to the world of WWF wrestling. Unlike the grudging courtesies submitted to by most sports stars, the relationship between professional darts players is an extension of the pub banter they have marinated in since their first game. Roger Carter, the former world champion from Atlanta, Georgia, enjoyed a lively exchange with his British rival, Phil "The Power" Taylor this week, when Taylor logged onto the American's website, typed "I AM THE BEST" and logged off again.

By 7pm, the Dutch TV crews have squeezed themselves into place below the stage and the crowd is poised to receive its heroes. "Former semi-finalist of the Denmark Open," chimes the compere (Mel and Kate twitch to attention), "Embassy World Champion, 1996 ... would you please welcome, Steve ... Beaton!" Across the auditorium, hands emerge from packets of Golden Wonder crisps to beat the air. Beaton smoothes down his moustache and the game begins.

While the match is undeniably exciting, the atmosphere of the event is generated away from the devoted fans at the front and in the rowdy mass of pleasure seekers at tables nearer the bar. When they got on the train at Neath, South Wales, this morning, Tim, Gavin, James, Gary and Chris opened their first cans of lager and drank to being 18. Tickets to the championship cost them £4.50, the train ride £40, the Welsh flag jester hats another £10. "Darts," says Gavin, straining to articulate his thoughts through the alcohol, "is a national institution." He gives it a moment's foggy contemplation. "Like Christmas."

"He's a twat, don't listen to him," says Tim. "Darts isn't the Six Nations, granted, but the drinking is unbeatable." Rather surprisingly Tim is drinking Baileys, a girls' tipple I venture, before being nudged towards the pint of lager he is mixing it with it. They leave to be sick before the match is over.

"We're here for the mullets," says Andrew Macpherson, with heavy sarcasm. He and his friends - Ralph, Tim, Neil and Andrew - are down from Cambridge, deploying the defensive irony of students in late adolescence.

"Yeah," says Tim, "we expected it to be full of sweaty men with big guts, and we haven't been disappointed. We're supporting Kevin Painter cos he's from Ipswich. Can you get Ray Stubbs to come out of the VIP lounge for us?"

Sweet-tempered Barney stands aside, smiling faintly, and within another quarter of an hour has won the match.

webTitle: Food: Portrait of experimental chef Heston Blumenthal

fields.headline: Mustard ice cream, anyone?
fields.standfirst: His creations include tobacco chocolate and veal cooked with hay. But his restaurant, the Fat Duck at Bray, has won a Michelin star - and he is rumoured to be the best chef in Britain. Victoria Moore watches Heston Blumenthal work his magic
fields.trailText: His creations include tobacco chocolate and veal cooked with hay. But his restaurant, the Fat Duck at Bray, has won a Michelin star - and he is rumoured to be the best chef in Britain. Victoria Moore watches Heston Blumenthal work his magic.
fields.body:
Crab risotto with crab ice cream. Veal sweetbread cooked with hay and pollen and roasted in a salt crust. Foie gras with smoked eel and jasmine and mead jelly. And smoked bacon ice cream with pain perdu, caramelised tomato and puree of cep. For dessert.

"Some people just start laughing when they read our menu," says Heston Blumenthal. "They think it's a joke."

Ah, but this menu is no joke: this menu is deadly serious. And 34-year-old Blumenthal is not the only one who thinks so. The Michelin inspectors have awarded Blumenthal's restaurant, the Fat Duck in Bray, Berkshire, its first star. Marco Pierre White, a close friend and mentor, has called him "an exceptional young man", adding that he expects Blumenthal will soon win a second star. And the current Good Food Guide fetes him as chef of the year.

Blumenthal is the Willy Wonka of modern British cooking. If his food sounds like the kind of food people politely like to call "challenging", then believe me, it's not, for the simple reason that you don't have to try hard to enjoy it. Blumenthal's are some of the cleanest, yet most intense, flavours you will ever taste. And the combinations of tastes are revelatory, blowing away all preconceptions about what one should eat when.

In his tiny kitchen at the Fat Duck, I watch entranced as he churns one absurd-sounding ice cream after another (whole grain mustard; chocolate and thyme; bacon). Someone else is whizzing a frozen cauliflower puree through a machine that grinds it to a fine crystalline powder ("to make it smoother").

Another is patiently monitoring electronic temperature prods stuck in venison fillets that are being very slowly pan-cooked and turned by hand every couple of minutes. On a shelf I notice a canister of liquid nitrogen that, I am told, is sprayed on foie gras to keep the outer surface cool so that it can cook evenly all the way through.

At the helm of all this, in his spattered green trousers, strawberry blonde hair shorn to frame a genial face, Heston Blumenthal is calm. Despite the exotic name he is English, born in London and brought up near High Wycombe. Only when you speak to him does he display signs of the maverick genius he clearly is.

"Do you remember space dust?" he asks me, a wicked glint in his eye. They don't sell it here any more but after laborious research Blumenthal has unearthed some in Spain. He bought a 15kg bag of it (the smallest amount available) and is now toying with the idea of putting it in ice cream so that, as they eat dessert, customers will suddenly experience a funny popping in the back of the mouth. "But maybe that's a step too far," he says.

Then he hands me a luscious-looking chocolate. I take it, raising my eyes in a questioning glance. "Fermented pipe tobacco," he smirks. The chocolate itself is delicious (only the best ingredients, in this case Valrhona). The next flavour I experience is rich - prunes and vanillas. I say this but Blumenthal is still eyeing me expectantly. "Wait," he promises. "You get another flavour - a sort of hot kick." Nothing happens. Thirty slow seconds pass. And then, suddenly, it comes - a light, peppery punch on the tongue.

I am delighted and Blumenthal is off, rattling out an explanation. The rate at which we register flavours varies according to the size of the food's molecules. The taste of small molecules bursts more quickly onto the tongue than that of large ones. This is why the chilli hotness took so long to come through. "And in theory ..." he says, "in theory, if you took three different foods with different sized molecules and mixed them very gently together you could create an ice cream with three separate flavours.

"Anchovies, tomatoes and pineapple ... anything. And you'd taste them one at a time - one, two, three, with just a slight overlap."

By now you will have realised that at the Fat Duck the kitchen is run almost like a laboratory. For all the firecracker creativity the role of science - physics, chemistry and psychology, too - is studied reverently.

"We don't believe in any of those 3,000-year-old housewives tales," one kitchen acolyte tells me proudly. Indeed, with the help of Bristol University physicist Peter Barham, who recently published a formula to determine how much gravy your roast dinner will soak up, Blumenthal has already debunked several myths. Heard the one about adding salting to the boiling water to fix the colour in green beans? "Rubbish," says Blumenthal. Chlorophyll, the green pigment, is held in beans by magnesium. Magnesium is attracted to calcium, so if your water is hard and therefore calcium-heavy, out goes the magnesium and the chlorophyll follows.

In Blumenthal's hands, though, plain old physics becomes a kind of alchemy that can transform base root vegetables into delicate sweetmeats and hulking sides of bacon into a soft, pale caramelly ice cream.

And some of his techniques are breathtakingly simple. "The inside temperature of meat is always fairly cool," he says. "So if you want your meat to be cooked perfectly all the way through then you should cook it at this low temperature for a long period of time." The venison I saw being prepared in his kitchen is cooked according to this theory and is succulent and evenly coloured all the way through. And because of the low-impact cooking the protein chains in the meat do not contract and knit together. Abracadabra, perfectly cooked meat.

He is always defying convention. Whole fish are difficult to cook perfectly because they are a different thickness from head to tail. And when you take them off the heat convection currents between the scales continues to cook them. "I just wish we could cook the tail perfectly, take it to the customer and tell them to eat from the tail upwards. By the time the reached the head it would be perfect."

Harold McGee's book On Food and Cooking: The Science and Lore of the Kitchen was an early influence on Blumenthal. And he has forged links with Firmenich, a Swiss company that creates flavours and scents and whose clients include Walker's crisps.

"They have extracted some 10,000 flavours," Blumenthal says, "some distilled, some recreated. And they are constantly experimenting."

So is he. One of his petit fours is a beetroot jelly - a sort of upmarket fruit pastille. "It's funny when you watch people eat it," he says with Puckish glee. "Tell them it's beetroot and they start to look nervous and don't know if they like it. But if you say it's blackcurrant they think it's delicious. In fact, beetroot, like blackcurrant, contains tartaric acid and that's what makes them taste so similar."

He is fascinated with the psychology of eating, noting that a lot of what we taste is determined by our expectations. "If I called my crab ice cream frozen crab bisque no one would bat an eyelid," he says.

We pause for a moment and try to work out why some flavours are considered savoury and some are not but can't think of a single reason (apart from natural sweetness, though even that breaks down when you think about tart blackcurrants).

Blumenthal believes that the way the palate interprets flavours is more strongly linked to the brain than people realise. The palate is trained from birth. One in eight people can't taste truffles properly, if at all; a bit like some people can't hear dog-whistles. But one of the flavour experts at Firmenich successfully trained his palate to find the taste of truffle by treating it to regular truffle hits over an 18-month period.

Seasonal produce is so appealing because we link the taste back to a childhood memory of, say, picking brambles, and use that to create an environment around a taste, says Blumenthal.

He is constantly thinking about the customer's experience, from the noise the restaurant door makes when it shuts to the taste of the palate-cleansing pre-starter on freshly cleaned teeth. And he wants people to trust him when they walk into his restaurant. If they don't his attitude is refreshingly down to earth: there may be no soft grilled chicken option on his menu but if someone feels very uncomfortable he's happy to rustle up something simple.

It's hard to know what is more impressive: the vision or the relentless hard graft behind it. It has taken the Fat Duck kitchens 18 months to perfect the crab tuiles to a melt-in-the-mouth, brandy-snap like consistency. Each test involved reducing several gallons of crab stock to a few marmitey fluid ounces. And that was just the beginning.

But Blumenthal never balks, just moves obsessively on to the next puzzle. In this case, his magic ingredient is maltidextrine, a carbon compound that looks and behaves like sugar but is not sweet. It is used commercially to thicken beef dumplings and gravies. "I had an idea," announces Blumenthal grandly. "Savoury candyfloss."

For his first attempt he unwittingly bought a fairground-sized drum that was several feet across. He had to send it back. Now he has got a domestic candyfloss-spinner but the temperature doesn't go high enough. "But we'll get there," he says. "It'll probably take six to eight months but we'll get there."

webTitle: TV and Radio: Sunday-night dramas

fields.headline: Comfort and joy
fields.standfirst: During the long winter months, Sunday night is drama night - but not just any kind. People dreading the return to work yearn for reassuring escapism.  Gareth McLean  on the secrets of Ovaltine TV
fields.trailText: During the long winter months, Sunday night is drama night - but not just any kind. People dreading the return to work yearn for reassuring escapism. Gareth McLean on the secrets of Ovaltine TV.
fields.body:
Alonesome vintage car traversing a thin road across wild and windy moors; a jolly nurse smiling benevolently into the camera; Bill Haley and the Comets playing on the pub jukebox; a winsome Irish woman standing atop a sun-dappled hill: these are the things of which Sunday night dramas are made.

Dubbed the Ovaltine of television drama, the likes of Where The Heart Is, Heartbeat and Ballykissangel may be ridiculed for their feel-good factors and cosiness but the fact remains: they pull in viewers in their millions. Even after several years and the departure of original cast members, the triumvirate of Sunday-night dramas regularly attract almost 10 million viewers each.

Nick Berry and Niamh Cusack may have left Aidensfield, Sarah Lancashire and Pam Ferris might have departed Skelthwaite and Dervla Kirwan and Stephen Tompkinson may have left BallyK (him in angst, her in a box) but the goings-on in those villages continue to exert a strange, almost hypnotic, fascination over the viewing public.

"At eight o'clock on a Sunday night, audiences have a particular need. When the week is in prospect and people are getting in gear, I'm not sure they want to be intellectually extended. However, I think there is an appetite for well-structured storytelling, strong characterisation and emotional engagement with those characters. These are essential elements for any drama but particularly those on a Sunday night."

So says Jeremy Gwilt, and he should know. Gwilt has worked on the likes of Ballykissangel, Lovejoy, Bergerac and all three series of The House of Eliot. He's currently producer of BBC1's Monarch of the Glen. Gwilt maintains there's no special formula for Sunday night drama (rural setting, handsome lead, a serious story and a comic story running concurrently, for example) but acknowledges there are certain things which work particularly well.

"Getting away from an urban, gritty setting certainly helps," he admits. "But there have to be good stories told too. It's no use having lots of beautiful scenery if your stories aren't up to it. You're not making a travelogue, after all."

A fan of Where The Heart Is, Gwilt admires its storytelling and knack of immediately engaging its audience while being more entertaining than a Wednesday-night drama.

"If you flick into Where The Heart Is, within 10 seconds you're engaged emotionally. It's all about the problems people have relating to one another and the way those problems are handled. You may be telling stories differently than you would in a drama going out on a Wednesday night or a post-watershed slot - Sunday-night dramas need to be more about entertaining and less about social realism - but this need not limit the impact of the stories."

Gwilt says for a Sunday-night drama to be successful, it must do two things: tell a self-contained three-act story which gives occasional viewers satisfaction, and, for regular viewers, develop characters and their relationships.

Monarch of the Glen does both, but differently from its contemporaries. "A show like Where The Heart Is is almost always driven by a story of the week and a guest character - say, a single mother who's dying of leukaemia and whose daughter's future is in doubt," Gwilt explains.

"By the end of the episode, her estranged husband will have been reconciled with his ex-wife and will have promised to care for his daughter. We know that the woman will die happy, knowing her daughter is being looked after. Meanwhile, the serial development of regular characters will continue apace."

Monarch of the Glen, on the other hand, relies on its ensemble to create the story of the week. "Our show has an underlying proposition - how this family is going to prevent itself from going bankrupt. We don't rely on guest characters for the story of the week. Instead, our characters generate a situation which creates a circumstance which has to be resolved."

Unlike Heartbeat, which relies on a B-story involving the exploits of Greengrass, the show's comic relief, Gwilt says Monarch of the Glen is more comedic from the outset. "Character-based comedy, I hasten to add," he says.

Whereas dramas broadcast later on a Sunday night, such as Cold Feet or Clocking Off, can be viewed as treat drama for a younger audience - the last vestiges of the weekend's bounty before the week's duties kick in, the Sunday-night drama broadcast around eight o'clock serves a particular purpose. It is televisual Ovaltine, but that need not be a bad thing, especially if you're looking to be soothed.

"The labels that these dramas attract - safe, comforting, feel-good, unchallenging - I know where they come from but I don't think they're deserved," says Gwilt. "It's to do with what Monarch of the Glen has in common with Where The Heart Is, Ballykissangel and Lovejoy. Ultimately, the dramas that are successful on a Sunday night at eight are the ones in which the characters have a positive view of human nature. Fundamentally, they are optimists. I don't think that's anything to be apologetic about."

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Seat Of Eagles | Schnittke Weekend
fields.body:
Snowdonia was declared a national park just 50 years ago. Sian Parri Huws, who has long associations with the region, reports on the changes wrought there over the intervening decades. The local name for these 800-square miles of Wales translates as Seat Of Eagles (11am, Radio 4) but there are also 28,000 humans trying to survive. Many must depend solely on tourists, of whom there are now far too many in the summer and far too few in winter.

Alfred Schnittke was one of the Soviet Union's most eminent composers, but his name is hardly a household word. The BBC Symphony Orchestra hopes to go some way to rectify this with its Schnittke Weekend (6pm, Radio 3), drawing on a selection of his prolific output. The main emphasis is on the symphonies and concertos, written in what Schnittke called his "polystylistic" mode. Boris Berman launches the series with performances of the first and second Piano Sonatas.

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Budle Bay, Northumbria
fields.trailText: Budle Bay, Northumbria
fields.body:
A new-year family rendezvous brought us to Northumbria and a week's residence in a holiday home at the head of Budle Bay. Across the road, Waren Mill, a watermill of long historic interest, now stands in a state of near dereliction, but the burn which provided the working head of water through a lade now thickly overgrown was in spate as the meltwater of a snow-covered landscape drained off the inland farms.

Flood warnings from the Environment Agency littered the kitchen, but the maximum height of the tumbling water peaked with five feet to spare. The low angle of the winter sun lit up the vast expanse of the bay at low water.

This was, in truth, a free open-air avian zoo, for a splendid range of estuarial winter visitors appeared on the mudflats which were clearly a very rich source of nourishment. English Nature provide the informative notices and describe it as part of the Lindisfarne Reserve. The delightful call of the curlew welcomed us, and curlews were prominent through the week. But so was a whole variety of duck and geese, although, oddly enough, neither of the varieties of winter-visiting swans, whoopers or Bewicks.

This was really birdwatching for the seriously lacking in energy. The minor road to Bamburgh runs beside the southern edge of the bay. Parking beside the road, erecting hi-tech binoculars on a tripod and gazing down as if checking a laptop seemed a popular visitor attraction. And its practitioners were certainly very informative on the species out on the mud before them.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip.
fields.body:
There have never been so many ways to get on telly. What with all this so-called "constructed reality TV" around, from Big Brother and Castaway to Popstars, it wouldn't surprise us if the entire nation hadn't applied for their own 15 minutes of TV fame by, say, 2005. Now there's a prediction to kick off the real millennium.

As you'd expect, Channel 5 has its own peculiar, yet endearing, way of jumping onto the latest TV bandwagon. It hasn't been entirely successful with reality TV so far (did you watch Jailbreak?), but it's having another go this year with what should be a much more popular format, The Mole. But as that programme starts this week, it's already too late to try to become one of the contestants.

Instead, why not apply to be one of the lucky 26 people chosen for Channel 5's next addition to the reality genre: Touching the Truck. True to its word, the show features people quite literally touching a truck.

Not very interesting, you might think. You'd be wrong. The challenge lies in winning a truck by becoming the last of the 26 hopefuls to keep at least one hand on a vehicle (worth £50,000) at ALL times for up to a week. EVEN WHEN YOU'RE ASLEEP. Contestants can try to distract one another, and let's hope they do - we'll need some dirty tricks to differentiate this particular programme from a webcast of a road junction near you, where you might be lucky enough to spot a cyclist putting one hand on a bus while pausing at the lights.

Surely things would have been a bit more titillating and Channel 5-ish if they'd used the name of the original American version of the show. Hands on a Hardbody is apparently even more than a programme in the States - it's a competitive event. Which leaves us wondering why Channel 5 didn't just buy the name, forget the truck and invent their own rules.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine.

webTitle: Rage

fields.headline: Rage
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is broad-brush film-making and is a bit incoherent, but Aduaka's direction has a lot of energy.
fields.body:
This is a rough-and-ready first feature from writer-director Newton I Aduaka, about Jamie (Fraser Ayres) - street name "Rage" - who stacks shelves at a warehouse supermarket in London, and dreams of making it big as a rapper and gangsta. Needing cash for studio time, Rage and his mates Thomas and Godwin ("T" and "G") try getting the three grand together by burgling the house of one of their relatives, an adventure which ends in the customary catastrophe.

This is broad-brush film-making and is a bit incoherent, but Aduaka's direction has a lot of energy, and the film has interesting contributions from actors playing the older characters: Shango Baku is gentle and dignified as Marcus, Rage's elderly Rasta father figure, and Wale Ojo is the droll and intimidating druglord Pin.

Aduaka has an eye for London's alienation and dispossession, and finally contrives an unexpectedly fierce scene between Rage and his mother Ellen (Alison Rose) in which he bitterly accuses her of "selfishness" in making him mixed race. Rage is a raw, unshaped movie, but Newton I Aduaka is a film-maker to watch.

webTitle: The Criminal

fields.headline: The Criminal
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Some very creepy and effective scenes and there's some nicely underplayed support from Eddie Izzard as the pathologist.
fields.body:
At just 23, Julian Simpson has made a formidably promising feature debut with this convoluted thriller, which he has written and directed, taking its cue from Prime Suspect and The Usual Suspects.

Steven Mackintosh is on characteristically intense and unsmiling form as J, an unemployed musician who finds himself in a bar one night chatting up the beautiful and mysterious Sarah (Natasha Little). When Sarah's body is found in his flat, J obviously finds himself in the frame and he goes on the run from bloated, malign copper Bernard Hill.

Between them, Simpson and his producer-editor Mark Aarons have come up with some very creepy and effective scenes, and there's some nicely underplayed support from Eddie Izzard as the pathologist. It all gets a bit too tangled and absurd by the final reel, however, and I couldn't help feeling that the sinister and enigmatic Shackleton organisation - supposedly the key to everything - had become a script-alibi for plot lines that otherwise wouldn't tie up. But this is undeniably a strong beginning from Simpson.

webTitle: Mitterrand's son bailed as graft inquiry widens

fields.headline: Mitterrand's son bailed as graft inquiry widens
fields.trailText: Three weeks after he was jailed on suspicion of illegal arms-dealing and money-laundering, the elder son of the late French president François Mitterrand was released yesterday when his mother posted £500,000 bail.
fields.body:
Three weeks after he was jailed on suspicion of illegal arms-dealing and money-laundering, the elder son of the late French president François Mitterrand was released yesterday when his mother posted £500,000 bail.

Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, suspected of playing a key role in the illicit sale of arms worth £350m to Angola in the 90s, made no comment about the scandal, which threatens to embroil further prominent figures, as he was driven away from La Santé prison in central Paris.

But in an interview published yesterday, Mr Mitterrand, who was his father's chief adviser on African affairs at the Elysée palace for six years, reasserted his innocence and attacked the magistrate heading the inquiry, Philippe Courroye.

"He exercises an arbitrary power, without any subtlety or mercy, like judges in totalitarian countries," he said.

"He evinced a dogged hostility, a real hatred. I don't know why I was jailed. The judges already knew everything. If my name was not Mitterrand, I would not have been given the same treatment."

The investigation into Mr Mitterrand, 54, was extended on Wednesday to Geneva, where the authorities said inquiries were being made about money-laundering, and 10 Swiss bank accounts had been frozen in consequence.

Mr Mitterrand, nicknamed "Papa m'a dit" (Daddy told me), has admitted being paid £1.3m by Brenco International, a company run by the accused arms dealer Pierre Falcone, but he insists that it was for legitimate consultancy work.

Mr Courroye's expanding investigation, which has so far dragged in a best-selling novelist and a former leading adviser to the late president, now includes the former interior minister Charles Pasqua.

His investigators have found that Mr Falcone paid £300,000 to Mr Pasqua's right-hand-man and senior Africa aide, Jean-Charles Marchiani.

They suspect that the illicit arms deals may have been made under a Franco-Angolan agreement negotiated by Mr Pasqua and President Eduardo Dos Santos.

French media have suggested the investigators also believe that some of Mr Falcone's money may have filtered its way, via Mr Marchiani, into the coffers of the RPF party founded by Mr Pasqua.

Mr Pasqua, whose name has also cropped up on the margins of a separate corruption inquiry involving the French oil company Elf, has repeatedly denied wrongdoing, and says he has never met Mr Falcone.

Danielle Mitterrand said she had collected her son's "ransom" from relatives and members of "the Mitterrand generation".

The main magistrate's union, the USM, demanded an inquiry into how Mr Mitterrand had managed to give an interview in jail.

webTitle: Video releases

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Essex Boys |  Jesus' Son  |  What Planet Are You From?
fields.trailText: Essex Boys | Jesus' Son | What Planet Are You From?
fields.body:
Essex Boys
Rental and DVD rental Fox Pathé Cert 18
***

Yes, it's British and it has gangsters - but Essex Boys is a proper crime thriller, not one of those larky, laddish Brit thugfests hopefully ended by the Fast Show's parody: "The Long Big Punch-Up, a right royal cockney barrel o' monkeys." Essex Boys is, it says, "inspired by a single true event. All the rest is fiction." It wraps a convincing and unpredictable tale around a 1995 news story when three men were found shot dead in a car. Director and co-writer Terry Winsor makes its protagonists unashamedly unpleasant. Sean Bean, usually seen as a loveable rogue, is worst of the lot as a vile ex-con and his girlfriend, Alex Kingston, is little better. Only chancer Charlie Creed-Miles, falling for the easy money as the gang's driver, has a shred of decency. Essex Boys gains originality by its settings, neon-drenched Southend and the Essex marshlands, virtually virgin cinematic territory.

Jesus' Son
Rental High Fliers Cert 18
***

Jesus' Son has handwritten credits, a hazy voiceover and a hazier approach to a narrative, lowlife hustlers, laconic humour, loads of drugs and a weirdo bit part for Dennis Hopper ("Talk into my bullet-hole and tell me I'm fine"). In other words, it's as archetypal an American independent movie as you could possibly find. Director Alison Maclean anchors its fractured sensibility with title cards rather than structure and gets memorable performances from on-off lovers Billy Crudup (soon to be seen in Almost Famous) and Samantha Morton, whose strange, luminous eyes suit her junkie role. Occasionally it's very funny - especially in Crudup's stint as a hospital orderly. But it all seems a bit too self-conscious to stand out from the indie herd.

What Planet Are You From?
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 15
*

Failed comedy is so much more painful than failed drama and this straight-to-video dud is all the sadder for having Garry Shandling as star, co-writer and co-producer, especially for those of us suffering Larry Sanders withdrawals. It's a thin tale about an alien coming to earth to pro-create, with obsolete comedy ideas (like an argument broadcast over a PA system) and wastes John Goodman, Annette Bening (as a real estate dealer, again) and the eternally misused Linda Fiorentino. Stick to Third Rock.

It's a thin tale about an alien coming to earth to pro-create, with obsolete comedy ideas (like an argument broadcast over a PA system) and wastes John Goodman, Annette Bening (as a real estate dealer, again) and the eternally misused Linda Fiorentino. Stick to Third Rock.

webTitle: Cast Away

fields.headline: Cast Away
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Zemeckis's film is blithely uninterested in any of the serious personal or social implications of becoming a modern Crusoe... This is just deeply silly.
fields.body:
Having given us his preposterous sub-Hitchcock snorefest with What Lies Beneath, Robert Zemeckis has followed it up with a giant two hour, 20 minute advertisement for FedEx. There is no other word for it. Tom Hanks plays a driven, work-obsessed systems engineer for FedEx helping them to expand triumphally around the globe. We see him first haranguing the local hirelings in the Moscow branch - a picture of Lenin is being unscrewed from a wall in one shot - generally kicking their asses and imbuing them with the ethos of the dynamic, beat-the-clock service economy.

Then his FedEx plane crashes and he's stranded on a desert island for four years with nothing to do but grow a very big and unattractive beard. But if you thought this was a critique of FedEx in some way, or a comment on the absurdity and meaninglessness of globalism and the ever-expanding imperatives of commerce, then boy would you ever be totally wrong. The FedEx packages washed ashore help our Tom to survive - and even, finally, to find love.

What happens when you are stranded alone, forced to survive in the wild? In real life, you grow skeletally thin, and become deeply traumatised by the solitude, unable to communicate properly for months afterwards and in dire need of therapy. None of this applies to cheerfully robust Tom! He looks dishevelled, sure, and he's got a modest Tarzan-style loincloth; he looks like the Michael Palin character who used to run up to the camera and say "IT'S..." before the Monty Python's Flying Circus title sequence. But Tom looks very, very well on his coconuts and occasional fish. He's got a paunch! Even after four years, he's got a right old gut on him. Castaway or no castaway, Mr Hanks has clearly been visiting the location catering van three times a day during principal photography.

Zemeckis's film is blithely uninterested in any of the serious personal or social implications of becoming a modern Crusoe. Hanks comes out of it the regular guy he was when he went in. John Sayles's Limbo was a far more convincing and terrifying account of being marooned. This is just deeply silly.

webTitle: Bishop's lament for bended knees

fields.headline: Bishop's lament for bended knees
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: "At the name of Jesus every knee shall bow" goes the old hymn, but not apparently any more in the Church of England. The bishop of Lancaster has attacked parishioners for not doing enough kneeling in church.
fields.body:
"At the name of Jesus every knee shall bow" goes the old hymn, but not apparently any more in the Church of England.

The Rt Rev Stephen Pedley, bishop of Lancaster, has attacked parishioners for not doing enough kneeling in church. But they have hit back by claiming there is no longer enough legroom to do so in comfort, and having chairs instead of pews makes the operation hazardous.

"I have noticed the death of kneeling," the bishop complained this month in See, the Blackburn diocesan magazine. "People crouch, they stand, they sit, in extremis they appear to lie down: but hardly anyone kneels.

"Many hands and fingers are filling our churches with kneelers. But who is using them for their original purpose? What do people do with them? Sit on them? Make castles of them? Throw them? Toss the hassock? Anything, it seems, but kneel on them."

He said the church's latest liturgy, Common Worship, introduced before Christmas, scarcely mentioned the practice, except for a note on page 330 saying kneeling was "appropriate" for certain prayers.

"Why is it only appropriate? When is it inappropriate? Why on one occasion rather than another?" he asked.

In the Church Times, Ian Wells of Preston replied: "As reader in my parish church, I have a stall with plenty of legroom, but when I am in the congregational seats in many other churches I find there is simply no room to kneel."

In churches that had replaced pews with chairs, he said, "any attempt to kneel results in your chair or the one in front moving over the bare stone with an ear-splitting screech. This is especially effective in Blackburn Cathedral.

"Not kneeling is not necessarily a sign of lack of reverence. It is often simple prudence ... [It] also lets you hold an order of service without the risk of using the back of the person in front of you as a prop."

webTitle: Lost Souls

fields.headline: Lost Souls
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: After what seems like hours of superfluous plot complication ... it delivers some pretty effective thrills and chills.
fields.body:
So soon after last week's execrable Bless the Child, another supernatural film comes a-rustling out of the shadows. This one is from the cinematographer Janusz Kaminski (Saving Private Ryan, Jerry Maguire), here directing his first feature. Like Bless the Child it has a handsome young British actor in an American role - Ben Chaplin - and a sexy, indie-looking girl in a vital, intuitive role; in this case, the delicate, elfin-faced Winona Ryder.

Chaplin plays a bestselling author who makes a good living delving into the psyches of mass murderers. But something weird is going on, and after what seems like hours of superfluous plot complication, this movie gets to the point: Chaplin has been chosen by the devil to be his human incarnation when Satan assumes a human shape. When this film finally makes this clear, after a tangled exposition that is evidently the residue of successive rewrites, it delivers some pretty effective thrills and chills.

But Kaminski does nothing very obviously new with the cliches and hand-me-downs from The Omen and Rosemary's Baby and the feeling of deja vu is overpowering.

webTitle: Sexy Beast review – at last, a good British gangster movie

fields.headline: Sexy Beast review – at last, a good British gangster movie
fields.standfirst: One of the most purely enjoyable films I have seen for a long time, a film which easily and cheerfully inhabits its chosen genre of old-fashioned caper comedy/thriller
fields.trailText: One of the most purely enjoyable films I have seen for a long time, a film which easily and cheerfully inhabits its chosen genre of old-fashioned caper comedy/thriller
fields.body:
The anti-prestige of the modern British gangster film has become such a commonplace. The Rada mockney, the cultural cringe to GoodFellas, Sopranos and the rest, the reactionary nostalgia of cheeky-Charlie whites-only "firms" (courtesy of the National Lottery) have all become a byword for naff. BBC Films' Love, Honour and Obey holds a special place of horror in our hearts, all the more painful because Ray Winstone's presence in it threatened to obliterate our memory of his performance in Gary Oldman's outstanding Nil By Mouth.

Sexy Beast changes that. The story of an east London wideboy bullied out of his Spanish retirement by an unspeakable ex-associate to do one more job should, in theory, be pretty ropey. But it isn't. Actually, this is one of the most purely enjoyable films I have seen for a long time, a film which easily and cheerfully inhabits its chosen genre of old-fashioned caper comedy/thriller, generously delivering laughs and a pleasing sense of menace. It has something of Stephen Frears's 1984 movie The Hit, and a sliver of Get Carter in its hint of sexual envy and self-loathing.

Its "heist" sequence, moreover, far from looking dated and implausible, actually manages to seem pleasingly classical in form, and pretty exciting at that. All this is owed to entertaining performances from Ray Winstone as the former hardman Gary Dove, gone plump and soft and lobster-red in the Spanish sun, and Ben Kingsley, the psychopathic villain Don Logan, who returns to spoil Gary's Iberian idyll, a man who talks to other people the same way he talks to himself in the bathroom mirror: in a clipped, cramped, twitchy monologue of fear.

Before Don's highly unwelcome arrival Gary lounges ecstatically by the pool in the company of his ex-porn star wife Dee Dee (Amanda Redman) and their lizard-like expat mates, Jackie (Julianne White) and Aitch (Cavan Kendall, who died shortly after filming). The director Jonathan Glazer, making his feature debut here, devises for them a setting that could almost come from the theatre, and Louis Mellis and David Scinto's script has a David Mamet-like quality of harshness and snap.

But Glazer cancels the staginess with a bizarre coup de cinéma: just as Gary is wriggling to deeper levels of sensual comfort on his sun-lounger, a giant boulder dislodged from the hillside behind his villa rolls down and, missing him by inches, lands with an almighty splash in the pool. Along with a presentiment of disaster, this very unsettling event ushers in something surreal and hallucinatory: a sense that mad dogs and Englishmen of the criminal classes are going loopy in the midday sun - of a piece with Gary's nightmares and anxiety attacks played out in the featureless scrub.

The role of Don Logan is perfectly suited to Ben Kingsley's gifts for control and stillness. There is something a little baroque and stylised about his approach - it is arguably a little actorly and unlike the behaviour of any real villain. But it is a very funny, intelligent performance nonetheless, beautifully scripted and acted, and Kingsley tops it off with a bravura show of pure sociopathic cunning when he is arrested on the plane for smoking, but gets away with it by claiming that he has been sexually harassed by one of the male stewards. His "explanation" to the gobsmacked Spanish airline security official is a veritable cadenza of witty and technically adroit screen acting.

His scenes with Ray Winstone work because they do not attempt the usual berk display of "violence". He is the instinctive psychological bully, shouting and sneering in Gary's face while Gary looks away, stunned, like a hapless abuse victim who should be taken into care. This cycle of abuse returns when Gary finally turns up in London, to be bullied by a much bigger, uglier animal in the criminal food chain, Teddy Bass - a satisfyingly nasty performance from Ian McShane. The robbery scene itself is an old-fashioned staple: safety deposit boxes.

This seems to come from the gangland era of Brinks-Mat rather than 2001: it's no hi-tech cyber-scam and no one has a laptop computer in this film. But Glazer carries it off by making it a virtual dream sequence: tunnelling in from a private health club swimming pool and flooding the strong room gives the whole thing a Dali-esque quality.

It almost defies belief that a gangster comedy, and one with so many familiar elements and faces, should work so well. But work well it does, and this is partly down to a literate script with clever visual ideas. More than this, it is down to a nicely-judged and humane performance from Ray Winstone, as the bruised ex-criminal who wants nothing more than to be left alone.
