webTitle: Roosevelt statue revealed in the state he carefully avoided

fields.headline: Roosevelt revealed in the state he carefully avoided
fields.trailText: A statue of President Franklin D Roosevelt has been unveilied, depicting him in a condition that he went to unending lengths to hide during his lifetime - in a wheelchair.
fields.body:
President Franklin D Roosevelt has finally been exposed to Americans in the condition he went to unending lengths to hide during his lifetime - in a wheelchair.

The public affirmation of his disability was made by President Bill Clinton's unveiled a bronze statue of his great predecessor on Wednesday at the entrance to the FDR Memorial in the centre of Washington.

The 2.8 hectare (seven-acre) memorial site - a succession of statues and waterfalls - marks the achievements of the man who led America out of the Depression and through the second world war.

Even before it was opened by Mr Clinton in May 1997 the memorial was criticised by disabled rights activists, who complained that the designers had connived in the deception which Roosevelt maintained throughout most of his presidency.

He contracted polio at the age of 39 while on holiday on the Atlantic coast of Canada in 1921. He never walked unaided again, but until his death in 1945, shortly after he began his historic fourth term in the White House, he preferred to make public appearances in a car, so that he could remain seated, and to deliver speeches wearing leg braces.

The main statue of Roosevelt in the memorial shows him seated alongside his dog, but draped in the cape wore to conceal the nature of his disability and the fact that he was sitting in a special chair.

The protesters successfully lobbied the Roosevelt family and won the support of former presidents Ford and Carter for their campaign to have a new statue added to the site.

"This dedication represents a great victory for people with disabilities," said Alan Reich, president of the National Organisation on Disability.

"FDR's memorial finally will acknowledge his significant disability experience, which forged his leadership qualities - courage, determination and compassion - that successfully enabled him to lead the nation through the worst crises of the 20th century."

Roosevelt is now unambiguously seated in a wheelchair in the first statue millions of visitors will see as they arrive at the memorial. But even this has failed to appease some campaigners, who complain that the new monument is insufficiently exact in its representation of Roosevelt's chair.

The sculptor, Robert Graham, had to work from very limited sources to create the work. Roosevelt's homemade wheelchair still exists, but there are only a couple of photographs showing the president in it, since he almost always refused to be photographed in any way which drew attention to his disability.

Mr Graham says the sculpture is intended more as an expression of Roosevelt's spirit and leadership than as a precise reproduction of the wheelchair the president actually used.

The wall behind the statue is inscribed with Eleanor Roosevelt's words about her husband's disability.

"Franklin's illness gave him strength and courage he had not had before. He had to think out the fundamentals of living, and learn the greatest of all lessons - infinite patience and never-ending persistence."

webTitle: Film: The best Moscow scene

fields.headline: The best Moscow scene
fields.standfirst: Cast Away
fields.trailText: Cast Away
fields.body:
The early 90s. A warehouse just off Red Square. In the process of setting up the company in Moscow, Fed-Ex trouble-shooter Chuck Noland (Tom Hanks) addresses a gaggle of prospective employees.

"Time," he announces, "rules over us without mercy. It can ruin us, or it can keep us from harm. It is like a fire. It can either destroy us, or keep us warm. And wherever I am, I look at the clock."

Noland gestures at a huge digital clock behind him.

"Because we live or we die by the clock. We never turn our back on it. And we never, ever allow ourselves the sin of losing track of time."

He brandishes a Fed-Ex package.

"Locally it's 1.15. That means we have three hours and 40 minutes to get this package on the plane. That's all we have. That's how much time we have."

He opens another package. It contains an Elvis CD.

"You see this? You know this? Fifty million record-buyers can't be wrong, huh? You know, I delivered this to myself. I Fed-Exed it before I left."

He checks the clock again.

"And delivery time is now coming up to... 87 hours, 22 minutes and 17 seconds. From Memphis, America to here in 87 hours."

He bellows at his audience. They step back.

"Eighty seven hours is a shameful disgrace! The cosmos was made in less time! Wars are fought and nations topple in 87 hours!"

See also: Mute Witness, Gorky Park, Our Man Flint.

Don't see also: The Saint.

Pointless trivia: The licence plate of Chuck Noland's car reads KAZ 2AY.

webTitle: Hubert Selby Jr and near-death experience

fields.headline: The night spirits told my wife I was dying
fields.standfirst: Legendary author of Last Exit to Brooklyn  Hubert Selby Jr  explains how a near-death experience became the inspiration for his junkie parable Requiem for a Dream
fields.trailText: Legendary author of Last Exit to Brooklyn Hubert Selby Jr explains how a near-death experience became the inspiration for his junkie parable Requiem for a Dream
fields.body:
I wrote Requiem for a Dream while living in Los Angeles, and had been for l0 or 12 years, so I had no idea what was happening in the real world. But I wasnt writing about the real world, so I was in the right place to write about the images of the Great American Dream, and how its seeking and attainment will destroy you.

There was also a physical part to the writing of Requiem. My physical condition colours everything I do though I am usually unaware of it. I was a merchant seaman during the second world war and was hospitalised with TB at the age of l8. I spent three years in bed and ended up having 10 ribs removed, a lung collapsed, a piece cut out of the other one, and had numerous complications, including getting hepatitis in transfusions.

Perhaps six months before starting Requiem I was very sick with pneumonia. I didnt sleep for about five days or nights, but I think I periodically went into a short coma. One night my wife was awakened by two Spirits who had pushed the bedroom door open. One stood slightly in front and to the side of the other, and she had the distinct impression that they were male and female, and it was clear that they had intended to awaken her. They were about the height of a tall person, oval shaped, and shimmery with rainbow colours like soap bubbles in the sun, and were transparent. They indicated to her, in her mind, that I was dying, and told her if she didnt wake me up I would die, and she should get me to a hospital immediately. I was hard to wake up and was having severe problems breathing, I refused to go to a hospital. (I have spent four years in hospitals and dislike them intensely, to say the least.)

My wife called a friend of ours who was a respiratory therapist and asked him to come over. He was a very mild man who never raised his voice, but he did after my wife explained the situation to him. He said, Hey, he weighs 80lbs soaking wet, what the fuck are you waiting for, take him to the hospital.

Eventually I agreed to go to the hospital and I looked so bad the people in the Triage took one look at me and got me to an examination room and a doctor before accident victims. Before my wife finished the paper work, I was in a bed, which is truly miraculous.

This is some of the background I brought to the book. I also brought a few memories of days gone by. While living on the lower east side I remember walking along Avenue C and seeing guys standing on the street corner, or outside a candy store, in the middle of winter with a wind chill factor of minus 20 degrees with nothing on but a thin windbreaker, their eyes pinned, sweating, eating a Snickers candy bar. I have often thought that the way to end the heroin problem is to take Snickers candy bars, and Chuckles, off the market and all the addicts would die of malnutrition.

One of the huge problems I was facing was writing while living in LA. I had written two books while living out here, but this was the first one that would take me back to the streets of New York City.

My initial problem, in writing my first book out here, was can I write in an artistic vacuum? I was accustomed to being in the midst of a great artistic community in New York, which was the artistic capital of the world. Los Angeles doesnt have any semblance of a community, outside of the ghettos, no less a community of artists, so I was really concerned when I sat down to start The Room. How do you write without any source of inspiration from the world you are living in? They say nothing is created in a vacuum, except, of course, politicians. So, I sat down and started writing at the end of l969, and in the middle of l970 the book was finished.

I discovered something of great value in that experience. I discovered that in the six years it took me to write Last Exit to Brooklyn I truly did learn how to write. I also learned that the lack of outer stimuli and inspiration forced me to look within myself for those things and learned that though its true if you dont have it within yourself out here youre doomed, I discovered I do have it within me.

So The Room, and The Demon that followed helped me to discover that I had what I needed, and, I believe, I always will in every area of life. However, I still didnt know about the music of speech that would be so necessary in Requiem.

I write, in part, by ear. I hear, as well as feel and see, what I am writing. I have always been enamoured with the music of the speech in New York. That is totally lacking in LA. There is no distinction of speech out here except for the ex-New Yorkers. There is, of course, Black speech and Latino, but this town is so much more segregated than New York, especially when I was writing Requiem, more than 20 years ago.

I had been living out here for about a dozen years when it came time to write Requiem and was afraid I had been away from that music too long to be able to get it on paper. But once I started the book the people came alive and I found I was able to "hear" them. So one of the results of all this was my discovering that I am more self-sufficient than I had believed.

Requiem started as a joke ... I guess you would have to say a rather dark one. I wasnt working on anything at the time so I wrote a couple of outlines for films. I have no idea what they were. Anyway, I decided to write an outline for a dark humour film about a couple of guys who are strung out on heroin during a drug panic and decide to drive to Miami where all the drug dealers went for the Christmas Holidays and they get busted in Georgia, or some such place, and one guy ends up on a work gang and the white guy ends up losing an arm. It was called A Pound of Pure.

I started the outline and was a couple of pages into it when I realised this just wasnt working as a movie outline, that it was a story. So I threw the outline away and started writing the story, but soon realised that it wasnt a story, but a book. With that realisation the idea of a "joke" disappeared.

Writing Requiem was quite an experience. It only took me six weeks, including the re-writing. I have never written at such a pace. Its almost as if I was racing against death. Thats not how I felt, rather it was just the opposite ... I was feeling very much alive.

At that point in my life Wednesday night was family library night. My wife and I, and our son and daughter, would go to the library, and our son, who was then about six, would have a pillow case filled with books and would drag it along the floor. Its an image that I hope will always be indelibly etched in my brain. I love it.

One night my wife found herself walking down an aisle she had never been in before, and had no intention of going to, and her arm sort of reached out and her hand grabbed a book from the shelf. It was a book about Huna, which has been referred to as a Polynesian Psychological/Spiritual Religion. We subsequently bought the books available on the subject and studied them intently.

At this point in my life I was a member of the Self Realisation Fellowship and was studying Raja Yoga. I thoroughly enjoyed these studies and diligently practiced. On Sundays we went to the SRF Temple in Hollywood as a family, our son and daughter going to the Sunday School.

These days were idyllic. I had made some money writing a film for TV and we bought a nice home pretty much in the midst of the Borscht Belt of LA and I loved to watch the families walking to temple on Friday night, and Saturday. So all I had to do was write, I did not have to work at a job to support us. We didnt have any furniture other than beds and kitchen table, and were always talking about getting some when extra money came in. But every time that happened we bought a painting or a statue. We much preferred that to furniture. After all, we/re New Yorkers and we like to sit around the kitchen table and talk. On the surface it seemed like all our troubles were behind us.

However, they are more than just Famous Last Words. As you can see, there were times of simple and exquisite joy, but there were also times of madness. Periodically I was a raving lunatic. There were a thousand demons in my mind and body and I could not exorcise them. It seemed like periodically the only relief I could get was screaming. It was a safety valve. The pressure would build up and I would feel as if I would burst and I would literally wrap my arms around my head, or bang it against the wall, or go for walks or meditate. Music, of course, would always soothe and calm me, but sooner or later I became a screaming lunatic.

This problem was compounded by the awareness that my family was being subjected to living with a man who periodically had to lock himself in his office and try to knock the house down with his head. So I was tortured and tormented by the only answer I could find for relief from the demonic pressure within me. I love my family, and they love me, unconditionally, but my heart and soul were being ravaged.

Oh, there is something else I should mention that was of importance. We had a garden behind the house and a lawn in front and a dozen rose bushes along one side. I love gardening, and working in a garden with a young child is beyond a delight. I remember how our son would lie on the ground and watch the worms, and whatever else was crawling around in the dirt. Gardening is something that can reanimate the wonder of life in a person, and when you are doing it with a young child its really exciting.

I loved taking care of the rose bushes. It is very easy to care for roses out here. They ask very little of you and give you so much. In addition to the joy the roses gave me, neighbours would tell me how beautiful they are, and you could see the joy in their faces when they said it.

All this is to say that there was so much joy in my life at the time, and the trouble I was experiencing did not have its source outside of me. It was truly an inside job.

I wanted a strong relationship between Sara and Harry to emphasis the nature of the problem. Most addicts are people with families, hopes, dreams, the same as anyone else. Most addicts are not living on the streets, stealing for a fix. Most are middle class people with love in their lives who go to their doctor and pharmacist for drugs. It could be said that Sara's love was suffocating, oppressive at times, but it was also grounded in wanting the very best for her son. I ended up doing many things I am not proud of, but the responsibility for those actions certainly does not lie with my parents. They only wanted the best for me. Primarily they wanted me to go to school, get a good job, and be happy. They also inculcated, by word and example, a strong sense of morality. Yet I had to leave home at 15, having only finished the ninth grade.

There is so much psycho-babble that says, "Everything I do is somebody else's fault." I wanted to create people who were addicted, but were also just plain "people". Sara, Harry, Tyrone, Marion, do not stand out in a crowd, they are simply one of many who do the best they can to get through a day, trying to find a little happiness without hurting anyone. I believe this basic concept is a reflection of my life then and now. The difference today is I no longer have to destroy myself on a daily basis, but can do what I can to add something of value to Life and the World.

The six weeks spent writing Requiem were fine. When I am writing I am totally focused on the people I am creating and all of my energy goes into that creating. The demons just dont seem to have a chance as long as I am working. Perhaps the Divine Energy that is within all of us gets channelled into that one area and the demons are powerless against it. However, they are just biding their time and playing possum, waiting for me to take a vacation.

The truth is sooner or later I have to face my demons so I can discover how they can be rendered powerless over my life. This, I believe, is true for all of us whether we are avoiding them by writing or pursuing the American Dream. The problem is we are told, and taught, that there is no reason for us to feel bad, to be depressed. If these things occur in our lives we should take a pill and feel good again. Better living through chemistry is the motto of America. To put it as simply as possible, the American Dream, in all its manifestations, cuts my awareness off from the Divine Nature of my life, and all Life. I must find a way through the madness of my demons, and the American Dream to uncover that Divinity within me, and I certainly can not do that while pursuing the Dream or using the chemicals it prescribes.

I have survived a lot in my life: success, failure, and boredom, more than once. I am 72 years old and am experiencing a commercial success once again. I have no idea what the ultimate outcome of all this will be, but I will survive it ... as a matter of fact I will prevail.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Czech boss quits
UN suspension in Chechnya
Eagle too fat to fly
fields.body:
Czech boss quits

Jiri Hodac, whose appointment as director of Czech Television sparked a widely supported newscasters' strike, quit yesterday because of ill health. But more than 50,000 people demonstrated in Prague to demand that his supporters also resign.
AP, Prague

UN suspension

The UN has suspended humanitarian operations in Chechnya after the kidnapping of a US worker for the aid group Médecins sans Frontières.
Reuters, Moscow

Too fat to fly

A wild golden eagle was grounded this week when it became too fat to fly. It had gorged itself on about 1.5kg of food, roughly half its normal weight, an expert said yesterday. The eagle was rescued 250 miles north-west of Oslo and will be released after a few days of dieting.
AP, Oslo

webTitle: Scientists on verge of HIV breakthrough

fields.headline: Scientists on verge of HIV breakthrough
fields.trailText: A newly discovered protein that stops the Aids virus from entering cells could be the basis for a new generation of drugs against HIV, researchers report today.
fields.body:
A newly discovered protein that stops the Aids virus from entering cells could be the basis for a new generation of drugs against HIV, researchers report today.

The virus has so far been impossible to outwit, because it smuggles itself into the immune system. But in the past five years, using an expensive cocktail of treatments, doctors have been able to suppress the viral levels in many patients in Europe and the US.

However, the virus has an almost fiendish capacity to mutate, and there is no drug or vaccine that can prevent infection. There are 33m victims worldwide and 16,000 new cases each day. Most sufferers in the developing world cannot afford any treatment.

Scientists from two US medical institutes report in Science that they synthesised a protein called 5-Helix which jammed the "grappling hook" that the virus uses to latch on to cells. If HIV cannot fuse with the outer wall of the cell, it cannot enter and hijack its machinery to replicate itself.

Peter Kim and colleagues of the Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and a group from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute at Harvard were looking for ways to stop the virus. They identified a class of proteins that might work and tested one in laboratory samples.

"We were pleasantly surprised to find that not only did it inhibit the virus, but it did so quite effectively," Dr Kim said. "What's more, we were pleased to find that 5-Helix was capable of inhibiting a wide range of HIV isolates. I think we are only a few steps away from testing on monkeys."

The researchers see 5-Helix as the basis for a suite of weapons against HIV, for use when current drugs fail. The new drugs would need to be injected, but patients could treat themselves, just as diabetics inject themselves with insulin.

Other viruses have the same strategy for infecting cells, so the 5-Helix drugs might also work against Ebola or flu.

"If 5-Helix-like molecules did work in animals, then the difficult and arduous process of developing it for humans could take place," said Dr Kim. "Sexual transmission of a virus that is resistant to treatment has been documented, making it important to continue to find new targets and therapies for stopping HIV."

webTitle: Neanderthal man challenges African Eve

fields.headline: Neanderthal man challenges African Eve
fields.trailText: Four US anthropologists today throw the story of human origins into confusion. They claim that new evidence shows that modern humans could have partly descended from the neanderthals, the hulking creatures who held Europe during the ice ages.
fields.body:
Four US anthropologists today throw the story of human origins into confusion. They claim that new evidence shows that modern humans could have partly descended from the neanderthals, the hulking creatures who held Europe during the ice ages.

The research, published in the US journal Science, is likely to cause a storm. It challenges the reigning "African Eve" hypothesis: that after a series of false starts, a group descended from just one woman emerged in Africa 250,000 years ago. Some of their descendants left Africa 100,000 years ago, shouldered aside all other species of human and took over the planet.

Instead, the US researchers argue, modern Homo sapiens is made up of more than one group of ancestors. Instead of competing for resources, different human groups shared food, shelter - and partners.

The 2m year fossil record of travelling, tool-using humans shows a number of forerunners, including Homo erectus and Homo neanderthalis. There is also evidence that these two were around when Homo sapiens emerged.

Milford Wolpoff, of the University of Michigan, and three colleagues took a closer look at early modern and archaic fossil skulls from Europe, Australia, Africa and the near east, and saw more resemblances than could be explained by chance.

"Ancient humans shared genes and behaviours across wide regions of the world, and were not rendered extinct by one lucky group that later evolved into us," Professor Wolpoff said. "The fossils clearly show that more than one ancient group survived and thrived."

His team focused on early modern fossils from Australia and central Europe from 20,000 to 30,000 years ago because they calculated that groups on the margin of human settlement would be more likely to show characteristics of more ancient species of human.

This week the researchers got support from 60,000-year-old Mungo Man in Australia. DNA recovered from the bones of an anatomically modern man in Lake Mungo turned out to be quite different from that of later Australian peoples - and Australian researchers argued that this was evidence of shared origins.

"Modern humans are the present manifestation of an older worldwide species with populations connected by gene flow and the exchange of ideas," said Prof Wolpoff. "Modern human groups are much more similar than different, because of comparable adaptations to ideas and technologies that spread across the inhabited world, and because of the dispersals of successful genes promoted by selection."

The latest claim is another salvo in a long running battle. In 1999 one specialist claimed to have discovered fossil evidence of interbreeding. Last year another group examined the DNA from the bones of a Neanderthal child and found no evidence of interbreeding.

Chris Stringer, head of human origins at the Natural History Museum and an architect of the out-of-Africa theory, said the latest analysis was incomplete. He also had questions about the methods, results and conclusions.

"One could look at the same skulls, choose different characters and get a different answer," he said. "If we are looking for the ancestry of modern people, where people alive today came from, where their genes came from - if there was such hybridisation it is neglible. It is impossible to find today."

Origins

Homo erectus appeared in Africa 2m years ago. By 500,000BC descendants, Homo heidelbergensis, occupied Boxgrove, West Sussex. Neanderthals evolved from them. But where did Homo sapiens come from?

 Out-of-Africa hypothesis: modern humans evolved in Africa. DNA evidence suggests they descended from one group which may have flourished because of command of language or tools. There is no evidence of interbreeding with other human species.

 Multiregional hypothesis: Europeans were descended from Neanderthals, but now a modified version is that these and other early human species bequeathed some genes to modern humans.

Instead, the US researchers argue, modern Homo sapiens is made up of more than one group of ancestors. Instead of competing for resources, different human groups shared food, shelter - and partners. The 2m year fossil record of travelling, tool-using humans shows a number of forerunners, including Homo erectus and Homo neanderthalis. There is also evidence that these two were around when Homo sapiens emerged. Milford Wolpoff, of the University of Michigan, and three colleagues took a closer look at early modern and archaic fossil skulls from Europe, Australia, Africa and the near east, and saw more resemblances than could be explained by chance. "Ancient humans shared genes and behaviours across wide regions of the world, and were not rendered extinct by one lucky group that later evolved into us," Professor Wolpoff said. "The fossils clearly show that more than one ancient group survived and thrived." His team focused on early modern fossils from Australia and central Europe from 20,000 to 30,000 years ago because they calculated that groups on the margin of human settlement would be more likely to show characteristics of more ancient species of human. This week the researchers got support from 60,000-year-old Mungo Man in Australia. DNA recovered from the bones of an anatomically modern man in Lake Mungo turned out to be quite different from that of later Australian peoples - and Australian researchers argued that this was evidence of shared origins. "Modern humans are the present manifestation of an older worldwide species with populations connected by gene flow and the exchange of ideas," said Prof Wolpoff. "Modern human groups are much more similar than different, because of comparable adaptations to ideas and technologies that spread across the inhabited world, and because of the dispersals of successful genes promoted by selection." The latest claim is another salvo in a long running battle. In 1999 one specialist claimed to have discovered fossil evidence of interbreeding. Last year another group examined the DNA from the bones of a Neanderthal child and found no evidence of interbreeding. Chris Stringer, head of human origins at the Natural History Museum and an architect of the out-of-Africa theory, said the latest analysis was incomplete. He also had questions about the methods, results and conclusions. "One could look at the same skulls, choose different characters and get a different answer," he said. "If we are looking for the ancestry of modern people, where people alive today came from, where their genes came from - if there was such hybridisation it is neglible. It is impossible to find today." Origins Homo erectus appeared in Africa 2m years ago. By 500,000BC descendants, Homo heidelbergensis, occupied Boxgrove, West Sussex. Neanderthals evolved from them. But where did Homo sapiens come from?  Out-of-Africa hypothesis: modern humans evolved in Africa. DNA evidence suggests they descended from one group which may have flourished because of command of language or tools. There is no evidence of interbreeding with other human species.  Multiregional hypothesis: Europeans were descended from Neanderthals, but now a modified version is that these and other early human species bequeathed some genes to modern humans.

fields.trailText: Australias notorious outlaw finds a voice and tries to put the record straight truly he does
fields.body:
My da were put in prison by the traps for a crime he didn't do and I know that to be true as it were me that stole the heifer but we were poor and hungry and what else were I to do. That last time inside broke him truly it did and he died soon after and my blessed mother got some land 60 crabholed miles north and it were I who tried to look after it as I were now the oldest man even though I were only 12.

Uncle James soon came round to deliver his attentions to me ma and they werent wanted I can tell you so I kicked him in the bawbles to get him off. He were effing and shouting adjectival this and adjectival that and he then set fire to the home before the traps came and took him away but neither me ma or me would say a word against him at the assizes. Harry Power the bushranger came round to see me ma too and I became his apprentice he bought me a pair of boots and he made me help him hold up a coach but I didnt think this were right when I seen him rob some poor people sos I escaped. What are you doing said me ma with her arms around Bill Frost I paid 15 quid to have Harry takes you.

Harry threatened to kill Bill Frost when he said he wouldn't pay to keep my mother and I set off a musket by accident and at that point Harry and I were one again people said I were criminal but I were just gullible seeing as I was only just 16. I were taken by the traps over a stolen horse and the lying adjectival says I has betrayed Harry when he were caught but I were no fizgig or dobber as me mother knew.

Mary Hearn were as good a woman as ever lived and she gave me you but Constable Fitzpatrick were a cur for what he done to my sister and we treated him right considering but the traps they hunted us down to Stringybark Creek and I promise you that all the killings that were done were all in self-defence.

The Euroa Bank robbery were not the way it were written in the paper but we was getting famous now. I would not of wanted Aaron to die even though he was a traitor but Joe insisted and the traps they soon surrounded us at the Glenrowan hotel and I made some armour and walked out firing.

webTitle: Richard Strauss: Don Juan

fields.headline: Richard Strauss: Don Juan
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Tim Ashley selects the definitive recording of Richard Strauss' Don Juan.
fields.body:
Don Juan was the work that made the 25-year-old Richard Strauss a star when it was first performed in Weimar in 1889 - and with good reason. An epoch-making score, it redefined the parameters of musical potential. No composer had previously used orchestral forces with such flamboyant audacity, and the history of sonority would never be quite the same again.

In his picture of the famous womaniser, Strauss also placed a hitherto unimagined emphasis on erotic hedonism, which remains startling more than a century later. The result has always been a firm favourite with players and audiences alike, though Don Juan is much more than a virtuoso musical porn show, and the whole thing can come adrift if conductors fail to probe its deeper ambiguities. Strauss took as his source an unfinished play by the deranged poet Nikolaus Lenau, in which the Don is very much portrayed as the prototype of the Nietzschean figures to whom Strauss was later drawn - an amoral being "beyond good and evil" whose sexual exploits form a psychological defence against his own destructive nihilism. A sense of jittery, existential danger needs to be added to the glamorous sexiness of it all if the piece is to succeed.

Several of Strauss's own performances survive, of which the finest - measured in speed but relentless in intensity - is his 1944 radio broadcast with the Vienna Philharmonic (Preiser). A similar spaciousness, rather than superficial glitter, pervades Wilhelm Furtwängler's majestic 1954 version with the same orchestra (EMI). The usually great Bruno Walter was never quite at his best in Strauss's music and his 1952 version with the New York Philharmonic (Sony) finds him occasionally ill at ease. Leopold Stokowski, ever the wizard when it comes to orchestral flamboyance, generates tremendous, visceral excitement.

Among the next generation of interpreters we find versions by Karajan (DG), Solti (Decca), Boehm (DG) and Rudolf Kempe (EMI), all great, all radically different. Karajan's lushness contrasts sharply with Solti's nervous edginess. Boehm is all romantic radiance and warmth, while Kempe, with the Dresden Staatskapelle on glorious form, is deeply humane, portraying the Don very much as a man whose emotions, though transitory, are sincere.

More recently we have Neeme Jarvi controversially and brilliantly turning the Don into a Sadean brute as part of his Chandos Strauss cycle with the Royal Scottish National Orchestra; Claudio Abbado, very fierce with the Vienna Philharmonic yet again (DG); and Herbert Blomstedt and the San Francisco Symphony, almost matchless when it comes to exposing Strauss's gorgeous palette of orchestral colour (Decca - the sound is astonishing).

But there's one version that towers above the rest, namely the 1954 RCA recording with the Chicago Symphony and Fritz Reiner. The work has never sounded quite so electrifyingly raunchy or so dangerous as it does here, while the downbeat ending is shockingly, devastatingly sad. The playing is stupendous and the whole thing knocks you sideways. It ranks among the most stunning performances ever committed to disc - an absolutely unmissable achievement.

Key recording: Fritz Reiner (RCA)

webTitle: Feature: In celebration of composer Alfred Schnittke

fields.headline: Voices in the dark
fields.standfirst: Alfred Schnittke's music, suppressed by the Soviets, was all about dark spaces, mystery and fleeting details.  Adrian Searle  celebrates the distinctive art of one of the 20th century's greatest composers
fields.trailText: Alfred Schnittke's music, suppressed by the Soviets, was all about dark spaces, mystery and fleeting details. Adrian Searle celebrates the distinctive art of one of the 20th century's greatest composers
fields.body:
The music is sliding back into that low, constant background that we take for silence. I hear the noise of the guy in the flat upstairs pacing about and doing his morning callisthenics to Robbie Williams. Canned laughter is coming up through the floor. Then there's the shouting and the sirens from the street. My own noise is just as pervasive. It buries the rest and papers over my empty moments.

There is never any real silence; I think it was John Cage who, when visiting a sound-proofed, anechoic chamber, heard two distinct sounds: the technician later told him that what he had heard were the sound of his blood going round and the electric hum of his own brain.

The general noise level here is unexceptional - less, I guess, than in the Moscow apartment buildings where composer Alfred Schnittke, whose work is celebrated this weekend at the Barbican, wrote much of his music. His father-in-law would slumpin front of an ice-hockey game on TV in the same room; he worked next to a window above the street, with his adolescent son's rock music bulging through the room. Schnittke, apparently, never unplugged the telephone when he worked, even when, in the 1980s, he was always in demand. No wonder so much of what he wrote was full of interruptions.

I imagine the harassed composer at work in the warrens of everyday Soviet life. So much music - scores for 66 films, eight symphonies, all those chamber pieces, choral works, solo piano compositions, an electronic work. Perhaps composers don't need silence, in the same way that chess masters don't need a board to run through their moves. It is all in the head. Artists, frequently, play music while they work: maybe it drowns out the the doubt.

As a writer I find it hard to work to music. I need to hear the voice in my head, a voice I like to imagine is my own. It is not always the same voice, and a writer often needs the voices of others, whose cadences and tone shake you out of your own frightful monologue, or fill in when your own voice refuses to speak. Alfred Schnittke's replay of old forms (the concerto grosso, Gregorian chants) and of other voices (Beethoven "mottos", Mozart and Vivaldi licks, memories of Schoenberg and Shostakovich, tango fragments, the brass section that swerves unexpectedly into big-band mode for a few bars) go to demonstrate that for him the past wasn't all used up.

Schnittke's phrase, "the difference between the conceivable and the audible", was his measure. There is a tension between what a composer can imagine and write, and what can be performed. He was at times happy to utilise what seemed like jazz improvisation - unscored tuning up as an integral part of a piece; or to ask performers to mime frenetic playing in performance while producing no sound at all - a "cadenza visuale", which, in recordings, is marked by the performer's exhausted sighs, sudden explosive "Oh"s and laboured breaths; or to orchestrate for an invisible piano (amplified, and hidden behind the stage).

Schnittke's music is much more than accumulation, accretion, disruption and surprise. It may be filled with other voices and different styles, but he is never just a montage-mannerist; no more a ventriloquist than any other artist of our time. But inevitably no less of one, either. Doubts about the authenticity of a voice, are for him another level of play: what he called his "polystylistic" voice.

You can't have Schnittke as background music. It demands too much attention. It isn't just the dissonant patches, the eardrum-flexing notes, the changing pace of it, the chase-music losing its way in the weeds, the alternating currents of anxiety and grace. It is simply too arresting. A passage of lush strings is systematically prised apart just when you are getting into it. Not simply because of all the switches, turnstiles and reverses the music goes through, but because Schnittke continually reconfigures our emotions, changing the pattern as well as the material, and our response to it.

His music is not like Matisse's comfortable armchair for a tired businessman. Nor is it bracing in that muscular, angular, tough-love way you think must be good for you, but makes you wish it would stop. Schnittke's music is very carefully structured, paced, configured, for all its seismic faults. If his music is as much spatial as temporal - sculptural and filmic as much as it is atmospheric - then all those movie scores may have had their uses.

His music is big, complex, erudite and multiformed, but you never lose the details amid it all - he is very good at details, at what I think of as glimpses, an eye flickering from the larger forms to something left accidentally on the floor. Listening, then, becomes an experience of transitions. Of phases, figures passing in front and behind one another, things in transit.

Familiarity doesn't dull it, The familiar is a necessary part of his repertoire, the almost subliminal sense of deja vu that holds the shapes together. I don't think Schnittke cared whether what he did sounded "modern" or "difficult", high or low. He could be all these things, with enough space in hand to let things breathe, to keep them alive.

Certain of Schnittke's spiritual preoccupations, such as his dabblings in the occult, in the I-Ching (like John Cage), in anthroposophy (though he said he could never trust a man with eyes like Rudolf Steiner's), culminated in his indecision as to whether to join the Catholic or the Russian Orthodox churches. Schnittke, half Jewish, his parents and grandparents atheists, a German Russian who spent much of his post-war childhood in Vienna, was a polystylistic man. He was led to the spiritual. His music, therefore, makes appeals to dark spaces, to mysteries, to enduring things, certainties. He was no reductivist, and more, I think, a synthetic than an analytical composer.

He plays too, on our sense of perpetual expectation, our hunger for differences, for change and mutability. Where he leads is another matter. His unusual orchestrations (the piano, harpsichord and celesta opening to the Fourth Symphony, for example) keep us listening, and waiting, keep us wanting more. The mad plunges, the returns to a sober, almost sentimental lyricism, sounds creeping in like light under a door and the shadow of someone pacing about beyond: there is real suspense here. It has been said that Schnittke's music is both ambivalent and pessimistic. This is its unavoidable condition. I can throw adjectives and claims at it all day, but they just slide off the surface. He is seductive, awkward, unhinging. Schnittke's music knows it will be subsumed back into the world around it when it is done, back into what passes for silence.

Notes from a life in music

1934: Alfred Schnittke is born in Engels, Russia, to German parents.

1946-8: Studies composition in Vienna - a formative experience of Austrian culture.

1949-61 Studies at the October Revolution Music College, Moscow, and at the Moscow Conservatory.

1958 His oratorio Nagasaki is condemned by the Russian Union of Composers. A troubled relationship with the Soviet authorities begins.

1974: His First Symphony is effectively banned in the Soviet Union. Schnittke dubs his work of this period "polystylistic".

Late 1970s: Works such as the First Sonata for Cello and Piano see him move to a personal language less reliant on musical quotation.

1982: Baptised a Catholic.

1985: Gorbachev comes to power; for the first time Schnittke is allowed to travel regularly outside the Soviet Union. At the same time, his health begins to fail.

1990: Moves to Hamburg.

1993-4: Schnittke's eighth and last symphony is completed. His mature style is spare and refined, reminiscent of late Shostakovich and the work of the Italian Luigi Nono.

1998: He dies in Germany after a series of strokes.

· The BBC Symphony Orchestra's weekend of music by Alfred Schnittke runs from tonight till Sunday at the Barbican, London EC2. Details: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: Switch now to save on power bills

fields.headline: Switch now to save on power bills
fields.trailText: The present cold snap means many of us will be turning the heating up to full blast, only to receive a nasty shock when the bill comes in.
fields.body:
The present cold snap means many of us will be turning the heating up to full blast, only to receive a nasty shock when the bill comes in.

But, if you want to keep the costs down, now is the time to consider switching your gas or electricity supplier.

Apathy is the main reason why many people don't bother. Gas and electricity companies offer a range of confusing tariffs and there are wide variations in price. They often try and market their services through door to door salesmen, an unsophisticated and off-putting method for many people. And, consumer advice and guidance has to date been in relatively short supply.

Competition in the utilities market is relatively new - the market was only opened up in May 1999. But by June of last year one in four electricity customers decided to switch suppliers and the results have only just been analysed by the National Audit Office.

It says the 6.5 million customers who had changed their electricity supplier by June 2000 will have seen their bills fall by £299 million since the start of competition. This is a 15% reduction in real terms, an average of £45 a customer.

But, even those who have not switched may still have experience savings since the regulator imposed price caps, which meant some bills fell. That said, there are still around 15.4 million customers who have not seen any reductions.

Although the market is now far better, many people continue to receive a poor deal.

"There is scope for the benefits to be spread wider," admitted the National Audit Office's head, Sir John Bourn, and he urged Ofgem and the newly set up consumers' watchdog, Energywatch, to do more to educate the public.

But, just by shopping around, it is possible to find out if you can obtain cheaper supplies. The website Unravelit.com allows consumers to check out all the suppliers in the market and its data and analysis is used by Ofgem.

Once an alternative supplier is provided, it is possible to sign up online. CEO Joe Malinowski admits that switching can appear complex on the surface.

First of all, customers need to decide what type of product they want based on whether they are a low, medium or high user. Then they need to look at payment options such as standard billing, direct debit or prepayment meters.

These have a major impact on any savings and once assessed, Unravelit will calculate savings and produce a list of products matched to preferences. The site contains over 5,000 gas, electricity and duel fuel tariffs ranked according to region, payment method and product features.

webTitle: Market forces: Shaky day for HSBC

fields.headline: Shaky day for HSBC
fields.trailText: In the present market environment - falling interest rates and wild price swings - few investors have had any reason to sell short the shares of HSBC, Britain's largest listed bank.
fields.body:
In the present market environment - falling interest rates and wild price swings - few investors have had any reason to sell short the shares of HSBC, Britain's largest listed bank.

But that could be about to change, and judging by the performance of the stock yesterday - down 16p to 987p - it may already have done so.

Very early yesterday morning, dealers latched on to news that the Hong Kong monetary authority had announced plans to sell a large chunk of the $HK150bn - slightly less than £13bn - stock portfolio, it built up during the financial crisis of 1998. For reasons best known to itself, the HKMA has decided to retain just $HK50bn of it.

While the HKMA claims it will be able to dispose of the excess stock in an orderly fashion with minimal disruption to the market, traders are not so sure. The portfolio's biggest holding, they point, out is 7% of HSBC, roughly 760m shares.

Taken to its logical conclusion, yesterday's news implies that some 430m HSBC shares are going to hit the market soon, and even the most junior trader knows what happens when supply outstrips demand - prices go down.

Leading shares, however, were going in the opposite direction, ending a three-day losing streak as the strong performances from the three most heavily weighted sectors of the market - telecoms, oil and pharmaceuticals - offset a horrendous day for retailers.

The FTSE 100 closed 55 points higher at 6,114.9, with BP, up 19p to 546p, and Shell, 15p stronger at 540, contributing 24 points following news that Opec member Saudi Arabia is preparing to cut deliveries, a move that could push crude prices higher.

In telecoms Vodafone, up 9.75p to 226.75p, rebounded from recent its weakness, while BT, up 29.5p to 705.5p, continued its good run.

Not everything was going up. The retail sector had probably one of its worst days on record as Christmas trading updates from three leading lights - Matalan, down 247p to 480p, Next, off 15.5p to 781p, and GUS, 82p weaker at 462.5p - proved disappointing.

Serious money was also being lost at the speculative end of the market. Life assurance specialist Legal & General fell back 8.25p to 183p as the bid from Barclays , up 23p to £21.09, failed to materialise and Schroder Salomon Smith Barney cut its rating on the stock to "sell". BG, another one of the punters' favourites, fell back 5p to 261 after analysts at CSFB cut earnings estimates.

But one story that continued to bubble away was an offer for Powergen by German power company E.ON.

Although Powergen's shares ended 1p weaker at 639, this was well off the 611p they reached early in the session.

Analysts reckon that any move by the German firm would have to be pitched above 750p to succeed.

Sema, 25p better at 320p, was also in demand on speculation that French rival Cap Gemini was weighing up the merits of making an offer the troubled IT services outfit.

Lower down the ladder, the punters were piling into the shares of automotive technology Torotrak - which was up 20.5p to 128p - on word that it is about to announce a major a deal with Ford. However, sources close to the company played down the speculation.

Expectations that full-year figures will meet market expectations helped the sausage skin maker, Devro, move up 3p to 55.5p, while DVD specialist Zen Research advanced 5p to 90.5p as stock overhang was finally cleared.

Churchill China advanced 24.5p to 175.5p after the ceramics maker warned that profits will significantly exceed market expectations.

On AIM, Pilat Technology International rose 10p - or 19.8% - to 60.5p, as investors responded to a bullish research circular from brokerage Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, which is said to carry a 170p target price.

webTitle: Yahoo! plight is a warning to all

fields.headline: Yahoo! plight is a warning to all
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Yahoo!'s profit warning has raised fresh questions not only about the future of dot.com companies but of the culture of the world wide web itself.
fields.body:
Yahoo!'s profit warning has raised fresh questions not only about the future of dot.com companies but of the culture of the world wide web itself. Yahoo!'s shares fell sharply in after-hours dealing on Wednesday when the company warned of a significant deterioration in its prospects for this year. Yesterday its shares were trading at $25, a fall of 88% since their peak last year.

Yahoo!'s deteriorating prospects is unsurprising in the wake of the sharp downturn in the US economy as a whole and the catastrophic crash in the dot.com area which has made some of the financial pages look more like an obituary section. But that will not stop the questions being asked. If Yahoo!, the most successful of all the web portals, cannot be turned into a prosperous business, what chance is there for the other dot.coms, most of whom, unlike Yahoo!, lose money on an unbelievable scale?

One of this week's casualties, Mercata, turned out to be losing $36.1m (£24m) on sales of only $6.3m. Mercata, like its troubled European equivalent, Letsbuyit.com, had the novel idea of grouping consumers together to negotiate lower prices. This is a wonderful way of harnessing the global power of the internet - in theory. In practice these companies underestimated the cost of marketing, delivery and servicing customers.

If it turns out that hardly any of the new internet companies are able to derive finance from elsewhere (other than banner ads) to finance services like email, web hosting, chat rooms, search engines and all the other services we have been used to getting for nothing, then something will have to give.

There are two reasons why these services are free. It is not that Microsoft and Yahoo! have turned into a web version of the Red Cross. It is, first, because they know that there are so many others offering similar free services that consumers would simply migrate to them as soon as any company started to charge. On the web the consumer is (still) king.

The second reason is that no one has yet devised a successful way of enabling small payments to be made on the web. If that had happened at the beginning (as it did for a while on BT's Prestel service) things might have turned out differently. The next year or two should see a breakthrough in devising acceptable internet payment systems.

What is likely to happen now is that lots more companies will fail and the bigger ones will gobble them up - and one another - in order to gain enough market power to start charging.

This does not mean that the underlying "mutual" ethic of the internet is at risk. People, institutions and many companies will continue to exchange information and services for nothing. And the internet will continue to be a vital conduit for the vast majority of successful businesses.

But it could mean the eventual end of the commercial free lunch. Yahoo! is already trying its luck. It has started charging punters who want to list items on its auction sites.

Some people think the big dot.coms will be rescued by charging for streaming video commercials that web users would be compelled to watch for a few seconds before accessing what they want. There will be a lot of resistance to this. But the lesson of this year is that dot.coms, including Yahoo!, cannot live by banner ads alone. Something has to give.

webTitle: Classical review: Moody magic at the Liverpool Phil

fields.headline: Moody magic at the Liverpool Phil
fields.standfirst:
RLPO/ Altrichter
Philharmonic Hall
Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
RLPO/ Altrichter
Philharmonic Hall
Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The Czech composer Bohuslav Martinu never really felt at home in the US: at times he hated it and felt desperate to leave. Yet his years there were richly productive, leaving a legacy of six symphonies, all the fruit of his mature style. The Sixth, subtitled Fantasies symphoniques, was a new departure - as he put it, "less geometrical" in its construction than his previous works. Its magical, wayward tone is more suggestive of an orchestral fantasy than a symphony, and its constant shifting of tone from darkness to light makes its moods difficult to pin down. Of all Martinu's symphonies, the Sixth is the most elusive, and the least prepared to gratify.

The sensitivity of Petr Altrichter and the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra to its ambivalence meant that the fleeting moments of radiance were never contrived or overdone. The finale's constant suppression of that longed-for moment of glory, eventually rejecting its polarised extremes of emotion to conclude with simple chords, had all the tension needed to make its unexpected ending work. Whether it comes across as resigned, peaceful or gently melancholic probably depends on your mood, but it was certainly beautiful.

Peter Donohoe has the technique to play Rachmaninov's massive Third Piano Concerto with a little insouciance. His avoidance of many of the mannerisms it has acquired over the years was refreshing, if disappointing to those who like Rachmaninov played with angst. Donohoe may not always linger where you want him to, but he plays with an intelligence and lucidity that maintains a sense of direction where others get lost in the detail.

The slower passages, where details cry out for attention, were treated more gently. The first movement coda and the lento section of the finale - oases of calm in the midst of merciless virtuosity - were played with a beauty and poise they don't always receive.

webTitle: Gillian Slovo's top 10 South African books

fields.headline: Gillian Slovo's top 10 South African books
fields.trailText: Gillian Slovo is the daughter of two of South Africa's most prominent anti-apartheid campaigners, and first became known as a crime writer. Her lastest novel, Red Dust (Virago), is an examination of the workings and effects of the truth and reconciliation commission
fields.body:
Gillian Slovo is the daughter of two of South Africa's most prominent anti-apartheid campaigners, and first became known as a crime writer. Her lastest novel, Red Dust (Virago), is an examination of the workings and effects of the truth and reconciliation commission.
Buy Red Dust at Amazon.co.uk

1. Frontiers by Noel Mostert
The story of the 18th- and 19th-century wars between whites and the Xhosa nation. Over 1,000 pages of fascinating detail that helps to explain the origins of the apartheid state.

2. The Master of Petersburg by JM Coetzee
This short novel set in Dostoevesky's St Petersburg by the Booker prize-winner has the exquisite structure and style of a true master.

3. Triomf by Marlene van Niekerk
A brilliant, grim comedy about a dysfunctional white family washed up by recent history.

4. Burger's Daughter by Nadine Gordimer
Nobel prize-winner Gordimer examines the costs of commitment paid by the family of a white anti-apartheid activist. A gripping view of a world that has now disappeared.

5. Country of My Skull by Antjie Krog
An in-depth look at the truth and reconciliation commission in all its complexity. A virtuoso attempt to let those contradictory voices speak out.

6. The Boer War by Thomas Pakenham
A blow-by-blow account of the turn-of-the-century conflict between the emergent Afrikaner nation and the British.

7. A Rainbow On The Paper Sky by Mandla Langa
A journey into the time of armed struggle. A poet's-eye view from the ground.

8. Mandela by Anthony Sampson
The definitive biography of the man and the pressures that formed him.

9. Armed and Dangerous by Ronnie Kasrils
Often hilarious account of the ANC military underground by the "terrorist" who is now South Africa's minister of water affairs.

10. Olive Schreiner by Ruth First and Ann Scott
A complex biography of Schreiner, South Africa's first major novelist, socialist and pacifist and one of the precursors of modern feminism.

webTitle: Workplace rituals you can do without

fields.headline: Workplace rituals you can do without
fields.trailText: Firm favourites:Wave goodbye before we all go mad and start to take them seriously, says Judi James.
fields.body:
Wave goodbye before we all go mad and start to take them seriously.

Positive Thinking
Perfect if there is anything to think positively about, but this trend reached well below demise point during the rail troubles. Railtrack ensured that there was nothing at all for commuters to be positive about by the end of last year. Anyone crammed into a rain-sodden carriage for three hours would have been risking a swift lynching if they so much as whispered the phrase: "Still, look on the bright side."

No-Blame Culture
Like most business concepts, this one had a lot going for it at first but then lost a lot in translation. Enormous public whoopsies like The Dome seemed to occur without fingers being pointed in any specific directions, and it was a similar situation in many companies. Cock-ups are only fun if you know who did them and the culprit is named, blamed and de-bagged.

"I'm on a learning curve"
This truly hideous statement was like being smacked in the face with a wet kipper. It became the most-used retort to accusations of every and any misdemeanour. The no-blame culture ensured the culprit learned nothing more than the fact that using this phrase meant they could get away with anything.

Workplace illnesses
Did we need to be told by an academic that we were all suffering from post-Christmas-depression-syndrome, or whatever the new term for "heartily pissed off at work" is? Did giving it a moniker make us feel braver or better? This catalogue of workplace syndromes has just got to stop. If not, then home-workers are going to have to fight back big-time, with a barrel-load of self-manufactured diseases like sofa-lounger's hump and late-newspaper-delivery anxiety syndrome.

"You are the weakest link.goodbye."
This and other game show catchphrases urgently need to be deleted from the office banter. They were never clever or remotely funny and now they are as stale as last year's Christmas cake. Impose massive penalties on anyone asking "Can I phone a friend?", etc. Either that, or smack them in the teeth before the phrase can be completed. Ditto anything regurgitated from the Christmas version of The Fast Show or any annoying mannerisms copied from the cast of Friends.

Work/home life culture
How virtuous did bosses feel quoting that one at us? It was like Ebeneezer Scrooge pitching up at the Crachitt household clutching a turkey and a sack of Pokemon games for the kids. Telling your staff about your nouveau-philanthropic intentions was never quite the same thing as letting us all go home on time and take a lunch break though, was it? In fact it was a cultural trend that was only ever used by the bosses who suddenly felt ok about dashing off from meetings early because some ghastly sprog you had never heard get so much as a name check before had simply got to be driven to the school gymkhana.

Duvet days
Sounds good but can you really have the brass-faced cheek to ring in first thing to inform your long-suffering colleagues they are going to have to shoulder your work for the day because "quite frankly, I just can't be buggered to get up out of bed." Lying about taking a sickie was never commendable but at least it did not make you hugely unpopular. Expect a return of the old favourite - the stomach bug - soon.

Gadgets
So a lot of the stuff's non-negotiable, like your PC and fax, but did you really ever need all those palm pilots and other dinky little bits? Anyone with the brain capacity of an elk swiftly realised that they took about three years longer to access than the average diary or address book and a whole decade longer to store the information in the first place. Manufacturers of paper-based equipment should hold off before announcing bankruptcy. Once the show-off factor has paled workers will be beating a path to your door once again.

webTitle: Equitable says it expects to clinch deal this month

fields.headline: Equitable says it expects to clinch deal this month
fields.trailText: Equitable Life yesterday said it expected to announce the sale of parts or possibly all of the business by the end of this month.
fields.body:
Equitable Life yesterday said it expected to announce the sale of parts or possibly all of the business by the end of this month.

The insurer said it was in intensive negotiations with several companies which should lead to offers for its salesforce, its asset management and administration operations, and its systems, either "as as whole or separately".

The statement bolstered hopes in some quarters that the company could be sold as a going concern rather than being broken up.

There is also a growing expectation that a deal to cap Equitable's £1.5bn-plus of liabilities will be reached soon.

That would improve the fortunes of up to 1m policyholders who have been warned they face lower investment returns and will be hit with a 10% penalty if they transfer their funds to another provider. These measures were put in place after Equitable lost a legal battle involving guaranteed annuities sold as part of pension plans.

In a policyholder update issued yesterday the company said talks to sell its assets were going well. GE Capital, Aegon, the Dutch owner of Scottish Equitable, and Australian financial services group AMP are thought to be among the interested parties.

An Equitable spokesman said it was too early to say whether an announcement would involve all or part of the company, adding: "The overriding priority is to generate value swiftly in order to strengthen the with-profits fund for the benefit of all members."

The maximum value would be delivered by a sale of the whole business, he said.

The company said it would be taking further legal advice about whether the Law Lords' ruling in July that caused the crisis might be overturned, but admitted it was not holding out any great hopes.

 The Consumers' Association said yesterday it would not appeal against a high court ruling in December which gave the go-ahead to insurer Axa's proposals for distributing £1.7bn of surplus cash.

webTitle: If the US goes, all bets are off for Asia

fields.headline: If the US goes, all bets are off for Asia
fields.standfirst: Slowdown across the Pacific could mean a repeat in Japan of the nightmare scenario of 1998
fields.trailText: Slowdown across the Pacific could mean a repeat in Japan of the nightmare scenario of 1998.
fields.body:
The Tokyo stock market slumped to a 27-month low yesterday as fears grew of a simultaneous recession in the world's two biggest economies - the US and Japan - that could tip Asia back into crisis.

In the clearest warning yet of the dangers ahead, the leader of Japan's largest employers' association said the share price slump could trigger a repeat of the financial system contagion that shook the world in 1998.

"The possibility that a financial system crisis will be induced is strong," said Hiroshi Okuda, chairman of the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations and of the Toyota motor company.

This nightmare scenario appeared to edge a little closer to reality this week as Japanese government figures and some doom-laden private sector forecasts for the US economy indicated that a twin vortex may already have started forming on either side of the Pacific.

According to the ministry of public management and home affairs, Japanese household spending slipped by 1.3% in November, crushing hopes that private consumption - which accounts for 60% of the country's output - could provide an engine for growth.

The American export market, which has acted as the main substitute for domestic demand, is also about to shrink, according to a study released by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. The brokerage house said the US economy would slide into recession during the first half of 2001, breaking a record 10-year expansion and prompting a wave of currency devalutions in Asia.

Following a slide in the Nasdaq, the reports have helped to push down the Nikkei index of the Tokyo stock exchange down to 13,201, close to its nadir during the crisis of 1998 and only 400 points above a 15-year low.

Japanese investors hardly need a new reason to be depressed. The Nikkei lost almost 30% last year as concerns grew that the government was delaying the structural reforms needed to address an anachronistic tax system, over-regulation and the world's most rapidly ageing population.

"At the end of last year, exports were the only thing propping up the Japanese economy," said Noriko Hama, director of the Mitsubishi Research Institute. "If the US goes, the whole horror story of the Japanese economy will come out."

For the moment, the real economy has managed to remain on the path of recovery thanks to record public spending and increased sales and investment by exporters such as Sony, Matsushita, Toyota and Honda. The government has forecast growth of 1.7% in the year to March 31, but the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, said last weekend that all bets would be off if the US made a hard landing.

"The slowdown in the US economy and the fall in stock prices is increasing the uncertainty over the economic outlook," he said at a meeting of a new government council on fiscal and economic policy.

There are already signs that Japan is feeling the chill from across the Pacific. In November, exports fell by 13.6% for the fifth month. Unemployment has crept back to near-record levels of 4.8%, industrial production has slowed and the latest Bank of Japan survey of business confidence indicates that a mood of pessimism is creeping back among executives.

The gloom is not just about shrinking demand for exports. A US recession also threatens Japan indirectly through its links with other Asian economies. The region sells more than a quarter of its exports to the US. For South Korea, Taiwan and Malaysia, which concentrate on electronics goods, the figure is closer to half.

Competition among these nations will increase as the US market stops growing. Exporters will come under pressure to cut prices and with lower profits they will have less money for investment, wages and the purchase of parts and services from Japan.

The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research predicts that the country's export growth will fall from 23% last year to 7.5% in 2001. In Thailand, government ministers have forecast a halving of export growth rates from the present 20% level.

Singapore has indicated that it will lower the value of its currency to boost the competitiveness of its exports, threatening another round of the regional devaluations that exacerbated the 1998 crisis.

Asia's economies were able to recover from that low point thanks to a sharp rise in exports to the US and a return of foreign investors to their capital markets. This was a case of the US returning a favour owed from 1987, when Asia's strength helped to pull western financial markets out of the rut that followed the Black Monday crash.

But this time, the two biggest engines of the world economy are at risk of going into reverse. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter forecast that US output will slow to 1.25% this year. The bank also cut its estimate of Japan's growth this year from 0.6% to 0.3% and cut its forecast for Asian expansion from 5.9% to 5.6%.

Despite the downward revision, such figures are still rosier than the mood indicated by Asia's low stock prices. In the past year the main indexes of the Seoul, Taipei, Bangkok, Jakarta and Manila bourses have lost more than 40% of their value. Although most have risen slightly since the Federal Reserve's decision to cut US interest rates by half a percentage pont, investor confidence remains volatile.

With most predicting a soft landing for the US, and the financial sector stronger than in 1997, Asia is expected to avoid a full-blown crisis. But a positive outcome is less certain than it was even three months ago. It is apparent that many Asian economies have refused to take the full course of medicines prescribed two years ago, making them vulnerable to a relapse. With Japan still on its sick-bed after 10 years and the US under the weather, it is hard to imagine who would administer the treatment if there were another Asian financial contagion.

webTitle: Pop review: Tompaulin

fields.headline: Tompaulin
fields.standfirst:
Toynbee Hall Arts Cafe
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Toynbee Hall Arts Cafe
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
If you thought of the ideal elements for a band, Tompaulin would come pretty close. But you probably wouldn't imagine the chip on their shoulder beneath their winsome charm.

They begin with singer Stacey McKenna waiting nervously for the guitars to be plugged in. She's a vision of well-studied 1960s style, from her Dusty Springfield eyes to her Mary Jane shoes. All eyes are on her, but she's not the only one looking for attention. As Jamie Holman strums his acoustic guitar, he is like Man at M&S, lost in melancholy.

When My Life on Buses finally begins, McKenna's sweet vocals are soft against the jaunty rhythm and end up battling against it. One hand cupped to her ear, she grimaces. Tompaulin soon settle into a brazen confidence, however, led by the light voice and strong opinions of Holman. Just as his songs reveal the mundane minutiae of life in a small town with both wistfulness and bitterness, his easy charm belies his bite. "Everything's fucking yellow - not where I come from pal," he sneers in a swipe at contemporaries Coldplay. "And we're not driftwood either."

His devil-and-angel appeal makes Holman's songs stand apart from other loved-up guitar merchants filling the charts. For Tompaulin, carpet burns and football teams, boy hairdressers and council houses matter. Hailing from Blackburn, Holman takes the "it's grim but great up north" approach adopted by Pulp, marrying it to swooning melodies and nagging rhythms.

Simon Trought's lead guitar is funky but with a 1960s feel, George Harrison discovering Dirty Mind-era Prince before deciding on a love affair with the Stooges. As Amos Memon builds a steady drumbeat during Slender, Holman and McKenna counter the growing tension with airy voices; it's only as Trought's guitar screeches into punky life that the air of disquiet is shattered. It's a fantastic song that has the band grinning as the final note fades away.

Tompaulin aren't content with being fine purveyors of quality scratchy pop; there's also the rose-coloured hue of Wedding Song. As bass player Katie Grocott takes centre stage, the warmth and fragility behind the bravado leave a lasting impression.

webTitle: Banks are a big hit with surfers

fields.headline: Banks are a big hit with surfers
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: More than a third of Europeans with internet access in their homes clicked on banking and financial sites in November, according to a new report.
fields.body:
More than a third of Europeans with internet access in their homes clicked on banking and financial sites in November, according to a new report.

The research group Jupiter MMXI says British surfers lag behind their continental counterparts, with the Danes being the most enthusiastic about finding financial help online.

In the Britain, 31.7% of people using the internet from home visited these sites, while in Denmark the figure was 41.3%.

Retail banks have been keen to sign up new internet users, developing websites and services to attract customers online. Their sites occupy all of the 10 most popular finance sites in Britain, forcing out financial information and wire sites.

Egg.com received 746,000 unique users who accessed the internet from home, 6% of the total such traffic.

The banking and finance sites also attract users for longer periods of time than other sectors, such as entertainment, retail and news.

The Germans are the keenest European users, spending the most amount of time on these sites; their average time spent is almost one and a half hours per visitor. The Danes spent about an hour online per visit.

The growth of popularity in Europe has been steady. In June last year, 27.4% of British internet users visited financial sites and in November the figure was 33.6%.

"We are seeing internet usage going up. More people are using the internet and more people are going to financial sites," a spokesperson for Jupiter MMXI said.

Arielle Dinard, president of Jupiter MMXI, said: "The popularity of finance sites and online banking shows that Europeans acknowledge the practical and time saving benefits of the internet. Most banks recognise that they can offer additional value by giving their customers access to their accounts via the internet,"

Security and the protection of sensitive data are still important issues to customers but, according to the research, Europeans trust the web for online banking.

Jupiter MMXI said the majority of banking sites provided secure internet connections.

Internet portal Freeserve yesterday teamed up with uSwitch to help visitors to its new property channel reduce their domestic energy bills.

The Freeserve property channel, in joint venture with Bradford & Bingley, signed up a number of e-commerce partners to provide information on a range of home-related services, including mortgages and insurance, as well as energy suppliers.

A co-branded service at www.uswitch.com will offer free, impartial advice on gas and electricity suppliers.

webTitle: Theatre review: High Spirits

fields.headline: Coward's Spirit lacks life as a musical
fields.standfirst:
High Spirits
Bridewell Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
High Spirits
Bridewell Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
They have a strange fascination with mystical, mid-1960s musicals at the Bridewell. This time last year they brought us On a Clear Day You Can See Forever, which dealt with reincarnation. Now they offer a rare sighting of Hugh Martin's and Timothy Gray's 1964 musical version of Noël Coward's Blithe Spirit, which takes us into the esoteric world of ectoplasm. The show is about raising the dead, and yet this fossilised specimen comes only fitfully to life.

A musical based on an existing play has to add a dimension missing in the original. But Coward's "improbable farce", dealing with a writer plagued by his dead wife's ghost and his living wife's jealousy, is complete in itself. The bland songs don't so much advance the action as impede it. In Coward's original, it is clear from the start that the hero's second wife, Ruth, ruefully accepts that her predecessor, Elvira, was more physically attractive. The musical kicks off with Ruth redundantly asking: "Was she prettier than I?"

What the musical does do is open out Coward's play, so that we get to see the happy medium, Madame Arcati, surrounded by Bohemian acolytes in her coffee shop "a few blocks below Sloane Square". In the Broadway version this gave Beatrice Lillie a chance to display her legendary eccentricity. Since he lacks a precious Lillie, I wish the show's director, Raymond Wright, had taken advantage of recent scholarship. Apparently Coward based Madame Arcati on the lesbian novelist Radclyffe Hall, who often sought to contact the spirit of her dead lover. A monocled, besuited Arcati exploring the well of loneliness might be an interesting innovation, but here Gay Hamilton makes her merely a mildly raffish figure trailing diaphonous scarves.

Only one number, Home Sweet Heaven, lifts the show above the amiably banal, and it's no surprise to learn that it bears Coward's lyrical imprint. Sung by Elvira, it envisions the empyrean as a historical melting-pot where "we all sit round King Arthur's table, me and Freud and Cain and Abel". For the most part, however, the songs never match the starched wit of Coward's dialogue. One is left spasmodically to enjoy Coward's faultless ear for camp outrage - "A woman in Cynthia Cheviot's position would hardly wear false pearls" - and perfectly decent performances by James Staddon as the haunted hero, Sarah Payne as a slightly too scrumptious Ruth and Kate Graham as a suitably ethereal Elvira.

Since the Bridewell is into rare revivals, a second look at Sail Away, which Coward himself wrote, might yield more fruit than this valiant attempt to resurrect the dead.

 Until February 3. Box office: 020-7936 3456.
